fields.headline: Nationwide round-up
fields.trailText: Joe Kinnear will be unveiled as Luton's new director of football this week, but Lil Fuccillo will remain as manager.
fields.body:
Joe Kinnear will be unveiled as Luton's new director of football this week, but Lil Fuccillo will remain as manager.

Kinnear, the former Wimbledon manager, had been touted for the newly created job just days after leaving the same role with the Second Division's bottom club Oxford.

Fuccillo said yesterday: "I have been told that my position is unchanged. If Joe is coming in, it is great for Luton Town."

Millwall returned to the top of the division after a 3-0 home win over managerless Bristol Rovers . The Lions led through Tim Cahill after 31 minutes but the game exploded soon after when he and Rovers' Dwayne Plummer were sent off after clashing. Paul Moody and Neil Harris scored the others.

Stoke extended their unbeaten run to nine games but were dissatisfied with a 1-1 home draw against Northampton. They led through Andy Cooke only for Steve Howard to level 16 minutes from time.

In the Third, Chesterfield are 13 points clear after a 1-1 draw at Barnet . An early David Reeves penalty put the leaders in front, but Mark Arber equalised .

Blackpool moved into the play-off picture after the 6-0 rout of Scunthorpe, who had Steve Torpey sent off for handball after nine minutes.

fields.headline: Gifts graciously received at Palace
fields.trailText: Crystal Palace 2 - 2 WBA
fields.body:
Dedicated followers of West Bromwich Albion bristle at suggestions that this season's promotion push is solely dependent on their prolific striker Lee Hughes.

Their manager Gary Megson was a firm adherent to the "one for all" team ethic as a player and has instilled the same belief at the club.

However, as Hughes was granted the freedom of Selhurst Park by a defensive line bereft of the Chinese international Fan Zhiyi and Hayden Mullins (and marshalled by the experienced, yet ever slowing Neil Ruddock), his prominence was inevitable.

He struck the visitors' equaliser - his 18th goal of the season - and could have completed a hat-trick if the Palace keeper Aleksandrs Kolinko and a post had not denied him.

Even when Des Lyttle looked to have pushed Hughes from the headlines with a 63rd-minute winner, the striker was there again. This time, though, he prevented a goal by apparently impeding Kolinko's vision from an offside position.

Lyttle, a true team man, refused to blame Hughes for denying him his second goal of the season and West Brom a thoroughly deserved victory.

"I thought Hughesy was nowhere near the goalkeeper. I think the linesman got it wrong," he said.

He added that his side's ability to recover from a two-goal deficit was further evidence that they are far from a one-man show.

"We've got goals coming from everywhere. We've got Foxy [Ruel Fox], Richard Sneekes, who scored today, and Michael Appleton who can score too," Lyttle said.

Appleton, a combative midfielder making his second appearance, seems to have a rosy future at the Hawthorns.

The centre-back Matt Carbon, however, may not, after the former Derby man failed to travel to south London without his manager's permission. Megson ominously decreed that the matter would be "discussed internally".

With Tony Butler also missing from West Brom's defence, Daryl Burgess started his first game this season.

Burgess, a former club captain, set the precedent for the day's defending by gifting Mikael Forssell his 10th league goal of the season.

Forssell, on loan at Selhurst Park from Chelsea, has impressed the Palace manager Alan Smith this season and is likely to be offered an opportunity to stay for another year.

The Finnish international, however, may be less impressed by the prospect after he watched his team-mates allow the two-goal head-start that he and Jamie Pollock had given them to be surrendered so meekly.

"I have two years left on my contract at Chelsea so, at the end of the season, we'll see," he said.

fields.headline: Way to survival points West
fields.trailText: Derby 1 - 0 Sunderland
fields.body:
The statistics are compelling: Derby have taken seven points from 15 games without Taribo West, 20 from 11 with him. Those 15 include two since he joined on three-month loan from Milan. Both were lost, one last week at Charlton, when West failed to return from Nigerian World Cup duty.

It was not quite fatted-calf time when he showed up on Friday but his manager Jim Smith sacrificed disciplinarian tendencies on the altar of discretion and wrapped his irritation in relief. He almost became philosophical.

"He's a strange guy," said the manager. "He likes going on planes too much. He's from a different culture and we have to try and regulate. With Taribo you get a certain amount of baggage." That is air travel.

What infuriated Smith was that West did not ring. Apparently there was a "serious family illness", which Smith accepted. It stood to reason: they have large families there and their health service is not much better than ours. But they have mobiles too.

On Saturday's evidence the manager is rightly desperate to extend West's three-month loan to the end of the season. It is not just his defensive strength or his quick eye for the break. By results alone he has become totemic: different culture, different hair, different class where there is not much.

As the Sunderland manager Peter Reid said: "They were catching us on the break. It was a strange game. We looked like the home side." But Derby were also caught offside so often on the break that in three second-half minutes they had three men booked for dissent. With seven booked in all, they will suffer an FA fine.

They deserved their win, though preserved it only by an elastic last-minute tip on to a post by Andy Oakes to deny John Oster. The 24-year-old keeper, who came to this debut via Bury, Winsford United and Hull for £450,000, once worked on a poultry farm. After action of battery dullness, it was a fine free-range save.

When Don Hutchison should have beaten him, he chipped wide. But that was Sunderland's only real chance. At the other end Horacio Carbonari and Craig Burley both hit posts and Deon Burton and Lee Morris shot wide when clear.

The goal, though, was almost by the way. Adam Murray played the ball through for what looked a likely goalkick but Stefano Eranio chased and crossed and Burley, getting more often forward with fuller fitness, swept in. For the second time in four days Sunderland had paid for not playing to the whistle. Detached and lacking focus? Mandelson's disease is catching in the north-east.

Reid was unfazed. "We had good possession but the final pass was not there," he said. He must be wary they do not throw away the good work that has put them in the running for a Champions League place. Last season defeat by Manchester United triggered a run of nine games without a win. A booking means Hutchison, like Alex Rae and Michael Gray, will miss the West Ham Cup game.

As Derby had Eranio forward on the right of midfield as a halfway stage to forward propulsion, so Reid deployed Hutchison, perhaps to supplement his reduced spearhead. Niall Quinn is top banana by any measure in Sunderland. Daniele Dichio, who prefers kilos, is just dead weight. Reid needs a different tactic, if not alternative striker. There is no point in starting with 10 men.

Meanwhile at Derby West is worth his weight in the gold of Premiership survival - 12 games to go, 22 points, easy.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Tiatto ruling has Royle in a spin
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 1 - 1 Man City
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
Maine Road's doors were thrown open to a sports psychologist last week as Manchester City's manager Joe Royle attempted to infuse a winning mentality into his battle-scarred troops. After this rip-roaring stalemate, Royle may book some time on the shrink's couch himself.

"I'm frustrated, exasperated, puzzled," he sighed, reflecting on a blistering eighth-minute strike from his workaholic midfielder Danny Tiatto which was cryptically disallowed for offside by the referee Alan Wiley.

With both sides in relegation trouble, this could have turned into a dour, nervous, struggle. Instead, it was brimming with attacking brio, which suggested that both teams could clamber to safety, although City may need better luck to survive.

Having weathered a torrid opening in which Nicky Weaver denied Hamilton Ricard and Paul Ince with his legs, Tiatto collected the ball in his own half. He tore into Boro's area and shot crisply across Mark Schwarzer into the far corner.

"I asked the referee at half-time and he said, as Tiatto shot, Andrei Kanchelskis ran across the goalkeeper's line of sight," said Royle. In fact the Ukrainian had been onside throughout, hovering on the edge of the area. "He's quick, but not that quick," Royle quipped.

The case of mistaken identity - Darren Huckerby was the City player ruled offside in the six-yard box, although he did not appear to be interfering - merely compounded City's frustration. Tiatto insisted he never had any intention of passing the ball. "I think the video replay should embarrass the referee for the rest of his career," said Royle.

Had Terry Venables been in a television studio rather than a post-match conference, he would surely have concurred. "But I just can't see how a referee could ever be right," he said. "How close does someone have to be to be interfering with play? If Tiatto takes the ball on and puts it across to the player who was in an offside position, what happens then? You don't know if the goalkeeper was looking for a cross, so you just have to ask whether the player was offside or not. He was.

"Funnily enough, the incident unsettled us and some of our lads thought, 'hang on, that shouldn't have happened."'

Contrition took its toll on Steve Vickers. Alf Inge Haaland's punt was chased to the byline by Kanchelskis and, with Shaun Goater and Huckerby waiting on the edge of the area, the Boro defender speared the cross into his own net as he back-pedalled.

Teessiders have not tasted defeat since their Cockney saviour arrived in December, but after Ince's header was parried, Ricard ballooned over an empty net and Keith O'Neill drilled wide from Ince's wonderful pass, they feared the worst. But, with City buckling, Cooper thumped an equaliser after a scramble at a corner.

The two sides blew themselves out in the latter stages, although O'Neill's dismissal for a two-footed lunge at Gerard Wiekens four minutes from time provided a sting in the tail. Goater, thwarted by Schwarzer, should then have earned City only their second win in 16 Premiership games.

fields.headline: Rangers begging change of fortune
fields.trailText: QPR 1 - 1 Bolton
fields.body:
The massive influx of investment needed to drag Rangers out of the mire cannot come soon enough. Shipping money off the pitch, the club is having no fortune on it either.

Gerry Francis's dejection after a late Bolton equaliser cost his side two crucial points in their fight against relegation was not helped by the prospect of persuading a benefactor to buy into the club after the chairman Chris Wright announced he was stepping down.

Wright said last week he was spending around £30,000 a game to fund the club's losses while the returns on his £20m investment over more than four years have been negligible. He decided to quit after three fans tried to attack him after the defeat by Fulham last Wednesday. As an advertisement for a replacement it is hardly inviting.

Wright will continue to bankroll the club to ensure it survives until a buyer is found but Francis, whose own future has been put in doubt, admitted on Saturday that potential investors are not queuing up.

"To get the club going forward again it's going to need an investment of around £30m to £40m," the manager said. "At the moment expenditure levels outweigh the income and only one man is covering that. There are not too many people lining up to take that position over.

"Chris needs help and, if someone can come in and put in money, that's the future. If he sells the club, there's a good chance the new owners will bring in their own backroom staff, but my position is irrelevant. It's the long-term future of QPR that's important."

Francis's 2-year contract runs out in the summer and, according to Iain Dowie, QPR's coach who came on as a substitute striker on Saturday, the strain of a spate of injuries and being second bottom is beginning to show on the manager.

"This year's been very tough and the pressure takes its toll on him," Dowie said. "He's a great coach, though, and given the right kind of finances he could have taken this club massively forward."

It now seems unlikely that Francis will ever get the chance or the financial means to try to make QPR the top team in London again, as he did in 1993 during his first spell as manager. Come May, he will settle for fourth bottom of the First Division.

Bolton's prospects are much brighter. Sam Allardyce felt that Per Frandsen's 86th-minute equaliser, after his side had been reduced to 10 men in the first half following the goalkeeper Steve Banks' sending off for a handball outside the area, could be a crucial goal in their attempt to return to the Premiership.

"It's a massive turning point in our season and greater than some of the wins we have achieved," Allardyce said. "It shows great resilience from the players."

Michel Ngonge had earlier scored his first goal for QPR with a looping header and the home side had enough chances to see off their depleted opposition. But goals, like money, are hard to come by at the moment.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Mancini wins battle of Italian imports
fields.standfirst: Chelsea fade away yet again as Leicester's new boys shine
fields.trailText: Leicester 2 - 1 Chelsea
fields.body:
It might help students of football psychology to know the precise moment at which Chelsea's blood turns to water once they have left Stamford Bridge. Saturday's defeat here confirmed the stark contrast in the team's form at home and away, but left the phenomenon largely unexplained.

If Chelsea are to embark on a late surge for a Champions League place this was the sort of fixture they needed to win. Certainly the circumstances appeared right for Chelsea's first away victory of the season in the Premiership.

Leicester, dealt a body blow by the departure of Neil Lennon, their midfield rotor arm, to Celtic, had lost four of their previous five league fixtures. They were also in the process of trying to bring a spot of Italian finesse, in the person of the 36-year-old Roberto Mancini.

For a time Mancini looked like a bottle of Frascati which had found itself in the company of brown ales. Chelsea's passing fizzed all around him while Leicester, when they were not giving the ball away, simply hoisted it forward to nobody in particular.

It appeared a toss-up as to which would occur first: a goal for Chelsea or the withdrawal of Mancini because of a crick in the neck. Yet the first goal was scored by Leicester and the first Italian in his mid-30s to be substituted was Chelsea's Gianfranco Zola.

Without Marcel Desailly, who had a calf strain, the vulnerability of Claudio Ranieri's defence to the kind of crosses which are Steve Guppy's speciality was likely at some stage to present Leicester with a scoring opportunity. All the more surprising, therefore, that Guppy was allowed so much room to produce a centre which glanced off the head of Frank Leboeuf on its way to the far post, where Muzzy Izzet headed Leicester in front after 24 minutes.

From then on Leicester were a team transformed while Chelsea merely reverted to type. The problems which the vision of Zola and Dennis Wise, the aggression of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and the penetration on the left of Jesper Gronkjaer had been causing should have encouraged Chelsea to carry on regardless. Instead they seemed to regard another away defeat as inevitable.

Their football became so passive that by the time an attack moved within scoring range it got lost in a thicket of bodies. Just past the half-hour Sam Dalla Bona found himself in space in the Leicester half but finding no one to pass to ended up attempting a hopeless shot from 35 yards.

The moment summed up the moribund mood which has affected most of Chelsea's away performances this season. It might have been different had Hasselbaink managed to put away a loose ball after Simon Royce had half-stopped a shot from Zola two minutes before half-time. And to be fair to Chelsea they did draw level 15 minutes from the end when Wise's precise cross found the Leicester centre-backs looking at one another as Hasselbaink's head found the net.

"I think that Leicester played better than us," said Ranieri, "though when we equalised I thought we could get a point or even win the game." Yet the time taken for this observation to be made and interpreted was roughly as long as it took Leicester to regain the lead.

Matt Elliott further punished the aerial deficiencies of Chelsea's defence to glance on a free-kick from Robbie Savage for Gary Rowett, unmarked at the far post, to drive the ball past Carlo Cudicini.

Leicester's win has revived Filbert's Street's hopes of European football next season although whether or not Mancini, signed from Lazio until the end of the season, is still around to participate will depend on how well Taylor feels he has fitted in.

The quality of cross which set up Izzet for a second goal five minutes after half-time, only for the midfielder to head wide, was evidence of Mancini's enduring class, yet the Leicester newcomer who caught the eye more was Junior Lewis, a midfielder on loan from Gillingham, Taylor's previous club.

Having lost Matt Jones, Lennon's replacement, through injury and suspension Taylor had to act quickly. Good management is as much about coping as coaching and the all-round strength of Lewis's performance proved the point.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

Without Marcel Desailly, who had a calf strain, the vulnerability of Claudio Ranieri's defence to the kind of crosses which are Steve Guppy's speciality was likely at some stage to present Leicester with a scoring opportunity. All the more surprising, therefore, that Guppy was allowed so much room to produce a centre which glanced off the head of Frank Leboeuf on its way to the far post, where Muzzy Izzet headed Leicester in front after 24 minutes. From then on Leicester were a team transformed while Chelsea merely reverted to type. The problems which the vision of Zola and Dennis Wise, the aggression of Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and the penetration on the left of Jesper Gronkjaer had been causing should have encouraged Chelsea to carry on regardless. Instead they seemed to regard another away defeat as inevitable. Their football became so passive that by the time an attack moved within scoring range it got lost in a thicket of bodies. Just past the half-hour Sam Dalla Bona found himself in space in the Leicester half but finding no one to pass to ended up attempting a hopeless shot from 35 yards. The moment summed up the moribund mood which has affected most of Chelsea's away performances this season. It might have been different had Hasselbaink managed to put away a loose ball after Simon Royce had half-stopped a shot from Zola two minutes before half-time. And to be fair to Chelsea they did draw level 15 minutes from the end when Wise's precise cross found the Leicester centre-backs looking at one another as Hasselbaink's head found the net. "I think that Leicester played better than us," said Ranieri, "though when we equalised I thought we could get a point or even win the game." Yet the time taken for this observation to be made and interpreted was roughly as long as it took Leicester to regain the lead. Matt Elliott further punished the aerial deficiencies of Chelsea's defence to glance on a free-kick from Robbie Savage for Gary Rowett, unmarked at the far post, to drive the ball past Carlo Cudicini. Leicester's win has revived Filbert's Street's hopes of European football next season although whether or not Mancini, signed from Lazio until the end of the season, is still around to participate will depend on how well Taylor feels he has fitted in. The quality of cross which set up Izzet for a second goal five minutes after half-time, only for the midfielder to head wide, was evidence of Mancini's enduring class, yet the Leicester newcomer who caught the eye more was Junior Lewis, a midfielder on loan from Gillingham, Taylor's previous club. Having lost Matt Jones, Lennon's replacement, through injury and suspension Taylor had to act quickly. Good management is as much about coping as coaching and the all-round strength of Lewis's performance proved the point.  You've read the piece, now have your say. fields.headline: Jefferies' anxious chat line recasts Carbone as saviour
fields.trailText: Bradford 0 - 3 Aston Villa
fields.body:
It has taken a "wee chat" for Bradford City's manager Jim Jefferies to recognise that the equally wee and unpredictable talent of Benito Carbone will have to be utilised if Bradford City have any prospect of avoiding relegation from the Premiership.

Carbone will play for the reserves against Liverpool tomorrow, provided he shakes off a groin injury picked up in training, and then may be earmarked for a return against Southampton on Saturday.

"Beni has set his heart on going back to Italy, but that window closed on Wednesday with the transfer deadline there," Jefferies said.

"He has no interest in going anywhere else and that means nothing can happen until the summer. But we've had a wee chat and he is now looking to get back into it. He is training very hard and there is a chance for him.

"Beni is a different case to Stan Collymore and Dan Petrescu, and it is better to persevere with him. The opportunity to go to Italy will open up again in the summer. It is a case of keeping his head up and getting him involved."

There was no doubting the perseverance that has gone into Bradford City's construction: a dutiful manager has produced an industrious team which in a decent world would deserve a chance of survival. Their midfield now comprises five hard-running professionals, as respectful of each other's dedication as they were suspicious of the flashier souls such as Collymore, Petrescu and Carbone.

But to summon up the form they now need to escape relegation, City need an inspirational goalscorer blessed by amazing talent and fortune. Instead they have Dean Windass.

It was Windass, hefty, wholehearted and sponsored by a local pub, whose spurned open goal at Sunderland a fortnight earlier had hinted that relegation was inevitable. He remains desperate to make amends. Whether it was a close-in header sailing narrowly wide, or a slithering run on goal ended by Steve Staunton's saving tackle, he was a picture of plucky self-admonishment.

Villa's manager John Gregory presented their escape from a losing run as proof that European qualification is still a realistic aim but they will require more creative wit. Until Bradford errors gifted them two goals early in the second half they relied entirely on the invention and touch of the admirable Paul Merson.

Darius Vassell was the beneficiary of Bradford's errors, twice scoring expertly after poor clearances, firstly from Robert Molenaar and then from the goalkeeper Gary Walsh, who must forever dream of those far-off days when goalkeepers could pick up the ball whenever they wanted to.

Julian Joachim, racing on to Lee Hendrie's pass, added a third late on as Bradford's desperate attacking response caused defensive chaos. Vassell should have finished with a hat-trick.

One Villa striker failed to benefit. Juan Pablo Angel, Gregory's £9.5m Colombian, might well be a master of the three-yard tap-in but on Saturday he was forever victim of the 30-yard offside trap. Mystified also by several debatable refereeing decisions in favour of his marker Peter Atherton, Angel was substituted 15 minutes from time, an expensive purchase still adrift in a bewildering land.

webTitle: Blair asks dome's Mr Fixit to take on Railtrack job

fields.headline: Blair asks dome's Mr Fixit to take on Railtrack job
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has personally approached troubleshooter David James - the man called in to stop the Millennium Dome going bankrupt - to ask him to consider taking over as chairman of Railtrack.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has personally approached troubleshooter David James - the man called in to stop the Millennium Dome going bankrupt - to ask him to consider taking over as chairman of Railtrack.

Details of the prime minister's approach emerged as a leaked independent report into safety on the rail network accused Railtrack of gross incompetence and negligence.

The report, which Railtrack refuses to publish at present, gives a damning insight into the failure of the company and its sub-contractors to deal with gauge corner cracking, the track disintegration which caused last year's Hatfield crash in which four people died.

The investigation, commissioned by Railtrack, draws attention to the poor relationship that exists between Railtrack and contractors appointed by the company to maintain the track.

With a general election approaching, the government is keen to be seen to taking a firm line with Railtrack in a bid to win back the confidence - and votes - of disgruntled passengers. Railtrack's chairman, Sir Philip Beck, is retiring in the summer and the early appointment of a tough and respected successor would send the message that improvements were on the way.

Mr James, who calls himself a "crisis manager", has made it clear that he is interested in the role, but would accept the job only as a fulltime executive chairman with the backing of Railtrack's directors.

But Railtrack is making it equally clear that it wants only a non-executive, part-time chairman so that the day-to-day running of the network remains with new chief executive, Steven Marshall.

Before Christmas the company circulated a letter to ministers pointing out that Railtrack's directors would decide who took over as chairman and that they would not tolerate intervention in the selection procedure.

The leaked report, undertaken by rail experts from Britain and abroad, was astonished to find that Railtrack had insufficient ultrasonic testing equipment for track inspection. It also blames some of the problems on fragmentation of the industry, which was broken up into more than 100 different parts when British Rail was hurriedly privatised by John Major.

Later this month the Health and Safety Executive is expected to recommend to the British transport police that criminal manslaughter charges be brought against up to six officials of Railtrack and Balfour Beatty, its main contractor at Hatfield, responsible for the maintenance of the track.

Criminal prosecutions would follow, which the Government hopes would prevent calls for a public inquiry into the events surrounding the Hatfield tragedy.

fields.headline: Iceberg tips Everton over
fields.trailText: Man Utd 1 - 0 Everton
fields.body:
Watching Manchester United splutter to this flattering victory, the thought occurred that they might not have it so easy next season if others can grasp the baton handed on by Liverpool, West Ham and now Everton. It may be clutching at straws but it is a notion the Premiership must cling to.

It is a trait of this declining title race that many of United's lessers have seemed almost frightened to offend when confronted with Sir Alex Ferguson's embarrassment of riches.

It is a fine line. While going gung-ho against the champions is usually the prelude to going belly-up, the popular stifling tactic of clogging defence and hoping for the best has proved a futile exercise. United, after all, have failed to score in only two of their last 51 home games.

Liverpool got the balance right to snaffle a 1-0 win at Old Trafford before Christmas and West Ham did so exquisitely in the FA Cup eight days ago. Everton, too, refused to hoist the white flag on Saturday.

Of course, there is always the suspicion that when the mood takes them, United's bloated resources are such they can dismiss any of their challengers without so much as a cursory look back.

They have also been operating on what is known in America as the iceberg theory, that the bulk of their most devastating power remains hidden beneath the surface.

Producing only a fraction of their awesome force yet emerging as victors is not a bad habit either but it has been noticeable of late that visitors to Old Trafford have been playing with a deal more adventure and self-belief. Will it last?

Everton accepted the challenge with surprising relish and the impertinence of it all unsettled United and unnerved their fans. "We're one of the smaller teams at the moment and it must be difficult for the likes of David Beckham and Ryan Giggs to get up for it," said Richard Gough. "I know myself from being at Rangers that, when you are dominating everything, it is hard to motivate yourself against the smaller clubs."

As Ferguson views complacency as something of a dirty word, he would doubtless recoil at the suggestion that some of his players had allowed it to creep in unnoticed. Yet it has been a long time since his team failed to manoeuvre a single shot on target in a match anywhere. "Come to Old Trafford for excitement, eh?" he asked, dryly.

The absence of Roy Keane deprived United of their driving influence and once Paul Scholes had suffered a recurrence of a rib injury the midfield skirmish was won by Thomas Gravesen and Scot Gemmill. Gough is 39 going on 21 and Michael Ball was outstanding alongside him as the left-sided centre-back in a five-man defence.

Walter Smith's limited but willing side deserved better than the two deflections that cost them. Andy Cole's diagonal shot was drifting wide until it ricocheted off Steve Watson's heel to loop over Paul Gerrard whereas, when Joe-Max Moore's shot struck Jaap Stam, the deflection wrong-footed Fabien Barthez but the ball spun over the crossbar.

All of which means United need 22 points to make certain of their seventh title in nine years, one that has come so easily that the rest of the Premiership should be squirming with embarrassment. For the time being clutching at straws is about the only thing left.

fields.headline: Houllier's men mock Hammers' pretence
fields.trailText:
Liverpool 3 - 0 West Ham
Houllier's men mock Hammers' pretence.
fields.body:
A question. Precisely how many times in recent seasons has the quaint, romantic notion that West Ham United are finally poised to blossom been posed? Three, perhaps four, times? In the more hysterical quarters of what was once Fleet Street it has become something of a tradition to declare the coming of a new force; it is called puffing up the unfashionable.

And so it came to pass that the happy-go-lucky 'Ammers, having strung together a couple of half-decent results and defeated a team of perceived betters in an FA Cup tie, were feted as the best thing since everything from sliced bread to jellied eels.

Before you can toss one of those wretched, hackneyed East End cliches into the pot, the word is out that lovable Harry Redknapp has, indeed, transformed base metal into gold and that there will shortly be a seismic shift in the Premiership's balance of power.

Cue anti-climax, for inevitably what follows is not Lord Mayor's show but dustcart and the only sound to be heard is that of the self-styled visionaries yelping in pain as reality plants a firm kick in what the late George Carman memorably referred to as the thinking parts.

Without wishing to burst one of those bubbles so beloved of the West Ham faithful, news of their club's emergence as a team so imbued of class and style that fear and panic will shortly engulf Old Trafford and Highbury has been somewhat exaggerated; it was ever thus.

If fact and fiction can be prised apart, West Ham are revealed as no more than a collection of the highly promising, the ageing, the aged and the foreign.

At the moment, in Paolo Di Canio, they also boast a genuine maverick with the capacity for brilliance but, sadly, he wasn't with us on Saturday. No, the Latin Lip was laid low by a virus, one which has a nasty habit of weakening his slender frame whenever there is the prospect of hard work away from Upton Park.

For all Joe Cole's unselfish, if futile, running West Ham were shredded at Anfield, outmanoeuvred, out-thought and ultimately outclassed.

No real disgrace, of course, for Liverpool are starting to resemble the fearsome, ruthless beast which Gérard Houllier used as a mental template when, two years ago, he began to throw someone else's money at a problem not of his making.

Once again, Liverpool were marvellous, an absolute joy to watch. By playing without wingers and using Vladimir Smicer as a free spirit just behind his forwards, Houllier was able to set Dietmar Hamann, Steven Gerrard and Igor Biscan toe to toe with Cole, Michael Carrick and Frank Lampard in central midfield.

It should have been intriguing, cracking stuff but it was no contest, Liverpool dominating to such an extent that West Ham all but surrendered after their brief, post-interval flurry failed to produce a goal.

"We changed our shape because I wanted to match them in midfield, where they are strong," said Houllier. "I knew that if they could not feed their strikers, it would be good for us."

And good it was for Liverpool. The outcome was rarely in doubt after Smicer's fabulous drive from distance flew beyond Craig Forrest midway through the opening half. Two smartly taken goals by Robbie Fowler, the renaissance man, wrapped it up and returned Harry's boys to just above the drop zone.

"Some of my players looked tired today," conceded Redknapp. "I'd like to have done what Liverpool did, rest a few, but I couldn't because of injuries. I'm not going to make excuses though - they were better than us."

fields.headline: Francis's winning worries
fields.trailText:
Birmingham 2 - 1 Norwich
Francis's winning worries increase.
fields.body:
In addition to the annual ritual of desperately striving to reach the play-offs - which this time has been decreed as the minimum requirement for Trevor Francis to stay in a job - recent victories have landed the Birmingham manager with a whole new set of problems.

His team, play-off semi-finalists for the past two years, are 12 points better off than they were this time last season and have a League Cup final to look forward to, but Francis is discovering that chasing success on two fronts puts increased demands on a man's squad.

"I've never been in this position before so I will have to learn as I go along," he said after an undistinguished performance which still produced a third win in a week. "I've got to get the balance right between picking up points and thinking about the final."

Next Saturday's visit to Sheffield United presents another problem. With only two fit centre-halves and one of them, the influential Darren Purse, on four yellow cards, a booking would see him miss the February 25 final. Francis will spend the week monitoring David Holdsworth's comeback from injury in a reserve game.

Karren Brady, the managing director, will also be asked if anything can be done about their far-from-level playing field. "Liverpool or Arsenal would struggle to pass the ball on that," said Nigel Worthington, the Norwich manager who missed out on a game for Francis's Sheffield Wednesday in the 1993 League Cup final due to suspension. "They should be ashamed of it."

Birmingham began playing with much of the pride they displayed against Ipswich in the cup semi-final, but this time with the debutant Curtis Woodhouse, who first met up with his team-mates at 1.15pm, impressing in midfield.

Stan Lazaridis soon fired a left-wing cross over and though Andy Johnson got a touch, Bryan Hughes knocked the ball home. Then they ran out of ideas. Fortune, or perhaps the pitch, favoured them after the interval, however, Lee Marshall handling and Purse doing the honours from the spot.

Chris Llewellyn pulled one back for Norwich to ensure a nervous 10 minutes for the faithful, who could at least be grateful that Geoff Horsfield's booking means he will be suspended for the visit of West Brom the week before the final.

fields.trailText: Tottenham 0 - 0 Charlton
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
If disgruntled Tottenham fans take to selling T-shirts outside White Hart Lane bearing the legend "I saw Spurs score", it is not difficult to imagine George Graham's reaction.

Nearby the manager would open a rival stall, proudly offering jerseys declaring "I was there when the defence was breached". A choice of design and colour would be out of the question. With Graham just now everything is tight and unattractive.

In drawing positives from this fourth successive goalless stalemate Graham was in a minority. Sure, Spurs are becoming harder to beat but such performances, devoid of quality and imagination, could scarcely be further from what their supporters want.

Three shots on targets was the sum of Tottenham's efforts and they have now failed to score in seven of their past eight Premiership matches. Graham's complaint that he is without three experienced strikers masks deeper problems.

Spurs' creativity and quality of crossing were so awful that it is hard to see what difference a fit Les Ferdinand would have made. Poor Sergei Rebrov, the one player capable of producing something truly unexpected, has been swallowed up by the ordinariness of it all.

"We could do with a bit of magic from him," Graham said, and he could do with Stephen Carr returning from injury as well. In Carr's absence, only the substitute Matthew Etherington looked capable of beating a marker and stretching Charlton's resolute defence.

Graham will not be concerned by the booing on the whistle nor the chants of "We want Graham out" but he ought to be worried by the thought of losing at Charlton in the fourth round of the FA Cup on Wednesday.

That would as good as end Tottenham's season and surely make it more difficult for the prospective owners Enic to persuade Sol Campbell and others to stay. "It could be a draw," Graham said of Wednesday, which was hardly like predicting the night's lottery numbers.

Sven-Goran Eriksson, who suffered through this game, will presumably not be rushing to the Valley. Charlton's manager Alan Curbishley pressed the England claims of Richard Rufus afterwards but the game's most impressive touch and movement came from a Dane, Claus Jensen.

Spurs' most accomplished passer, Darren Anderton, was peripheral at right wing-back and they showed a hint of fluency only after Tim Sherwood came on. "Their confidence is very low," said Charlton's Matt Svensson. "You can see that with every player."

Graham hopes the solidity at the back will foster more belief coming forward but he could do with a few strikes from his midfielders. Between them they have seven goals from open play, and on Wednesday with Andy Booth cup-tied graham may use only one striker.

The Scot plans to make signings once the takeover is completed this month and has to hope Enic will back him. Curbishley, meanwhile, goes on overachieving on more modest resources. For all Spurs' talk of injuries, Charlton arrived without their captain, goalkeeper and four strikers. Easily the brighter in the first half, they should have scored in the second but Shaun Bartlett drew a rare save out of Neil Sullivan.

Spurs wasted two late chances, so Graham equalled the four successive nil-nils he achieved with Arsenal in 1993. Tottenham fans knew he had been there and done that but they did not want the T-shirt.

fields.headline: Elusive Larsson pierces Hearts
fields.trailText:
Hearts 0 - 3 Celtic
Elusive Larsson pierces Hearts.
fields.body:
Henrik Larsson scored a hat-trick to warm the hearts of the coldest of Celtic supporters in the capital's blizzards last night and moved his team nine points clear of Rangers, whom they meet at Parkhead next Sunday.

The league leaders handled the cold, the drifting snow and a determined Hearts side with professional ease and Larsson showed the coolest of finishing touches as he took his goal tally for the season to 35.

Celtic were mightily relieved when the pitch was passed fit by the referee as a second late postponement was the last thing they wanted after last week's at St Johnstone, called off due to fog. That had given Rangers the chance to close the gap to six points and the Bhoys kicked off last night under as much pressure as they have been for some time.

The conditions had evidently scared off a large number of their fans, who had presumably opted to watch on television, but Celtic were undaunted and took the lead after only four minutes.

Alan Thompson fired in a free-kick from the left and Larsson got in ahead of Grant Murray to head emphatically into the bottom corner.

But the visitors were dealt a cruel blow in the sixth minute when Joos Valgaeren was carried off with a suspected broken ankle after falling awkwardly when contesting a header with Gordon Durie.

Antti Niemi excelled himself for Hearts in the 12th minute after Didier Agathe burst down the right and tried to cut the ball back, the goalkeeper making a telling save as Larsson set himself up for a shot. The pressure was mounting and Niemi again had to come to Hearts' rescue when Chris Sutton got to Thompson's free-kick only for the goalkeeper to thwart him.

Celtic continued to press Hearts back after the break and after 60 minutes Sutton was again presented with a glorious chance. Jackie McNamara found the £6m striker on the edge of the box but, once the former Chelsea man had jinked past Stephen Pressley, a block by Murray denied him the chance of getting a shot on target.

Hearts were still in the game and after 67 minutes they went close when Colin Cameron's free-kick came off the head of Tommy Boyd and flew past the far post.

Celtic, however, killed the game off a minute later when Thompson broke down the left before crossing for Larsson, who flicked the ball past Niemi with the outside of his right foot.

The Swede was not finished either and with six minutes remaining he got on the end of Agathe's cross and fired past Niemi before wheeling away in understandable delight.

fields.headline: Cottage industry is bogged down
fields.trailText:
Fulham 1 - 1 Sheff Utd
Cottage industry is bogged down.
fields.body:
Fulham could have taken a leaf out of Sir Alex Ferguson's book and blamed the rugby matches played at Craven Cottage for a pudding of a pitch that contributed to this disappointing result, though as it is over 15 years since they had a rugby league side here, that might have been stretching it even by Fergie's standards.

Their pitch could not have looked worse if they had hosted the entire Six Nations Championship, as well as the Horse Of The Year show. So poor was the surface that before the start of each half, a dozen sheepish looking officials in sou'westers came out to stamp down the divots and possibly on the heads of a few moles.

But to their credit, Fulham did their best to live up to their reputation as the side who have brought a version of the beautiful game to the Nationwide League, even if at times, inevitably, the conditions made it seem as though they were playing with an oval ball.

This was more a lesson that even the most outstanding side - and Fulham are clearly that in Nationwide Division One - cannot always have things their own way. Or as Sheffield United's Neil Warnock eloquently phrased it: "We don't have the riches but sometimes the rags can achieve things."

United arrived with a Baldrick-style cunning plan for teenager Nick Montgomery to mark Lee Clark out of the game. But unlike Baldrick's plans, it worked superbly, which must have put a red hue on Clark's face when he picked up the man of the match award.

United were also imbued with such fighting spirit that they began brawling among themselves when Georges Santos flattened Michael Brown after a disagreement over the working of the offside trap.

Santos was immediately substituted by Warnock, who remarked: "That's what Frenchmen are like - they lose it sometimes."

The state of the pitch did not prevent Fulham scoring an exquisite goal, Louis Saha brilliantly controlling a long, crossfield pass from Fabrice Fernandes, which must have made older fans think of Johnny Haynes, and the onward ball to Luis Boa Morte was so precise it made a goal inevitable.

Fulham fans might have expected a rout after that but once Laurent D'Jaffo headed the equaliser from a Brown free-kick just before half-time, one suspected that this live TV match would not follow the intended script.

This was, after all, only a blip for a Fulham side who are certainties for the Premiership. The real problem for them is that they have not only outgrown the Nationwide League but also their Craven Cottage home, which in terms of the modern game, belongs in some black museum.

Leaving the pitch out of it, the open terracing behind both goals is unacceptable for the Premiership and there are even a couple of floodlight bulbs missing.

That's why the club's most crucial fixture is not next month's game against closest challengers Bolton here, which will also be televised live, but the meeting of Hammersmith and Fulham Council's planning committee in 22 days' time, which will decide whether they get permission to build a new stadium here.

One trusts the plans include a new pitch.

fields.headline: Bottom of the class for Grange Hill XI
fields.trailText:
Sheff Wed 2 - 3 Watford
Bottom of the class for Grange Hill XI.
fields.body:
They were both relegated from the Premiership last season but the two clubs may be two leagues apart by the summer.

Graham Taylor is hoping his Watford team hold a return ticket in the play-off lottery while his opposite number Paul Jewell can only dream about such things after sinking to the bottom of the pile.

Watford may get even luckier, according to their wing-back Neil Cox, a positive thinker despite the scars of promotion battles won and lost with Middlesbrough and Bolton. His current team may be nine points behind second-placed Bolton, albeit with a game in hand, but Cox insists that the gap can be closed in the final third of the season, when pressure sometimes turns form upside down.

"We haven't given up on second place, definitely not. When this club went up last time they won nine out of the last 10 games," Cox said. "We've got 17 games left and I've just said to the lads 'Another 17 wins and we're there.' We've got a lot of games against teams in the lower half.

"Bolton are in the FA Cup and that can affect things. They've all got to play one another as well but we've played most of them twice already. And this squad is experienced; we've been through it before and that's vital."

Jewell, hoping to complete a deal for Manchester City's striker Gareth Taylor this week, has pushed young players in when he needs experience, but it is the only way to go for a club in chaos. In fact he may already be thinking long term - Hillsborough-speak for the Second Division.

Publicly he says his players - locally labelled the Grange Hill XI - can keep the club in the First Division, even though their record of five points from the last 27 is a sure signpost to relegation.

Wednesday have 16 games remaining and probably need to win half of them. "We've got a hell of a battle. It's going to be a fight but there is a lot of football left yet and I think we'll get the points we need," said Jewell.

Paolo Vernazza opened the scoring though Gerald Sibon equalised for the hosts. Darren Ward restored Watford's lead then Efan Ekoku, who should have scored earlier at 0-0, replied .But Tommy Smith hit the winner after the break.

There is hope for Wednesday. They made chances in the first half, fought back twice, and should have been awarded an 80th-minute penalty when Gilles de Bilde was clearly brought down by Robert Page.

fields.headline: Bergkamp's rare air raid
fields.trailText:
Coventry 0 - 1 Arsenal
Bergkamp's rare air raid wins the day.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger has had his striking problems this season. So much so that he hailed the 31-year-old Dennis Bergkamp almost as a new signing after the Dutchman delivered a rare goal. Multiply Arsenal's concerns fivefold, and the sum of Gordon Strachan's worries come into sight.

Strachan insisted afterwards that his team had "recovered their pride", but their weakness in front of goal illustrated precisely why Coventry gambled in reviving the pursuit of John Hartson, only to miss this target again. Wenger has suffered different frustrations, but at least Arsenal are still shooting for the FA Cup and Europe, even if the title might as well be the moon.

Wenger looked a relieved man, not only because he is still free to fine-tune tactics from the touchline but also because Arsenal travelled successfully for the first time since early November. And even if Bergkamp, like this team, operated in fits and starts, at least he scored - a relative rarity for any Arsenal striker in the league these days. Thierry Henry was rested on Saturday, said to be suffering thigh trouble, though his own goal block could equally have been cited.

Wenger has long been counting the lost championship opportunities; Coventry may soon be counting the cost of relegation. But Strachan is determined he will not be the manager vilified for losing top-flight status after 34 years. "This is Coventry - we've been in tighter spots than this before," he said. "Once in my time we were 9-1 on to go down." But the odds are shortening with his side now five points away from the safety zone.

Before the match Coventry's chairman Bryan Richardson was crunching different numbers. He offered a vote of confidence in his manager: "If the board were not 1,000% behind Gordon, you would have to see the matter differently. We don't feel there is any problem in that area. We support Gordon, and we will support Gordon, in every way."

Would Strachan still be manager if relegated? "I don't expect that to happen," said Richardson. "That's a hypothetical question and that's how it will have to remain."

If Coventry do fall, then Richardson will partly blame English football's transfer-fee and player-wage inflation. "We invested a few years ago heavily in players and in the stadium. We believed we would climb into the eighth-12th [position] bracket. But the price of many players, the whole package, is now astronomical."

He could have noted that there is no guarantee even when Coventry lay out a club-record £6.5m for Craig Bellamy, which is only half the fee paid by Arsenal for Sylvain Wiltord. Both strikers have been called expensive flops, even if Wenger made reassuring noises about Wiltord. "He's getting more and more used to the English game ... he's looking more the player I invested so much money in." Yet he has not scored a Premiership goal for over three months.

But Bergkamp and Wiltord, said Wenger, currently lack confidence although that notion was briefly dispelled 12 minutes from the end of a poor game. Wiltord crossed for Bergkamp, aided by Magnus Hedman's headlong rush and two defenders' in attention, to glance home a rare headed goal - for the Dutchman and for Arsenal.

Coventry by then were spent, counting the cost of physical endeavour in the first half and misses by David Thompson, Bellamy and John Eustace. Neither the team nor their fans, applauding sympathetically at the end, could overly complain because Arsenal were denied a penalty before the interval when Thompson handled - an injustice that saw Wenger remonstrating with the fourth official.

Strachan set his side a 17-point target for safety before this latest setback, although, upbeat as ever, he suggested 15 points "might do it". That is also still the gap between Arsenal and Manchester United but Wenger is not revising his estimates. The only chance for anyone, he said, is that United "go on holiday and come back for the last day maybe".

Wenger has conceded title defeat, and his team may also now struggle in the FA Cup. Tony Adams and Ray Parlour will miss the fifth-round tie with Chelsea after being booked here, as was Patrick Vieira, his first caution in 25 games since his suspension early this season. On Thursday Vieira faces a further ban if the FA find him guilty of alleged misdemeanours caught on camera in a league match at Leeds in November.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Anfield old boys entertain but settle for stalemate
fields.trailText:
Blackburn 0 - 0 Barnsley
Anfield old boys entertain for a stalemate.
fields.body:
Graeme Souness refused to blame his players for a result that cost Blackburn the chance to close the gap on Bolton but it is significant that the Rovers manager is today attempting to complete a move for the Israeli midfielder Eyal Berkovic from Celtic.

Blackburn have the pick of five strikers and they possess arguably the best midfield in the division but still they could not score. However, they are currently enjoying a 12-match unbeaten run and are sure to be major contenders in this season's promotion race. But Souness knows his team may need more cunning to fulfil their dreams of a Premiership return. And Berkovic could be just the man to provide it.

Souness and the Barnsley manager Nigel Spackman are graduates of the Anfield academy and it showed in the way they approached a contest between teams separated by 25 points in the table but sharing the same willingness to play the Liverpool way.

Barnsley, in the first half, produced the sort of football more suited to success than survival. But in the final 30 minutes Blackburn had enough chances to win the game as Matt Jansen, David Dunn and Marcus Bent all hit the woodwork.

Afterwards Jansen said: "On another day I could have had a hat-trick. It is very disappointing."

fields.headline: Breakfast with honeyed Frostie makes an England coach's day
fields.standfirst: Eriksson bans the bottle
fields.trailText: Eriksson's chief problem was not avoiding ambushes on early morning TV, but working out what the heck it was that Frost was saying.
fields.body:
Confusing times for Sven-Goran Eriksson. Having been warned of the rat-like cunning and sheer viciousness of the British media, he found himself yesterday morning wading through the bath of warm syrup that is Breakfast With Frost.

Here his chief problem, which must have been especially taxing for one who did not grow up with The Frost Report and That Was The Week That Was, was not avoiding ambushes, but working out what the heck it was that Frost was saying.

As has been cleverly observed by Rory Bremner and others, the more celebrated Frost has become, the less necessary he has found it to articulate actual complete words.

Sometimes the endings trail off into the ether, sometimes the middles are replaced with a non-specific grunt, and when he really hits his stride entire words are inclined to go awol.

So it was that Frostie yesterday asked the new England boss: "Whe the plays get togeth, wi, er, be stric roos abow alhol?"

After only a slight delay while he dealt with the double translation needed - into English, and then into his native tongue - Eriksson, magically, was able to come up with a response. His ability to construct something meaningful from only the scantiest of evidence was impressive, and fills you with hope that those midweek visits to Pride Park and the Stadium of Light may not have been a waste of time after all.

His answer was that the squad might as well get used to Perrier water.

"I don't know about strict rules," said Eriksson, "But we are together for playing for England, not for other things."

Sven delivered his message with a smile, but there is something about his face when he smiles - it is probably those glasses - that reminds you of Erich von Stroheim and Max von Sydow and all those other Vons that Hollywood wheels out to play U-boat commanders. I certainly would not want to be caught with liqueur chocolates in my kit bag with Sven in charge of the ship.

"Wi Enland plays ha to be tee-tollers?" Frostie asked. "Look, I am a Swede, I am used to alcohol myself," replied Eriksson, although possibly not as used to it as you, he might have added but didn't. "But these are professional footballers and you expect them to behave professionally, especially if they are playing for England."

It was Eriksson's first major television interview, and provided sound-bites for Five Live's sports bulletins for the rest of the morning, illustrating the great strength of Sir David. He is such a powerful networker that he does manage to secure the top people for his show.

They are also liable to relax their guard in the face of Frostie's honeyed part-words, although I am not sure Sven revealed a great deal, apart from the fact that Beckham will be in his squad, and he will choose his players first before fixing on tactics, although he expects to play with a back four.

The nation's football fans will have been heartened by Sven's apparent seriousness of purpose. He did not seem at all out of place on Frostie's show alongside Lord Wakeham and the Israeli politician Binyamin Netanyahu, although we will want to see him with Robbie Williams and Razor Ruddock on Sky's Soccer AM before we are convinced he is one of us.

If you are looking for a suitable analogy for the job that now confronts Eriksson, how about The Race, a non-stop, no-holds-barred contest between six massive catamarans aiming to circumnavigate the world in around 65 days. "Most people say it's fantastic, but impossible," said the yachtsman Bruno Peyron, who came up with the idea of The Race. Sven may soon be able to empathise.

Like international football managers, the skippers of these huge craft must learn to deal with periods of calm followed by bursts of feverish activity, during which if you are not careful your sail will be torn to shreds, or your lovingly constructed vessel might even fall to bits altogether.

One of the boats has already dropped out of the event, while other rain-lashed crews are trying to complete running repairs while navigating the treacherous Southern Ocean. As the skipper of the Polish boat said: "The Southern Ocean is very special. You are just in the middle of a big nature. It is not your place to be there."

That became abundantly clear in watching sailors cope with the challenge not just of staying alive - difficult enough in itself in these seas - but also winning a race.

If confirmation were needed of the hazardous nature of the enterprise, we were shown close-ups of one of the crew of the Polpharma-Warta having his head stitched up after a fall. Not for the squeamish. There must be easier ways to get a suntan and grow a beard.

The Race is being brought to us by Sky Sports, who tell me each boat is equipped with seven cameras (that's as well as the rum and ship's biscuits and all that other stuff that sailors need), beaming pictures via satellite to race headquarters in Paris, where the material is compressed, edited and encoded for transmission. Apparently it takes 20 minutes to send one minute of broadcast-quality footage.

I, for one, find it comforting that such trouble is being taken to refresh my jaded palate. Absolooey teriff, as Frostie might say.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Eriksson bans the bottle
fields.trailText: Sven-Goran Eriksson has laid down the law on alcohol and said he believes the influx of overseas players can be turned to his England team's advantage.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson believes the influx of overseas players can be turned to his England team's advantage.

"I know there is a problem with the number of foreign players," the Swede told the BBC's Breakfast with Frost programme. "But even Italy has the same problem, and it is a pity if you want a good national team.

"But it is not only a negative thing because foreign players come with something different, and the young players in England can learn from that."

The Swede, whose first game is a friendly with Spain on February 28, also warned that he will not tolerate a drinking culture. "If you play for England you don't need to drink wine or beer with your meals. We are together to play football, not for anything else.

"I am a Swede, so I am used to alcohol. But if you are a professional footballer you have to behave like a professional footballer, especially if you want to play for England."

Eriksson also confirmed he will play with a four-man defence. "I believe in a back four," he said. "I have always played like that, and there are very few times when I have chosen to play with three central defenders. I think we will start with four at the back."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Seven-up Barca triumph despite kidnapping hell
fields.standfirst: Sid Lowe on an eventful week in La Liga
fields.trailText: Sid Lowe on an eventful week in La Liga.
fields.body:
The nutters are out in Barcelona. Just two weeks after police in the Catalan capital arrested a man for planning to kidnap a Barça player, the abductors are at it again. To be fair to Santiago Cantón, an escapee from Barcelona´s Modelo Prison and the man up to no good this time round, at least he knew who he was after: midfield baldy and "little Buddha", Iván de la Peña.

Cantón - and a woman whose name hasn't yet been released but whose initials are AMA - followed de la Peña home from the Camp Nou on Monday. Fortunately, de la Peña was on the ball enough (groan) to take down the registration number of the car that pursued him, and managed to escape when he was approached in the underground car park at his home.

The attempted kidnappings have come as a huge psychological blow to one Barça player in particular. Michael Reitzeger was "horrified" by recent events and admitted on his website that he is "very worried, especially as this kind of thing gives people all sorts of crazy ideas. I'm constantly looking in my mirrors to see if I'm being followed these days and I keep double-checking the locks and alarms at my house."

"I'm terrified," declared the Dutchman. "It's like something out of the Wild West."

While Reitzeger was busy hiding out in the Sheriff´s Office on Saturday night, the rest of the Barça side seemed totally unconcerned, destroying Athletic Bilbao in the Nou Camp.

Barcelona boss Lorenzo Serra Ferrer had the cheek to enjoy things a bit too much and, worse still, to demand even more. With Serra Ferrer still cajoling his side at 5-0 up with goals from Abelardo, Cocu and Luis Enrique (3), Athletic manager Txetxu Rojo decided he'd had enough and turned to the Barça dug-out to remonstrate with his bemused opposite number.

"What´s the matter with you?" he ever-so politely enquired. "Do you want some more? Isn't this score enough for you?" Obviously not - Cocu and Overmars added two more to complete the scoring at 7-0.

Barça's win has had the Catalan press purring. Sport declared Serra Ferrer´s side "the true dream team". It also re-establishes the blaugranas's championship credentials. But despite 17 games unbeaten, Barça just can't close the gap on Real Madrid, who survived a tough test from Málaga on Sunday. Dario Silva and Dely Valdés yet again proved their class for Málaga.

It was Raúl, though, who was the real star, despite recent criticism. His two headed goals helped Real Madrid to a 4-3 victory and took him to the top of the league's goalscoring charts, and at 23 he's already scored more in the Primera División than anyone else currently playing.

It's not just Barça chasing Madrid, though. Deportivo La Coruña remain a point ahead of the Catalans in second place after beating relegation-bound Racing Santander 2-1, with Roy Makaay grabbing two more goals.

Makaay's first caused a bit of a stir - he was miles offside, the linesman's flag went up, Racing's defenders stopped, their keeper José Ceballos stopped, even Depor´s players stopped. But eagle-eyed referee Megía Dávila, aware that the "pass" to Makaay was a deflection off Racing striker Mazzoni, didn't, and waved the Dutchman on to score easily. A giggling Makaay waxed lyrical over the assist: "It was a phenonmenal pass from Racing's striker."

While Barça, Madrid and Depor kept up their end, Valencia stumbled again, this time in Mallorca, where Alberto Luque scored a late equaliser to secure a 2-2 draw for Luis Aragonés's side. Things have gone from bad to worse for Héctor Cúper's super troops, but with the league's four strongest sides now out of the way and new signing Pablo Aimar set to join the team next week (he was in the stand on Sunday), Valencia fans can perhaps look forward to better times.

One slight problem, though - the Italian passport fiasco is about to touch down in Spain, with judge Guariniello set to look into 27 La Liga players of "italoamerican" origin. And if reports in today's press are anything to go by, Valencia's Fabian Ayala is first in line - with a possible six-month jail sentence if found guilty.

Meanwhile, Mallorca fans seemed less interested Valencia's visit than the arrival of Celta de Vigo for the Cup quarter-final second-leg in midweek. Mallorquinos carried banners on Sunday warning Celta players, and Valeri Karpin in particular, not to come to the Balearics and accusing the Galician club of "buying referees with drugs".

Why? Well, all the fun centres on a bruising and extremely bad-tempered first-leg, and on two incidents in particular.

First, a penalty given to Celta by referee Antonio López Nieto despite the fact that he couldn't possibly have seen the "challenge" in question - he had his back to the incident and only turned round in time to see the final, and less blatant, stages of a shocking dive from Vagner.

The second thing that wound up Mallorca fans was the running battle involving Karpin, Finidi George, Samuel Etoó and the Balaídos crowd which boiled over at the final whistle and again at the airport later that night. Etoó had fired a parting "gesture" at the Celta fans at the end of the game and one of them decided to go to the airport to have it out with the Cameroon striker in person.

Luis Aragonés tried to calm the fan down, but soon lost his conciliatory mood when he called Etoó a "black shit". Aragonés took off his glasses (a la Clark Kent) and proceeded to grab the man by the throat. Only the intervention of players and club officials kept a seething Aragonés at bay.

Meanwhile, López Nieto´s inept display has opened up the refereeing debate - yet again. This time, one of the solutions being banded about by players is the introduction of foreign refs. Obviously, Mauro Silva, Miguel Soler and the rest have never seen Graham Poll in action.

Even though Pablo Aimar stayed in the stand, there were some big name debuts this weekend. Stan Collymore, on as a second-half sub, couldn't stop Oviedo securing a new league record - they've now gone ten away games without a goal following a 1-0 defeat at Las Palmas.

Collymore barely saw the ball. What he did see, though, was the weekend's scariest moment - a clash between Oviedo´s Pablo Suárez and Las Palma´s Josico, resulting in a bizarre fit for the Oviedo man that left him looking terrified and uncontrollably waving his arms and legs about like an upside-down woodlouse. He was rushed to hospital where, fortunately, he's been given the all-clear.

The most eagerly awaited debutant was, of course, Martín Palermo. The Argentinian may partake of feather boas and evening dresses but he doesn't wear women's knickers - not during games anyway. Palermo was pulled down by the shorts for what should have been a penalty during Villarreal's 2-0 win over Alavés on Sunday. Eager to prove that he'd been fouled, "El Loco" left his shorts down and brandished his arse in the ref's direction to reveal a pristine pair of white pants. Lovely. Not that Alvarez was impressed, mind you.

The weekend's best newcomer award surely goes to one of Las Palmas's subs, though: it's a warm welcome back to Spain, from this column at least, for Mario Turdó.

John Benjamin may be doing things right in San Sebastián, but he's just not getting the luck - Alexander Mostovoi got a late, late goal for Celta in the Anoeta to secure a 2-2 draw, denying his side a much-needed three points. Fumbling for the Spanish for "it's a funny old game, Saint", John Benjamin just shrugged and said "that's football".

At least Real´s nearest rivals also dropped points. Numancia drew 0-0 against Valladolid while Osasuna were beaten 3-1 by on-form Espanyol, with Toni Velamazán scoring two brilliant goals. The side Espanyol thrashed 5-0 last week, Zaragoza, bounced back with a hammering of their own: 6-1 against Rayo Vallecano. Juan Esnaider has proven a real boost for Zaragoza since his transfer from Juve's reserves, and the Argentinian was on the scoresheet again - a wonderful touch setting himself up for the home side's second.

And although it's still a month away, attention is already turning to the next derbi instalment. Real Madrid´s directors have decided to welcome Barça with 80,000 white balloons and ... silence. In contrast to the "barbarism" of the Camp Nou´s reception for Figo, Madrid´s president Florentino Pérez rather conceitedly regards the silent treatment as a symbol of Madrid's "honour" and "gentlemanliness".

But after Málaga's 3,000 fans outvoiced the 65,000 madridistas in the Bernabéu on Sunday, cynics might suggest that a call for silence is, in fact, simply more realistic.

webTitle: Scandal tonic gives Inter a lift

fields.headline: Scandal tonic gives Inter a lift
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle reports on a week in which unfettered sleaze made a bid for a place on the training pitch
fields.trailText: Sean Ingle reports on a week in which unfettered sleaze made a bid for a place on the training pitch.
fields.body:
Prostitutes, forged passports, a kidnap threat and the biggest display of campness outside an Are You Being Served convention - this week Serie A had it all. And judging by yesterday's results, indulging in, ahem, 'vigorous' activities off the pitch can only help a side's performance on it.

Need convincing? Then take a look at Internazionale. In the past week, Italian football's big-spending underachievers have faced the sort of sleaze allegations that would make even Neil Hamilton blush.

On Tuesday their Uruguay international Alvaro Recoba was exposed as an illegal immigrant - Daily Mail, man those barricades - after his Italian passport was found to be more dodgy than a 47m lira note. Recoba, who recently signed a new contract worth 15bn lire (£4.5m) a season, is now back in Montevideo awaiting permission to return to Italy.

Meanwhile, the situation doesn't look good for Inter. Before leaving, Recoba told Milan magistrates that he was given the fake passport by the club's technical director Gabriele Oriali. Oriali later confessed to the crime, claiming he had obtained the documents from "an official in Rome". But despite the overwhelming evidence, the club are still insisting that "no one at the club was responsible for the situation". No one? We'll see

At least the worst of the Recoba scandal had blown over within 24 hours. In its place, however, came something a lot worse: an internet sex ring involving ten Inter players. According to reports, the Inter Ten organised a party with several £1000-a-night hookers at an exclusive restaurant in Milan - and then spent the night with them at the home of one of the players.

After initially denying the story, coach Marco Tardelli told state television the allegations were true. "They were so stupid, they got caught," he said. "Compliments to those who don't get caught. I never got caught." Words which must be comforting to Mrs Tardelli

Then on Sunday something strange happened: Inter produced their most impressive performance of the season to win 3-0 at Bologna. Christian Vieri started things off, before two goals in a minute from Luigi Di Biagio and Vladimir Jugovic settled the game. Amazingly the win takes Inter into ninth - just five points off a Champions League place.

Batistutu camps it up, but Roma still win

Gabriel Batistuta turned 32 this week and to celebrate he held a fancy dress party. Abel Balbo and Eusebio Di Francesco both turned up as Casanova - who said footballers were vain? - Marco Delvecchio as an Arab, and the birthday boy donned a Captain Hook suit. Meanwhile, Vincent Candela came disguised as a woman.

But there was nothing camp about Roma's performance away at Parma. After going a goal down to Marco di Vaip and missing a penalty through Francesco Totti, the Giallorossi came back to win 2-1, thanks to two superb volleys from Gabriel Batistuta - his 12th and 13th goals of the season - in the last 20 minutes.

The performance even impressed Roma's incredibly-hard-to-please coach Fabio Capello, who announced afterwards: "This was the Roma that I have planned and striven to create and I feel that it is very much mine.

"It was a momentous performance. We truly showed our strength," he claimed. "We played great football and showed great character, pace and strength. But, above all, we showed the right spirit."

"I'm not looking at any other sides. They don't interest me - and neither does the six-point lead. With the Roma team that I saw today, I fear nobody and nothing."

Capello's future at the club is still uncertain - he is yet to sign a new contract and a move to Barcelona is reportedly afoot - but Roma fans are in no doubt that their coach should stay, even jokingly chanting 'Let's kidnap Capello' during the game.

"My contract is not important," was Capello's response. "What matters is the team, my players, and their conviction that we can win. The rest are meaningless details."

Lazio keep up the chase

Inspiring Roma to a six-point gap at the top of Serie A would be enough for most coaches. But not Capello. On Saturday he used a press conference to lambast the Italian Football Federation for not punishing Lazio after the club fielded illegally registered EU players - notably Juan Sebastian Veron.

"Ours is the only federation which has not taken action, which has not docked points from teams which have committed irregularities of this kind," claimed Capello.

Not surprisingly those comments met with an angry response - and a lawsuit - from Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti who called them "gratuitous and without foundation".

"Has Capello gone mad?" he asked. "It seems that Lazio's title has hurt a lot of people, most of all Capello, who doesn't seem to have digested it yet."

But the furore didn't distract Lazio on the pitch as two goals from Hernan Crespo - that's now seven in four games - and one from Juan Veron helped them edge past Lecce 3-2.

Juventus lose ground

After notching up an impressive 12-game unbeaten run, nobody expected Juventus to stumble at newly promoted Atalanta. But that's what exactly happened. Juve went ahead after 72 minutes after Massimo Paganin headed into his own net. But somehow - especially as Juventus had all the play - Atalanta managed to conjure up an unlikely victory, thanks to goals from substitute Stefano Lorenzi and Nicola Ventola.

Juve coach Carlo Ancelotti was understandably a disappointed man afterwards when he said: "When we went 1-0 up we should have closed the match out but instead we lost concentration and conceded a silly goal from a set piece.

"What upsets me is not so much having lost but losing when we played so well," he continued. "After a very balanced first half we dominated the second. A draw would have been a fairer result."

But as Ancelotti picks up the pieces from the defeat, maybe he should take a few lessons from what's going on at Internazionale and Roma. Judging by this weekend's events, a side that enjoys themselves off the pitch also seems to win on it.
