fields.headline: Surviving Survivor
fields.standfirst: The second edition of US reality TV show Survivor, being shot down under, may be good for tourism, but does nothing against cultural stereotype, writes Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: The second edition of US reality TV show Survivor, being shot down under, may be good for tourism, but does nothing against cultural stereotype, writes Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
Forty two million Americans are currently peering around the Australian outback, taking in the heat and the natural hostility of the driest continent on the planet.

The second series of the US smash-hit reality TV show, Survivor, was filmed about five hours drive from Cairns, north Queensland, and began airing in the US a week ago.

As with most foreign tourists, America's conception of Australia is largely gleaned from the annals of the two Crocodile Dundee films, and Survivor II makes no attempt to challenge these outback stereotypes of snakes, spiders and benevolent Aborigines.

This latest gift from the gods for Australia's tourist industry won't do much to educate potential visitors about the harsh realities of life in the Australian interior.

Last week, for example, it was revealed that Aborigines are dying at almost three times the rate of other Australians, with the average male dying at the age of just 46. But the only view of indigenous Australia the Survivor II audience gets are two token Aborigines, dressed up in kangaroo skins and wielding spears and boomerangs.

The photogenic American contestants are, one by one, voted out of pseudo-indigenous tribes called Ogakor and Kucha, while attempting to light fires (not recommended in the tinder-dry bush at this time of year), feast on "bush tucker", and become the last one standing in a Machiavellian quest for $1m.

After declaring in the first episode "When I wake up in the morning, there's two things I'm thankful for. I'm thankful I'm alive and I'm thankful I'm a Texan," the "successful, self-employed custom-auto designer" Colby Donaldson seemed safe for another episode.

Instead, the contestant with the least convincing positive mental attitude was summarily ejected, to the echo of a didgeridoo soundtrack.

Despite its American ethos and its, at best, casual acquaintance with Australia, Survivor II is described as "an ideal vehicle to help showcase Australia" by the Australian tourist commission's managing director, John Morse.

Tourism is spreading like wildfire in Australia: it was up 11% to a record 4.9m international tourists last year, with the tourist commission forecasting a rise to 5.3m this year.

The number of foreign tourists visiting Sydney, now considered by many an essential place to celebrate New Year's Eve, is growing by 10% each year. Most come from the US, the UK, Japan and New Zealand.

But there has been some uneasiness about the filming of Survivor II in the country. The Queensland government's environmental authorities are monitoring the show to check the contestants don't damage the fragile outback environment.

Two Aborigines from the local Warungnu traditional group paid to parade around in kangaroo skins voiced their dissatisfaction to the local press, after they were paid A$814 (£305) each for more than two weeks' work as token "wild natives".

Actors' union agreements entitle first-time performers to A$586 a week in Australia. The two men also suffered the indignity of being given a small pocket-knife with their pay cheques.

Warungnu elders also claimed that Survivor II's producers obtained all the necessary approval from government departments to film the show, but failed to consult the indigenous owners of the land.

It is a common courtesy, observed by many western companies and individuals, to acknowledge and seek the permission of the "traditional owners" before entering remote areas.

As Australia welcomes its tourists with the kind of charming friendliness that was such an admired part of the Sydney Olympics, so Survivor II is being welcomed onto Australia's Channel Nine.

(For worried Britons, it seems ITV, which bought the rights to the show for the UK, is developing a version more akin to British tastes with the help of Popstars' puppetmaster Nigel Lythgoe .)

The US channel CBS has reportedly gone to enormous lengths to stop news of the winning Survivor from being leaked out, with the final votes locked away in a safe.

The real winner is tourism. No amount of publicity about lethal funnel web spiders dropping from tree branches, crocodiles lurking on river banks, or deadly Taipan snakes slithering quietly through the grass - to say nothing of the risk of deep-vein thrombosis on long-haul flights to and from Australia - will be able to dissuade people from flocking to the "lucky country".

fields.headline: Gilbert Trigano
fields.standfirst: Selling a holiday dream of sun, sand and sea
fields.trailText: Selling a holiday dream of sun, sand and sea.
fields.body:
Gilbert Trigano, who has died aged 80, started out in the tourism business by lending a friend a few tents. That was the beginning of Club Mediterranée, the French holiday "concept" which turned postwar fantasies of holidays in faraway places into reality. Making deals with local governments, Trigano was to open up Club Med villages in isolated places - so long as sun, sand and sea was guaranteed. Club Med pre-dated the now popular "all-inclusive" holiday resorts by a quarter of a century.

A former member of the French resistance and an actor who had also worked as a journalist on the official French communist daily L'Humanité, Trigano was largely self-educated. His family ran a tent business and when, in 1950, his friend Gerard Blitz, also a veteran of the resistance, needed some tents for holidays in Majorca for ex-servicemen, Trigano provided them. So began Club Med.

The concept was idealistic, claimed Trigano; a desire for ordinary people to "discover the sea, to breathe deeply and live healthily". The idea that everything was included in the price and that "nothing is for sale in the village" was part of Trigano's philosophy. It was, he argued, a way of making sure that everyone was holidaying on equal terms.

He called Club Med "the best idea since happiness was invented". The appealing aspect of a Club Med holiday to a postwar Europe still locked into holidays on wet beaches and in grey guesthouses was that it offered a safe, good time in a fantasy beachside environment. No matter that your holiday was in Greece or Mexico, Marrakesh or Luxor - there were Polynesian thatched huts, shells for money, unlocked doors (for sexual frisson), and endless social and sporting events provided by the "gentils organisateurs".

A new sort of good-time ghetto was created in which no "gentil membre"- as customers were called - needed to move outside the self-striving culture of Club Med; no need to meet the host community, no need to deal with them; no need to spend money with the locals. While equality might exist within the walls of Club Med, those on the outside failed to benefit.

But the formula was successful. By the mid 60s, 45 Club Med resorts and two cruise boats provided for half a million holiday makers a year. By the 70s there were 129 "villages" in five continents. Club Med had expanded into new markets - in such places as the US, Brazil and Japan.

Yet despite its air of the new it was an old-fashioned management structure which contributed to Club Med's downfall: its market became older rather than younger; and the resorts began to look a bit weary and unreconstructed. Critics said its "core identity" was lost. It also suffered a blow when a plane carrying 30 Club Med tourists to Senegal crashed. (Last year, Trigano and his son, Serge, were convicted of involuntary manslaughter.)

By 1996, Club Med was reporting losses of US$120m and the next year the Trigano family was deposed by a shareholders' revolt. Philippe Bourgignon, the man seen to have revived Euro Disney, was installed as president. Trigano and Serge resigned, protesting that Club Med was becoming a "Mickey Mouse" set-up. The new management called the old "amateurish".

Trigano was also instrumental in taking computers to the French public. An enthusiast himself (computers were set up in Club Med holiday villages by the early 80s), he was invited in 1985 by Laurent Fabius, the socialist prime minister, to head a project to put computers in every school and college in France. Earlier, President Mitterrand had asked him to set up "Mission Trigano", which installed computers in deprived urban areas.

In 1997, Trigano created the virtual University of Tourism and Culture for Peace, based in Marseille, linking universities around the Mediterranean - starting in France, Israel, Palestine and Morocco. Combining his two passions of tourism and technology, Trigano believed that such educational projects around tourism could generate a "culture of peace".

Trigano, a small, energetic and creative personality, worked a 14-hour day. "If you live enough for three men every day you don't have to live as long," he once said. His missionary zeal for providing holidays for other people did not extend to himself - he never took a holiday.

He married Simone Sabah in 1945. He is survived by a son and three daughters.

 Gilbert Trigano, businessman, born July 28 1920; died February 3 2001

webTitle: Liverpool boosted by twinned city, Dublin

fields.headline: Dublin's rich add twist to tale of two cities
fields.standfirst: Starving Irish immigrants of the 19th century have been replaced by a new elite, helping turn Liverpool into a millionaires' playground
fields.trailText: Starving Irish immigrants of the 19th century have been replaced by a new elite, helping turn Liverpool into a millionaires' playground.
fields.body:
They are two cities of roughly the same size, with similar cultures and accent, 140 miles apart - yet separated by a frequently stormy sea.

In the mid 19th century, tens of thousands of starving immigrants poured into Liverpool from Dublin to work in the city's docks and workshops as the area became one of the world's great trading posts.

Now, in a remarkable reversal, Ireland's dynamic new entrepreneurs and Dublin's cash-rich property elite are pouring tens of millions into Liverpool and helping to transform a down-at-heel city into a millionaires' playground. It has become a place to dump surplus capital and make money work faster than in overheating Ireland.

They are buying up flats by the hundred, helping to fuel an unprecedented property boom, investing in new port facilities to serve high-speed ferries, and even planning supermarket distribution depots - to serve Ireland, not England.

The historic connections between the cities are being further strengthened by cut-price air travel and express ferries - making it much faster, and cheaper, for Liverpudlians to get to Dublin than to London.

Since the cities twinned in 1998, David Tinsey of the Liverpool chamber of commerce said the links between them have strengthened to such an extent that their economies are almost merging.

"Dublin is not thought of as a foreign city," he said. "People here consider Dubliners to be kith and kin. The links are natural. As the economy in Dublin peaks, business people are looking elsewhere for prime areas to invest. London is expensive and a more difficult market to penetrate."

Across the Irish Sea, Phil Sweeney, director of sales and marketing for the Prem Group, one of Dublin's largest property concerns, agreed. They are taking out leases on scores of Liverpool apartments and are now opening serviced offices in the city.

"A lot of people in Dublin are sitting on serious wealth and it is getting harder and harder to find investment opportunities over here," she said. "Development in the city is just not encouraged any more. We have lost a lot of our tax incentives, which makes cities outside Dublin - particularly Liverpool - an attractive proposition."

Part of the attraction is the more favourable fiscal regime in a UK outside the eurozone: taxes levied on properties valued between £25,000 and £500,000 are small compared with Irish taxes of 15% on similarly priced homes.

As a result, the chief executive of one large Liverpool property company said he knows of at least one Irishman who is borrowing £30m of mortgage cash each year to buy flats in Liverpool.

The type of investment and talent coming across the Irish Sea is also diversifying, taking in sectors other than the traditional areas of property and construction.

Mr Tinsey points to supermarket distribution and the professional services sector as a prime example of the shift. High profile Dublin residents such, as fashion designer John Rocha, are also taking an interest. He has chosen to launch his second major hotel interior design project in Liverpool.

The timing of the Irish interest in Liverpool is no coincidence. The city council and key players in the private sector point to a change in attitudes to Liverpool and to a new business confidence taking root.

Tom Bloxham, whose Manchester-based Urban Splash has been at the forefront of residential property development in the north west, said: "Liverpool has not been seen as a business-friendly city historically. But all this is changing. New investment capital is coming in and a chunk of it is coming from Ireland."

Paul Bolton of property developers the Charlton group agreed: "We have strong relationships with a number of Irish firms and they have an appetite for rental properties in the city centre in particular."

Mr Bolton said that Dublin's new-found business confidence is rubbing off on Merseyside. By investing in the city, which would benefit from a similar "can do" ethos as the Irish capital, he predicted that cash from Dublin could be a significant factor in Liverpool's future success.

Charlie Parker, executive officer for regeneration at Liverpool city council, said investors from Ireland and beyond are beginning to take Liverpool seriously. "It is very well placed as a gateway to east and west. It has benefited from its location in the past but we are now seeing different benefits. Add this to cheaper property and cheaper labour and we have an attractive package for new investment."

If the cash currently flowing from Ireland does turn into a flood, Dublin could once again be the engine for Liverpool's economy. There is an element of history repeating itself said local historian Steve Burns - albeit with Irish money rather than labour.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Roland
fields.trailText: While you're in Malaysia, don't forget Penang Laksa (with the fish paste), the Curry Mee, the Rojak, the Nasi Lemak, and the Murtabak, amongst the other mouth watering and spine tingling delicacies.
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

I'm pleased you are having a great time in Malaysia, especially KL. The land of my birth, you know, before I became an anglophile, and decided to spend my life here in good ole Blighty.

Get away from the modernised bit, and you will have good time.The places you have mentioned are interesting. KL is much better than Singapore for its hustle and bustle, and its vibrancy (I might be prejudiced here). Not artificial at all, although Singapore has its delights. Don't forget Penang Laksa (with the fish paste), the Curry Mee, the Rojak, the Nasi Lemak, and the Murtabak, amongst the other mouth watering and spine tingling delicacies. Selamat, and good luck. Hoping to hear more about your exploits.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From: Neil
fields.trailText: Malawi is an excellent choice; one of the best countrys in south Africa. Check out Mount Mulange in the south, an amazing monolith mountain rising out of the ground.
fields.body:
Hi Sam

Malawi is an excellent choice; one of the best countrys in south Africa. Check out Mount Mulange in the south, an amazing monolith mountain rising out of the ground (but beware: when I was there the whole main trail caught fire and we had to back off. Incrediible views though). You can trek across the flat top from hut to hut... takes a few days... Very cool.

Also, take a boat down the middle of lake Malawi to Chizamulu island... this is about as isolated as you can get with only one boat a week... fantastic friendly people... would be good to know if it has become over developed or is still quiet..

Good luck,

Neil

webTitle: Ten ways to give your guilt a holiday

fields.headline: Ten ways to give your guilt a holiday
fields.standfirst: Does eco-tourism have to be a contradiction in terms? Ros Coward reports on companies who are offering ways of making holidays more of a give and take experience
fields.trailText: Does eco-tourism have to be a contradiction in terms? Ros Coward reports on companies who are offering ways of making holidays more of a give and take experience
fields.body:
You might well think eco-tourism is a contradiction in terms. How can places of great natural beauty, or wildlife, be preserved once tourists start visiting in their thousands, bringing with them the need for services and development? Is it really possible to have a guilt-free holiday? Can you visit a place without damaging it in some way?

The answer to that is in most cases no. But that's not to say we should all stay at home. With careful planning and research and a responsible attitude, you can holiday all round the world while ensuring that your conscience remains clear. But a word of warning - look carefully at what companies that offer 'green holidays' actually mean by the phrase. It is no greener to drive a motor boat down the Amazon than hire a car on the Costa del Sol, probably less so since the damage is already done on the latter. Unless a company is actively looking to minimise their impact on host countries or even working to make contact a positive thing, the claims should be regarded with scepticism.

But it's not all bad news. If you look carefully there are many small independent tour companies or environmental organisations who are genuinely committed to develop sustainable tourism. The Association of independent Tour Operators' (AITO Committee for Responsible Tourism has developed voluntary guidelines for travel companies which it hopes to make mandatory within two years.

In the meantime, here are 10 ideas for how to take a guilt-free green break, from work camps to conventional packages.

1. Go Organic (on a bike)

Not everyone is a fan of the 'charity trek' but if you want to acquire a virtuous green glow, this is hard to beat. In May a bike ride from Bilbao to Barcelona will raise money for the Soil Association which campaigns for organic food and sustainable agriculture and forestry. Participants will stay at organic guest houses and eat organic produce, boosting local organic enterprises. There's no age limit but participants must raise £2,500, half of which is for the Soil Association, half for the trip's expenses. Suzanne Austin, who went last year, says, "The trip will remain ingrained in my mind as well as my heart for the rest of me life. I wanted to get fit. All I wanted to do when I got back was to get on my bike and ride as fast as possible back to those mountains in Spain." Email info@soilassociation.org for more details.

Organic Places to stay has details of organic hotels, b&bs and cottages throughout the UK and much of Europe as well as further beyond - from Sri Lanka to Hawaii.

2. Leisure and Learning

The long running environment education charity Field Studies Council offers a vast number of courses, some to very exotic locations. Their aim is "low-impact" tourism - small groups staying in local accommodation using local guides and experts to promote "environmental understanding for all". Customer satisfaction is high. Michael Edwards, who has travelled with them to remote parts of China, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Spain and Cuba says he's only ever had "remarkable" experiences. "We always go somewhere interesting; we are shown things by experts and you don't feel you're harming the people or the wildlife. In fact because they use local resources, it even feels as if you are doing some good." More information can be found at fscoverseas.mcmail.com. Back in the UK, there are numerous courses in study centres like Flatford Mill.

3. Plant a tree in Iceland

For unadulterated nature, you could do worse than head for Iceland. So few people live in this extraordinary island that last year the number of tourists exceeded the population. Fortunately there's plenty of wilderness to go around, and in some respects tourism has been positive for the country. Inge Ingesdottir of Northern Lights Tours encourages tourists to plant a tree before they leave. Another environmentally-aware company, Arctic Experience pioneered whale-watching trips - now such money spinners that Iceland has abandoned ideas of commercial whaling. Both companies offer treks, riding holidays and whale-watching. Northern Lights tours even offers 'children of nature' youth camps where children "run free, spending most of their time outdoors, living a healthy lifestyle".

4. Tourism for conservation

If you want a wildlife holiday, try to use a company that takes conservation seriously, and choose a destination where conservation measures are already in place and small-scale tourism is properly managed by locals. Arctic Experience's sister company, Discover the World runs wildlife tours to exotic locations, including Jordan and Madagascar. It's one of a few small companies actively supporting conservation work in the host countries: they support the Born Free Foundation in Tanzania. Discovery Initiatives is actively working with several conservation charities including The World Wildlife Fund. Director, Julian Matthews says, "tourism should guarantee that things which draws us now should be the same in a hundred years. Currently, our most popular trip is to the orang-utans in Borneo. Participants stay at the camp made famous by Birute Galdikas and help research and tracking. The company donates $1,000 per person to fund wardens and resources."

5. Beach holidays with a conscience

In terms of the global footprint, the traditional beach holiday is the worst offender. They cater for large numbers travelling by air, increasing carbon dioxide emissions. They use hotels and complexes which not only scar the landscape but are not locally owned so tourist money doesn't help the local economies. But, a few small and admirable companies are doing their best to minimise tourist impact, even putting something back into the host countries. The Gambia Experience helps local schooling projects and promises to match tourist donations. They also encourage tourists to understand and respect Gambia's own commitment to conserving their environment.

6. A hands-on approach

Laskarina, which operates mainly on the Greek islands and won The Observer's best travel company award for four years running, has "a hands on approach" to the environment. They've encouraged and helped locals to restore traditional buildings which can be included in their programmes, they distribute cotton shopping bags to their clients in an attempt to reduce use of plastic bags, and they are encouraging numerous environmental initiatives including working with local environmentalists after a serious fire on Samos.

7. Agro-tourism

Since the first appearance of gites in holiday brochures in 1970, agrotourism has become an important part of the tourist market. It still makes sense environmentally. Agrotourism injects money into rural communities, it encourages locals to value and preserve their natural environment, and leads to the restoration of traditional houses. Richard Hearn, managing director of Inntraveland Chair of AITO's Committee on Responsible Tourism says he's proud of the impact his holidays have had on areas like the Asturias in Northern Spain. There, farmers were struggling and the countryside was becoming very neglected. His company used local bed and breakfasts and tapped into local resources and helped open up neglected footpaths. "When tourism values nature it has a knock on effect."

Friends of the Earth have tried to encourage agrotourism on Cyprus to counter the destructive effects on the environment of coastal ribbon development. Sunvil Holidays organises trips to less visited parts of the island, and has a strong commitment to environmental protection.

8. Volunteer work nearer home

It may not be as exotic as Namibia, but there's a lot to be said for staying at home and helping conserve what's on your own doorstep. For a start it's a great and inexpensive way of getting fit. The British Trust for Conservation Volunteers runs Work camps and Canal Camps. The Wildlife Trust also need volunteers for days and weekends doing jobs including pond clearing and hedge laying.

9. Environmental research in exotic locations

Earthwatch will take you to more remote and exotic locations where you can participate in environmental research projects. They can offer advice on how to fund your trip through sponsorship, and this year, funded by Lottery money, they are also offering awards for the over 50s to take part in one of their conservation projects. For more info contact millenium@earthwatch.org.

10. Go it alone

The jury is still out on whether you do less harm by going it alone. More money goes into the local economy, but you may just be opening up remote parts for mass tourism. If you do travel independently, get a good guidebook. Bradt publications, pioneers of wilderness travel, puts a high priority on wildlife and environment. If you travel by plane, consider paying a 'carbon tax' - see Carbon Care for more information, or plant a tree or two to neutralise your carbon emissions.

 Consult Tourism Concern for general issues about responsible tourism, destinations and guides.

webTitle: Charities in competition for awareness days

fields.headline: Charities in competition for awareness days
fields.trailText: Charities fear the proliferation of "awareness days" to sell goods such as push-up bras is leading to public apathy towards their "less sexy" promotional campaigns for good causes. David Batty reports
fields.body:
Charities fear the proliferation of "awareness days" to sell goods such as push-up bras and chips is leading to public apathy towards their "less sexy" promotional campaigns for good causes.

Many charities have decided to join forces with high-profile businesses to prevent their messages being sidelined by headline-grabbing stunts such as national cleavage day. Save the Children will be receiving funds from national doughnut week, which began on Saturday.

Awareness campaigns, such as world Aids day and breast cancer awareness month, have traditionally been used by charities to boost public awareness of their cause and provide a major source of their income. Breast Cancer Care's monthly income rose from £300,000 to £1.3m in its awareness month last October.

But the sector is unregulated and increasingly congested with about 430 events jostling for public attention this year - more than double the amount in 1996. Commercial campaigns now account for 10% of the market. These include national chip week, national lather day, sponsored by Imperial Leather, Dualit national toast day and sausage awareness week.

Peter Maple, director of public affairs at disability charity Leonard Cheshire, said: "In such a cluttered market, it's increasingly difficult to establish or maintain a charity campaign. The problem is it's much harder to ingrain an 'issue' into the public conscious than a 'sexy' brand such as Wonderbra."

The Profile Group, which runs the awareness day register to help coordinate awareness campaigns, admits there have been embarrassing clashes between commercial and charity events.

Vicki Ormiston, editor of the awareness day register, said: "Some have had to reschedule their events. Quality Street day was moved last year so not to clash with UN starvation day."

However, the somewhat insensitive coupling of national impotence day and contraception awareness week will go ahead this year.

Ms Ormiston said charities were increasingly linking up with commercial promotions or adopting their marketing ploys to get their message across.

"Most charities lack the PR resources of big business. Teaming up can bring fresh interest to a long-running campaign."

The Institute of Cancer Research Everyman campaign, which runs an awareness drive for prostrate and testicular cancers every June, teamed up with supermarket chain Asda last year and is working with a menswear's designer this year.

"It's been beneficial for us to join forces with commercial interests," explains Hugo Middlemas, fundraising manager for the campaign. "Our income nearly doubled in June 2000 from the previous year - rising from £24,000 to £43,000.

"We have limited funds or expertise in PR and Asda really helped to get our message across - especially in the regions through local newspapers."

But Ms Ormiston said commercial awareness days would not have the longevity of their charity rivals. "They have hit hard but will fade away, as the corporate sector is always looking for new forms of promotion."

The problem is it's much harder to ingrain an 'issue' into the public conscious than a 'sexy' brand such as Wonderbra." The Profile Group, which runs the awareness day register to help coordinate awareness campaigns, admits there have been embarrassing clashes between commercial and charity events. Vicki Ormiston, editor of the awareness day register, said: "Some have had to reschedule their events. Quality Street day was moved last year so not to clash with UN starvation day." However, the somewhat insensitive coupling of national impotence day and contraception awareness week will go ahead this year. Ms Ormiston said charities were increasingly linking up with commercial promotions or adopting their marketing ploys to get their message across. "Most charities lack the PR resources of big business. Teaming up can bring fresh interest to a long-running campaign." The Institute of Cancer Research Everyman campaign, which runs an awareness drive for prostrate and testicular cancers every June, teamed up with supermarket chain Asda last year and is working with a menswear's designer this year. "It's been beneficial for us to join forces with commercial interests," explains Hugo Middlemas, fundraising manager for the campaign. "Our income nearly doubled in June 2000 from the previous year - rising from £24,000 to £43,000. "We have limited funds or expertise in PR and Asda really helped to get our message across - especially in the regions through local newspapers." But Ms Ormiston said commercial awareness days would not have the longevity of their charity rivals. "They have hit hard but will fade away, as the corporate sector is always looking for new forms of promotion."

fields.headline: Vanishing voters
fields.standfirst:
People won't turn up on election day unless they have something to cast their ballot for, rather than against

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: People won't turn up on election day unless they have something to cast their ballot for, rather than against.
fields.body:
Alongside eating your greens, giving your seat up for pregnant women and not dropping litter in the street, voting has always occupied a particular ethical place within the British social psyche. Ranking somewhere between community responsibility and moral rectitude, it has been regarded as the act of the upright citizen and concerned individual.

Even as colonies around the globe were denied the ballot and MPs in Northern Ireland were left to die on hunger strike, the vote was hailed as an inalienable right. It was our passport to modernity and civilisation; the cornerstone of democracy; like death, the great leveller.

Almost regardless of where you stood on the political spectrum during the latter half of the 20th century, you could always see a reference point to support the innate, wholesome decency of the electoral act. It was why we fought the Nazis and why we will fight the commies if we have to, said the patriots. Suffragettes died for it, Martin Luther King lived for it and Nelson Mandela went to jail for it, said the internationalists.

But somehow voting has begun to look, to many, like brussels sprouts left out over night. We understand there is good in it, but in the cold light of day we have the lost the taste for it and, given the choice, would rather go hungry for the time being.

The last election saw the lowest turnout since the second world war. The next, according to a recent Guardian/ ICM poll, promises to be even lower. The number of people who say they would be certain to vote if there was an election tomorrow stands at 60% of the electorate, compared with 64% at the same stage in 1997. In a parliamentary byelection in Leeds in July 1999, turnout dipped to a postwar low of 19.6%.

To blame this all on the ideological vacuity of mainstream politics prompted by Labour's drift to the right, is tempting but simplistic. The turnout for elections to the Greater London Assembly, where Livingstone stood as a clear left choice, was also low. When the leftwing independent Dennis Canavan vacated his Westminster seat of Falkirk West at the end of last year, prompting both a leftwing and nationalist surge, the election turnout was the lowest in Scotland for more than 50 years.

The stay-away might not be entirely Labour's doing, but it is almost completely its problem. Its biggest threat come the next election is not the Tories, but turnout. The two times that the Conservatives have beaten Labour in the popular vote since 1997 - in the European elections of 1999 and the local elections of 2000 - the problem has not been Labour voters switching sides, but Labour supporters refusing to take sides.

This has always been the principal glitch in New Labour's electoral arithmetic. It has operated on the calculated assumption that as it went foraging for votes on the right and centre, there was a hard core of Labour supporters who would vote for it come what may, because politically they had nowhere else to go. The trouble is, it got its sums wrong. What it didn't bargain on was its supporters not going out of the house.

This, too, is reflected in the polls. The Conservative vote has hardened slightly since the last election with the likelihood of Tory supporters turning out to vote rising slightly on a statistical scale from 9.02 in January 1997 to 9.10 now. Meanwhile the likelihood of Labour voters going to the polls has dropped sharply from 9.11 to 8.68.

Blair has referred to this as apathy, but it is something far more dangerous. The issue is not people who cannot be bothered but people who are fed up with being bothered. Many of them were, in the past, the foot soldiers of active democratic citizenry - activists who not only voted but spent their spare time going out at night and trying to get other people to vote too. When they sit on their hands it is not apathy but disillusionment, the seeds of which were sown before the last election and were already bearing fruit on May 1 1997.

Ask any Labour supporter to recall just one image that signified the sweetness of victory that night and they all say the same thing - Michael Portillo losing his seat. On a night when Labour won the largest majority of any single party since 1924, bringing with it a new generation of political leadership and a record number of women MPs, the high point of the night was not Labour being voted in, but the Tories being kicked out.

After 18 years of one-party rule that was maybe as it should have been. In any case, it is almost certainly as Tony Blair had intended it to be. The whole thrust of the last campaign was to reassure middle England that it could trust him by lowering expectations of how different a Labour government would be.

To the extent to which these low expectations delivered him a decisive victory at the last election, this strategy was successful; to the extent to which these low expectations are defining him in the run-up to the next election, it is proving a huge liability. For a healthy democracy is not founded just on the number of people who turn up to vote, but on the choice that they have when they get there.

The issue is not whether there is any difference between Labour and the Tories - there patently is - but whether there is sufficient difference for there to be any moral argument for putting your cross next to one instead of the other.

It is no good evoking Nelson Mandela in this regard. They may have cheered him at last year's party conference, but under current asylum laws, had he managed to flee apartheid, he would have been detained when he reached Britain. It is difficult to imagine that he would have wanted to swap Robben island for Campsfield detention centre.

Claiming you're not as bad as the other lot might work in opposition, but it is a feeble excuse after four years in power. The rise in pensions and teachers' pay, for all their faults, suggest the Labour leadership has at least partly understood that this time people want to vote for, rather than against, something.

It also suggests that the very part of the movement that New Labour once regarded as dead is actually keeping it afloat. It is the left, inside and outside the party, that has kept the issues of pensions and public sector pay at the fore and the unions who backed it during the fuel crisis.

Meanwhile it is the right which has proved the greatest liability by descending into the kind of vain bickering, venal indulgences and personal rivalries that has led voters, according to a recent poll, to believe that Labour is sleazier than the Tories.

Under those circumstances, Millbank would do better to promise even higher pensions and better public services than appeal to our sense of active citizenship and moral rectitude come polling day.

fields.headline: £3bn budget help for families
fields.standfirst:
 Brown rules out tax cuts
 Bid to lift further 1m children out of poverty
 Maternity pay boost

Special report
New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is to kickstart Labour's re-election campaign with a Budget next month that will spurn demands for an across-the-board cut in income tax in favour of a £3bn pre-election package focused on helping families with children.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is to kickstart Labour's re-election campaign with a Budget next month that will spurn demands for an across-the-board cut in income tax in favour of a £3bn pre-election package focused on helping families with children.

A new measure aimed at providing financial support for parents with infants under one is to form part of a three-pronged approach designed to lift a million children out of poverty in a second Labour term.

It will be buttressed by an increase from £8.50 to £10 a week for the children's tax credit (CTC) - the replacement for the married couple's allowance - and an uprating of the working families tax credit (WFTC), the tax break for the low paid.

With recent polls showing support for the government falling among women voters, the Budget will also extend paid maternity leave from 18 to 26 weeks and increase statutory maternity pay.

The chancellor will outline his strategy in Downing Street today in a joint presentation with the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, which will stress that Labour's extra cash for families is to be accompanied by a tougher line on fathers who shirk their parental responsibilities. Mr Darling will single out the minority of parents who seek to evade their duties, saying that they are denying their children their right to the best start in life.

The Treasury is still finalising the details of the Budget, which is expected to pave the way for an election in early May.

But Mr Brown has already decided against a 1p cut in income tax - the measure traditionally favoured by Conservative chancellors in the run-up to polling day - in favour of a targeted approach.

Sources have indicated that a headline-grabbing reduction in income tax would use up almost all the money that Mr Brown has set aside for tax cuts, and would not be an effective way of helping the less well-off.

Although many City analysts believe that the strength of the government's finances will result in a budget surplus of £15bn this year, Mr Brown is concerned by the signs of weakness in the global economy. Money has already been earmarked for pensioners and motorists, and the chancellor is determined that the Budget should not provide an excuse for the Bank of England to raise interest rates. "We don't want to take risks with economic stability," one source said. "We aren't looking at massive giveaways."

Within his self-imposed constraints, the chancellor will argue today that priority should go to families. Under Labour, the number of children living below the poverty line has fallen from 4m to 3m, but Mr Brown believes that further fiscal action is needed to shave a further 1m off the total in the next parliament.

The prime minister is said to be in full agreement with the budget strategy, which marks a determined attempt by Labour to appeal to its core vote while at the same time safeguarding its reputation for economic prudence. Government strategists believe that the Conservative strategy of offering £8bn of tax cuts has backfired, with voters sceptical about whether the opposition's figures add up.

Instead, they will counter critics who say that Labour has not done enough for its heartlands by pointing out that every family with children gets a minimum of £15.50 a week through child benefit and that the working families tax credit can be worth an extra £50 a week for those on low incomes.

In the Budget, Mr Brown will be relying on the increased generosity of the children's tax credit and the extra help for parents with young children to appeal to voters in middle England. The CTC will be worth £10 a week for many families, but will be tapered away for the better-off. However, under the proposals in the Budget, it will only be when families earn more than £41,500 year that they will receive nothing.

The new tax credit to help families with very young children has been under consideration for several months. Mr Brown has rejected calls for a tax break payable for the first three years of a child's life on the grounds of cost, but is determined to press ahead with a more limited scheme for children in their first year, when households see their finances suffer from an in crease in expenditure and a reduction in income.

Over the next month, officials will decide whether the extra cash will be delivered universally through child benefit, or added to the CTC or WFTC. The weekly sums involved have yet to be decided. While most of the focus in the Budget will be on working families, parents who are not working will not lose out.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, will today set out Tory plans to abolish tax on pensioners' savings as the first stage of its £8bn package of wider tax cuts due to be outlined. Mr Portillo yesterday claimed the reform would encourage savings.

fields.headline: Labour must woo women voters
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
New Labour in power
fields.trailText: It was women "wot won it" last time. But, unless the government tries harder to woo them, they are in danger of deserting at the next election, research published today reveals.
fields.body:
It was women "wot won it" last time. But, unless the government tries harder to woo them, they are in danger of deserting at the next election, research published today reveals.

Female voters, more fickle in the polling booths, are significantly less enamoured with New Labour than their menfolk, according to the report by the women's campaigning group, the Fawcett Society.

This "dissatisfaction gap" - the difference between the numbers of men and women happy with the government - appears to be growing. While there was no difference last June, by the end of the year a nine point gap had emerged - with 31% of women claiming to be satisfied with the way the country is run, compared with 40% of men.

The analysis, which also reveals that women are slower to forgive mistakes such as the pension fiasco and fuel crisis, will chime with the government's deepest anxieties.

Last week, the women's minister, Lady Jay, warned a pre-election cabinet meeting that the government had to try and retain younger women voters.

The Fawcett report - Where is Worcester Woman? Women's Political Priorities and Voting Intentions 2001 - backs this up, stressing that younger women are the least likely to be able to pinpoint whether they are satisfied with the government - a sentiment suggesting deep apathy, the government's greatest fear, and a sense of alienation from politics and politicians.

Older women, in particular Worcester Woman, the mythical Middle England floating voter who swung the last election, are also a cause for concern - traditionally the group most likely to vote Tory, women voters aged 55 and over are also the most likely to express dissatisfaction with the government, with 62% unhappy with the way in which the country is run.

The research, drawn from recent Mori polls and discussions with three focus groups, suggests Labour should seek to woo the crucial female electorate with policies to help balance working lives and caring responsibilities after it found 89% of women prioritise childcare, 79% the right to work part-time, and 79% paid parental leave.

Such issues were touched upon at last week's pre-election meeting, and the government line suggests a rise in paid maternity leave to £100 from £60.20. "No party can afford to take women's votes for granted," said Mary-Ann Stephenson of the Fawcett Society. "To regain women's trust, parties need to bring forward policies that will make a real difference in women's lives."

webTitle: Cambridge may look into its own Hinduja donations

fields.headline: Cambridge may look into its own Hinduja donations
fields.trailText: Cambridge University has hinted it might have to hold an inquiry into multi-million pound donations it received from the Hinduja brothers at the centre of the passports affair that led to the fall of Peter Mandelson.
fields.body:
Cambridge University has hinted it might have to hold an inquiry into multi-million pound donations it received from the Hinduja brothers at the centre of the passports affair that led to the fall of Peter Mandelson.

Gillian Evans, a theology lecturer, has called for an inquiry and said the university would have to return the money if the brothers, who face charges of bribery over an arms deal involving the Indian government, were to be convicted.

Her call was initially dismissed by the university but a later statement said: "Whilst we are not currently planning any enquiry into the Hinduja FoundationÕs donations to Cambridge, the position could be reviewed if there is any significant change in the situation."

Ten years ago the Hinduja Cambridge Trust was set up with a £2m endowment and the Dharam Hinduja Institute of Indic Research was established in 1995 through a benefaction from the Hinduja Foundation worth £250,000. The donation was made in memory of Dharam Hinduja, the son of Srichand Hinduja, chairman of the foundation. In 1998 the brother put £100,000 towards the divinity facultyÕs new building which was opened by the Queen.

"Ethical issues surrounding the acceptance of benefactions are considered by the executive committee of the University Council.

A university spokeswoman said: "Ethical issues surrounding the acceptance of benefactions are considered by the executive committee of the university council."

"We need to ask some serious and searching questions about our involvement with these people," said Dr Evans, who has taken on the university authorities on several occasions, notably over its methods of appointing professors.

"We need to take a very hard look at whether we should take any more money from them. And, certainly, if they are convicted of offences as a result of the legal proceedings in India, we should give back the money they have donated."

She added: "Sometimes we are very naive. We are babes in arms. Our eyes tend to glaze over when we see the number of noughts on the end of the cheque.

"We have no system or policy on who we should take money from and who we shouldn't. And we need to develop a policy."

Ten years ago the Hinduja Cambridge Trust was set up with a £2m endowment and the Dharam Hinduja Institute of Indic Research was established in 1995 through a benefaction from the Hinduja Foundation worth £250,000. The donation was made in memory of Dharam Hinduja, the son of Srichand Hinduja, chairman of the foundation. In 1998 the brother put £100,000 towards the divinity facultyÕs new building which was opened by the Queen. "Ethical issues surrounding the acceptance of benefactions are considered by the executive committee of the University Council. A university spokeswoman said: "Ethical issues surrounding the acceptance of benefactions are considered by the executive committee of the university council." "We need to ask some serious and searching questions about our involvement with these people," said Dr Evans, who has taken on the university authorities on several occasions, notably over its methods of appointing professors. "We need to take a very hard look at whether we should take any more money from them. And, certainly, if they are convicted of offences as a result of the legal proceedings in India, we should give back the money they have donated." She added: "Sometimes we are very naive. We are babes in arms. Our eyes tend to glaze over when we see the number of noughts on the end of the cheque. "We have no system or policy on who we should take money from and who we shouldn't. And we need to develop a policy."

webTitle: Rich students should pay fees says academic head

fields.headline: Rich students should pay fees says academic head
fields.trailText: Rich students should pay top-up fees for degree courses, a university vice-chancellor has said.
fields.body:
Rich students should pay top-up fees for degree courses, a university vice-chancellor has said.

Sir Colin Campbell, vice-chancellor of Nottingham University, argued that people who can afford extra fees should pay them as they benefit from better paid jobs following their university education.

The comments, made during the BBC TV's On the Record programme yesterday afternoon, come only days after the education minister did not completely rule out the introduction of top-up fees after the next general election.

University heads are to produce proposals on fees and the future funding of universities next month. The education secretary, David Blunkett, has said there will be not extra fees while he remains in position. But most university heads think that extra fees are inevitable as the government is unwilling to commit more money to higher education institutions by raising taxes or diverting other public funds.

"People who can afford it should pay, up to a modest limit," Campbell said. "They are beneficiaries to the extent of four-hundred-thousand upwards in their life time, they can afford to pay, they should pay."

He added: "I think the hard question is for Baroness Blackstone and her colleagues because they will be asked the question increasingly - are you investing adequately to maintain the universities to be internationally competitive and to give first class education to the brightest of the young generation? Now the answer to that is no, so something will have to give, I think it will give after the election."

Also speaking on the programme, education minister, Tessa Blackstone, predicted that most university heads will not come out in favour of top-up fees when their report is published next month. "I think the majority of them are not in favour of top up fees, so I think that the advice that we will get from them will be consistent with the way we view things at present."

But the minister last week told MPs on the House of Commons education committee that she would talk again about the government's policy towards fees "when we get to the general election". Students currently pay a maximum of £1050 a year in fees.

webTitle: Cambridge college denies rejecting candidate over transplant and background

fields.headline: Cambridge college denies rejecting candidate over transplant and background
fields.standfirst: Special report: Oxbridge and elitism
fields.trailText: A Cambridge college today strongly rejected the accusation that it turned down a promising student because she had had a heart and lung transplant and was from a lone parent family.
fields.body:
A Cambridge college today strongly rejected the accusation that it turned down a promising student because she had had a heart and lung transplant and was from a lone parent family.

Julie Kent phoned Emmanuel College to ask why her daughter, Vikki, had been turned down for a place to study English. She said the admissions tutor, Dr David Jarvis told her that her daughter's transplant had disrupted her education and that the college was worried that she might not be able to pay tuition fees because she was from a single parent family.

The college, which for the past two years has received more applications than any other in the university, said it sympathised with Vikki Kent in her disappointment but insisted it did not discriminate in favour of or against any type of candidate.

"We are convinced, however, that she has completely misunderstood the conversation she had with Dr Jarvis, as the position she outlines is entirely contrary to the philosophy that Emmanuel College applies to admissions."

Students at the college also sprang to the defence of Dr Jarvis. College student union president, Scott Allsop, said he was from a low income, single parent family and received financial help from the college. Dr Jarvis had been his director studies and shown "enormous compassion" in dealing with his family difficulties.

But Julie Kent, of Threntham, Staffordshire, responded robustly. "I am perfectly capable of understanding a telephone conversation. I spent half an hour talking to Dr Jarvis on the telephone and was well aware of what I was being told."

Vikki, who has now been offered a place at Bristol University to study English and philosophy, said: "What is really upsetting isn't the rejection, it is the reasons they gave. There is obviously some stiff competition and if it had been on some academic ground I would have understood.

"But to say that I am not good enough because my mum has raised me on my own and because I once had a transplant operation is unbelievable."

Predicted to get top grades at A level at St JosephÕs College, Stoke-on-Trent, Vikki was born with a congenital heart defect and underwent eight operations before having a heart and lung transplant carried out by Sir Magdi Yacoub at Harefield Hospital, London, in 1990.

The row, with its echoes of the Laura Spence case that exposed Oxford to accusations of elitism and unfairness, precipitated an emergency meeting at Emmanuel yesterday and a long statement. The accusation is galling for the college which prides itself in making efforts to widen its field of applicants, particularly through the Sutton Trust summer schools for inner city pupils, one of which it hosts.

The college said it welcomed students with disabilities. "If Emmanuel College is advised of any medical condition (ranging from congenital or chronic conditions to being ill on the day of an examination) that should be taken into account because it might affect a candidateÕs performance during the admissions procedure, this information is always taken into account and it can only act to the candidateÕs advantage."

The college said it was "acutely aware" of the financial pressures on students and did all that it could to make sure that no candidates were discouraged from applying because of their financial circumstances. It provided hardship grants to students.

fields.headline: Reorganisation to create 'University of Lincoln'
fields.trailText: The University of Lincolnshire and Humberside is to reorganise its main campuses and rename itself the University of Lincoln, following the conclusions of a strategic review. The university is also planning closer links with the University of Hull.
fields.body:
The University of Lincolnshire and Humberside is to reorganise its main campuses and rename itself the University of Lincoln, following the conclusions of a strategic review. The university is also planning closer links with the University of Hull.

During the past six years the recruitment of full time undergraduates at the university has fallen by 30%, from 9,840 in 1995-96 to an expected 6,614 in 2000-01.

In response ULH is selling off its Cottingham Road Hull campus to the University of Hull. The largest falls in admissions have been in business, engineering and applied social sciences, all of which are taught at Cottingham Road.

Some courses - including computing, business and social work - meanwhile will be transferred to the ULH Hull city centre campus as part of a planned expansion from 900 to 1500 students. The university also hopes to expand its Lincoln based campus to teach 5000 students.

According to a report to the university's governors by the vice-chancellor, Professor David Chiddick, this reorganisation was "academically and financially the most favourable option" to the university. Another option being considered was moving all facilities to Lincoln.

Research for the review had demonstrated that names which identify with a particular city location have the most appeal for students. The university will now make an application to the Privy Council for a change of name - expected to take about four months.

"The emerging partnership between this university and the University of Hull will be the first such collaboration in the UK," a statement from ULH said.

fields.headline: Tameside council's PSA submission summary
fields.standfirst: Increasing access to information technology training and allowing more older people to live independently are among the council's priorities
fields.trailText: Main targets agreed with government
fields.body:
Main targets agreed with government

 Making all our services available electronically
 Creating a fivefold increase in the number of local people getting information and communication technology training
 Improving the quality of all Tameside's social housing beyond national targets and creating a single joint register for all social landlords, making social housing easier and quicker to access
 Improving pupil achievement across Tameside and focusing on those groups that have traditionally underachieved - a 10% improvement in English and maths for 11 years from Bangladeshi or Pakistani origin
 Halving truancy levels in secondary schools
 Doubling the number of older people receiving intensive home care so they can live independently in their own homes
 Making sure more older people receive their minimum income guarantee entitlement - up to 85% by 2004
 A 20% reduction the number of people killed and seriously injured on our roads - halving in next seven years
 Increasing our cost effectiveness by over 2% per annum

Vision
1. Addressing a community plan priority and therefore an issue important to local people
Addressing local needs has been our starting point in choosing the proposed PSA outcomes. Each of the proposed PSA outcomes has been drawn from the key community priorities identified in the Tameside community plan.

The plan was produced jointly by 19 key public bodies, voluntary organisations and businesses who have worked together, under a new local strategic partnership - the Tameside community forum - to develop the plan and to commit to a shared set of priorities and actions.

The development of the community plan has been a major exercise for the council and its partners. The community plan was published in April 2000. It is based on what local people have said they want to see for Tameside over the next few years. Its publication followed an extensive programme of consultation with local residents, businesses and other stakeholders.

2. Addressing national priorities
We have examined how our outcomes will feed into the achievement of a wider national agenda such as the national strategy for neighbourhood renewal, the social service national priorities guidance (which underpins the PSA between the Department of Health and the Treasury), national best value performance measures, Department for Education and Employment targets etc.

3. Improving the outcomes for those in the Tameside community most at risk of social exclusion
Making sure social inclusion is mainstream to the thinking and activity of the Council and its partners is critical. The council's analysis suggests that achievement on inclusion priorities will make a measurable impact on local people's lives and has been a key factor for consideration in the choice of local PSA outcomes.

4. Offers the potential of substantial efficiency gains through developing innovative forms of service delivery
Outcomes have also been chosen on the basis of the level of potential gains possible by breaking down inhibitors and looking radically at new ways of service delivery. Tameside Council has a long track record of realising such gains.

 We have an innovative approach to performance management that has delivered substantial service improvements in services right across the organisation. It is based upon the achievement of continual improvement through the practical application of a series of tools and techniques. We have actually delivered higher quality services while reducing unit costs. For example, within our housing benefit service we have reduced waiting times by 75% and increased the percentage of new claims dealt within 14 days from 60% to 100% while reducing unit costs.

 We have a mature approach to the procurement of services based around the 'what matters is what works' principle. We were one of the first councils to externalise our elderly persons' homes. We have been proactive in developing (award winning) joint health and social care services and we want to do more through the local PSA pilot. Last year we transferred the whole of the council's housing stock as part of a wider strategy that is going to deliver substantial improvements to the choice and quality of social housing in Tameside.

 As an organisation we are committed to learning. For example, as well as having achieved beacon status for our joint mental health service, we have also been awarded beacon council status this year for our work around community safety and in two areas (quality environment, access to services) for next year's scheme.

 We were praised by the IDeA for our track record in innovation and willingness to embrace change and for our work in developing joint working to deliver real community benefits.

We want to build on the successes already achieved through the development of a Local PSA. We believe removing the inhibitors to new forms of service delivery can realise substantial gains. For the pilot we want to:

 Use the electronic delivery of services to join public services together. Our baseline work has already been seen and praised by two government ministers (Ian McCartney and Margaret Beckett).
 Promote independent living for older people and reduce the dependence on residential and nursing care by bringing health and social services together (along with the achievement of other key outcomes such as benefit take up)
 Develop new higher quality social housing through new forms of delivery and more choice through new joint working across all the social housing providers.
 Address key determinants of social exclusion in the borough, by working with our local schools to implement new approaches to tackling school absence and underachievement.
 Deliver real reductions in traffic accidents through the development of innovative, collaborative and cost-effective approaches to local road design and management.

What flexibilities have ministers given?

Key flexibilities include:
 Working with government to develop new electronic ways of data sharing
 Potentially becoming a national pilot help to drive forward the early delivery of electronic public services
 Discussion on removing benefit barriers that act against older people living independently
 More joined up working between the Benefits Agency and the council to make sure older people are receiving benefit entitlement
 Long term budget planning for education grants
 Use of speeding fines to help reduce traffic accidents
 A commitment to more joint working between the Highways Agency, local police and council in tackling road safety.

What will the £1m pump-priming money be used for?

Key features include:
 Development of ICT training centres
 Development of new IT systems across the key social landlords and other partners
 Provision of a new one stop shop for all social housing tenants
 More occupational therapy equipment and intensive care packages for people aged over 65
 New electronic registration systems for schools with high truancy levels
 New speed reduction schemes at accident black spots
 More training for classroom assistants in schools with a high proportion of Pakistani and Bangladeshi heritage children
 New GNVQ accredited out of hours learning ICT scheme and the development of out of school clubs in local community buildings

Performance reward grant
If we achieve all our targets, we would receive £5.2m in performance reward grant

webTitle: Analysis: will city academies fare better than education zones?

fields.headline: The learning zone
fields.standfirst: Education action zones failed to attract sufficient business sponsorship. But are the new city academies likely to fare any better?
fields.trailText: Education action zones failed to attract sufficient business sponsorship. But are the new city academies likely to fare any better?
fields.body:
Although the new chief inspector of schools, Mike Tomlinson, criticised "unacceptably wide variation in quality" among councils in his report last week, he thought it good that they existed. But there will be no return to the old days for local education authorities (LEAs). Estelle Morris, the schools standards minister, has made that clear. In fact, LEAs will continue to get smaller.

Some 18 LEAs deemed to be failing have, or soon will have, their work given to contractors. Ms Morris is even looking at ways of contracting out the services provided by successful councils, spending £1.5m on pilot projects.

Yet as Labour looks beyond traditional education administration, one of its own experiments with private enterprise has come under scrutiny. Two recent reports - one from the national audit office and one from the Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) - confirm that education action zones have not delivered on the promises made when they were launched in 1998.

The zone idea began with promises of an annual sum of £750,000 of taxpayers' money for each zone. People were to come together in a "local action forum" to plan to improve standards in poor-performing schools. The forums linked schools, parents, councils and business. The latter were to play a major part and provide £250,000 a year in funding.

The forums would innovate, take over school governing bodies (if schools let them), pay extra money to teachers and substitute parts of the national curriculum. Zones represented "a fundamental challenge to the status quo, a real threat to those vested interests that have for too long held back our school system," said the then schools minister, Stephen Byers.

Since September 1999, 73 "large" zones have been set up. Results for 11-year-olds in these zones have improved by more than the national average and rates of truancy have gone down. Dalton Fojambe in Rotherham and Cleeve primary in Hull have topped government league tables for most improved test scores. In Newham in east London, in east Manchester, Wolverhampton and elsewhere, their achievements have been hailed. Even National Union of Teachers activists have found themselves welcoming zones.

But zones have broken no moulds. They now play definite second fiddle to the newer and much larger Excellence in Cities initiative, which operates through traditional channels: Whitehall to local authority to school.

Private money is being encouraged into new individual city academies, rather than zones. The Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) has been relying more and more on that hardy annual, the council, and trying to get out of the habit of overestimating the altruism of British business. Up to 100 new zones are being created, but they are "mini-education action zones", based on a single secondary school and its feeder primaries. There will be no new big zones. Mini-action zones receive £250,000 a year for three years plus matched funding for sponsorship up to £50,000.

Meanwhile new "excellence clusters" are being piloted with £4m in government grants for seven areas. These are roughly the same size as zones without the paraphernalia; and business sponsorship is not a requirement.

The national audit office report showed that zones attracted barely half the government's target figure for business sponsorship: £1,296,000 rather than £2,562,000. Of the money raised, nearly a third - £400,000 - was delivered to a single authority, Newham, and only three zones met their projected amount. In its first seven months, the Leicester zone raised only £3,000; Aston and Nechells, east Brighton and Halifax nothing at all.

Rob Watling and Joe Hallgarten of the IPPR say that because the bids relied on being able to show potential for attracting local business, many of the poorest areas did not bother to apply in the first place. They also suggest that existing education business partnerships already tapped a lot of private money. No business can be described as leading a zone, they say: many of the businesses listed as zone partners have "minimal or no participation".

Accounts showing business contributions often include donations from the voluntary and public sectors, and benefits in kind have been much more popular than cash. The Halifax zone has since been given £500,000 by Halifax Bank to cover its three years of sponsorship targets. Overall, however, most zones are still short of their targets. Watling and Hallgarten say regulation - from the DfEE and from Ofsted - put off bidders and prohibited innovation.

Ministers believe that zones established the essential principle of getting secondary and primary schools to work together. They think they are a success story. But ministers also accept that trawling for sponsorship created problems, and argue that many local communities lacked confidence. Within the zones, even their most vocal supporters believe that they were invited to do too much, too quickly.

Despite their experience with the zones, ministers are pressing ahead with city academies and finding similar problems attracting sponsorship. After the Tories' struggle to win money for their city technology colleges, the DfEE might have felt it was time to be less starry-eyed about its ability to attract time and money from business.

 Will Woodward is the Guardian's education editor.
