Zones represented "a fundamental challenge to the status quo, a real threat to those vested interests that have for too long held back our school system," said the then schools minister, Stephen Byers. Since September 1999, 73 "large" zones have been set up. Results for 11-year-olds in these zones have improved by more than the national average and rates of truancy have gone down. Dalton Fojambe in Rotherham and Cleeve primary in Hull have topped government league tables for most improved test scores. In Newham in east London, in east Manchester, Wolverhampton and elsewhere, their achievements have been hailed. Even National Union of Teachers activists have found themselves welcoming zones. But zones have broken no moulds. They now play definite second fiddle to the newer and much larger Excellence in Cities initiative, which operates through traditional channels: Whitehall to local authority to school. Private money is being encouraged into new individual city academies, rather than zones. The Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) has been relying more and more on that hardy annual, the council, and trying to get out of the habit of overestimating the altruism of British business. Up to 100 new zones are being created, but they are "mini-education action zones", based on a single secondary school and its feeder primaries. There will be no new big zones. Mini-action zones receive £250,000 a year for three years plus matched funding for sponsorship up to £50,000. Meanwhile new "excellence clusters" are being piloted with £4m in government grants for seven areas. These are roughly the same size as zones without the paraphernalia; and business sponsorship is not a requirement. The national audit office report showed that zones attracted barely half the government's target figure for business sponsorship: £1,296,000 rather than £2,562,000. Of the money raised, nearly a third - £400,000 - was delivered to a single authority, Newham, and only three zones met their projected amount. In its first seven months, the Leicester zone raised only £3,000; Aston and Nechells, east Brighton and Halifax nothing at all. Rob Watling and Joe Hallgarten of the IPPR say that because the bids relied on being able to show potential for attracting local business, many of the poorest areas did not bother to apply in the first place. They also suggest that existing education business partnerships already tapped a lot of private money. No business can be described as leading a zone, they say: many of the businesses listed as zone partners have "minimal or no participation". Accounts showing business contributions often include donations from the voluntary and public sectors, and benefits in kind have been much more popular than cash. The Halifax zone has since been given £500,000 by Halifax Bank to cover its three years of sponsorship targets. Overall, however, most zones are still short of their targets. Watling and Hallgarten say regulation - from the DfEE and from Ofsted - put off bidders and prohibited innovation. Ministers believe that zones established the essential principle of getting secondary and primary schools to work together. They think they are a success story. But ministers also accept that trawling for sponsorship created problems, and argue that many local communities lacked confidence. Within the zones, even their most vocal supporters believe that they were invited to do too much, too quickly. Despite their experience with the zones, ministers are pressing ahead with city academies and finding similar problems attracting sponsorship. After the Tories' struggle to win money for their city technology colleges, the DfEE might have felt it was time to be less starry-eyed about its ability to attract time and money from business.  Will Woodward is the Guardian's education editor. will.woodward@theguardian.com

webTitle: Comment: Labour dishonest about education policies

fields.headline: Selection is creeping in by stealth
fields.standfirst:
Labour isn't being honest about its education policies

Education Unlimited
New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour isn't being honest about its education policies.
fields.body:
Snow fell through the fog in Sheffield last Thursday night - a combination which was as unpleasant as it was unusual. But 300 damp men and women spent a couple of hours in the City Memorial Hall talking about the future of education in south Yorkshire. Perhaps "complaining" would be a better description of their conduct. The complaints were justified.

Meetings to discuss education are usually dominated by teachers. When two or three of them gather together, a union representative always expresses their legitimate grievances in language which, any sensible person would realise, will antagonise public opinion and reduce the possibility of justice being done.

If Chris Woodhead had infiltrated the NUT with secret Ofsted agents and told them to discredit the profession, they would not have behaved very differently from some militant teachers. Last Thursday I heard the call "to take our battle on to the streets" for the first time in years. Common sense, not to mention inclement weather, kept us in the hall.

I had ventured out to argue that the campaign for comprehensive education must go on - even though Sheffield, like most education authorities, has long abandoned formal secondary selection. I proposed to suggest that, even in that enlightened city, the hierarchy of schools which exists in parents' minds means that there is a subtle, but still damaging, educational apartheid. Before the meeting began, I was handed a document which made such sophisticated arguments no more than an aside. It was a paper prepared for the Sheffield city council "cabinet" by the executive director of education. It concerned "proposals to enter into negotiations with potential sponsors" of a city academy.

The paper set out two key advantages of the new foundation. It would receive "capital investment which would not otherwise be available" - a genuine bonus since the scheme will require the private "sponsor" to provide £2m. The second "benefit" was intangible to the point of vacuity - "the opportunity to demonstrate the council's commitment to embracing change and innovation". Change for change's sake was a feature of New Labour during its political adolescence. It seems that the Sheffield Liberals are attracted by the same juvenile nonsense.

It also appears - since the paper was approved for submission to the cabinet by the "member responsible for education" - that Sheffield Liberals are prepared to accept the features of the academy which it is anticipated will be particularly attractive to a private sponsor. Like other "specialist schools", the academy will be allowed to admit 10% of pupils "on the basis of aptitude". Read my lips. Creeping selection, introduced by stealth, is now government policy.

Unfortunately, I am unable to report how many of the new "specialist schools" have chosen to admit 10% of their pupils on that basis since Labour was elected in 1997. For, incredibly, that statistic is not available, according to the extremely obliging press officer at the DfEE. By incredibly I do not mean to suggest that he was lying but that, five years ago, none of us would have believed that Labour education ministers would need to cover their tracks in such a disreputable way.

I have begun to accept double talk as part of Labour's education policy, but the stupidity still astounds me. The failure to keep the comprehensive promise is an element of what, three years ago, seemed to be a calculated decision to alienate teachers. Now there is a half-hearted attempt to prove that the government is on their side. But the antagonism still shines through. David Blunkett, losing his temper on the radio last Friday, described the "failure" to give disadvantaged children a decent start in life as a "disgrace". Teachers say the same, but they blame him. Blaming them fools nobody.

The government will never be able to pay teachers what they certainly want and probably deserve - though it could do better than 3.7%. But it should try to make up the cash deficit by improving morale and showing respect and gratitude. Instead, for three years, it chose criticism which came near to abuse and the imposition of rules which no self-respecting profession would accept. The change of attitude, if not of heart, has come too late. It will take more than Tony Blair's sudden assertion that they are "the best in the world" to make teachers feel that the government is on their side.

The refusal to keep its promises on comprehensive education is - like the early attacks on teachers, the imposition of tests, the tables and all the other bureaucratic obligations - an attempt to convince middle England that Labour no longer holds with any of that equality nonsense. I hope it works. Labour is going to need those middle-class votes if - thanks to its denigration of teachers - staff shortages are so severe that schools are closed all over England before the election.

webTitle: A new relationship between central and local government

fields.headline: A new relationship between central and local government
fields.standfirst: New public service agreements give councils an unprecedented degree of flexibility, says Local Government Association policy officer Tony Blake
fields.trailText: New public service agreements give councils an unprecedented degree of flexibility, says Local Government Association policy officer Tony Blake
fields.body:
The signing of local public service agreements (PSAs) by six pilot local authorities today is not just good news for those councils' residents. It is good news for all councils who want to enter into a new kind of relationship with central government to deliver better outcomes for local people.

The six local PSAs signed by Blackburn, Kent, Middlesbrough, Stockton on Tees, Tameside, Warwickshire and government ministers begin to deliver on one of the Local Government Association's (LGA) key priorities - our belief that local authorities can do their job better if they have more freedom and flexibility to act.

Greater local discretion was the LGA's starting point when we sat down with the Treasury to design local PSAs. Several government projects in recent years have invited local authorities to suggest areas where they need greater freedom and flexibility to tailor their actions to suit local needs - so that concept is not new.

But translating this general invitation into concrete action has been difficult, and neither the government nor local authority partners would claim that tangible gains had been made.

Local PSAs are, by contrast, emerging as an effective, and potentially highly effective, route for councils to win more freedom to get on with delivering services with reduced interference from central government.

They are different because agreeing with ministers what flexibility can be given is part of the deal. In order to improve school results, for instance, the local PSA authority will want greater flexibility to construct the right local education policy. For the pilots, this involves greater freedom and certainty of funding in the council's share of the school standards fund. For some of the pilots, there is also a commitment to work with the Department for Education and Employment to streamline the number of education plans required from a council.

Some authorities have promised to increase rates of recycling. Warwickshire has agreed with the government to borrow an extra £2.5m to support new recycling initiatives. Local PSA pilots have also been allowed to test out the concept of unsupported credit approvals - councils borrowing above their allocated credit approvals, providing they are willing to meet the cost of those loans from within their own budget.

On youth justice, Sunderland hopes to agree flexibility in the way it uses youth justice funding. The council will now be able to bring more coherence to young offender support initatives. Complex rules have made this difficult in the past.

The government has made clear that flexibility will not always be available as a ready package for the start of the three-year life of a PSA. But the agreements are allowing councils and the government to recognise problems and to commit to working together - as part of the deal - to find solutions. In Kent, this sort of commitment may help alleviate problems of differing VAT regimes for local and health authorities, which are currently inhibiting the take up of powers to pool their budgets. In Middlesbrough, it may help to simplify and speed up the payment of disabled facilities grants for home adaptations for older people.

As the first local PSAs are agreed, much will be made of the financial rewards that they offer to councils. The government is negotiating tough targets with authorities in areas such as social care, education, transport and recycling, because an authority that meets its targets for stretched achievement - over and above its best value performance plan - will be rewarded financially. Performance reward grant - a payment potentially amounting to 2.5% of an authority's budget - will be available in proportion to the amount of extra achievement.

The financial rewards are substantial for the authorities involved. But from the national point of view, we must recognise that a key benefit of local PSAs is that they offer a way to open doors, and create movement on previously intractable issues. If future local PSAs can build on what has been achieved today, we have a powerful tool for innovation, improved performance, and a more creative relationship between central and local government.

 Tony Blake was involved in the local public service agreements negotiations with central government

webTitle: 'How we will deliver our local pledges'

fields.headline: 'How we will deliver our local pledges'
fields.standfirst: Councillor Gail Barton, executive member for resources for Blackburn with Darwen borough council, explains how the PSA will improve the quality of life for local people
fields.trailText: Councillor Gail Barton, executive member for resources for Blackburn with Darwen borough council, explains how the PSA will improve the quality of life for local people.
fields.body:
Today we are signing a major contract with the government. The local public service agreement (PSA), invented by the Local Government Association and the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, is the first of its kind in the country.

We are one of only six councils selected to sign up first from a group of 20 national pilots.

At Blackburn and Darwen, we will be committing ourselves to stretching our already challenging best value performance targets even further. In return, the government will provide £1m in "pump-priming" funds to each council to help us "invest to save" - putting in funding today to make savings and increase performance in the longer term.

If we achieve our "stretched" performance, we will be paid over £4m over the next three years as a "performance reward grant".

As well as the extra cash, the PSA brings benefits such as preferential access to private finance initiative resources and access to extra credit approvals.

So what exactly are we committing ourselves to as a council over the next three years?

 Getting electoral turn-out up by 5%
 Delivering our overall cost effectiveness at an extra 0.25%
 Improving customer satisfaction by an additional 5%
 Increasing the numbers of children achieving level 5 at key stage 3 by up to 6%
 Enabling 5,000 local people to access school resources for learning
 Reducing the number of those killed or seriously injured in road accidents by 25%
 Recycling an additional 5% of household waste
 Cutting the youth offending rate by an additional 3%
 Becoming the first unitary authority with a library open 60 hours per week
 Providing 2% more intensive support at home for older people.  Helping an additional 200 unemployed people secure a job
 Reducing the rate of teenage conceptions by an extra 5%
 Setting up a community car scheme in an isolated rural area

As executive member for resources, it will be my responsibility to ensure we hit these targets. I want to use this pilot year of the PSA, working with political colleagues and employees at every level, to strengthen our performance management culture. Experience has taught me that managing performance and delivering continual improvement is as much about how motivated staff feel on a Monday morning as it is about monitoring performance indicators.

It looks likely that next year the PSA will be rolled out nationally and we are working with the Office of Public Management to ensure lessons are learned from the pilot year.

We called our initial submission to the LGA Delivering Local Pledges and we must not forget that is what the PSA is all about. We are committed to using this opportunity to strengthen us as an organisation and partner, but more importantly to increase the quality of life and the standards of services within local communities in Blackburn and Darwen.

webTitle: Councils push ahead with PSA plans

fields.headline: Councils push ahead with PSA plans
fields.trailText: Councils today have won new powers to slash red tape, cut back on government inspections, and work with police and health professionals to fight crime and drugs. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
Councils today have won new powers to slash red tape, cut back on government inspections, and work with police and health professionals to fight crime and drugs.

The new freedoms are part of the pilot round of local public service agreements (PSAs), contracts signed by ministers and councils, in which authorities gain new powers by committing themselves to tough performance targets in key services such as education and social care.

The six councils that signed up today are Blackburn with Darwen, Kent, Middlesbrough, Stockton-on-Tees, Tameside and Warwickshire. They will each receive a grant of up to £1m to help lay the groundwork for their service improvements. If they meet the targets, they will also be eligible for a performance reward grant, which could be worth around £25m for larger authorities.

The agreements are the result of months of negotiation between ministers, councils and the Local Government Association (LGA). Policy officer Tony Blake said: "We don't expect to change the world tomorrow, but local PSAs are an effective mechanism that really should prove their worth over the next few years."

Kent chief executive Mike Pitt added: "We had to convince the Treasury that there will be real benefits and that we can deliver."

Local PSAs were first announced by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in last summer's comprehensive spending review. They are based on the public service agreements central government departments sign with the Treasury in return for funding increases.

The agreements will be piloted by 20 authorities this year, and ministers hope that they will eventually be rolled out to cover all the country's councils.

While many in local government have welcomed the agreements, they have been attacked by the Local Government Information Unit as a means for the chancellor to impose central priorities on local authorities.

webTitle: Kids' charity calls for boycott of girls' magazine

fields.headline: Kids' charity calls for boycott of girls' magazine
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: A leading children's charity has called on newsagents to boycott new magazine Mad About Boys, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A leading children's charity has called on newsagents and retailers to boycott a new magazine called Mad About Boys, claiming it could encourage paedophiles.

Kidscape, whose patrons include Katie Boyle and Phil Collins, said today that they believed Mad About Boys, which was launched last week, drove a horse and cart" through legislation designed to protect children.

Director Michele Elliott said: "I would encourage WH Smith and other newsagents not to carry this magazine".

"This is encouraging children to be sexual, to worry about their bodies and to have themselves made up and ready for boys considerably older than them," she said.

The magazine, which is targeted at girls between the ages of 10 and 12, features pin-up boys as old as 17 and offers tips on hair and beauty.

Elliott objected to girls of that age being encouraged to think of themselves as "sexy".

But Richard Maskell, a spokesman for publishing company Planet 3, denied that the magazine had a sexual theme.

"We're not giving advice about how to deal with sex," he said.

"We're teaching them how to put on make-up and style their hair but we're not encouraging them to do anything that they're uncomfortable with."

fields.headline: New-look Popstars fly in
fields.trailText:
The media got the first glimpse of the new image created for the lucky five chosen to form the Popstars band at the Sheraton Heathrow hotel this lunchtime.
Feb 5: Popstars double cheers ITV
fields.body:
The media got its first glimpse of the new image created for the lucky five chosen to form the Popstars band at the Sheraton Heathrow hotel this lunchtime.

The five - (from left to right) Kym Marsh, Danny Foster, Myleene Klass, Noel Sullivan and Suzanne Shaw - were flown in from Norway, where they have been in the studio working on their first single and an album.

All five have had a makeover since the Popstars auditions footage shot last year and broadcast on ITV over the past month.

The five have also been given a makeover to help boost their image with the public.

Suzanne, the youngest at 19 years, has been given blonde extensions while Kym is sporting a red streak.

Changes to the appearances of the other three are less dramatic but they have achieved some sort of unity with their green combat clothing.

webTitle: Fresh bid to try and halt tube chaos

fields.headline: Fresh bid to try and halt tube chaos
fields.standfirst: Special report: Transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Talks are to be held in an attempt to avoid a repeat of today's strike by London Underground drivers which crippled services and caused fights among frustrated commuters waiting for buses.
fields.body:
Talks are to be held in an attempt to avoid a repeat of today's strike by London Underground drivers which crippled services and caused fights among frustrated commuters waiting for buses.

The huge disruption led to overcrowding on bus and rail services and police were called to several scuffles in queues as people desperately tried to get to work.

Just 10% of tube trains ran, although there were no services on several lines in the morning rush hour, leading to chaotic scenes across the capital.

Traffic was around 30% heavier than normal as commuters took to their cars, jamming roads into London throughout the day.

The train drivers' union Aslef said that there was solid support among its 2,200 members for the strike, which was called over safety fears about the proposed public-private partnership (PPP) to run the tube.

Aslef leaders will meet LU bosses at the conciliation service, Acas, tomorrow to try to head off two further strikes planned for the next two Mondays.

"I am pleased with the wonderful show of support and solidarity from our members, other workers and the travelling public," said Aslef general secretary Mick Rix.

"I hope that, in light of the strike, management will now start taking a more constructive approach to resolving the dispute."

The strike cost LU an estimated £3.6m in lost revenue and led to a miserable day for the three million travellers who normally use the tube each day.

"There's been a lot of crowding and queuing and there have been some scuffles, but nothing that's really required major police intervention," a City of London police spokesman said.

"People have been falling out with people who have failed to observe the queue system."

London mayor Ken Livingstone, who travelled to the capital by train after spending the weekend in Brighton said: "The situation is totally unreasonable.

"It has been provoked by London Underground managers who have been consistently unconvincing about safety on the tube to myself and the trade unions."

A convoy of about 250 taxi drivers added to the travel chaos by driving from Gatwick to Victoria in central London as part of a dispute with the British Airports Authority.

An AA Roadwatch spokesman said that the rush hour was "horrendous", with sections of the M25 brought to a virtual standstill.

Aslef members picketed depots and there were reports that other workers were refusing to cross picket lines.

A British Transport police spokesman said that the biggest picket lines were at Golders Green, Cockfosters and Baker Street.

He said picketing had been peaceful, but added that the transport situation was "disastrous".

"There's not many trains running at all. There's continuous overcrowding at main line stations."

The strike went ahead despite progress last week between the government and the capital's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, over the public-private partnership plans.

Steve Norris, Transport for London board member, described today's strike as a "cynical waste of time".

He said it had nothing to do with safety and a lot to do with job preservation.

City law firm Charles Russell warned that employees not turning up for work because of the strike could expect their pay to be docked or even face disciplinary action.

Employment lawyer Michael Bradshaw said: "Employees should be aware that, if they do not turn up for work today, citing the tube strikes as the reason, then they may find employers have a right to deduct a day's pay.

"In extreme circumstances, an employer could bring disciplinary action."

fields.headline: Exclusive, Expropriate, and Exclude
fields.trailText: ENIC FAIL TO NICK GLENN
fields.body:
ENIC FAIL TO NICK GLENN

As long-term subscribers will testify, your super soaraway Fiver is number one for exclusives! You heard it here first when Gareth Southgate signed for Southampton, and we left all our red-faced competitors standing with our Tony-Yeboah-to-big-London-club scoop. So you'll be excited to hear that, according to sources close to Tottenham owners ENIC, Glenn Hoddle will definitely NOT be taking over at White Hart Lane in the summer. Stick with us, this one sounds sort of plausible.

If you believe the latest rumours - and who the hell are you calling gullible? - Hoddle was approached by Spurs chief executive Daniel Levy to return to his old club as manager. The God-fearing Saint agreed, on the condition he was given £25m to spend on players who are not Andy Booth. Sadly, Tottenham don't have two brass bawbies to rub together, and Levy could only dangle £10m in front of Hoddle's unbelievably square-jawed face.

As a result, the Southampton boss told his suitors to take a walk (on water). Whether this will save the skin of Arsenal's George Graham - who, as current Spurs manager, would have been out on his ear if Hoddle had agreed to move - is another issue. But we're fairly confident that Hoddle won't be going to Spurs in the close season. How can you trust us? Well, what we've told you makes good sense, for a start. And haven't you heard the saying "third time lucky"?

BRAZIL NUTS

In England last week, David Beckham was spat at by foul-mouthed West Ham fans, who surrounded his car and chanted that familiar ditty about his wife. Everyone was rightly horrified, but at least Beckham knows the good citizens of Alderley Edge aren't armed to the teeth and planning to steal his beloved Ferrari 355. And that's something you can't say about some of the not-so-good citizens of Rio de Janeiro.

At 10pm last night, Brazilan superstar Ronaldo was driving towards his home in the fashionable Barra da Tijuca district of Rio when his BMW was blocked off by another car. Before you could say "long-term knee injury", three armed gunmen jumped out and surrounded the striker's pricey vehicle. "They pointed guns to my head and told me to get out," Ronaldo revealed. "I was calm, turned around and just prayed nothing would happen." Fortunately, nothing did. "They were aggressive, but one recognised me and they lowered their guns," he continued. "I sensed a reaction of shock and surprise, but it was too late. They weren't going to waste the trip."

After forcing Ronaldo to hand over his keys and wallet, the car-jackers then sped off, leaving him standing shocked - but unhurt - at the side of the road. But at least the story has a happy ending: the car, equipped with a satellite tracking system, was found undamaged an hour later in a residential neighbourhood. Only Ron's cash pouch was missing. What's more, despite the assault, Ronaldo says he has no plans to leave Brazil or hire a bodyguard. "I was born here. I don't want to leave now and I hope that the situation will get better," he insisted, as The Fiver wondered whether Becks would be so loyal if he were to suffer a similar misfortune on the Cheshire plains.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Diego still takes cocaine on an occasional basis. If we can keep his weakness under control and he continues to take drugs only in moderation he can go on to live until he is 70" - Diego Maradona's doctor, Alfred Cahe, gives his patient a warning. Still, every white cloud has a silver lining.

WALK ON BY

By nature, goalkeepers are not happy people. Manchester United keeper Fabien Barthez wears the pained expression of a small boy whose mates never allow him a kick of the ball. Liverpool's Sander Westerveld always looks as though he's about to punch your face in. And who hasn't seen Peter Shilton in Ladbrokes? But today, Tottenham's Ian Walker pushed out the boundaries of goalkeeping misery as the penny finally dropped that he is no longer the number one keeper at the Lane.

Speaking in the London Evening Standard a couple of days after losing his place when Neil Sullivan returned from suspension, the man who has been Spurs' number two all season announced: "I know now I have no future at the club at all and the sooner I get away the better!" After the worst of the tears and stamping had subsided, Walker lapsed into a mild sulk. "The manager has always gone on about competition for places between us," he continued as he tripped over his lower lip, "but by dropping me after all my hard work he is basically saying there is no competition."

"I don't know any other club in the Premiership where you keep two clean sheets and don't stay in the team," whined Walker. "It makes my position impossible!" Sure enough, the word "agent" was soon being bandied about, as if it were a threat his manager was going to take seriously. "If Ian wants to have a chat with me, then fine," growled Arsenal's George Graham, manager of Spurs. "Neil was absolutely outstanding before his suspension so it wasn't a hard decision." Hmm, it doesn't sound to us as though you've got him very worried, Ian. Do you want us to send Sander round to stare at him a bit?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Charlton, Manchester City and Bradford are all interested in Hearts captain Colin Cameron. The Scottish international midfielder is available for £2m.

Fulham are on the verge of making a bid for West Ham defender Ian Pearce.

NEWS IN BRIEF

George Best has been admitted to hospital with suspected pneumonia. Best's representative, Phil Hughes, claims he is "poorly" but his condition is "not life-threatening."

Chelsea defender John Terry has signed a new four-and-a-half-year contract. "I am delighted to pledge my future to Chelsea and hope to achieve a great deal of success with the club," he admitted.

Ipswich striker Marcus Stewart is to launch an appeal against his sending off on Saturday. "I will definitely appeal against the decision," he told the East Anglian Daily Times. "I barely touched the lad. He went about 50 feet up in the air and it looked as though someone much bigger than me had tackled him."

Liverpool midfielder Jamie Redknapp's Wirral home has been burgled. Jewellery, credit cards and cash were taken while he was out enjoying a meal with his wife Louise on Saturday evening. "It's not so much what has been taken as the fact that someone has rooted through our private belongings," said Redknapp. "It was a bit of a nightmare and has left us both pretty shaken."

Swansea City has been put up for sale by owners Ninth Floor plc. The company today issued its half-yearly financial report which showed pre-tax losses of £797,000. It is expected the club will go on sale valued at £3m.

Hibs captain Franck Sauzee has once again delayed his retirement to sign a new two-year deal with the Edinburgh club. The 35-year-old former French international had intended to hang his boots up at the end of last season but will now carry on playing until the summer of 2003.

Dunfermline's Scottish Cup third round replay against St Johnstone tomorrow has been postponed. The tie will now go ahead next Tuesday at 7.45pm.

The draw for the FA Umbro Trophy is as follows: Burton Albion v Yeovil Town, Weymouth v Southport, Evesham United or Morecambe v Hereford United or Leigh RMI, Canvey Island v Stevenage Borough, Histon or Billericay Town v Telford United, Tiverton Town v Worksop Town, Chester City v Blyth Spartans, Matlock Town or Forest Green Rovers v Rushden & Diamonds. (Ties to be played Saturday 24 February).

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (1am)

"Wotcher! I'm television chef Jamie Oliver. Don't mind me, I'm just using your TV and Radio section to film a well pukka advert where I wake up with a massive hangover."

Channel 5: Argentine Football (2.30am, 4am)

[glug, glug, drinks half a pint of weak lager, hic, wayhey, I'm wild, me]

Sky Sports 1: World Football Show (7.30pm, 12midnight)

[slips into deep sleep, finally wakes up, cor ain't I crazy, must have slept in me clothes]

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2.30am)

[ooh me head, I feel so rough, ere love, rustle us up a working-class salt-of-the-earth fried breakfast dripping in lard and no mistake]

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5pm, 6.30pm SS1, 11pm SS1)

[guffaw, I'll make it with these overpriced "health" products, he won't know the difference]

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm)

[grills fat-free bacon medallion, poaches egg, listens to pop single of extremely low quality]

British Eurosport: Eurogoals (10.15pm)

[stuffs everything into huge ciabatta to make something nobody suffering from a proper hangover would be able to stomach]

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm)

[ciabatta stuffed in mouth with cheeky wink, look at me in my West Hampstead pad, I keep it well real]

webTitle: In brief: Billy Elliot wins two Evening Standard Awards

fields.headline: Billy Elliot wins two Evening Standard Awards
fields.standfirst: Plus: Courtney Love keen to play Paula Yates; Steven Spielberg and Ron Howard get animated about dreamy films on the web
fields.trailText: Plus: Courtney Love keen to play Paula Yates; Steven Spielberg and Ron Howard get animated about dreamy films on the web
fields.body:
 Billy Elliot won two prizes at the Evening Standard Awards last night. Teenage actor Jamie Bell, who plays the lead role as an aspiring dancer in a northern mining town, took the Best Newcomer Award whilst Julie Walters, who plays his ballet teacher, was named Best Actress. Mike Leigh's comedy based on Gilbert and Sullivan's Mikado, Topsy-Turvy, also won two awards, for Best Film and Best Actor for its star Jim Broadbent.

 Rumours that Courtney Love will portray Paula Yates in a film about the tragic TV presenter's life (see earlier story) appear to have been confirmed by Love herself. The lead singer of Hole, who met Yates only days before she died, will write the script herself if she has to, according to Showbiz Ireland. Love believes that the chance meeting was a sign: "We exchanged numbers and made plans to hang out." She told the Irish Star newspaper: "I still can't believe she's dead. But I believe that I met her for a reason. And now I'll bring her true story to the world."

 Two new three-minute cartoons directed by Steven Spielberg and Ron Howard are available to view on the American film site Countingdown.com from today. The films, called Steven's Dreams and Ron's Dreams, star animated versions of the two directors who also narrate. Philip Nakov, co-founder of the site, says fans will get a different look at the directors. "In a film, the director is telling a story," says Nakov. "In this instance, they are telling a story that happened to them, which is a very personal look, and hopefully the fans will get to know the directors a little better."

fields.headline: Granada shows off Popstars
fields.trailText:
3pm update: Granada TV today showed off the five young pop hopefuls that have delivered it the biggest entertainment hit of the year. By Matt Wells.
Click here to see the first pictures

Feb 5: Popstars double cheers ITV
fields.body:
Granada Television today showed off the five young pop hopefuls that have delivered it the biggest entertainment hit of the year.

The five members of the manufactured band featured in the hit show Popstars faced a largely sympathetic media at a Heathrow Airport press conference.

Danny, Kim, Myleene, Noel and Suzanne demonstrated their unique selling point - they can actually sing, wowing the hacks with an impressive acapella rendition of Bridge Over Troubled Water.

They claimed not to fear being exploited by Granada Television and its record company partner, Polydor.

"We are all going to keep each other's feet on the ground. We all know where we have come from. There is massive mutual respect between the five of us," said Noel Sullivan, 20, from Cardiff.

LWT, the Granada subsidiary that is making the show for the ITV network, revealed that last Saturday's episode was the most-watched of the series so far, pulling in over 11m viewers.

In the band's first press conference, the five faced a grilling about their experiences so far and their hopes for the future.

Noel said they were relieved to be finally let out into the public arena. "We have been trapped in a Popstar's bubble since Christmas ... It is nice to finally get out," he said.

All five seemed comfortable with their new raunchier image, but Myleene insisted that it was not such a radical change.

"It's just a tweak - not really a make-over," she laughed.

During the auditions for Popstars the hopefuls were tested on their ability to deal with awkward questions from the media.

Today that training came into its own when they were asked the obvious question about whether any of them had ever tried drugs.

All five shook their heads solemnly and Kym said: "We do not do drugs and we do not think it is cool for anyone else to do drugs."

Myleene also faced an awkward question about pictures which have emerged from when she was involved in a webcast fly-on-the-wall documentary called the Doll's House.

Despite pictures in which she is seen in scantily clad poses, Myleene insisted she had no regrets.

"I do not regret taking part in it. It was a video diary that got blown out of all proportion. When I found out some of the things that were happening I just left," she explained.

In the band's first press conference, the five faced a grilling about their experiences so far and their hopes for the future. Noel said they were relieved to be finally let out into the public arena. "We have been trapped in a Popstar's bubble since Christmas ... It is nice to finally get out," he said. All five seemed comfortable with their new raunchier image, but Myleene insisted that it was not such a radical change. "It's just a tweak - not really a make-over," she laughed. During the auditions for Popstars the hopefuls were tested on their ability to deal with awkward questions from the media. Today that training came into its own when they were asked the obvious question about whether any of them had ever tried drugs. All five shook their heads solemnly and Kym said: "We do not do drugs and we do not think it is cool for anyone else to do drugs." Myleene also faced an awkward question about pictures which have emerged from when she was involved in a webcast fly-on-the-wall documentary called the Doll's House. Despite pictures in which she is seen in scantily clad poses, Myleene insisted she had no regrets. "I do not regret taking part in it. It was a video diary that got blown out of all proportion. When I found out some of the things that were happening I just left," she explained. fields.headline: MoD admits malaria responsibility
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Defence chiefs today admitted they were responsible for a soldier catching malaria in Sierra Leone, but another 14 soldiers face further legal proceedings if they want to claim compensation for catching the disease.
fields.body:
Defence chiefs today admitted they were responsible for a soldier catching malaria in Sierra Leone, but another 14 soldiers face further legal proceedings if they want to claim compensation for catching the disease.

Crack troops from the First and Second battalions of the parachute regiment fell ill on duty in Sierra Leone as stocks of anti-malaria drug Mefloquine ran low last summer. Army medics were forced to buy a less effective French drug, called Gavarin, in the west African state of Senegal when the problem was discovered.

Doctors confirmed 112 soldiers contracted the disease, with another three suspected cases. Now defence chiefs are prepared to pay compensation to one victim, a Ministry of Defence (MoD) spokeswoman said.

But claims lodged by 14 other soldiers have been dismissed and the men will have to sue if they still believe they are entitled to compensation. "It will be up to the 14 other claimants to pursue this further if they still feel they have a claim," the MoD spokeswoman said.

It is thought to be the first time servicemen have lodged claims against the MoD over the medication they were given. However, the spokeswoman said the MoD did not believe it would have implications for Gulf war veterans claiming their health had been damaged by the cocktail of chemical weapons vaccines they were given.

Paul Keetch, Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, attacked the MoD's handling of the affair. "The Ministry of Defence has a duty to ensure that our Armed Forces are given the best protection we can afford, not only in terms of the best equipment, but also the best medical protection," he said.

Mr. Keetch is calling on the MoD to make a "full and frank disclosure" on the malaria cases. He said: "By the very nature of their jobs, our soldiers, sailors and aircrew are willing to lay down their lives in defence of the country. But they do not expect to suffer from avoidable illness or disease like this as a result of their duties."

webTitle: Brown rules out mass tax cuts

fields.headline: Brown rules out mass tax cuts
fields.standfirst: Election countdown
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, today ruled out "indiscriminate" tax handouts in the run-up to an expected spring election.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, today ruled out "indiscriminate" tax handouts in the run-up to an expected spring election.

With this year's budget probably only a month away, he said: "We will do nothing that puts economic stability and the improvements we are investing in for our public services at risk."

Mr Brown was speaking at a press conference in Downing Street to launch a television advertising campaign for the new children's tax credit.

He said: "We will not have indiscriminate, across-the-board tax cuts that would put our stability and these services at risk."

However, Mr Brown insisted that he was not specifically ruling out a cut in the basic rate of income tax and that details would have to wait for the budget, widely expected on March 6.

He said: "We are not going to prejudice the stability we have achieved for the economy  we cannot go along with a proposal that would try to get billions of pounds out of our public services."

Instead, the chancellor repeated the message of his pre-budget report that he wanted to do more to support families.

He said: "I want to raise the children's tax credit to £10 a week. This would mean that for most families with children, weekly support for the first child would rise to £25.50 a week.

"And I want to do more, too, to meet the needs of parents who wish to stay at home for longer after the birth of a child.

"It is now time to do more for mothers who want to stay at home, particularly in the first months and years of their young child's life."

Mr Brown reiterated that the details would be announced within the budget.

fields.headline: Four killed in Surrey shooting
fields.trailText: Two adults and two children have been killed in a shooting incident at a housing estate in Camberley, Surrey, police said today.
fields.body:
Two adults and two children have been killed in a shooting incident at a housing estate in Camberley, Surrey, police said today.

The bodies were discovered by officers at a family home in Heathside Park, an estate in the suburb of Heathside, on the outskirts of Camberley, after worried neighbours reported a build-up of milk and post at the address.

Surrey police confirmed the dead were a man, a woman and two children. It is understood the victims were all members of the same family.

Detective Inspector Dean Hollands refused to confirm that police were not seeking anyone else in connection with the deaths.

He said: "At the moment that's not something we're really concerned about. We are trying to ascertain what occurred in the house and what we're dealing with."

Det Insp Hollands said that police were alerted to the tragedy at 10am yesterday by a call from a resident on the new private estate. He said: "The milk and papers had been building up. It was just a concerned neighbour that called."

Neighbours watched from their windows as forensic officers conducted a fingertip search of the house.

The five bedroom red brick house, worth an estimated £300,000, was sealed off and a white forensics tent erected by Surrey police officers.

An R-reg black Saab and a T-reg green Peugeot 406 were parked on the drive outside the house, which has a double garage.

Two officers were maintaining a guard at the imposing black gates of the fenced-off estate, situated in an exclusive part of Camberley.

Barbara MacDonald, chief reporter at the Camberley News, said: "Police cordoned off the estate this morning at 9.30am.

"They completely sealed it off and were not allowing anybody onto the estate. It's a fairly small estate of 30 to 40 houses and as far as I'm aware there are not armed police there."

Detectives said they will not disclose the names of those killed until relatives have been contacted.

webTitle: One2One launches unmetered mobile phone service

fields.headline: One2One launches unmetered mobile phone service
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: One2One has launched the UK's first unmetered mobile phone service, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
One2One has launched the UK's first unmetered mobile phone service in a bold attempt to tempt customers away from using landlines.

Pay-as-you-go phone users will be able to make unlimited free calls at any time for £75 a month if they sign up to the Precept Max service.

"The introduction of the Precept Max price plan reflects the increasing acceptance of mobile phones as a more convenient and versatile alternative to landlines," said Harris Jones, managing director of One2One.

One2One has unveiled the package at a time when mobile phone operators are becoming increasingly concerned about the profitability of pre-paid phones.

The company, which has the highest proportion of pre-paid customers, said the new service will represent better value for money to anyone using a pay-as-you-go phone for about 40 minutes a day.

Rivals such as Orange, Vodafone and BT Cellnet are expected to follow suit, as more than 60% of their customers also use pre-paid services.

One2One is owned by German firm Deutsche Telekom and is the fourth largest mobile phone operator in the UK, with 8.3m customers.

webTitle: Indian relief workers focus on supporting survivors

fields.headline: Indian relief workers focus on supporting survivors
fields.standfirst: In the first of a series of reports from India, Help the Aged's Hilary Carter explains why older survivors of the apocalyptic earthquake are particularly vulnerable
fields.trailText: In the first of a series of reports from India, Help the Aged's Hilary Carter explains why older survivors of the apocalyptic earthquake are particularly vulnerable
fields.body:
Between 20,000 and 100,000 people lie buried under rubble in the worst earthquake to hit India in 50 years. After a week of desperate rescue work, the focus has now turned to support for the living.

The situation is apocalyptic. Half a million people who are now homeless are facing diseases due to a lack of fresh water and the health risks from unburied bodies. Temporary shelter is needed to protect the survivors from the heat by day and cold by night.

Fourteen aid agencies under the umbrella of the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC), including Help the Aged, are raising money and working with local Indian partners organisations. They will focus on providing clean drinking water, food, shelter, medical supplies, doctors, and emergency tents, clothing and blankets.

Older people are particularly vulnerable in a disaster situation due to physical frailty and special medical needs. They are often among the poorest groups and the least mobile. Many older people also have an integral role in the family unit, and some are having to take over the role of parent for grandchildren whose mothers and fathers have died in the disaster.

Help the Aged and its sister charity HelpAge International are working through their partner HelpAge India to provide emergency relief work. Five fully equipped mobile medical units staffed with orthopaedic surgeons, paramedics and pharmacists are already working in the stricken town of Bhuj, where the earthquake struck, and the outlying regions. HelpAge India is also providing support to 37,000 survivors in the form of food, water, shelter and blankets.

Help the Aged and HelpAge International are sending out a small team of experts from London to support the relief work being undertaken by HelpAge India. They will work with Indian colleagues to assess the specific needs of older survivors from the earthquake as well as coordinating support with other aid agencies and local authorities.

Part of their brief will be to try and track down Help the Aged's sponsored "grandparents", from whom there is currently no word. British supporters are currently sponsoring 30 older men and women in the quake region and are keen to have news.

Help the Aged's head of communications Nikki Hill is flying out with the team for a week. She will be supporting HelpAge India and the DEC appeal by providing the stories to maintain media attention on the earthquake and its after effects.

She said: "We are only at the tip of the iceberg and no one knows the full extent of the damage to people from the area. It is absolutely essential for the aid effort that the support for the appeal continues in the media and that the story stays in the headlines.

"As well as the general relief effort, we will be focusing on the particular impact on the older generation and why their specific needs must be tackled along with other vulnerable groups such as women and children."

webTitle: Two 'miracle' survivors of Indian quake rescued

fields.headline: Two 'miracle' survivors of Indian quake rescued
fields.standfirst: Special report: Natural disasters
fields.trailText: A brother and sister were pulled alive and unharmed from under the rubble in the Indian town of Bhuj today, 10 days after the devastating earthquake which killed an estimated 30,000 people.
fields.body:
A brother and sister were pulled alive and unharmed from under the rubble in the Indian town of Bhuj today, 10 days after the devastating earthquake which killed an estimated 30,000 people.

The two survivors, both in their fifties, were rescued from the kitchen of their home on the ground floor of a three-storey apartment. They survived by sharing a small box of crackers and some water.

"Everyone had given up hope of finding any survivors. This is a miracle," said Bakshi Singh, an inspector general with the Border Security Force (BSF).

A fellow BSF worker, VN Roy, said: "A BSF rescue party heard feeble voices and that attracted their attention. They had food and water with them. They were on the ground floor of their house and luckily they were not seriously hurt."

He said a team of 20 BSF paramilitaries worked carefully with hammers, pickaxes and their bare hands for three hours to dig the couple out of the weakened building.

"It was a delicate operation. If we had used bulldozers, they would have been killed," he said. The man and woman were very weak and were admitted to a makeshift civil hospital in the town.

Bhuj on the western corner of the state of Gujarat was badly hit by the January 26 earthquake, which registered 7.9 on the Richter scale.

The last survivor to be pulled alive from the rubble was rescued on Saturday. The teenager was discovered in a well near the flattened town of Bachchau.

webTitle: What the Middle East papers say

fields.headline: What the Middle East papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The campaign is over, the pollsters have had their day, and there is a rare unity of opinion in Israel, and its neighbours, that the next prime minister will be Ariel Sharon.
fields.body:
The campaign is over, the pollsters have had their day, and there is a rare unity of opinion in Israel, and its neighbours, that the next prime minister will be Ariel Sharon.

The liberal Tel Aviv daily, Ha'aretz, reports that, in private conversations, Barak supporters are already conceding defeat. The report goes on: "The sole concern of Sharon's advisors was that a low turnout could cast a cloud over his victory.

"If the voter turnout is less that 50%, this would seriously damage his legitimacy and give ammunition to his opponents, said one Sharon advisor, especially if Sharon forms a narrow government."

The paper rather gallantly, if predictably, continues to endorse Barak: "The two candidates for the post of prime minister need to be judged on the basis of three main criteria - their intentions, their diplomatic policies [in dealing with the Arab-Israeli conflict], and their personalities.

"In each of these categories, Ehud Barak is a better option than Ariel Sharon. When all the data is added up, there is a single, unequivocal conclusion - Barak must be elected tomorrow."

The Jerusalem Post reports that the Palestinian national authority, headed by Yasser Arafat, is already preparing to deal with Sharon.

Commentator Yossi Goell voices widespread Israeli disquiet with the system of directly elections for the prime ministership: "As far as one can tell, one day ahead of tomorrow's vote, incumbent prime minister Ehud Barak, who was elected primarily because he seemed to be so much more trustworthy than his 1999 opponent Binyamin Netanyahu, will be booted out of office primarily because of significant flaws in his own personality.

"The fact that his current opponent, Ariel Sharon, is also nothing to write home about will apparently make little difference in the latest of a series of elections in which voters have been forced to choose between the lesser of two evils."

The Post website also features a electronic reader poll, in which 76% of respondents opt for Sharon, and just 24% for Barak. The result is obviously slewed by the paper's rightwing views and readership, but still the poll has attracted, so far, an impressive 41,000 responses.

The latest issue of the monthly Palestine Times carries a biting commentary by the redoubtable former peace negotiator, Hanan Ashrawi.

She is bitterly critical of Sharon's record, but detects some advantage in his probable victory. "For the Palestinians, Barak has left us with very little to fear from Sharon in the area of murder and mayhem.

"If peace is far with Barak, it will only become more unattainable with Sharon. Sharon, however, will bring the added ingredient of universal condemnation and repulsion that will stigmatise Israel and subject it to closer scrutiny, accountability, and condemnation."

The Jordan Times, which maintains a close watch on Palestinian affairs, highlights a Reuter's dispatch by the highly informed Wafa Amr, suggesting that Arafat is extremely depressed by the prospect of having to deal with Sharon.

"On a personal level, Arafat could find it extremely difficult to deal with Sharon, a champion of Jewish settlement on occupied land and a man who has, in the past, sought to use Israel's military might to frustrate Palestinian aspirations.

"Sharon led Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon which forced Arafat and his fighters to evacuate their strongholds in Beirut for a new exile in Tunisia.

"Palestinians see Sharon as a war criminal, mainly for his role in the massacre by Israel's Lebanese militia allies of hundreds of Palestinian refugees in the Sabra and Shatila camps (in Lebanon in 1982)."

Further afield, the Gulf News in Dubai is horrified by the prospect of an Sharon prime ministership.

"Some argue that a Sharon victory will not be a major problem because, while the election is the post of prime minister, the present Knesset stays the same with no overall majority for anybody.

"But to rely on the Knesset to remain divided would be to underestimate Sharon's powers as prime minister.

"He will still be able to order the Israeli army into action, to build settlements, to continue killing Palestinians. All the horrors of the occupation will continue, guided by an expert."

Commentator Yossi Goell voices widespread Israeli disquiet with the system of directly elections for the prime ministership: "As far as one can tell, one day ahead of tomorrow's vote, incumbent prime minister Ehud Barak, who was elected primarily because he seemed to be so much more trustworthy than his 1999 opponent Binyamin Netanyahu, will be booted out of office primarily because of significant flaws in his own personality. "The fact that his current opponent, Ariel Sharon, is also nothing to write home about will apparently make little difference in the latest of a series of elections in which voters have been forced to choose between the lesser of two evils." The Post website also features a electronic reader poll, in which 76% of respondents opt for Sharon, and just 24% for Barak. The result is obviously slewed by the paper's rightwing views and readership, but still the poll has attracted, so far, an impressive 41,000 responses. The latest issue of the monthly Palestine Times carries a biting commentary by the redoubtable former peace negotiator, Hanan Ashrawi. She is bitterly critical of Sharon's record, but detects some advantage in his probable victory. "For the Palestinians, Barak has left us with very little to fear from Sharon in the area of murder and mayhem. "If peace is far with Barak, it will only become more unattainable with Sharon. Sharon, however, will bring the added ingredient of universal condemnation and repulsion that will stigmatise Israel and subject it to closer scrutiny, accountability, and condemnation." The Jordan Times, which maintains a close watch on Palestinian affairs, highlights a Reuter's dispatch by the highly informed Wafa Amr, suggesting that Arafat is extremely depressed by the prospect of having to deal with Sharon. "On a personal level, Arafat could find it extremely difficult to deal with Sharon, a champion of Jewish settlement on occupied land and a man who has, in the past, sought to use Israel's military might to frustrate Palestinian aspirations. "Sharon led Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon which forced Arafat and his fighters to evacuate their strongholds in Beirut for a new exile in Tunisia. "Palestinians see Sharon as a war criminal, mainly for his role in the massacre by Israel's Lebanese militia allies of hundreds of Palestinian refugees in the Sabra and Shatila camps (in Lebanon in 1982)." "Some argue that a Sharon victory will not be a major problem because, while the election is the post of prime minister, the present Knesset stays the same with no overall majority for anybody. "But to rely on the Knesset to remain divided would be to underestimate Sharon's powers as prime minister. "He will still be able to order the Israeli army into action, to build settlements, to continue killing Palestinians. All the horrors of the occupation will continue, guided by an expert."

fields.headline: Hindujas hand PR account to Luther Pendragon
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: The Hindujas have handed their PR account to Luther Pendragon after only two weeks with their last firm, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Hindujas, the brothers at the centre of the Peter Mandelson passport row, have handed their PR account to Luther Pendragon after only two weeks with their last PR firm.

The appointment comes after Brown Lloyd James, the Hindujas' incumbent firm, quit the account after a fortnight of press speculation about a relationship between its executive, ex-Downing Street aid Howell James, and Peter Mandelson's partner Reinaldo da Silva.

Luther Pendragon could be seen as a curious choice for the Hindujas, since the PR agency has close links with New Labour.

It numbers the cabinet office and the Department of Culture, Media and Sport among its clients, and also the Commission for Racial Equality, Rock the Vote, McDonald's and the Food Standards Agency.

One of the firm's partners, Ben Rich, told the Independent that Mr Mandelson was "soiled goods" with "a reverse Midas touch" just a day before the agency became the Hindujas' voice-piece.

The firm, which prides itself on being an issues-led consultancy, was recommended to the Hindujas by a mutual friend.

The account is being run by Luther Pendragon partner Charles Stewart-Smith, who co-founded the firm with George Pitcher and two other members of staff in 1992.

Mr Stewart-Smith, a journalist by trade, worked at the BBC on programmes including The Nine O'Clock News and Newsnight and later moved to ITN, where he became editor of News At Ten.

He is an executive director of Rock the Vote, the charity which aims to encourage young people to vote.

webTitle: Monroe heads Emap working life magazine

fields.headline: Monroe heads Emap working life magazine
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Former Time Out features editor Josephine Monroe is to spearhead a title about workplace culture, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Josephine Monroe, former Time Out features editor and founder of online news service the-bullet, is to spearhead a planned new Emap Elan magazine.

Ms Monroe is believed to have been working on the launch of the magazine for over a month.

The title, codenamed Project Floyd, will focus on workplace issues and culture.

David Davies, managing director of men's magazines at Emap, is believed to be coordinating the magazine's launch.

He refused to comment on plans for the magazine, saying only: "We haven't made any announcements about when it's going to launch."

It is believed Ms Monroe will be editorial director of the project, which sources say is expected to be glossy and have an investigative edge.

Ms Monroe was features editor at Time Out before leaving to start the-bullet with co-founder Geraldine Billam.

The-bullet was one of the first online breaking news sites for the media industry but foundered last summer.

It failed to secure second-round investment because of a loss of confidence in technology stocks.

Ms Monroe was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: Partnership approach is bridging regional divide

fields.headline: Partnership approach is bridging regional divide
fields.standfirst: Where there's smoke suddenly there's Blair
fields.trailText: For too long some regions of Britain have been lagging behind the south-east, with lower wages, higher unemployment, less inward investment, fewer small businesses and poorer educational qualifications for school leavers.
fields.body:
For too long some regions of Britain have been lagging behind the south-east, with lower wages, higher unemployment, less inward investment, fewer small businesses and poorer educational qualifications for school leavers.

All of this can and must change. Those areas have a great opportunity to overtake the south-east in the next few years - in jobs, investment and rising living standards.

Last week's news that Corus is to close its plants in Wales and Teesside has come as a severe blow. Urgent government action is necessary to clear the sites and retrain the thousands of redundant workers.

But one company's problems should not cast a shadow over other good news - new investment by Toyota and Nissan, and most recently Boeing, which is spearheading a new aerospace manufacturing research centre in Rotherham, potentially leading to 7,000 more jobs in the next five years.

We have a historic opportunity to invest in new ventures and technologies not only because of stable interest rates and the economy, but also because the new challenges of the global economy and the information revolution mean that companies are increasingly mobile as they search for the new technologies and specialist skills that they need.

Regions and cities prosper if they are open to trade and new ideas. They can attract new investment by offering skilled labour and good infrastructure They can also profit from companies merging together to integrate their operations, to exploit economies of scale or to draw on a pool of specialist labour.

Several factors, such as increasing rents, the costs of scale and congestion, make companies think again about establishing themselves in London.

Expanding new financial centres, investment in airports and infrastructure, world class universities and a thriving regional media outside the south-east are just some of the reasons why companies are inclined to relocate.

And the government is backing the regions through more money for transport and uni versities, and through larger budgets for regional development agencies, which have 100% flexibility on how this money is spent. It all adds up to a new regional policy for Britain*.

The first generation of regional policy, before the war, was geared to help the high unemployment areas.

The second generation in the 1960s and 1970s was based on large capital and tax incentives delivered by the then Department of Industry, almost certainly opposed by the Treasury. It was inflexible and top-down. It did not work.

The new regional policy is based on two principles. First, it aims to strengthen the essential foundation for growth - innovation, skills and the development of enterprise - by exploiting the indigenous strengths of each region and city.

Second, it is bottom-up not top-down, with government enabling powerful regional and local initiatives to work by providing the necessary flexibility and resources.

A commitment is needed from businesses and trade unions, manufacturers and the media, teachers and lecturers, as well as councillors and MPs for a region to succeed.

To take an example, Yorkshire Forward is one of England's leading and most innovative RDA.

It has identified regional weaknesses: too few businesses, especially in the hi-tech sector, and poor business survival rates; low levels of inward investment; low levels of educational achievement, particularly staying-on rates at 16; and insufficient use of IT by small and medium-sized companies.

But it has also pinpointed the region's strengths, which it can build upon: an excellent strategic location; unrivalled communications infrastructure; a strong financial centre in Leeds; excellent universities, with a joint institute for enterprise between Sheffield, Leeds and York Universities; and a skilled workforce which has shown great resourcefulness in adapting to change.

Yorkshire Forward is proposing ambitious targets for the region, for example, to double the rate of small business start-ups, triple foreign manufacturing investment, and train 2m people in IT skills.

These targets demonstrate ambition and commitment to accountability - regionally as well as nationally - which is essential if the new regional policy is to succeed.

As we develop regional policies, which are locally generated and managed, there has to be local and regional accountability. We also need a greater role for both the House of Commons and the regional chambers. We hope that the regional chambers established in every region will hold annual hearings to examine the RDAs' annual reports and review progress against their published strategies - and report back on their findings.

So now it is up to the regions to rise to the challenge. There seems to be an assumption in Britain - among commenta tors, economists and policymakers - that the cities and regions north and west of London will continue to fall behind the south-east and Europe.

There is nothing inevitable about regional inequalities in income, employment or opportunity. Stability, the new challenges and opportunities of the global economy and the new regional policy mean we can close regional divides and deliver higher growth and full employment in every British region.

 Ed Balls is chief economic adviser to the Treasury. John Healey is parliamentary private secretary to the chancellor and MP for Wentworth.

Their pamphlet, Towards a New Regional Policy, is available from info@smith-institute.org.uk

fields.headline: Carlton fat cats get the cream
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Carlton Communications' annual report reveals some fat pay checks for those at the top, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications executive director Nigel Walmsley received a £109,000 annual bonus last year for services to the company.

The former Capital Radio boss landed a total package of £415,000 in the year to September 30 2000, according to the Carlton annual report.

Mr Walmsley's pay package - combining salary, benefits and annual bonus - was up by £84,000 on the previous year, according to the report for the 12 months to the end of September.

But his pay was still dwarfed by that of Carlton chairman Michael Green, who remains the highest paid executive in the company with an annual income of £892,000.

Mr Green's package consisted of a £610,000 salary, £44,000 in benefits and a £238,000 annual bonus. He received £153,000 more in the year to September 30 last year than in the previous 12 months.

The report also reveals that former chief executive Steven Cain received a cool £2.33m for just 13 months at the company.

Mr Cain, who left in January last year because Clive Hollick was due to take the chief executive role in the merged Carlton/United News & Media combine, received £978,000 in salary, benefits and bonus for his time with Carlton.

He also got £518,000 in compensation for the early termination of his contract and a made further £834,000 on share options which he was allowed to cash in early.

fields.headline: Lavish BBC1 adaptation fails to dent ITV ratings
fields.trailText: 3pm TV overnights: BBC1's Love in a Cold Climate failed to compete with ITV's dramas on Sunday night, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1's lavish Nancy Mitford adaptation Love in a Cold Climate could not dent ITV dramas Heartbeat or London's Burning on Sunday night.

The two-parter, adapted by Deborah Moggach from Ms Mitford's two comic novels, was on between 8.45pm and 10pm and featured a meaty cast including Alan Bates, Celia Imrie, Sheila Gish and Anthony Andrews.

Love in a Cold Climate opened with 5.8m and a 22% share, according to unofficial overnights.

Heartbeat had 13m from 8-9pm, while London's Burning weighed in with 10.4m in the following hour.

But Love in a Cold Climate still managed to debut more strongly than the previous drama in the same BBC1 Sunday night slot.

Controversial Irish drama Rebel Heart opened with 3.9m and averaged just 3.3m and a 13% share over its four-week run.

It was the same story for BBC1 on Friday night, with hotly anticipated new comedy drama Adrian Mole: The Cappuccino Years and Pauline Quirke sitcom vehicle Office Gossip making no impact on The Bill's ratings.

Office Gossip led off BBC1's new Friday night comedy double-bill at 9pm, with Adrian Mole following on at 9.30pm.

Both had a 26% share of viewing, though Office Gossip had a slightly higher audience, with 6.3m to Adrian Mole's 6m.

The Bill on ITV had 7.9m - 200,000 more than the previous Friday, when it was up against BBC1 movie repeat Apollo 13, with 6.4m.

Two weekends ago the ITV police drama had 8.2m, against BBC1's Vicar of Dibley repeat with 5.9m and They Think It's All Over, which had 6m.

Earlier on Friday night, a BBC1 Casualty special lost out to Michael Barrymore's My Kind of Music between 8 and 9pm.

The BBC1 medical drama had 7.1m and a 30% share on a rare Friday outing; while My Kind of Music had 8.6m and 36%.

On Saturday night, BBC2's I Love 1982 comprehensively won the battle of the archive shows in a head-to-head with Channel 4's Top Ten Teen Idols.

I Love 1982 pulled in 2.8m and an 11% share. The show went out between 9.05 and 10.35pm.

Top Ten Teen Idols, presented by Cat Deeley, was broadcast on Channel 4 between 9 and 11.10pm.

But it could only manage an average of 1.6m and a 7% audience share over that period.

Channel 4 enjoyed far more success with Sex: the Annabel Chong Story, 11.10pm-12.55am.

The documentary about a Singapore porn star who had sex with 251 men in 10 hours had 2.1m and a 20% share.

fields.headline: Surviving 'el susto'
fields.standfirst: As Oxfam aid worker Rachel Stabb prepares to leave El Salvador, she reflects on 'el susto', the fear Salvadoreans have that another devastating earthquake is imminent
fields.trailText: As Oxfam aid worker Rachel Stabb prepares to leave El Salvador, she reflects on 'el susto', the fear Salvadoreans have that another devastating earthquake is imminent
fields.body:
By the end of January, El Salvador had felt more than 2,600 aftershocks since the earthquake struck on January 13. One aftershock brought down the cathedral tower in Sonsonate town, others set off fresh landslides.

Buildings and landscapes are still unstable. As you travel the country you only have to look up at the volcanoes on the horizon to wonder what Mother Nature will bring next.

But as I prepared to return home, leaving the rest of the Oxfam team hard at work, I had an enduring impression of the resilience of the ordinary people in the rural communities I'd visited. Resilience in the face of poverty and disaster.

The day after it happened and their lives collapsed, they were organising themselves, drawing up lists of families badly affected, calculating the scale of damage, noting what was needed and getting help from local non-governmental organisations. Their past, with its commitment to class struggle and community, was now serving them well.

In some places, though, it was clear that districts run by the governing Arena party were the recipients of plenty of food, water and shelter distributed through the government's aid effort, while those in opposition hands received barely anything. Politics was never far from the surface

Many people in rural areas did not want to leave their homes after they collapsed, fearing problems over their right to return. They set about clearing up and putting up temporary shelter beside the rubble and timbers. Others left, not wanting to return to certain areas that no longer offered them any future.

After an initial cash outlay to selected groups, Oxfam International's office in San Salvador is now sifting through requests and proposals from their local partners to support longer term work. They're looking at a "techo minimo" (basic roof) project which will give the largest number of people affected the framework to start rebuilding their homes.

Fear and anxiety certainly remain in El Salvador. The survivors of Santa Tecla's mudslide will be in mourning for a long time to come.

The fundamentals of life for Salvadoreans have been severely shaken. Agriculture has suffered damage to the tune of $140m on initial estimates. Landslides have affected 1,423 acres of coffee with a price tag of $2.3m, and the fishing communities along the coast, again some of the poorest, have seen demand dive, fishing stocks displaced equalling losses of $11.5m. These figures are only the tip of the iceberg.

Perhaps the starkest statistic is that of house rebuilding. El Salvador manages to build 20,000 homes a year. It's little comfort knowing that 150,000 houses need to be reconstructed.

But when you ask people in the countryside what their main problem is, they reply "el susto", or fear. Fear of another quake has made them sleep outside at night and has stopped them plying their street trade in tortillas and fruits. They're afraid to leave their families for too long and anyway business is slack.

El susto is what Salvadoreans must first get over before they begin the long journey back to recovery.

 Oxfam International's $3.5m emergency aid operation has in its first phase installed 30 water tanks and tapstands in five provinces, organised a health promotion campaign and distributed blankets, tents and food through several partner organisations.
