fields.headline: Asda launches cut-price jewellery range
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Asda is to challenge high street jewellers by launching a cut-price range of costume jewellery, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
This Valentine's Day, a trinket from your loved one could come wrapped in a not-so romantic Asda plastic bag and may have cost less than £5.

And if he pops the question on February 14, he could also pop down to Asda for a cut-price diamond engagement ring.

The supermarket is to challenge high street jewellers such as H Samuel and catalogue retailer Argos by launching its first ever own-branded range of costume jewellery.

The Wal-Mart owned supermarket is promising up to 40% off manufacturers' recommended retail prices on gold, silver and cubic zirconia jewellery and diamond engagement rings.

Designer watches at discounted prices will also be offered as part of the range, which continues Asda's aggressive assault on the branded goods market.

The idea has been imported from the US chain, which opened its first jewellery store in 1962.

In-store jewellery shops will launch in 20 Asda stores, with the first opening its doors at Chadderton in Oldham this April. The second will open at Horwich, near Bolton, in May.

But, from today, a limited range of jewellery priced under £10 will be available across Asda's 241 stores nationwide, to enable the retailer to cash in on Valentine's Day.

The Valentine's range offers a glimpse of what is to come. A pink crystal necklace and earring set at £6.97, saving 42% on the manufacturer's recommended price of £12.

A heavy chain with heart drop bracelet is offered at £4.97 compared with the manufacturer's recommended price of £7 - a saving of 29%.

The jewellery shops will form part of Asda's speciality division, a new group mirroring Wal-Mart's speciality division in the US which also includes photo, optical and pharmacy services.

Asda says the costume jewellery market is set to grow by a quarter every year for the next four years and that the UK jewellery sector is bigger than women's fragrances, which Asda also discounts.

"The arrival of 'Asda price' to jewellery is good news for all those customers whose hearts are bigger than their pockets," said Paula Kennedy, jewellery development manager at Asda.

Asda's move comes after rival Tesco launched a new 'Tiffany' heart-shaped trinket for St Valentine's Day. However, it had withdraw the chain after objections from the upmarket jewellery store of the same name.

fields.headline: MacLaurin Group unveils new look
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: The MacLaurin Group, PR adviser to BSkyB and Procter & Gamble, has shortened its name and introduced a new logo, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The MacLaurin Group, PR adviser to companies including BSkyB and Procter & Gamble, has undergone a rebrand, shortening its name and introducing a new logo.

The move has been designed to modernise the company's appearance and simplify the organisation for clients and contacts.

The company is dropping the 'group' from its name and from now on will be called MacLaurin.

The revamp means its sub-brands, such as MacLaurin Powerhouse and MacLaurin Communications, no longer exist.

"The MacLaurin Group was divided into sub-brands that had teams within teams. Over the past 12-18 months, we have brought everything under one brand to simplify the offering. It's much easier," said Amanda Lovejoy, assistant to chief executive Brian MacLaurin.

Design house Trigger Art created the new blue M logo, which carries the strapline "Challenging expectations".

Mr MacLaurin said: "The slogan reminds us to continue to push the boundaries of communications excellence."

MacLaurin employs 70 people and has offices in London and Edinburgh.

The company covers six sectors: consumer, corporate, media, entertainment, technology and online.

Its client list includes the Jim Henson Company, Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, Chrysalis Group, Ogilvy Group, Safeway and British Design & Art Direction (D&AD).

webTitle: Casting news: Sigourney Weaver back for fifth Alien movie

fields.headline: Sigourney Weaver back for fifth Alien movie
fields.standfirst: Plus: Bruce Greenwood lines up opposite Sharon Stone in Basic Instinct 2; Billy Campbell joins Jennifer Lopez in marital drama; Madeleine Stowe set for Vietnam saga with Mel Gibson
fields.trailText: Plus: Bruce Greenwood lines up opposite Sharon Stone in Basic Instinct 2; Billy Campbell joins Jennifer Lopez in marital drama; Madeleine Stowe set for Vietnam saga with Mel Gibson
fields.body:
 Clearly a glutton for punishment, Sigourney Weaver (pictured) looks set to star in a fifth instalment in the Alien saga, though reports suggest that the actress will be compensated for her ordeals to the tune of $15m (£10.19m). Weaver, the star of all four previous Alien movies, will also serve as executive producer on Alien 5, which is slated for release in 2004. According to the Sunday Express, the film will focus on the alien's arrival on planet Earth. "I've always wanted to do one where we go back to the planet where the alien originally came from or even get to Earth," said Weaver.

 Link to netnotes on Alien.

 Bruce Greenwood has been cast as the male lead opposite Sharon Stone in Basic Instinct 2. Currently impressing critics with his turn as JFK in 13 Days, Greenwood replaces original star Michael Douglas, who decided against the sequel, and Kurt Russell, who at one stage looked certain to take the role. Basic Instinct 2 will be directed by John (Die Hard) McTiernan, who replaces David Cronenberg after he reportedly quit the movie following clashes with Stone.

 The Rocketeer star Bill Campbell is to play the abusive husband of feisty Jennifer Lopez in Enough. A female saga along the lines of Sleeping With the Enemy, the film shoots in March.

 Madeleine Stowe is in negotiations to play Mel Gibson's wife in the Vietnam war drama We Were Soldiers Once and Young. Based on the first major battle between US soldiers and the Viet Cong in 1965, the Paramount production will be directed by Randall Wallace and stars Gibson as a hardy battalion commander. The film has already attracted criticism from some Vietnam veterans who worry that Gibson will romanticise what remains a controversial and painful struggle.

fields.headline: All about sex
fields.standfirst: Candace Bushnell may seem to have a lot in common with her most famous creation, Carrie Bradshaw, man-crazy star of Sex and the City. But, she says, she is actually  very conservative
fields.trailText: Candace Bushnell may seem to have a lot in common with her most famous creation, Carrie Bradshaw, man-crazy star of Sex and the City. But, she says, she is actually very conservative
fields.body:
Hey, I can see the crack in your ass!" shrieks the stranger with the endless thighs and glitter boots. Ah, that must be Candace. The legs walk into the room a few seconds before the face. I'm bending over, smelling the leather seats in the terribly posh club, thinking they probably taste pretty good with a bit of mustard. And she seems quite excited. " I could! I could see the crack ."

Candace Bushnell wrote the newspaper column Sex and the City, which she turned into a book, which was turned into the television series. It's about four women (including a journalist, Carrie Bradshaw, based on herself) making their way in the world. It is shocking, groundbreaking, empowering, or old-fashioned, depending on whom you speak to.

The four New Yorkers are hungry for sex, on their terms. They spend much of their time shagging, then comparing notes with their girl friends. It's a world defined by cocaine, penis size, cappuccino, blow jobs, executive jobs and Ferraris. Bushnell's writing has been called "Jane Austen with Martini" and compared to the novels of Edith Wharton. Which is fair enough because ultimately, despite their financial independence, the lives of the women in Sex and the City are defined by men. Like Austen and Wharton, she examines the ways that women position themselves in society and, hopefully, snare a man.

In her dazzly boots and hip-length skirt Bushnell is looking very country and western. She has an amazing knack of crossing her legs without revealing anything improper. Quite a feat in that skirt. "I was going somewhere, and this guy sat down next to me and said, 'Are you Nashville?' and I said, 'No, why?'" She lurches into the dopey Homer Simpson voice that she often uses to impersonate flailing men. "And he said, 'Well your boots - you look like a country and western singer.' I almost punched him." She spits out the word "punch". No one messes with Candace Bushnell.

How often does she hit people? "I don't usually . . . I've slapped a guy's face once or twice." She says she has dreams in which she throws punch after punch and they never connect. Has she ever caused damage? "Noooooah. Noooooooah . I'm not really big enough to cause damage. Also it's not really me. I don't like physical violence. I did get really mad at one guy once and I slapped his face." Now she's turned into a drama queen on confessional TV, her liquid lips quivering with angst. " It was as shocking to me as it was to him. "

She's painting her face for the photograph with a make-up brush that could double as a mop. "That's professional, a professional make-up brush." She addresses her mouth with a finger and red lipstick. "I actually have a lip brush but I'm too lazy to use it."

Then she addresses the photographer. "I'm not that young. Make my head really tiny." Why? "Cos then it can't look that bad. The smaller it is the better I'll look." Bushnell is pretty and skinny. She never diets, never eats healthy foods, never exercises. In the past, she says, men have walked up to her and told her that her body is wrong, not womanly. "Well a womanly shape just happens to be if you're a woman. Whatever it is."

Bushnell's new book is called 4 Blondes. Whereas the characters in Sex and the City are slight and self-absorbed but likable, here they are slight and self-absorbed and contemptible. If they have a good side, we don't get to see it. The book is spiked with withering observations: from the vacuous beauty, Janey, who screws the wealthiest man possible every summer to get herself a great vacation house in the Hamptons; to the society princess suffocating in her trophy marriage; to the smug, married journalists who sit in judgment on the rest of the world. It's a powerful, well-written book that occasionally makes you shiver with recognition.

She says she feels her women have changed since Sex and the City, which she wrote in her mid-30s. "In Blondes, the women are not looking for men, they're looking for themselves, looking for some kind of meaning, and their place in the world." She gives "place" a good whipping. "I think that's the hardest thing to find, your place in the world. Why are you here? What do you do? And should you even be here or should you just kill yourself? Don't you wake up some mornings and think maybe I should just kill myself?"

Why does she think we're here? "I don't know. Are we here to reproduce or do something else? I think people do innately aspire to everything... success, being happy, being loved. Janey would like to be loved but nobody is ever going to love her because she is an asshole . It's like if you're a jerk you'll end up with jerks." Then there's Winnie, the superior journalist who measures out her life in coffeespoons, and damns anyone who dares to differ. "Winnie's just nasty isn't she?" Yes, I say, she's disgusting. "I know, I know, and I love that." She giggles, and says it's fun to write nasty.

But she bristles when I suggest the characters in 4 Blondes are irredemable. "I think that's a really, really judgmental thing to say. I think everybody's made mistakes and behaved in ways they probably shouldn't have, and I think we should be a little bit more generous. I think they're human. I feel like I'm pretty moral, and I can be a judgmental type of person, but I'm probably much more generous than people who feel the characters are irredemable. Like, how cruel. Like, none of these people has killed anybody. You'd probably have more sympathy for a murderer than these characters who think dark thoughts and show you something about yourself."

She has a point. And in fact, at the end she does redeem her characters, she does give them their moment of happiness. Bushnell says so many people are quick to damn the characters because they see themselves in them, and that hurts. Take the portrait of Winnie's loveless marriage. "Winnie is a bit horrible, but she kind of gets better. You understand why she is so horrible because she's so frustrated and she shouldn't have married James. A lot of women think about the men they're with, you know that he's not holding up his end. If you sit down with some unhappily married women and all that stuff comes out, but they don't have the guts to end the relationship because there's that fear maybe there's nothing better out there."

Bushnell, 41, has never married and has had a series of high-profile affairs. In 1978 she left rural Glastonbury, Connecticut, and headed for New York. Soon after she moved in with Gordon Parks, the great photographer who directed the original Shaft movie. Bushnell was 18, Parks 60. She calls him "the coolest guy you'll ever meet". There followed the relationship with Ron Galotti, the fearsome, Ferrari-fixated New York publisher (and the role model for Mr Big in Sex and the City). Now she's going out with Stephen Morris, a 34-year-old English venture capitalist. When she's not in New York she lives with him in Chelsea. She says they are very happy, may get married, may not, may have kids, may not.

Bushnell worked for many years on women's magazines, like Winnie does. Magazines that told their readers if you followed the rules everything would turn out OK. "If you never eat fat, and you exercise, and any problem that comes up you go to a shrink, and if you decorate your house cheaply but chicly, it's all going to be fine isn't it?" She says there's an anarchist in her that wanted to scream out it was all a lie.

I ask her what gave her greatest satisfaction as a journalist. She mentions two stories she wrote about runaway teenagers and migrant workers. She spent weeks with her subjects, on the streets and in trailer parks. "The social workers were like, 'Don't sit on their couch, you could get something.' It was like, 'I've got jeans on, I'll sit on the couch.' " At times she speaks with the shambling eloquence of the girls in the movie Clueless.

Although she is most proud of these articles, they are also what made her want to quit journalism. "The thing about it is, you come in from the outside and befriend these people. They really think they're your friend and you're going to help them down the road, and you're going in as a journalist to do that story and when the story's done you can't continue a relationship with those people. I thought there was something cruel about that. I didn't like it, I just didn't think it was nice."

She looks embarrassed. "I know you're not buying that, but it doesn't seem like the right thing to do." I do buy it.

Bushnell orders a Coke and lights yet another fag. "You're not gonna get all hyper again are you?" joshes the waiter. "I'm like one of those hyperactive kids - don't give him sugar!" She talks about people we know in America, and her publicist, and the journalist she's just seen. She doesn't seem to have a bad word for any of them. I start muttering, ineptly, about how she understands ghastly people so well, and I was wondering... She finishes the sentence for me. "Oh, you mean am I one?"

Again, she says she doesn't think the people she satirises are truly horrible. "I think they're behaving in the way that people do in certain circumstances. Most people are easily swayed by the circumstances they are in."

Bushnell says she couldn't write a book like Sex and the City now. "In my mid-30s I was much more absorbed by men." At the time she wanted to realistically depict the sex lives of single women in New York, but all that has been lost on television. "In the TV series they go out and meet a different guy every week. That just doesn't happen to most women. I have some girl friends who'd go to a party and they'd met a footballer or something and they'd have sex with him in a closet, and I was always, 'Oh my God! How could you do that!' Like a mixture of 'gosh, that's really brave' and 'that's really slutty'."

She never did that? "No. I'm not like that. I couldn't. I'm too conservative. That's so not me. I actually couldn't do that." She says she dabbled with cocaine at Studio 54 in her younger days, but that's about it. "I'm very conservative. I don't necessarily dress conservatively." She looks at her thighs. "I think my skirt is a bit inappropriately short." But it does go down well on book tours. "Now I mostly wear pants."

So where did she find her gallery of vile creatures? "There was this time in the late 80s and there was this excess and everyone was going mad, and people were pretty nasty to each other." Is she talking about the likes of Brett Easton Ellis and his literary brat pack? She looks shocked. "No, they were probably the nice ones. He's a doll. Other people. I think the meanest people are people in their late 20s and early 30s. They're so judgmental and they're mean to each other, not very forgiving. And I was around this group of people where they were all shagging each other and taking ecstasy and doing all this stuff, and I just loved to hear about it but I didn't really want to do it." She pauses. "Ever since I was a kid I realised I'm one of those people who will run to the edge of the cliff with everyone else and then I'll watch them jump off. I won't jump off, but others will."

Bushnell hasn't finished her Coke. Her PR says we have to wind up because the News of the World is waiting to take her round town in a stretch limo. A stretch Saab. She'll have to lie on the back seat and make the most of her legs. "Let me just warn you they have two champagne flutes. I said you had an upset stomach and you might not drink any," the PR says. It's the last thing she feels like doing, but a book tour is a book tour. "I'm so depressed," Bushnell says. "I might throw up on them."

Most people are easily swayed by the circumstances they are in." Bushnell says she couldn't write a book like Sex and the City now. "In my mid-30s I was much more absorbed by men." At the time she wanted to realistically depict the sex lives of single women in New York, but all that has been lost on television. "In the TV series they go out and meet a different guy every week. That just doesn't happen to most women. I have some girl friends who'd go to a party and they'd met a footballer or something and they'd have sex with him in a closet, and I was always, 'Oh my God! How could you do that!' Like a mixture of 'gosh, that's really brave' and 'that's really slutty'." She never did that? "No. I'm not like that. I couldn't. I'm too conservative. That's so not me. I actually couldn't do that." She says she dabbled with cocaine at Studio 54 in her younger days, but that's about it. "I'm very conservative. I don't necessarily dress conservatively." She looks at her thighs. "I think my skirt is a bit inappropriately short." But it does go down well on book tours. "Now I mostly wear pants." So where did she find her gallery of vile creatures? "There was this time in the late 80s and there was this excess and everyone was going mad, and people were pretty nasty to each other." Is she talking about the likes of Brett Easton Ellis and his literary brat pack? She looks shocked. "No, they were probably the nice ones. He's a doll. Other people. I think the meanest people are people in their late 20s and early 30s. They're so judgmental and they're mean to each other, not very forgiving. And I was around this group of people where they were all shagging each other and taking ecstasy and doing all this stuff, and I just loved to hear about it but I didn't really want to do it." She pauses. "Ever since I was a kid I realised I'm one of those people who will run to the edge of the cliff with everyone else and then I'll watch them jump off. I won't jump off, but others will." Bushnell hasn't finished her Coke. Her PR says we have to wind up because the News of the World is waiting to take her round town in a stretch limo. A stretch Saab. She'll have to lie on the back seat and make the most of her legs. "Let me just warn you they have two champagne flutes. I said you had an upset stomach and you might not drink any," the PR says. It's the last thing she feels like doing, but a book tour is a book tour. "I'm so depressed," Bushnell says. "I might throw up on them."

fields.headline: Big names invest £7m in iFilm
fields.trailText: 2pm: The movie portal has picked up financial support from Yahoo!, Sony Pictures and Kodak, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Movie portal iFilm has picked up £6.9m in financial support from a band of investors that includes Yahoo!, Sony Pictures and Kodak.

It is the second time Sony and Kodak have invested in the company.

iFilm showcases short films and provides support to the independent film industry.

Sony's investment means the portal is likely to become a key content provider for Sony's planned broadband entertainment initiative, due to launch in May.

Yahoo!'s involvement will mean iFilm's library of short films will be added to Yahoo!, boosting its entertainment site.

Former Microsoft heavyweight Paul Allen has also reinvested in iFilm through his investment vehicle Vulcan Ventures.

Mr Allen was also involved in the now defunct Pop.com, which was wound up in September after merger talks with iFilm collapsed.

Pop.com investors Steven Spielberg and Ron Howard have since made internet films for a new website called Countingdown.com.

A number of other high-profile online film and broadcast ventures have suffered setbacks recently.

Icebox.com, for example, has been forced to make a number of redundancies and cutbacks.

The problems have largely been attributed to the immaturity of the market for broadcasting short and animated films over the web.

However, this fresh round of funding from such heavyweight backers suggests the online broadcast market is more stable than it was a year ago.

iFilm claims it is already changing the rules of filmmaking by giving directors a free, global showcase for their work.

The "success stories" section of iFilm.com lists 17 filmmakers that have been discovered by Hollywood and have won critical acclaim.

Launched in October 1998, iFilm now contains links to more than 15,000 internet films.

An iFilm spokesperson said the new funding would help keep the company afloat but declined to give an estimate of expected profitability.

webTitle: Low public trust in food safety

fields.headline: Low public trust in food safety
fields.trailText: Five million people in Britain could have suffered food poisoning last year, but few reported it to a doctor or a food outlet that may have been responsible, the food standards agency reveals today.
fields.body:
Five million people in Britain could have suffered food poisoning last year, but few reported it to a doctor or a food outlet that may have been responsible, the food standards agency reveals today.

Its survey of attitudes to food safety has found confidence to be "unacceptably low", with less than half the population happy with the present regime, a finding that is sure to prompt a blitz on industry standards.

Three in five people were still worried about BSE, despite a rise in beef consumption, and about food poisoning in general. Concern was widespread about the way abattoirs and butchers handled raw chicken and beef, as well as hygiene in fast food outlets, markets and supermarkets.

Interviews with 3,153 Britons in October suggest that levels of food poisoning may be 50 times as high as official figures suggest, although the agency emphasised they reflected individuals' perception of the problem. But officials were concerned by 14% of those questioned in England who said they had experienced vomiting or diarrhoea due to poisoning. Fewer Scots (13%), Welsh (11%) and Northern Irish (10%) reported such incidents.

Only 3% of people over 65 suffered such an attack while 20% of those aged 26-35 thought they had been struck down. Just one in five consumers reported their experience to anyone, and they were far more likely to tell their GP than the place where they bought or consumed the food which may have been responsible.

The survey found 48% were confident about safety measures. Sir John Krebs, chairman of the foods standard agency, said: "It may be a reflection of two decades of food crises, but it is an unacceptably low figure."

Urban consumers were more concerned about food issues than those in the countryside, but they were also more likely to have suffered food poisoning. In all 63% of people said they were worried about food poisoning, 61% about BSE, while 43% had concerns over GM foods and 37% were worried by the level of antibiotics that might be present in the farm animals they ate.

The survey suggested that healthy eating messages from the government still had some way to go. Of the 43% who were aware of official advice to eat at least five portions of fruit and vegetables a day, only half did so the day before they were interviewed. Few actually knew what a portion size was - a whole fruit if eaten raw or two tablespoons of vegetable.

A third of those questioned had eaten organic food but just one in 20 households included a vegetarian.

webTitle: Prison does not work. We know that

fields.headline: Prison does not work. We know that
fields.standfirst: Why do we send more and more there? It doesn't look good
fields.trailText: Roger Graef: Why do we send more and more there? It doesn't look good
fields.body:
Who said that the level of civilisation in any society should be judged by how it treated its weakest members, such as those left forgotten in prison? What government declared that prison was "an expensive way to make bad people worse"?

These are not the words of do-gooding, woolly liberal Guardian readers who care more about the rights of criminals than victims. The first was said by Winston Churchill, then home secretary, calling for parliament to respond to the need for prison reforms. Crucially, he urged that we never give up hope on the capacity of the human heart to change.

The second comes from a white paper published by another Conservative home secretary, David Waddington, in 1990 under Margaret Thatcher. The prison population fell under those Tories, from over 50,000 to 40,000. The subsequent Criminal Justice Act of 1991 ordered sentencers to use prison as "a last resort", and to give reasons why it was necessary for "serious offences". But that required judges, magistrates, and ministers to face up to the primordial British love of punishment - so vividly expressed daily in our tabloids. And from Kenneth Clarke onwards, they flunked it. As a result, our prisons are now overflowing with half again as many people as only a decade ago. By 2005, the population may have doubled to 90,000.

And these are "our" prisons. People are sent to fester behind bars in such numbers using our precious taxes, for our protection and in an attempt to win our votes. When we read the immensely sad stories in this newspaper during the past week, or hear the savage indictment of Brixton prison conditions by Gen Sir David Ramsbotham, Her Majesty's inspector, we cannot merely shake our heads and move on to worrying about where we will take our children skiing at half term.

The vast majority of the people now behind bars will be emerging in due course. If they have TB, we will breathe their germs on tubes and buses. If they are mentally ill, they will become our problem soon enough. If they are untrained and unemployable, it is our houses and cars they will be ransacking for saleable goods. If they go in for modest offences, and emerge angrier and better skilled both at heavier crimes and avoiding detection, prison will not have "worked" for the rest of us.

Moreover as Emrys James and David Wilson both pointed out, these people are not a sub-race, but people like us, with the same complex feelings, the same urges, vices, restlessness and dreams. Research shows that offending is widespread among all social classes, especially among teenagers and young adults. The difference is who gets caught.

The appalling vista laid out in the Guardian's investigation is so bleak it is tempting to believe nothing can be done. But the experience of Grendon is inspiring: the 40 years it took to build a second one tells us more about our love of punishment than our concern for redemption and community safety.

Restorative justice operates in the wing communities in Grendon in ways that could change the whole culture of the prison service: complaints and discipline, bullying and many other grievances that now add to the sense of injustice both from inmates and staff would be far better settled through mediation, in which both parties can feel involved. Moreover, mediation and reparation with their victims brings home to offenders the real consequences of their actions while prison makes them feel victimised.

If the government is committed to "what works" as its guide for criminal justice policy and crime reduction, then it must bite the bullet and face down public ignorance and vindictiveness which now places prison as the main option, and all else as an alternative to prison. It should again be a last resort.

Safety does require some people to be locked up. Prison can lead damaged people to reconsider their lives and learn new skills, take new options. The arts in prison are especially effective both as tools for expression beyond violence and as a route to education and social skills. They too suffer from lack of staff and resources.

But to work effectively with those who need to be incarcerated, the prison service must be freed from the disastrous burden of those who could be dealt with effectively and far less expensively in the community.

Moreover, for the vast majority of inmates, the loss of local connections with family, job and home sentences them again to return to crime. Is that really why we are spending so much in scarce financial and human resources, and destroying so many families in the process - to increase future crime? The real scandal of prison is that by Churchill's test we are uncivilised. Shame on all of us.

 Roger Graef is a filmmaker and criminologist.

fields.headline: Hospital rejects Van Velzen's claims
fields.standfirst: Special report: Alder Hey organs scandal
fields.trailText: Claims by the doctor at the centre of the Alder Hey organs scandal that he never knowingly removed body parts without consent were dismissed by the hospital today.
fields.body:
Claims by the doctor at the centre of the Alder Hey organs scandal that he never knowingly removed body parts without consent were dismissed by the hospital today.

Professor Dick van Velzen, now the subject of a police investigation, blamed NHS management for the failings that led to last week's damning public inquiry report.

The pathologist, also wanted by police in Canada over the retention of organs found in his possessions, said in a BBC interview yesterday: "It's not my fault."

But Alder Hey Hospital said in a statement today: "The claims made are not substantiated in the inquiry report."

The hospital rejected the doctor's claims that he had never taken children's organs without the permission of their parents and had always carried out postmortem examinations either with consent or on behalf of the coroner.

Prof van Velzen's denial comes as health officials prepare for an emergency summit to combat a feared collapse in the number of transplants following the Alder Hey scandal.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, will hold the meeting with surgeons, health chiefs, business representatives, unions and parents "as soon as possible" in a bid to rebuild public confidence as donations are feared to have dropped by more than half.

Prof van Velzen, 51, said he inherited a run-down, dilapidated system when he started work at the Alder Hey children's hospital in Liverpool.

"The support that was needed, that was promised, that was agreed to by NHS management ... the support to re-establish care for parents in that hospital where it had been absent for years ... that was not forthcoming.

"That was not my choice. That was the management's choice. The main apology I can offer parents is that I have not resigned on their behalf earlier."

He added: "People forget to tell the parents what the postmortem actually is," he said. "It's terrible. It's not my fault."

New acting chief executive at the Alder Hey Tony Bell acknowledged that the procedures at the time for obtaining parental consent for postmortem organ removal had been inadequate.

He added: "The hospital is deeply sorry for what has happened in the past at Alder Hey in relation to these children and families. It is almost that no apology could be enough for what these parents have gone through."

The president of the Royal College of Pathologists, Professor John Lilleyman, said he found Prof van Velzen's line of defence "surprising".

He said it failed to address the most serious findings of the official inquiry report that he had taken material specifically against parental wishes and that he had falsified autopsy reports.

"I think the manner and scale of what went on at Alder Hey during what the report described as the van Velzen years was quite extraordinary and really cannot be defended or excused in any way as acceptable professional practice, even by the standards of the time," he said.

fields.headline: Alien
fields.standfirst: Sigourney Weaver is going to receive a reported $15m to star as Ellen Ripley in a fifth Alien movie. Here's our guide to the best links on the gooey extra-terrestrial franchise
fields.trailText: Sigourney Weaver is going to receive a reported $15m to star as Ellen Ripley in a fifth Alien movie. Here's our guide to the best links on the gooey extra-terrestrial franchise.
fields.body:
1. Alien 5 is go! Sigourney Weaver's on board, as star and executive producer and there's the vaguest inkling of a plot (it'll be set on Earth).

2. Come Earth Date 2004, it'll be in our cinemas. That's the 25th anniversary of Ridley Scott's original film, which took an age-old haunted house story and blasted it into space.

3. What was entirely original was the queasily authentic biology of the production design. The alien ship was something straight off Planet Subconscious, with its vagina-like orifices and phallus-headed inhabitants, all from the homely mind of Swiss artist HR Giger.

4. So with sexuality and The Other amply covered, film studies students could make "readings" to their hearts' content and as it was extremely scary, the punters rejoiced too.

5. Another unusual feature was a strong, resourceful female protagonist who didn't faint when the monster so much as picked its nose near her.

6. It was seven years until a sequel though. James "King of the World" Cameron simply added an "s" and a lot more guns, and the bracing traipse through ET-hell that was Aliens was spawned in 1986.

7. Six more years and Alien3 appeared. The jury's still out on this film, with many rattled by Ripley's climactic death and the producers' strange decision to apparently hire a Rochdale theatre troupe, led by Brian Glover, to play the inmates of a cosmic penitentiary.

8. Guns'n'Ammo subscribers were also mystified by the fact that no one seemed to be "packing". That was something introduced at the behest of star Weaver, then going through an "anti-violence" phase.

9. It seemed to have passed by 1997 in the fatuous Alien: Resurrection, when Ripley was reconstructed from her DNA and, extra-aggressive thanks to her new alien genes, appeared quite happy to blow the heads off anything.

10. Can we expect anything better this time? A touch more of the comic-book insanity of some of the previously rejected scripts floating around and things may go in an interesting new direction.

fields.headline: Media Business
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 5
fields.trailText: February 5: IPC Southbank has appointed its first ad director for Woman & Home, Essentials and Family Circle.
fields.body:
IPC Southbank has appointed Amanda Pitt as its first ad director for Woman & Home, Essentials and Family Circle.

Emap Elan is planning to take Empire and its entertainment title Heat onto TV.

Cisco Systems has put its £4m corporate media planning and buying account up for review.

Jill Thomas has joined the Manchester media independent Media Vision.

AMS is understood to have seized the £1.5m Lavaza media planning and buying account from Booth Lockett Makin.

IPC Ignite has split its magazines into two sales portfolios - lifestyle and music.

Eurobusiness has announced the appointment of Julian Barrett as ad director.

IPC Connect is rumoured to be preparing another of its Now Star Diet & Fitness specials as a spoiler to Emap's launch of Celebrity Bodies.

fields.headline: Russell killer appeals
fields.trailText: Double murderer Michael Stone today began a legal challenge to his convictions for killing Lin and Megan Russell.
fields.body:
Double murderer Michael Stone today began a legal challenge to his convictions for killing Lin and Megan Russell.

Stone, 40, was flanked by three security officers as he sat in the dock.at the court of appeal.

Dressed casually, he answered only to his name as the proceedings began before Lord Justice Kennedy, sitting with Mr Justice Maurice Kay and Mrs Justice Hallett.

The start of the hearing had been delayed for around 30 minutes after the prison van taking him to court became stuck in heavy traffic due to the London Underground strike.

Stone was given three life sentences at Maidstone crown court in 1998 for the murders of Lin Russell and her six-year-old daughter, Megan, and the attempted murder of Megan's sister, Josie, then nine, near their home at Chillenden, Kent.

But he has always insisted he is innocent and is challenging the convictions on grounds including the way DNA tests were used and non-disclosure of evidence. The hearing is expected to last two to three days.

Stone, from Gillingham, Kent, is represented by William Clegg QC. Nigel Sweeney QC is acting for the Crown.

Before the appeal began, Stone's sister Barbara, 38, said: "Michael has always maintained his innocence. We have waited a long time to be able to prove to the courts that this is so.

"We are very hopeful of the convictions being quashed and that the British legal system proves to be just."

webTitle: Asda eyes up Kwik-Fit style repair market

fields.headline: Asda eyes up Kwik-Fit style repair market
fields.trailText:
1pm update: Asda is looking into the possibility of launching Kwik-Fit style tyre and exhaust repair businesses, writes Julia Day.
February 5: Asda launches cut-price jewellery range
fields.body:
Asda is looking into the possibility of launching Kwik-Fit style car tyre and exhaust repair businesses.

The revelation comes the day Asda announced it was rolling out in-store jewellery shops, following the lead of its parent company, US retailing giant Wal-Mart, which has sold jewellery since 1962.

In the US Wal-Mart operates what it calls "tyre and lube" centres at its stores, which are similar to Kwik-Fit operations, according to an Asda spokeswoman.

She said: "Tyre and lube is the only other thing that the US does and we (the UK) don't. It is something we are looking at to decide whether to go into it.

"But there are no plans to launch tyre and lube in the UK at present."

Asda has created a new speciality division looking after the jewellery, photo, optical and pharmacy areas and innovations such as tyre and lube.

Speciality division head David Miles has approached watch manufacturers such as Calvin Klein about stocking their brands in Asda's jewellery shops, but has been turned down by at least one.

Swatch told Miles that its watches had "attitude" and needed to be sold in an appropriate environment. Asda says it is more interested in value than attitude and will source designer watches on the grey market.

Asda is persistent in its use of the grey market for a variety of products, from fragrances to household cleaners.

Tesco went to the European Court of Justice in January for its right to sell cut-price Levi jeans against the manufacturer's wishes.

The case, which has taken two years to reach court, is seen as a test of whether makers of luxury products can dictate where and how their brands are sold.

fields.headline: RTL eyes FTSE 100 after Bertelsmann deal
fields.trailText:
1:15pm update: RTL is aiming for a place in the FTSE 100 after key shareholder Bertelsmann took a controlling stake, writes Dan Milmo.

Feb 5: Bertelsmann ups RTL stake
fields.body:
RTL is aiming for a place in the flagship FTSE 100 index after key shareholder Bertelsmann took a controlling stake in the broadcast group.

Only 11% of RTL's shares are listed on the London Stock Exchange, barring it from entering the main share listings.

Bertelsmann is planning to increase the amount of available shares, or the "free float" after raising its holding in RTL to 67% following a deal with Belgium's Groupe Bruxelles Lambert.

A spokesman for Pearson group, the UK media company which owns 22% of RTL, confirmed the intention to get the broadcaster into the FTSE 100.

"Getting the free float above 15% is very important to us because it enables us to qualify for the FTSE. Our priority is to ensure that happens," said the spokesman.

However, some analysts said Pearson, which publishes the Financial Times newspaper and has a strong presence in the educational publishing market, may follow GBL out of the door.

"The next stage will probably be the Pearson stake. There are no synergies with educational publishing whatsoever, and it would be more stabilising for Pearson's stock if the company was to get out," said Nicola Stewart, media analyst at Commerzbank.

Selling the £2bn stake would give Pearson the cash to make further acquisitions in the education sector. German media group Bertelsmann would be the favourite to buy the stake.

Pearson's shares fell 1% to 1585p in early trading, well below their high of nearly 2100p in September last year.

Relevant story Feb 5: Bertelsmann ups RTL stake

webTitle: Media: Hollywood directors shooting British ads

fields.headline: Get ready to buy a car from a star
fields.standfirst: Big-name stars do ads, so why not directorial giants? UK advertising agencies are looking to Hollywood's celebrity directors for commercial inspiration. By  Belinda Archer
fields.trailText: Big-name stars do ads, so why not directorial giants? UK advertising agencies are looking to Hollywood's celebrity directors for commercial inspiration. By Belinda Archer.
fields.body:
Fancy getting Oliver Stone to direct one of your commercials? Or how about Hugh Hudson? Maybe even Dennis Hopper or Anjelica Huston or, just imagine, Woody Allen.

For decades UK advertising agencies have been hiring celebrities to star in their ads - everyone from top-flight footballers to the shiniest of supermodels and hot new TV chefs. But, as of this week, agencies will be more readily able to access big-name Hollywood directors to make the ads themselves.

A new company is being launched which aims to link celebrity directorial talent with British agencies for one-off advertising projects. The company, called Top Dog, is the creation of RSA Films, the TV commercials arm of the directorial giants Ridley and Tony Scott.

Between them, the Scott brothers have made numerous award-winning commercials for Orange, Barclays, Foster's and Apple, as well as feature films ranging from Thelma and Louise, Blade Runner and Alien to Gladiator and the upcoming Hannibal. But now they are going to harness their power in Hollywood for the benefit, or otherwise, of the British commercials market.

Adrian Harrison, the managing director of RSA Films, explains: "We have always been seen as a form of conduit with Hollywood because of Ridley's and Tony's connections - between them they know everyone over there. We often just seem to get the calls when agencies want to access celebrity directors as well as certain stars in front of the cameras, so we are now formalising that and capitalising on it."

In addition to being able to tap into the wealth of the Scott brothers' fancy contacts, Top Dog will also benefit from being run by Kate Driver, the older sister of the actress Minnie. An experienced commercials as well as features producer based in Los Angeles, Driver frequents the sort of social gatherings that boast the biggest of celebrity guests from the film industry.

Demand for the use of top directors has certainly been growing. At the end of last year Trevor Beattie, executive creative director of TBWA, solicited the help of the famously weird David Lynch to direct the launch commercial for Sony's PlayStation 2. The ambitious Barclays "big" ads of last year, featuring Sir Anthony Hopkins, Tim Roth and Robbie Coltrane, were all directed by Tony Scott himself, while Allen has just been used to film an ad for Telecom Italia (in which he also stars) and Hudson has filmed Nelson Mandela for Unicef.

Leagas Delaney creative director Tim Delaney, who hired Tony Scott to direct the Barclays ads, comments: "You just don't get that polished look from commercials directors. Tony makes features like commercials. There is a real attention to detail and to the fact that you've got to cram a lot of story-telling in. The Barclays ads were immaculate films, and the whole experience was fantastic."

To hire a "celebrity" director need not be prohibitively expensive. Commercials directors are paid pretty handsomely anyway (anything between £5,000 and £10,000 per shoot day for an average UK director) so the extra expense of using a big name, at an estimated cost of between £17,000 to £23,000 per day, might not seem too lavish. And if you are already shelling out for a top model or some famous talent then it is possibly a good insurance policy to hire a director of similar stature.

In addition, the spin-off PR could alleviate the expense, if not generate extra media coverage way beyond that which could have been achieved without the star name. Beattie secured enviable column inches for his PlayStation commercial, for instance, regardless of whether it was any good or whether Lynch's involvement made any difference to the average viewer.

But celebrity directors have also become big names for a reason: they are talented film-makers, often known for a particular look or style. While you obviously wouldn't bring in Stone to do a table-top (adspeak for static, studio-based commercial with endless close-ups of food products), you might well want him if you are going after an ambitious, cast-of-thousands filmic look.

Delaney adds: "If you use a celebrity director you've got to want them to express themselves. You've got to let them go and you must be bringing them in for the right reasons - you have to buy the talent, not the name."

Perhaps most useful of all, though, is that celebrity directors can oil the negotiations for securing celebrity names in front of the camera. Just as stars can be picky about who does their make-up and hair, so they can fuss over who is going to be ultimately responsible for how they appear on film. In short, if you want a big name you've often got to have a big director.

Harrison of RSA comments: "Tony [Scott] got Anthony Hopkins for Barclays and he also recently filmed Marlon Brando in another commercial. Marlon only agreed to do it because he was going to be directed by an A-list director. A jobbing English director would probably either not have got him in the first place, or else would have been eaten alive." Driver is now busily signing up hefty names for Top Dog. So far she has bagged, among others, Huston, Stone, Hudson, Roth, Diane Keaton and Gary Oldman, but others will follow.

You may wonder what's in it for the likes of such premier league Hollywood talent to dip their toes in the grubby world of UK commercials, but they seem to be queuing up.

A major attraction is the relatively luxurious experience of having three whole days to film just one minute, instead of the average feature film shooting-pace of four to five minutes a day. Another is that doing a commercial can keep the directors busy and give them the buzz of being behind a camera in between film projects.

"I have a wish list and I have zoned in on people I think would make the transition," says Driver. "We've already got a varied list of directors, some of whom are good at dialogue, some action, some really offbeat. All of them are proven as directors, if not necessarily commercials directors, but a lot of directors have made the transition and a commercial is really just a mini-movie anyway."

Indeed, RSA is not alone in signing up heavyweights. Anthony Minghella, who directed and adapted The English Patient, has been signed to the Paul Weiland Film Company for several years, while Guy Ritchie has just signed to the same company (possibly prompted by his advertising creative father, John). The Waking Ned director Kirk Jones has recently signed to Tomboy Films.

It may well not be plain sailing, however, and some wonder whether Hollywood can hack it over here. They criticise features directors for wanting to shoot "big" all the time and for not knowing enough about concentrated story-telling, while availability will be a problem as well as the vagaries of the UK advertising scene.

"I'm under no illusions. It's a two-way process because not only will it be about educating agencies on how to use these directors, we've also got to educate the directors themselves about the process of British advertising," cautions Harrison.

Hopefully it will all work nicely, though. And maybe punters can look forward with relish to the prospect of Francis Ford Coppola doing a nice pasta sauce commercial, or a wide-boy cockney heist ad for De Beers filmed by Ritchie. If they're not making movies, that is ...

webTitle: Foster withdrawal has Cannes in a panic

fields.headline: Foster withdrawal has Cannes in a panic
fields.trailText: Jodie Foster's decision to take the lead role in David Fincher's Panic Room means that the actress no longer has time to be jury president at this year's Cannes Film Festival
fields.body:
Jodie Foster's eleventh-hour withdrawal from jury duty at this year's Cannes Film Festival has left the organisers of the world's premiere film showcase with a major headache. The actress - a fluent French-speaker and star of the 1976 Cannes winner Taxi Driver - had been confirmed as the jury president for this year's event, which runs from May 9-20.

But at the last minute Foster opted to throw the festival over for the lead role in David (Fight Club) Fincher's siege thriller Panic Room. The actress has been drafted in to replace original star Nicole Kidman, who last week retired two weeks into filming after aggravating a knee injury she suffered on the set of Moulin Rouge. According to unconfirmed reports circling in Hollywood, Foster will be paid $12m (£8.15m) for the role. Panic Room will not finish filming until after the Cannes Film Festival.

Apologising for her decision, 38-year-old Foster claimed that she was "mortified" and expressed her wish that she might still serve as president at some stage in the future. "I hope with all my heart that this is only a postponement," she said. In a statement released yesterday, Cannes chief Gilles Jacob admitted that: "Since shooting continues in May, Jodie has asked us to postpone her presidency for another year. The embarrassment and regret she has expressed match the level of our disappointment, but everybody understands that for an actress her work comes first."

But Jacob's gracious words mask a sudden crisis. Variety quotes an inside source as complaining that a new president may throw the balance of the entire jury out and force a major overhaul of this year's festival. "It's a real pain," the source said.

fields.headline: Popstars double cheers ITV
fields.trailText: 12.30pm TV overnights: A double-helping of Popstars with both shows topping 10m viewers propelled ITV to its best Saturday peaktime of the year, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
A double-helping of Popstars, with both shows topping 10m viewers, propelled ITV to its best Saturday peaktime of the year.

Saturday night's two instalments of Popstars began at 6.45pm with a 30-minute recap of how the 10 remaining hopefuls had got to that stage.

From 9.15pm over 60 minutes, the judges travelled to the homes of the final 10 to reveal the good and bad news.

Popstars cemented its position as the biggest TV phenomenon since Channel 4's Big Brother, with the first show pulling in 10.9m and a 49% share, and the second 11.6m and 47%.

The BBC1 opposition from 6.45pm, Jim Davidson's Generation Game, had 6.2m.

The 9.15pm instalment of Popstars was up against a Jonathan Creek repeat, which drew 5.7m; and Simon Nye-scripted vet sitcom Beast, which managed just 3.9m.

The Popstars effect also benefited ITV's Weekend News, which followed the second show at 10.15pm.

The bulletin had a whopping 9m and a 39% share, double the audience of BBC1's News and Sport, which started 10 minutes later.

Overall, ITV had an average audience of 10.4m and a 43% share of peaktime viewing from 7-10.30pm on Saturday.

BBC1 had just 6.6m and a 27% share.

webTitle: The heyday of the hack'n'slash teen flick

fields.headline: What no massacre?
fields.standfirst: Beginning his weekly review of US movie releases,  John Patterson gets nostalgic for the heyday of the hack'n'slash teen flick
fields.trailText: Beginning his weekly review of US movie releases, John Patterson gets nostalgic for the heyday of the hack'n'slash teen flick
fields.body:
Saint Valentine's Day is the diametric opposite of Halloween, yet in movie terms they have a lot in common. They are the twin solstices of Hollywood's teen release schedule: the idyllic, hand-holding noontime of young love versus the black midnight of onrushing death and the lately upraised legions of the damned. But love's no fun without the spectre of death lurking somewhere; likewise, death is more fun when you season it with a little exploitative sex.

So elements of the Valentine's Day movie and the Halloween movie are always seeping from one to the other and back again. The hack'n'slash boom of the late 1970s, inaugurated by John Carpenter's Halloween, not only dripped with inventively disgorged plasma and viscera, it fairly hummed with teenage hormones and libidinal turmoil. Sadly, the price of teen tumescence usually meant being impaled on a portcullis or a weathervane before you got those post-orgasmic fags lit. Your average drippy Love Story knock-off, on the other hand, sees young love stalked by encroaching death, usually in the form of a disease with no discernible symptoms, since romance tends to wilt somewhat when you introduce chemo or amputation or open-heart surgery to the mix.

Although Valentine's Day is still nine days away, the studios are already chasing its teen adher ents with all the vigour of the Hallmark Greeting Card Company. Next week sees the arrival of the Love Story variant on the theme - Keanu Reeves and Charlize Theron in Sweet November - but the horror variant, Valentine, opened this weekend.

I freely confess I'm a well-adjusted child of the 1970s hack'n'slash generation. Our idols were George Romero, Tobe Hooper, early Wes Craven, make-up supremo Tom Savini, Carpenter, and Sean Cunningham, father of the Friday the 13th franchise. Our benchmark movies were Dawn of the Dead, Last House on the Left, Prom Night and Black Christmas. Our nightmares teemed with entrail-hungry zombies, heads split by axes, nubile girls fleeing large men with buzzsaws or electric turkey knives, and teenage unknowns like Kevin Bacon getting harpoons shoved through their throats. We didn't think much of Scream - too clever by half. The genre needed its innate dumbness to flourish; it needed all the tireless sexism and grand guignol violence that the film-makers could muster, just to pack all those beautiful, long-gone drive-in theatres.

It says something for my high expectations that I felt compelled to rewatch the entirely unremarkable 1980 Canadian horror flick My Bloody Valentine as preparation. Well, Valentine wasn't fit to kiss the blood off My Bloody Valentine's hands, frankly. It's neither violent enough nor scary enough, so what's the point? Worse, it's incoherent, presumably thanks to extensive test screenings and the crude palmprints of no less than four writers. And none of them noticed they'd more or less rewritten National Lampoon's Class Reunion, another terrible movie.

It's the familiar story of jilted high school love producing a string of grisly murders many years later. The story isn't strong enough to survive without some leering, gratuitous nudity or a few eyeballs on skewers, and neither are there any satiric ambitions to enhance it.

One of its co-stars, Marley Shelton, also appears in the most likable movie out now, Sugar and Spice, about a group of cheerleaders who start robbing banks. It's pitched at the same teen demographic as Valentine, but seems to understand its mindset: it's filled with adorably dumb and innocent characters, but never sneers at them. Valentine doesn't exactly patronise its characters, but it certainly patronises its targeted ticket-buyers.

The other teen outing this week was Head Over Heels, starring Freddie Prinze Jr and a quartet of airhead supermodels. Prinze's father, comedian Freddie Sr, was one of the first Latino stars on US TV in the early 1970s, before he blew his brains out in a maelstrom of coke and Lenny Bruce delusions. Freddie Jr isn't associated with the Latino boom of the late 1990s, despite his family connections, and his handlers have pitched him as just another deracinated white boy. He makes the kind of movies you'd expect: anaemic romantic comedies for the Britney Spears fanbase.

In limited release, we have Wim Wenders' The Million Dollar Hotel, an almost unwatchable aesthetic catastrophe. Wenders was once an idol of mine - right up until the last 10 minutes of Wings of Desire. For me, his Kings of the Road, The American Friend and The State of Things have always been desert island movies: elliptical, beautifully shot, and teeming with ideas. Back then Wenders was working with serious writers like Peter Handke and Robert Kramer; The Million Dollar Hotel is based on an idea by Bono.

It's another stage in the seemingly unstoppable decline of one of the world's great manipulators of celluloid - grim evidence of what hanging out with too many colourless rock stars will do. I was better off watching Valentine, I swear.

webTitle: Media: New film channel The Studio

fields.headline: Universal appeal?
fields.standfirst: How many new film channels can the market support? The Studio, a newly launched provider, aims to prove it doesn't need Sky to survive.  Matt Wells  talks to Janet Goldsmith, its movie-loving boss
fields.trailText: How many new film channels can the market support? The Studio, a newly launched provider, aims to prove it doesn't need Sky to survive. Matt Wells talks to Janet Goldsmith, its movie-loving boss.
fields.body:
There's something about the launch of a new film channel that seems far more exciting than the birth of a sub-QVC shopping network or a glorified dating agency. Maybe it's the lure of Hollywood glamour or the romanticism of a night in front of the telly with popcorn and Humphrey Bogart that makes it all seem a little more classy than your average digital channel conception.

Certainly that's the image that the men and women behind Vivendi-Universal's new venture, The Studio, would like to project. It's a "movie channel for movie lovers", says its movie-loving boss, Janet Goldsmith.

The Studio launched in a blaze of publicity (well, a hurriedly-organised party in east London) last Thursday. It certainly looked like a classy project - full of background report shows, film news programmes and "personal view" inserts between the films. All, says Goldsmith, to give the channel "a context". So, not to pad out the films, then. Never mind that the first movie to be screened was the sickly children's feature Babe, this is an intelligent channel for a broad audience, we are told.

Goldsmith is keen to stress that The Studio will have a universal appeal. "This is not a channel for buffs, it is a channel for movie lovers," she says again. "It will have the best films, new and old, put into context for the audience and well-scheduled."

The problem is that not very many people can watch it at the moment. The Studio has secured a carriage deal only with NTL - and while the channel boasts that this gives it access to 2.2m viewers, the fact is that The Studio really needs to be on Sky Digital if it is to have any hope of making an impact. Otherwise, say some analysts, it is destined for the same division as Carlton Cinema rather than the Sky Digital premier league.

Executives at The Studio deny that the lack of a deal with Sky is a problem. They are in negotiations with all carriers, and hope to conclude deals soon. The problem is that Sky is in no hurry to carry a basic-package competitor to its cash-generating premium channel offerings.

Carriage deals notwithstanding, Universal believes that its new venture - which has already been launched in France and Italy - will be a winner in Britain. Certainly, it is a new way of offering movies, as it is the first general movie channel to be launched directly by a mainstream Hollywood studio.

Until now, the movie moguls have concentrated on selling their products to pay-TV networks such as Sky; channels such as The Studio, the theory goes, should change the face of the film channel market, forcing pay-TV suppliers to settle for deals that are more advantageous to the big film distributors.

But there appears to be an inherent contradiction in the idea. Universal cannot simply stop doing deals with pay-TV operators and terrestrial networks because these operators dominate the viewing market. There is no chance that Universal will cut off its own lifeblood by signing over all its blockbusters to its own TV channel. The Studio, consequently, must conclude deals with other distributors to shore up its offering.

Universal's president of acquisitions, Graeme Mason, rejects the suggestion that launching a film network, while continuing to deal with pay-TV networks and terrestrial channels, is a contradictory business proposition. "I don't think the two positions are mutually exclusive. We will continue to do deals with Sky, and the terrestrial channels. At the moment, we have films running on BBC1, BBC2, ITV and Channel 4, and that will continue." The film distribution business will operate at "arm's length" from the television channel, he says.

Mason identifies a broader aim, saying that the channel will help increase the audiences for film, not just on multi-channel television, but in cinemas too, which would be to the commercial advantage of everyone. "We want to take advantage of people's interest in film. Last year saw a 28-year box office high in British cinemas. If this helps to increase the level of interest in cinema, then that's good for Universal as a whole," he says.

Observers believe that the key to The Studio's success will be the quality of films that it offers to viewers. At the moment, the channel has a bank of 1,500 films that will be shown in the next three years - which, if you think about it, is little more than two a day. Goldsmith says, however, that deals are being concluded all the time, and the film bank balance will be significantly boosted.

The movies on offer at the moment include In the Name of the Father, Mona Lisa, 1492, True Lies, Chaplin, The Meaning of Life, Carlito's Way and Lord of the Flies. All quality stuff, then. There will be a contemporary blockbuster every night at 9pm - later than the traditional time of 8pm, which Goldsmith and Mason believe to be too early for most people to "commit" to a film - and themed scheduling. Sunday, for example, will be family day. But what does contemporary mean? "Post-1970," says Goldsmith. One wonders whether re-runs of Rollerball will be quite what viewers regard as contemporary - but Goldsmith denies that the Studio will be a film equivalent of "gold" radio. "This is not a nostalgia channel," she says.

Goldsmith insists that plans for the channel are ambitious, but concedes that she is in a tough game. FilmFour, for example, is finding it hard going, losing £20m in 1999 and not expecting to break even until 2003. And the competition is about to intensify, with the launch of more FilmFour channels. It was announced on Friday that FilmFourWorld, a channel devoted to foreign language films, and FilmFour Extreme, featuring more controversial films, will launch in April.

"It is very difficult to stand out in this market, you have to build a strong brand," says Goldsmith. "With the multi-channel audience, the trick is to address the audiences at the relvant parts of the day. You need a schedule that is defined, and easy to navigate. And it's very important to deliver a simple, clear message to the audience."

Goldsmith says that the NTL deal - the cable operator is a major investor - is an indicator of confidence. "We convinced NTL that this was worth investing in, and that was no mean feat," she says. But Universal is in it for the long game. "Building a success of something, that takes a long time. But we aim to spend the first year really trying to make it work. We will take risks, and not everything is going to work, but there are so many areas to explore."

webTitle: Labour under fire over new logo

fields.headline: Labour under fire over 'brutish' new logo
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Michael Wolff, creator of Labour's red rose symbol, has dismissed the party's new logo as a "brutish-looking thing". By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Michael Wolff, creator of Labour's iconic red rose symbol, has dismissed the party's new logo as a "brutish-looking thing".

Mr Wolff, a partner at brand consultancy The Fourth Room, said the new emblem - a combination of a cross and a heart -- was playing into the hands of those who criticised Labour as a triumph of style over substance.

"The Labour party has no problem being recognised as it is - it is a fantastically strong brand," said Mr Wolff.

"This feels like new broom-ism. When we came up with the rose, everyone really believed in it and there was a feeling it stood for something. It felt right to the party. No one but a professional communicator could say this feels right."

But even the professional communicators were today unconvinced by the symbol, which adorns a new array of Labour merchandise.

Rita Clifton, chief executive of branding consultancy Interbrand, said the strategy behind the logo was too transparent.

"There are so many allusions here it feels a bit like a quiz," she said. "The cross is obviously a reference to voting, then the heart suggests voting with your heart, which makes it feel like a campaign device."

Ms Clifton also said the logo looked overly familiar.

"You feel like you must have seen it somewhere before," she said.

"It looks a bit like one of the ribbons you get on charity logos - the breast cancer or the Aids ribbon. That gives it the feel of a charity, which you may or may not think is appropriate."

Dan Bobby, a senior consultant with the brand consultancy Wolff Olins, said it was a mistake to introduce a new symbol this close to an election.

"It doesn't resonate at all and I think it just confuses the issue," he said. "As symbols go, the red rose seems like a pretty good one. People like it, and they know what it stands for. Bringing in something new might backfire if people see it as more spin."

The Labour party said: "The head represents the dedication to policies that improve the quality of life, policies such as the national minimum wage and New Deal. The heart stands for our enduring belief in fairness and equality. The cross symbolises the importance of voting, and voting Labour."

There has been speculation for some time that the party may ditch its red rose symbol, adopted in the mid-eighties when Neil Kinnock was party leader and Peter Mandelson was director of communications.

The departure of Mr Mandelson from the cabinet may make it easier for Labour to change the logo he sanctioned.

The new logo was created by a team of designers at the party's Millbank headquarters and will be used in addition to the red rose. Labour supporters can buy the logo on keyrings, stickers, mugs, cufflinks and t-shirts.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The press complaints commission has thrown out a complaint against the Guardian by Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union (MSF) over an article written by David Hencke, the paper's Westminster correspondent, on huge financial cutbacks planned by the union after they spent up to £900,000 in payoffs to staff.
fields.body:
The press complaints commission has thrown out a complaint against the Guardian by Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union (MSF) over an article written by David Hencke, the paper's Westminster correspondent, on huge financial cutbacks planned by the union after they spent up to £900,000 in payoffs to staff.

The Guardian article revealed that the union's accountants had drawn up a three-year plan to save £3 million - imposing up to £400,000 in cuts in four months to balance the books. Mr Lyons had made over 80 individual complaints about the one article - and the PCC threw out all except one of them, which it said was "not significant". The letter on the PCC's decision sent to Alan Rusbridger, the editor of the Guardian, is reproduced below:

Sir,

I write further to Ms Namdjou's letter of 8 December as the Commission has now considered the complaint from MSF and Roger Lyons. The objections raised were reviewed within the context of the article as a whole, taking into consideration the requirements of the Code of Practice.

After review the Commission has decided that no matters have been raised which show a breach of the code. Its more detailed reasons are as follows:

The Commission noted that the complainants had made a number of specific allegations of inaccuracy about the article, but that at its heart the complaint was an objection to a perceived implication that the union was in financial difficulty and that it was faced with taking drastic measures to avert a crisis.

The Commission is not in a position, and does not seek, to be able to discern the facts of a matter behind a newspaper article, but is rather charged with ascertaining whether material has been obtained and published in accordance with the Code of Practice. Clause 1 of the Code requires, among other things, publications to 'take care not to publish inaccurate, misleading or distorted material' and also to distinguish between comment, conjecture and fact. It also calls for newspapers to correct 'significant' inaccuracies.

It appeared to the Commission that your newspaper largely had material on which to base the allegations contained in the article. The minutes of the numerous meetings of the GPFC seemed to confirm the involvement of the accountants in discussing options for making large savings between 2001-2003 and recorded that following a presentation to the GPFC there had been a discussion about how such savings could be achieved. While the complainants maintained that this did not amount to an 'emergency savings package' such a description was clearly your newspaper's view of the matter, as was the term 'unpalatable' to describe the options before the union. The precise time at which the proposals had been discussed was not in the context of the article a matter of significance under the Code. Similarly, complaints relating to whether or not the report could be considered to be confidential, or even a 'report', were not matters of significance.

The minutes (of the meeting on 21 September 2000) had also recorded that all necessary action was to be taken 'to curb expenditure to reduce any end of year deficit to the minimum' and the accountants' indication that there would be a deficit for the year of £400,000. While the complaints had objected to some of the language used to describe the union's financial position by your newspaper, the Commission concluded that your paper had grounds to justify its description of the situation.

It was also clear - and both parties accepted - that the journalist had confidential sources from which he had obtained further information. It was the Commission's job to establish the veracity of the claims made by such sources - upon which the journalist had based some of the claims in the article - but it considered that in the context of the rest of the article and the available on the record evidence that the complainants had not established that the presentation of the material obtained from sources was a breach of the Code. Such claims included the remark of a senior officer that the union was facing a financial crisis; the suggestion that property might have to be sold; the suggestion that staff cuts were being proposed and the statement that the scrapping of a number of initiatives had been discussed. Although the union had another view of whether such proposals had in fact been discussed, the Commission noted that the article had not said that the proposals were anything other than 'options' that had been 'discussed'. It was your newspaper's case that such discussions may not have been minuted or had been discussed outside the GPFC and the Commission could not see any way of resolving the different positions of the parties, given that they rested on assertion and counter-assertion and not any firm evidence.

Regarding the complaint about the union's position on the website, the Commission noted that while no legal action was now planned the union had sought legal advice about the site but that the advice was that nothing could be done. The Commission therefore found no breach of the Code in the article's statement that 'lawyers are also being asked to take action to close down [the] website'. Neither did the Commission consider that a breach of the Code had been established concerning the reporting of the cost of employment cases; your newspaper had shown how it had arrived at its figure of £900,000 and there appeared to have been a number of settlements resulting in the union paying out significant sums of money to individuals. Although these settlements may not literally have followed tribunals nor involved admissions of liability there appeared to be no doubt that they had been made and the Commission did not consider that there was a material inaccuracy in referring to them as 'employment tribunal cases'.

The Commission noted the complainants' position that the reference to a projected increase in pensions contribution from 6% to 19% had been based on the possibility that the payments holiday would end and that this was by no means certain to happen. However, as your paper had pointed out, the figures had been included in the minutes which recorded that one of the key issues that had to be addressed by the union was that "by the end of the forward projection period set out in the presentation, the pension fund contributions 'holiday' may not apply, necessitating a rise in contributions from 6% to 19%". In light of the inclusion of these precise figures in the minutes and the assertion that it was a key issue that required consideration by the union the Commission did not consider that there was any material inaccuracy in the reference to the pension contributions in the article.
