fields.bodyText: The press complaints commission has thrown out a complaint against the Guardian by Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union (MSF) over an article written by David Hencke, the paper's Westminster correspondent, on huge financial cutbacks planned by the union after they spent up to £900,000 in payoffs to staff. The Guardian article revealed that the union's accountants had drawn up a three-year plan to save £3 million - imposing up to £400,000 in cuts in four months to balance the books. Mr Lyons had made over 80 individual complaints about the one article - and the PCC threw out all except one of them, which it said was "not significant". The letter on the PCC's decision sent to Alan Rusbridger, the editor of the Guardian, is reproduced below: Sir, I write further to Ms Namdjou's letter of 8 December as the Commission has now considered the complaint from MSF and Roger Lyons. The objections raised were reviewed within the context of the article as a whole, taking into consideration the requirements of the Code of Practice. After review the Commission has decided that no matters have been raised which show a breach of the code. Its more detailed reasons are as follows: The Commission noted that the complainants had made a number of specific allegations of inaccuracy about the article, but that at its heart the complaint was an objection to a perceived implication that the union was in financial difficulty and that it was faced with taking drastic measures to avert a crisis. The Commission is not in a position, and does not seek, to be able to discern the facts of a matter behind a newspaper article, but is rather charged with ascertaining whether material has been obtained and published in accordance with the Code of Practice. Clause 1 of the Code requires, among other things, publications to 'take care not to publish inaccurate, misleading or distorted material' and also to distinguish between comment, conjecture and fact. It also calls for newspapers to correct 'significant' inaccuracies. It appeared to the Commission that your newspaper largely had material on which to base the allegations contained in the article. The minutes of the numerous meetings of the GPFC seemed to confirm the involvement of the accountants in discussing options for making large savings between 2001-2003 and recorded that following a presentation to the GPFC there had been a discussion about how such savings could be achieved. While the complainants maintained that this did not amount to an 'emergency savings package' such a description was clearly your newspaper's view of the matter, as was the term 'unpalatable' to describe the options before the union. The precise time at which the proposals had been discussed was not in the context of the article a matter of significance under the Code. Similarly, complaints relating to whether or not the report could be considered to be confidential, or even a 'report', were not matters of significance. The minutes (of the meeting on 21 September 2000) had also recorded that all necessary action was to be taken 'to curb expenditure to reduce any end of year deficit to the minimum' and the accountants' indication that there would be a deficit for the year of £400,000. While the complaints had objected to some of the language used to describe the union's financial position by your newspaper, the Commission concluded that your paper had grounds to justify its description of the situation. It was also clear - and both parties accepted - that the journalist had confidential sources from which he had obtained further information. It was the Commission's job to establish the veracity of the claims made by such sources - upon which the journalist had based some of the claims in the article - but it considered that in the context of the rest of the article and the available on the record evidence that the complainants had not established that the presentation of the material obtained from sources was a breach of the Code. Such claims included the remark of a senior officer that the union was facing a financial crisis; the suggestion that property might have to be sold; the suggestion that staff cuts were being proposed and the statement that the scrapping of a number of initiatives had been discussed. Although the union had another view of whether such proposals had in fact been discussed, the Commission noted that the article had not said that the proposals were anything other than 'options' that had been 'discussed'. It was your newspaper's case that such discussions may not have been minuted or had been discussed outside the GPFC and the Commission could not see any way of resolving the different positions of the parties, given that they rested on assertion and counter-assertion and not any firm evidence. Regarding the complaint about the union's position on the website, the Commission noted that while no legal action was now planned the union had sought legal advice about the site but that the advice was that nothing could be done. webTitle: Comment: A nation of food slobs

fields.headline: A nation of food slobs
fields.standfirst:
It's official: we are currently enduring an epidemic of food poisoning. But we may only have ourselves to blame, writes food editor Matthew Fort

Download the FSA's full report (pdf file)
Special report: What's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Comment: It's official: we are currently enduring an epidemic of food poisoning. But we may only have ourselves to blame, writes restaurant critic Matthew Fort.
fields.body:
Five million people in the UK fell victim to food poisoning last year, according to a report published today by the food standards agency.

Fourteen percent of the sample of 3,100 people interviewed between October and December 2000 said they had suffered from vomiting or diarrhoea, which they felt could be attributed to food. This is far in excess of the official statistics.

Well, blow me down. I know that the NHS is in crisis, but I didn't know that we had come to self-diagnosis. Perhaps now that we are all trained on a diet of medical soaps, we can tell the difference from diarrhoea caused by food poisoning, a virus or plain overeating.

However, even if this figure were to be taken seriously, it throws no light at all on the source of the poisonings. The FSA research goes on to detail at some length the fears of the 3,100 people who were interviewed, about the safety of raw meat (69%), of meat in market stalls (56%), butchers (25%), supermarkets (21 %) and the home (19%), among many other quite legitimate concerns.

But people's attitudes tell us nothing about the realities of hygiene in any of these places. Above all, it doesn't tell us how many food poisoning cases are caused by the food-producing or food-retailing part of the food chain, and how much is caused by filthy habits at home.

The FSA may well argue that the research is only into consumer attitudes, not into fact. The trouble is that the way the data is presented, it is treated as fact.

A year ago, I attended a conference of paediatric gastro-enterologists, the people who have to deal with the effects of diet on children. One of the startling pieces of information that came out of it is how many of the poisoning cases are caused by the fact that our systems are no longer resistant to even quite mild bugs because food production is now so hygienic.

Indeed, so concerned are the authorities in Sweden, that cleanest of clean countries, that they have been experimenting with inoculating children with tiny amounts of E coli bacteria to stimulate the development of infant immune systems.

The remotely controversial piece of information in the rest of the survey is that it confirms the low incidence of vegetarianism in the UK ­ only 5% of the sample admitted to having a vegetarian in the house, although 7% include someone who is "mainly vegetarian", whatever that may mean.

This leaves 93% of the population staunchly carnivorous, which may come as something of a surprise given the disproportionate amount of space devoted to vegetarian eating in the media.

Indeed, reading the report in full merely confirms how resistant the British are to advice from well-meaning bodies. Our eating habits are as atrocious as they ever were, if for contemporary reasons. We still eat too much fat, sugar and things that are bad for us, and too little fruit, veg and the things that are good for us.

The difference from, say, ten or 15 years ago, is that we cook very little of this food ourselves, but buy it ready-made, packed with fat, sugar, air, water and those chemicals beloved of the food manufacturing industry.

In fact, the FSA report, for all its spelling out of contemporary concerns, merely confirms that we are, as we have always been when it comes to food matters, dirty, dishonest and lazy.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are right behind the striking Tube drivers
fields.trailText: Tottenham have asked Glenn Hoddle to become their new manager, according to sources close to the club's new owners, ENIC. However, the Southampton boss has turned down the offer: he wanted a £25m transfer kitty but ENIC are only prepared to set aside £10m for new players.
fields.body:
Tottenham have asked Glenn Hoddle to become their new manager, according to sources close to the club's new owners, ENIC. However, the Southampton boss has turned down the offer: he wanted a £25m transfer kitty but ENIC are only prepared to set aside £10m for new players.

Coventry are looking for a "helper" for boss Gordon Strachan, according to a report in the Daily Mail. But Strachan is not happy at the plans and would quit if such a figure is imposed on him. Birmingham boss Trevor Francis is the first person to be linked with the Venablesesque post.

Bayern Munich midfielder Thomas Strunz is on a week's trial at Manchester City, reports Planet Football. The 32-year-old former German international midfielder is available on a free transfer and would like to complete a permanent move to Maine Road, although Bundesliga sides 1860 Munich and Cologne will tempt him to stay in Germany.

Charlton, Manchester City and Bradford are all interested in Hearts captain Colin Cameron. The Scottish international midfielder is available for £2m.

Sheffield Wednesday striker Andy Booth, currently on loan at Tottenham, will leave Hillsborough at the end of the season on a Bosman free, according to the Sun. His destination? As if you didn't know: he's going to join arch-rivals Sheffield United.

The Sun go on to report that Sheffield United are also in the running for Gillingham striker Carl Asaba, who is out of contract in the summer.

Southampton are giving a trial to Norwegian defensive duo Helge Haugen and Jon Peder Gjesdal, who play for Norwegian Second Division club Asane, reports Planet Football.

Planet Football also claims that Fulham are on the verge of making a bid for West Ham defender Ian Pearce.

fields.headline: Briton 'admits' Saudi bombings
fields.trailText: Saudi Arabian television viewers last night saw three westerners confess to two car bombings which killed a Briton and injured several others.
fields.body:
Saudi Arabian television viewers last night saw three westerners confess to two car bombings which killed a Briton and injured several others.

Alexander Mitchell, from Britain, said the three men had been obeying orders when they carried out the two blasts in the Saudi capital Riyadh, but did not say who had given the orders.

Human rights watchdogs have expressed concern about the confessions, which are thought to follow lengthy detentions.

The first car bomb attack, on November 17 last year, killed Christopher Rodway, 47, from Gloucestershire, and injured his wife, Jane, 50.

Five days later a second blast injured three Britons and an Irish woman working for the Boeing-owned Al-Salam aircraft company.

In the broadcast, Mr Mitchell said that he had carried out the attacks in collaboration with William Sampson from Canada, and Raf Schifter, from Belgium.

According to an Arabic voiceover of his remarks, Mr Mitchell said: "I confirm and confess that I received orders to carry out the bombing here in Riyadh on November 17 against Christopher Rodway, a British citizen. William Sampson, a Canadian, helped me carry out the bombing."

The three men all confessed to involvement, pointing to street maps as they explained how they had set a device in Rodway's car before following him and detonating the explosive by remote control.

Saudi interior minister Prince Nayef said before the broadcast that the kingdom knew who was behind the bombings and would reveal further details at a later stage. He added that diplomats from the three countries had visited the men in custody.

Stephen Jakobi, director of the campaign group Fair Trials Abroad, said there were serious doubts about the validity of the confessions obtained by the Saudi authorities.

"We are not aware how long these three have been in custody and there has been a long row about lack of access to British prisoners," he said.

"Standard operating technique in Saudi is to beat prisoners until a confession has been obtained. We can be absolutely sure that these confessions have been obtained under circumstances that make them totally unreliable."

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said she was aware of the broadcast but could not confirm any of the details were true.

Canadian foreign affairs spokesman Oussamah Tamim said Mr Sampson had been in custody in Saudi Arabia since November and that consular officials had seen him as recently as last week. He said they had tried to assist the men earlier but were denied permission by Saudi authorities.

webTitle: British Designer of the Year award contenders

fields.headline: East End's prize designer
fields.trailText: The contenders for the British Designer of the Year award were unveiled yesterday, with Julien Macdonald, Alexander McQueen and Clements Ribeiro in the running.
fields.body:
The contenders for the British Designer of the Year award were unveiled yesterday, with Julien Macdonald, Alexander McQueen and Clements Ribeiro in the running.

McQueen, the strong favourite, is recognised as one of the greatest global talents and has scarcely been out of the fashion headlines. His Voss2001 summer collection, staged in a mirrored padded cell, earned rave reviews. But he faces strong competition.

Clements Ribeiro are a highly respected husband and wife design team whose spring/summer 2001 collection, featuring Grecian draping and grommeted leather, looks set to be one of the most influential of the season.

Macdonald, dubbed the British Donatella Versace, is a flamboyant figure who has won a celebrity following with his sensationally sexy dresses.

Outfits by the three designers were on display yesterday in Covent Garden, London. The award will be presented on February 20.

fields.headline: BBC1 set for budget boost
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Greg Dyke will today unveil plans to boost BBC1 programming budgets as part of his strategy to improve the schedules, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke will today unveil plans to boost programming budgets on BBC1 as part of his long-term strategy to improve the schedules.

One sources said an extra £70m would be made available to the channel on top of the £95m "bonus" already promised to the station as part of the cost-cutting drive announced by the director-general last year.

The announcement comes as part of an address to staff on the anniversary of Mr Dyke joining the corporation.

In a television studio in west London, Mr Dyke will outline his plans for new digital services and programming, and talk about his ongoing cost-cutting measures.

Several hundred staff from top executives to junior producers were expected to attend with special coaches laid on from central London to help staff beat the tube strike.

Mr Dyke told the BBC's Breakfast with Frost programme yesterday he had already made cost-savings of between £25m and £30m, raising speculation that he plans to announce further job cuts.

Gerry Morrissey, assistant general secretary of union Bectu, said 750 jobs cuts would be made over the next two years but these were in line with plans already announced by Mr Dyke.

"I don't believe it is a fresh announcement about redundancies. If it was, we would resist it," said Mr Morrisey.

As part of his drive to reduce duplication at the BBC, Mr Dyke announced that he planned to make 1,250 redundancies over a three-year period.

He told Sir David Frost yesterday that cutting the number of management consultants used so freely by his predecessor Lord Birt had already saved £16-17m.

Mr Dyke also admitted that the BBC was examining the possibility of taking a stake in a commercial sports channel.

webTitle: In brief: accident holds up Scorsese's Gangs of New York

fields.headline: Accident holds up Scorsese's Gangs of New York
fields.standfirst: Plus: Ted Kennedy gives thumbs up to Cuban missile crisis movie, 13 Days; The Wedding Planner stays on top in US
fields.trailText: Plus: Ted Kennedy gives thumbs up to Cuban missile crisis movie, 13 Days; The Wedding Planner stay on top in US
fields.body:
 Filming on Martin Scorsese's The Gangs of New York was halted for a day after an on-set accident left a trio of extras in hospital. The injuries occurred when a horse-drawn carriage capsized in the Villa Borghese park in Rome, harming two women and a young girl. "It was decided out of respect for them to suspend the day's shooting," said publicist Larry Kaplan. Italian news agencies, however, claim that the situation was exacerbated by a stand-off between the paparazzi and the film's star Leonardo DiCaprio (pictured), who began pelting the press with manure as they gathered to photograph the crash. Sources on set claim that DiCaprio was angered that the press were preventing medical aid from reaching the park. Yesterday, he and co-star Cameron Diaz are reported to have visited the extras in hospital.

 The Cuban missile crisis movie 13 Days grabbed another glowing review over the weekend when it was deemed "excellent" by surviving Kennedy brother Edward. The Massachusetts senator had been invited by Republican president George W Bush to a special screening of the movie (which stars Kevin Costner) at the White House. Directed by Roger Donaldson, 13 Days follows the efforts of President John F Kennedy and attorney general Robert Kennedy to prevent the Soviet Union building long-range nuclear missile bases in Castro's Cuba. After the visit, Ted Kennedy paid tribute to the film's accuracy, but confessed that he found it an emotional experience as well. "I obviously have a lot of emotions because it reminds me of my brothers," he told reporters, "and a day doesn't go by when I don't think of them."

 The dopey matrimonial rom-com The Wedding Planner clung to the top of the US box-office chart for a second week running, scooping $11m (£7.47m) from a generally quiet weekend. Starring Jennifer Lopez and Matthew McConaughey, the film held off the challenge of the R-rated psycho-thriller Valentine, which finished second with $10.1m (£6.86m). The other new entry into the top ten was Head Over Heels, a teen drama starring Freddie Prinze Jr which hit number seven with opening weekend takings of $5m (£3.39m) and has already been judged a failure for the young star.

fields.headline: Deutschland, keine Insel der Seligen
fields.standfirst: Beef sales in Germany have plummeted as mad cow disease spreads panic among consumers. Nicole Prestle asks young people how they have reacted
fields.trailText: Beef sales in Germany have plummeted as mad cow disease spreads panic among consumers. Nicole Prestle asks young people how they have reacted.
fields.body:
Deutschlands Fleisch ist sicher. Punkt. Zweifel? Nicht gerechtfertigt. Bis vor einigen Monaten waren sich Politiker und Verbraucher in diesem Punkt einig. Bis die erste Kuh an BSE erkrankte. Oder besser gesagt: Bis man die Krankheit zum erstenmal an einem Rind feststellte. Seitdem ist Deutschland in seinen Grundfesten erschüttert. Der Konsum an Rindfleisch ist stark zurückgegangen. So stark, dass die Regierung nun plant, mehr als 400 000 Tiere zu töten und das Fleisch zu verbrennen, um den Markt zu stützen.

Drei Minister haben bereits den Hut genommen, haben Fehler im Umgang mit dem Problem Rinderwahnsinn eingestanden. Doch kaum gewinnen die Bürger langsam das Vertrauen zurück, dass man sich wenigstens um Lösungen bemüht, bahnt sich der nächste Skandal an: Tierärzte und Landwirte in Bayern sollen Schweinen eine Überdosis an Antibiotika verabreicht haben.

Die Tiere sollten schneller fett und reif für die Schlachtung werden, sollten im Klartext schneller Geld bringen. Was können wir nach all diesen Enthüllungen eigentlich noch essen? Wir haben uns bei Jugendlichen umgehört.

Rinderwahnsinn und Antibiotika im Schweinefleisch, freut man sich da noch auf einen saftigen Sonntagsbraten?

Beate (19): Ehrlich gesagt: nein. Ich habe zwar noch nie viel Fleisch gegessen, aber in der Zwischenzeit ist es mir ganz vergangen. Wenn ich daran denke, was wir in all den Jahren schon alles gegessen haben...

Peter (15): Mir ist das egal. Wir haben doch in den vergangenen Jahren ständig Fleisch gegessen, ohne über Rinderwahnsinn oder andere Krankheiten nachzudenken. Wenn das Fleisch sicher ist, dann jetzt. Schließlich wird jedes geschlachtete Rind auf BSE getestet.

Großbritannien hatte seine BSE-Krise lange vor Deutschland. Hätten wir daraus Konsequenzen ziehen müssen?

Angelika (17): Auf jeden Fall. Aber wir saßen damals auf einem hohen Ross, haben gedacht, uns kann das nie passieren. Wenn wir damals schon angefangen hätten, jedes geschlachtete deutsche Rind auf BSE zu testen, hätten wir früher bemerkt, dass auch bei uns nicht alles in Ordnung ist. Dann wäre wohl auch die Forschung hierzulande schon weiter.

Nicolette (18): Schuld ist meiner Ansicht nach die EU. Nach der Krise in England hätte man sofort entsprechende Gesetze erlassen müssen. Man hätte die Bauern zwingen müssen, ihre Tiere testen zu lassen.

Peter: Die Landwirte haben eine zu große Lobby bei uns. Wahrscheinlich hat man schon viel früher geahnt, dass auch Deutschland keine Insel der Seligen ist. Aber weil die Bauern Angst hatten, dass sie ihr Fleisch nicht mehr verkaufen können, haben sie stillgehalten und gehofft, dass nichts passiert.

400 000 Rinder sollen geschlachtet und das Fleisch verbrannt werden, weil der Markt beinahe zusammengebrochen ist . . .

Beate: Das ist doch absolut pervers. Die Tiere können wirklich am wenigsten dafür, dass wir sie hochzüchten, und dann vernichten wir sie, nur weil sie uns kein Geld mehr bringen. Wir Menschen sollten mal wieder darüber nachdenken, wie wir mit anderen, hilfloseren Lebewesen umgehen.

Nicolette: Es wird sich dabei wahrscheinlich herausstellen, dass die wenigsten dieser Tiere den BSE-Erreger in sich tragen. Es ist schon unglaublich, wenn man daran denkt, dass die Menschen in anderen Ländern verhungern müssen...

Peter: Ja, ja. Und dann bekommen die Bauern noch finanzielle Unterstützung dafür, dass sie die Tiere jahrelang mit tierischem Eiweiß und Medikamenten gedopt haben. Ich kann da wirklich nichts mehr sagen.

Wo seht ihr Lösungen, die Landwirten und Verbrauchern zugute kommen?

Angelika: Wir müssen wohl in Zukunft einfach mehr Geld für Lebensmittel ausgeben. Wenn alle bereit wären, für Fleisch von Ökobauern mehr Geld zu bezahlen, dann könnten die Landwirte leben, die Tiere auf natürliche Weise groß werden und wir wieder mit Genuss essen.

Beate: Deutschland und alle anderen Länder sollten in die Forschung investieren. Sogar die Amerikaner setzen sich mit BSE auseinander, obwohl sie bisher keinen einzigen Fall in ihrem Land hatten. Man sollte nicht immer abwarten, bis die Katastrophe schon über einen hereingebrochen ist.

Nicolette: Das kann ich nur für mich persönlich beantworten: Ich werde in Zukunft einfach weniger Fleisch essen. Der Mensch braucht ohnehin nicht so viel davon, wie wir in unserer Gesellschaft konsumieren. Ich will auch nicht, dass die hilflosen Kreaturen gemästet und geschlachtet werden, nur weil wir nicht genug bekommen können.

fields.headline: Earthquake diplomacy brings subcontinent detente
fields.standfirst:
The Indian earthquake has got the region's two leaders talking again, writes Rory McCarthy in Islamabad

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: The Indian earthquake has got the region's two leaders talking again, writes Rory McCarthy in Islamabad.
fields.body:
It was the briefest of telephone calls. Late on Friday evening, India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, spoke to Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, and formally thanked him for sending aid to the survivors of the Bhuj earthquake.

On the sidelines of the gruesome recovery operations in Gujarat, it was barely noticed. But it was the first time the leaders of the two hostile,nuclear-armed nations have spoken since Gen Musharraf seized power in a coup 15 months ago.

Could this be the first sign of a thaw between two old enemies?

For the officers in the army headquarters in Rawalpindi, it represented the culmination of a week of earthquake diplomacy.

In the past, Pakistan has never been particularly canny about its public relations. By contrast, India, with a strong lobby in Washington, has succeeded in painting Muslim Pakistan has the home of Islamic fundamentalist militants and an ardent supporter of the hardline Taliban regime in Afghanistan.

But this time Islamabad moved quickly. Hours after the quake on January 26, Gen Musharraf was the first foreign leader to send his condolences.

Within four days, Pakistan was sending the first of three aid flights to the scene, providing tents and blankets for the survivors.

In the face of the colossal devastation in Bhuj, it was a small gesture. But it comes after several weeks of incrementally small steps towards negotiations on the bitter dispute over Kashmir.

Claimed by both India and Pakistan since partition in 1947, Kashmir has triggered two wars between the south Asian neighbours and held back any prospect of friendly dealings. Now those relations are starting to improve.

"The atmosphere today is less tense and, hopefully, this atmosphere will make it possible to take further steps," Pakistan's foreign minister, Abdul Sattar, said yesterday.

The latest thaw began last summer when Hizbul Mojahedin, the largest of the Pakistan-based militant movements fighting against the Indian army in Kashmir, announced a unilateral halt to its operations.

Within weeks, it backed out of the ceasefire, after an outcry from other militant groups.

Then in November, India said that it would suspend military operations against the militants in Indian Kashmir for the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

That ceasefire has now been extended for the third month, and in return, Pakistan has promised to exercise "maximum restraint" on the so-called line of control, the ceasefire line which divides Kashmir.

Of course, the winter months are the season for diplomacy in Kashmir.

Freezing temperatures and heavy snow on the mountains make it much harder for militants to cross into Indian Kashmir, and much more gruelling for the soldiers of the Indian and Pakistani armies, who, until the latest ceasefire, were shelling each other every day.

The last rapprochement between the two sides was in February 1999, when Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif met Mr Vajpayee in Lahore and both promised a new era of peace and negotiations.

Within three months, the snow in Kashmir had melted and the fighting began again in the Kargil heights, almost pushing the countries into yet another war.

Now Pakistan is pushing New Delhi to grant passports and visas to Kashmiri political leaders from the All Parties Hurriyat conference, so they can travel to Islamabad for talks on the area's future.

Huge problems lie ahead. Islamabad still wants Kashmir to be part of Pakistan, but many Kashmiris would rather rule themselves under a degree of independence from India.

Pakistan cannot risk the wrath of its own religious right by withdrawing support for the militants fighting in Kashmir.

"Clearly there is a nexus between the political and the military struggle," said Mr Sattar. "Involvement of the people of Kashmir in a political process is the answer to a reduction of militancy."

Pakistan is today marking a day of solidarity with those opposing Indian rule in Kashmir. Flags with the words "Kashmir - Picture of Indian inhumanity" and "India stop state terrorism in Kashmir" line the streets of Islamabad.

The general and the prime minister have had their first telephone call. Many more must follow.

fields.headline: P&G unveils cunning product plan
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Procter & Gamble is asking its customers to come up with ideas for new products -- but is making them sign away all rights. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
Procter & Gamble, one of the world's biggest companies, is asking its customers to come up with ideas for new products -- but is making them sign away all their rights to their own ideas.

The multibillion dollar company is ensuring it will not have to pay customers a penny for their ideas, even if they prove to be hugely successful. Instead, P&G will keep all the profits for itself.

The company has set up interactive areas on its website for customers' feedback on how to improve existing products and ideas for new products or services which P&G could use.

The information is being used by P&G's marketing and product development teams.

In the new product idea area customers are encouraged to click on one of four statements including "I wish someone would invent a product to..." and "I have a great idea for a product".

But before they can join put forward their idea, customers must click in two boxes on an agreement document that binds them to the terms and conditions waiving all rights to their ideas and suggestions forever.

The agreement document states: "P&G shall be entitled to unrestricted use of any submissions it may receive from you, for any purpose whatsoever, commercial or otherwise, without compensation to you as a provider of the submission."

The area for improving products asks consumers to help with marketing.

For example, under the question for the Pampers brand "If you were in charge, how would you sell more Pampers?" there are a list of statements to be agreed or disagreed with.

One of the statements says: "I would run a contest like Pepsi and other companies do with their products. Their payoff would be a year's supply of free diapers. You could have smaller prizes like a month's supply free, etc."

fields.headline: Bertelsmann ups RTL stake
fields.trailText: 10.15am: German media giant Bertelsmann has tightened its grip on Channel 5 owner RTL in a surprise all-share deal, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
German media giant Bertelsmann has tightened its grip on Channel 5 owner RTL in a surprise all-share deal.

Bertelsmann today bought a 30% stake in RTL from Belgium's Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, taking its holding in the pan-European broadcaster to 67%

In exchange, GBL will take a 25% stake in Bertelsmann, which it can float within three to five years.

It would be an unprecedented move for Bertelsmann to launch on the stock market, as it has always been a private business.

"All parties involved agree that Bertelsmann has found a ground-breaking new way to adjust to changing conditions and to use its own shares as a acquisition currency, while still retaining entrepreneurial independence," said Bertelsmann in a statement.

The family-owned group had always intended to take a majority holding in the publicly listed RTL, which last year merged with Pearson TV and floated on the London Stock Exchange.

RTL, which started out as Luxembourg's broadcaster, runs 22 TV stations and 18 radio stations in 11 countries. Pearson continues to own 22% of RTL.

"It simplifies the shareholding structure of RTL Group and further strengthens our working relationship with Bertelsmann," said Marjorie Scardino, chief executive of Pearson group.

A partial flotation will allow Bertelsmann to use its shares for acquisitions, after the group was stung by criticism that it lacked flexibility in executing deals.

Although the German group signalled that today's announcement meant the end of its activity in the TV sector for the time being, there may be further consolidation around the corner.

RTL has made clear that it wants to acquire United Business Media's 35% holding in Channel 5, which would cost it up to £350m.

A firming up of RTL's share structure will increase the pressure on United, which is looking to quit broadcasting altogether, to sell its holding.

"RTL Group's clear focus is to strengthen its unique position as Europe's leading broadcasting and production company," said Didier Bellens, chief executive of RTL.

Bertelsmann is a multi-media powerhouse, with significant interests in TV music, internet and publishing, including Bertelsmann Music Group and BOL.

fields.headline: End of the line for Fat Friends
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The first series of Fat Friends, one of the most star-studded TV dramas of recent times, is to be the last, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The first series of Kay Mellor's Fat Friends, one of the most star-studded dramas of recent times, is to be the last.

The cast included Alison Steadman, Josie Lawrence, Meera Syal, Thelma Barlow, Ruth Jones and Ms Mellor's daughter Gaynor Faye.

The series focused on a group of Yorkshire women struggling to shed the pounds at a weight-watchers club.

A source close to Ms Mellor said the screenwriter would not create another series because she had "said all she wants to say on the subject".

The news has come as a blow to ITV, which wanted to run another series of the hit show.

Fat Friends pulled in huge ratings and was considered to be one of ITV's key weapons in its ratings war with the BBC.

"ITV definitely wanted another series, but Kay felt she had gone as far as she could with the characters and is now busy doing other things," said a TV source.

The series was a massive hit with audiences of up to 10m for the last episode of the last series in November.

Women in particular - and all those accustomed to the pendulum of weight loss and weight gain - lapped up Ms Mellor's tales of the lardy lasses at a northern slimming club.

Critics marvelled at the down-to-earth script packed with one-liners.

As one critic said: "It didn't mock the calorifically-challenged. Much. It didn't preach at all.

"The women's desperation to shed pounds was matched by acute self-awareness."

In one episode Gaynor Faye, who played a weight-obsessed actress called Lauren, moaned that everybody in The Bill and Casualty had tiny little bums.

"And telly makes you 10lbs heavier!" she sighed. "Oh, my God! If I get a telly job, my arse will fill the screen!"

webTitle: Media: Interview with C4 Michael Jackson

fields.headline: You want a piece of me?
fields.standfirst: The Tories want to privatise it and rivals want to curb its expansion. But what is Channel 4's secret plan? Michael Jackson tells  Maggie Brown  why he wants to split the channel in two
fields.trailText: The Tories want to privatise it and rivals want to curb its expansion. But what is Channel 4's secret plan? Michael Jackson tells Maggie Brown why he wants to split the channel in two.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo must be surprised. His rehashed plans to privatise Channel 4 went down like a lead balloon last week, provoking the Daily Mail of all papers to point to all its wonderful programmes and snap: "Keep your hands off."

The truth is that the critics circling around Channel 4 are no longer "shocked of Tunbridge Wells" but a range of jealous commercial broadcasters. They recognise, however, that privatisation is off the agenda while Labour forms the government. So they are pointing instead to a "complete muddle" about what this public service broadcaster is supposed to be doing. They accuse it of abusing a privileged position by lavishly funding pure commercial ventures such as FilmFour and the new E4, which is affluent enough to showcase fresh series of Friends and ER.

David Elstein, ex-chief executive of Channel 5, landed a blow before government ministers last year when he pointed to the "missing £250m" in 4's accounts.(This was the difference between its 1999 total revenue of £642m and its annual programme budget of £390m). But behind the scenes Channel 4, led by chief executive Michael Jackson, has spent the past few months cooking up a response to meet objections head on. It will unveil its most fundamental reorganisation since its launch as a single public service channel in 1982.

Channel 4 is splitting in two, to create a new 4 Ventures Ltd to handle developments such as E4. The two arms will have separate accounts, which will also make it much easier for it to fund joint ventures with new partners. New channels and commercial activities - 10 so far but proliferating fast - will go into 4 Ventures; besides E4 and a projected documentary channel, they also include the FilmFour channels, Interactive, FilmFour Ltd and Sport on Four.

A related division will handle joint ventures including a Go Racing channel (not due till 2002) with betting, and slam.com (a 50:50 owned teen site in partnership with Emap). Eventually, successful joint ventures could be floated off to crystallise company values, and realise capital gains. "We have no plans to float 4 Ventures," says Jackson. "But I do not rule out offering shares in the joint ventures and possibly in the whole ... but one thing at a time".

The restructuring will accompany the annual report in April. The report will also, for the first time, state how much Channel 4 is committing to building up new ventures. Last year's sum will be a little below 10% of its total income, now approaching £700m a year. "About time too," says Peter Ainsworth, shadow Culture, Media & Sports spokesman, of the proposal. "But this is a defensive mechanism."

Of the reorganisation, Jackson says calmly: "It's a natural response, much like the BBC's, to a changing world where a single channel strategy is no longer appropriate for our audience or for the market. It's a natural evolution.

"It's about transparency. It is important to understand we are protecting and ring-fencing our investment in Channel 4 [where programme budgets will be rising], not weakening it." Has he modelled the plans on BBC Worldwide? "Not really, but it is illuminating that the BBC is doing these things. It's pretty universal".

4 Ventures will have its own managing director to pull all the new developments together. Headhunters are currently canvassing, and an appointment will be made in the next three months. One key requirement: he or she must be entrepreneurial.

Even those sympathetic to Channel 4 say the changes, in the name of clarity, are overdue, that the relationship should have been sorted out when FilmFour was launched in 1998 - though in fairness FilmFour was an experimental toe dipped in the digital water. (In retrospect it had a deceptively easy launch, encouraged by BSkyB - which subsequently found E4 more threatening).

"They have built a strong brand in FilmFour, but their budget of up to £100m before breaking even is astonishing. That's four times the cost a commercial operator could commit," observes the head of a recently launched rival film channel.

Asked about tardiness, Jackson replies that Channel 4 is a small organisation, and that his style is action first rather than bureaucracy. "It is an appropriate time to be doing this. You can announce your huge vision, then the detail comes later. With us, we launched FilmFour first and tried to work out where next. I am a builder-out. Our strategy has been to take Channel 4 successes and build them across platforms.

"I have to say that some of our critics are our competitors and they don't particularly want to see a strong Channel 4. Look at ITV! Who has done a better job in the new world of multi-channel? Not the red-in-tooth-and-claw capitalists." He is proud that FilmFour has won 415,000 subscribers at £5.99 a month - nearly half as many takers as ONdigital's one million. And says that he is convinced it is right to go on investing in internet developments, despite the cold feet of some major players.

But will the "new transparency" quell the critics? The case against Channel 4 is a mini version of the attacks on the BBC - but with significant differences. As a public service broadcaster, it is there not to make profits but to fund original UK production, so it pays nothing for its spectrum - while ITV and Channel 5 must pay for theirs. It also has a terrestrial channel to use to cross-promote its new channels. The independent television commission has applied pressure for the coming changes after receiving complaints.

Nor is Channel 4 judged to have made the public service case for starting E4 as clearly as it might. An ex-Channel 4 insider says: "I'm surprised. It comes over as very commercial, it looks as if it is taking programmes away from Channel 4. You could easily argue that a place to try out new entertainment formats is exactly what is needed. It is a massive investment of faith to stick some of these things on even late at night on Channel 4".

Adam Singer, chief executive of Flextech/Telewest, which runs a clutch of rival channels, says: "E4 is going to lose a lot of money in the start up.Why is public money being used to fund a totally commercial channel?"

He is unmoved by the offer of more transparent accounts. "The answer is that the government should be thinking very carefully about the remit of Channel 4. Either it is a commercial company, or it is a public body. Privatise it, or, if it's there to help British production, then make it spend all that money on much better quality drama, comedy or entertainment.

"Channel 4 is using its money to bid up the cost of rights. Essentially, it is using my money and your money to fund new ventures by avoiding giving money back to the Treasury. I'm in the camp which says, I don't mind what you do but please be clear."

Jackson flatly denies Channel 4 is being shorn of resources. "Absolutely not. It's the rational thing to do." E4, he says, "doubles our opportunity to develop new talent."

In truth, informed critics argue, Channel 4 ought to be able to defuse attacks. It has no direct public funding via a licence fee. As a commercial/public service hybrid, its income comes from advertising and sponsorship. And it is not as vast a media player as the BBC.

Yet there are difficulties. What value should be placed on its privileges? What is the public service gain extracted for a free frequency? How is that monitored? And should it be allowed a free hand elsewhere in order to protect its public service remit?

There are other complications. Not all of Channel 4's new ventures are expected to be profit-making, so most of its online education service, 4 Learning, is being left with the Channel 4 television division.

In the longer term, the channel's business plan says that it faces the same sort of decline as other mainstream terrestrial networks, as the digital explosion causes their collective share of audiences and revenues to fall. Indeed, the hunt is on to find new revenue, to enable the main channel to fire on all guns. It is possible that Channel 4 could be subsidised by its new ventures before 2010, provided the right ones are chosen. Jackson thinks the current model "of which I'm a big supporter" can be sustained in the short to medium term.

How to strike a fair public interest balance is a question posed by the communications white paper: Channel 4 is being required to draft a more positive statement of programme requirements. The white paper says: "We will review C4's remit to make it more positive and to ensure [it] provides distinctive and innovative programming in the future." Crucially, the phrase requiring it to make programmes for "tastes and interests not catered for by Channel 3", is to be struck out, because it is seen as far too negative and old fashioned, benchmarking its performance against ITV.

Jackson says the new promises will include "innovation, distinctiveness" and, for the first time, a commitment to "diversity". Culture secretary Chris Smith, known to be an admirer of Jackson's tenure, says Channel 4 is expected to be "at the cutting edge of culture, and particularly doing the unusual and quirky. It should be benchmarked against the whole broadcasting industry", rather than just ITV.

On privatisation, Smith said last week: "There is a very wide consensus [against], the Tory proposal simply got it wrong." But as for the grey areas of commercial expansion: "We have to watch quite carefully what Channel 4 does with the surplus that it makes from its basic Channel 4 services. Channel 4's argument is that FilmFour and E4 will become self-sustaining. We have to hold them to that.

"Having said that, ensuring that the public as a whole sees ER or Friends on free-to-air TV may well be a good piece of public service. We don't want to see them completely corralled into a ghetto. I think on the whole Channel 4 has fulfilled its job pretty well over the last five years."

As a public service broadcaster, it is there not to make profits but to fund original UK production, so it pays nothing for its spectrum - while ITV and Channel 5 must pay for theirs. It also has a terrestrial channel to use to cross-promote its new channels. The independent television commission has applied pressure for the coming changes after receiving complaints. Nor is Channel 4 judged to have made the public service case for starting E4 as clearly as it might. An ex-Channel 4 insider says: "I'm surprised. It comes over as very commercial, it looks as if it is taking programmes away from Channel 4. You could easily argue that a place to try out new entertainment formats is exactly what is needed. It is a massive investment of faith to stick some of these things on even late at night on Channel 4". Adam Singer, chief executive of Flextech/Telewest, which runs a clutch of rival channels, says: "E4 is going to lose a lot of money in the start up.Why is public money being used to fund a totally commercial channel?" He is unmoved by the offer of more transparent accounts. "The answer is that the government should be thinking very carefully about the remit of Channel 4. Either it is a commercial company, or it is a public body. Privatise it, or, if it's there to help British production, then make it spend all that money on much better quality drama, comedy or entertainment. "Channel 4 is using its money to bid up the cost of rights. Essentially, it is using my money and your money to fund new ventures by avoiding giving money back to the Treasury. I'm in the camp which says, I don't mind what you do but please be clear." Jackson flatly denies Channel 4 is being shorn of resources. "Absolutely not. It's the rational thing to do." E4, he says, "doubles our opportunity to develop new talent." In truth, informed critics argue, Channel 4 ought to be able to defuse attacks. It has no direct public funding via a licence fee. As a commercial/public service hybrid, its income comes from advertising and sponsorship. And it is not as vast a media player as the BBC. Yet there are difficulties. What value should be placed on its privileges? What is the public service gain extracted for a free frequency? How is that monitored? And should it be allowed a free hand elsewhere in order to protect its public service remit? There are other complications. Not all of Channel 4's new ventures are expected to be profit-making, so most of its online education service, 4 Learning, is being left with the Channel 4 television division. In the longer term, the channel's business plan says that it faces the same sort of decline as other mainstream terrestrial networks, as the digital explosion causes their collective share of audiences and revenues to fall. Indeed, the hunt is on to find new revenue, to enable the main channel to fire on all guns. It is possible that Channel 4 could be subsidised by its new ventures before 2010, provided the right ones are chosen. Jackson thinks the current model "of which I'm a big supporter" can be sustained in the short to medium term. How to strike a fair public interest balance is a question posed by the communications white paper: Channel 4 is being required to draft a more positive statement of programme requirements. The white paper says: "We will review C4's remit to make it more positive and to ensure [it] provides distinctive and innovative programming in the future." Crucially, the phrase requiring it to make programmes for "tastes and interests not catered for by Channel 3", is to be struck out, because it is seen as far too negative and old fashioned, benchmarking its performance against ITV. Jackson says the new promises will include "innovation, distinctiveness" and, for the first time, a commitment to "diversity". Culture secretary Chris Smith, known to be an admirer of Jackson's tenure, says Channel 4 is expected to be "at the cutting edge of culture, and particularly doing the unusual and quirky. It should be benchmarked against the whole broadcasting industry", rather than just ITV. On privatisation, Smith said last week: "There is a very wide consensus [against], the Tory proposal simply got it wrong." But as for the grey areas of commercial expansion: "We have to watch quite carefully what Channel 4 does with the surplus that it makes from its basic Channel 4 services. Channel 4's argument is that FilmFour and E4 will become self-sustaining. We have to hold them to that. "Having said that, ensuring that the public as a whole sees ER or Friends on free-to-air TV may well be a good piece of public service. We don't want to see them completely corralled into a ghetto. I think on the whole Channel 4 has fulfilled its job pretty well over the last five years."

fields.headline: With friends like these ...
fields.standfirst: So the Daily Mail has come out in favour of Channel 4. This should give the station serious cause for concern, says Emily Bell. It proves its agenda is now dictated by popularity rather than experimentation
fields.trailText: So the Daily Mail has come out in favour of Channel 4. This should give the station serious cause for concern. It proves its agenda is now dictated by popularity rather than experimentation.
fields.body:
As a piece of détente it might not quite rank with Richard Nixon's trip to China, but the Daily Mail outing itself as a great fan of Channel 4 last week provided something of a queer spectacle.

The fulsome article, penned by former TV critic Max Davidson, proclaimed "Shock! Horror! The Mail now Loves Channel 4", handily reminding us in the process that it was once the paper that campaigned against "the sleazy reign of the Pornographer in Chief". Or Michael Grade as he prefers to be known.

Davidson trowelled praise onto Channel 4's current output, comparing it favourably to the "crass and naive and patronising" programming that had tarnished the station as recently as five years ago. "It has become ... the channel of choice for the thinking middleclass," burbled Davidson, "intelligent without being pompous, provocative without being outrageous, quirky without being infantile". In fact it is clear by the end of a hagiography that includes everything from Channel 4 News to Sex and the City, from Big Brother and Graham Norton to the Kumbh Mela coverage, that Davidson loves Channel 4 so much that he would marry chief executive Michael Jackson were that sort of thing allowed.

Getting quite carried away, he writes of the inspired programme Embarrassing Illnesses, posing the almost unanswerable question: "Would the BBC have dared to produce a medical series kicking off with a no-holds-barred film about anal fistulas?" I don't know, Max, you tell us.

Jackson, the man responsible for dragging Channel 4 kicking and screaming into the realm of suburban respectability, must have read Davidson's paean with some unease. It would be like the thrill of discovering you have a secret fan club, only to find out it was founded by John Redwood.

The Mail's championing of Channel 4 must be taken with a pinch of salt. It is the mischievousness of a paper that enjoys confounding expectations as much as it enjoys reinforcing prejudices. To credit Channel 4 with Seinfeld, as Davidson does, suggests that he spends less time glued to his new favourite channel than you might think.

And to say that Channel 4 has abandoned crudity and infantilism would be to overlook last week's ruling by the Broadcasting Standards Commission that detailed necrophilia in a Channel 4 children's programme - South Park - was going too far. Indeed one wonders what Davidson would have made of Daisy Donovan gently leading an Italian aristocrat into a deliberate mispronunciation which had him confirming that there were "many cunts in this part of Italy".

For the Mail, it is always expedient to have a televisual target; staff remember the paper fulminating in anger over the BBC's "summer of sport" a few years ago, because the wife of editor Paul Dacre had been incensed over the rescheduling of her favourite programme - Murder One - to make room for bowls or cricket or some such. Last year it found a new target when any indiscretions from Channel 4 were well and truly put in the shade, so to speak, by Keith Chegwin airing his genitals on Channel 5's Naked Jungle. So the wrath of middle England moves from 4 to 5.

But there is a more fundamental truth in Davidson's piece, that Channel 4 has undeniably changed under Jackson, and its interests now converge far more closely with those of the Daily Mail. Channel 4 may approach subjects such as Victoria Beckham's insights, Lena Zavaroni's anorexia and Michael Hutchence's death with its eyebrow cocked in postmodern irony, while the Mail twitches its net curtain to tut pruriently at same, but the constituencies now firmly overlap. Even the piles, impotence and irritable bowel syndromes of Embarrassing Illnesses and Better Sex are surely prevalent among Mail readers.

Yes, Channel 4 is more watchable, and, yes, it does have the best bought-in programming on British television and some of the best originated. It became the channel that would schedule Queer as Folk where once it had Sebastiane, the Derek Jarman opus that scandalised the Mail among others with its unique blend of religious imagery and gay sex. Where once it had foreign language films scattered with joyless couplings, bearing the "red triangle" that "warned" the audience of explicit material, it now has the snappy Sex and the City.

It has left behind the more earnest and challenging programming, which the Daily Mail so despised for its "preachy sanctimony", but which provided a tiny space on British TV for the freedom to experiment and be unpopular without immediately being hauled off the air.

For all the plaudits that West Wing is now receiving, it is a series Channel 4 sat on for more than a year because it feared the theme of US politics would be poison to audiences. Like the Mail, Channel 4's agenda is now firmly dictated by popularity not experimentation. The Daily Mail is right when it says that Channel 4 now does what other stations do - only better. Which is why the Daily Mail is wrong to append a hasty caveat to Michael Portillo and those who would privatise the channel.

"If it ain't broke don't fix it - leave well alone," is Max Davidson's advice. But when even the Daily Mail approves of your programming, surely the rationale for keeping Channel 4 as a special case in commercial broadcasting has also disappeared.

 Emily Bell is editor-in-chief of Guardian Unlimited.

fields.headline: Who is in charge of the jokes?
fields.trailText: Peter Bazalgette: Recently a Very Famous Person called me. This VFP (a TV mogul for 30 years or more) agreed that working in television now is bewildering and exhilarating in almost equal measure. This is well illustrated by producers' negotiations with broadcasters, argues the creative director of Endemol Entertainment UK.
fields.body:
Recently a Very Famous Person called me. This VFP (a TV mogul for 30 years or more) agreed that working in television now is bewildering and exhilarating in almost equal measure. As long as the exhilaration outweighs the bewilderment, Micawber-style, then the result is happiness. This is well illustrated by producers' negotiations with broadcasters. We used to know what to argue about. Now we may as well tear up existing contracts. Technology is reinventing our business, leaving lawyers to try to work out what it all means. And rather like pre-nuptial agreements, the new deals are extremely revealing as to some of the broadcasters' potential assets.

Take the idea of "catch-up TV". This will be when a channel offers viewers the chance to watch a programme they missed first time round. One way to deliver it is as a video-on-demand service on broadband, free or for a payment. Broadcasters now want to wrap this up, for no extra fee, into "primary rights" (the ability to show a programme twice that lies at the core of all deals). But should they get this benefit for nothing?

Then take the arrival of "enhanced TV". Digital channels can now offer web-style options of a choice of camera or text information. Sky Sports is already doing this with its pioneering football coverage. Understandably, broadcasters wish to have the right to enhance programmes in this way. But at what level of interactive complexity would broadcasters be, in effect, creating an additional production based on the idea supplied by the producer? Not if they employ basic software that simply offers additional text information. But imagine being transported to a virtual world based around, say, Ali G or The Mole. That's not an enhancement the show's creators would wish broadcasters to be able to make at will.

If you are finding some of this terminology unfamiliar, brace yourself. It gets stranger. "Viral marketing" is one of the buzz phrases among the sages of Soho and Fitzrovia. This is the idea that a short clip or animation which is sufficiently wicked or funny will be emailed from office to office, much as the intimate activities of poor Claire Swire were recently. It can be a powerful way to promote a product, a film or a TV show. Recently a broadcaster told an animation company that it wanted to make just such a promotion. It turned out that, at five minutes and with new ideas, it was essentially a new programme. Its publicity plans were politely declined by the producers, whose message was: "We make the jokes, thank you".

All these are new issues that need to be settled contractually. And there are many more. As an inventor of TV formats, my company does not want UK broadcasters videostreaming our shows around the world on the web. If it is available in foreign territories, particularly English-speaking ones, our chances of selling the format there could be damaged. The UK broadcaster, on the other hand, is equally scared that foreign versions of our format should not be videostreamed back into the UK, thereby competing with the programme's home-grown version.

What should happen when viewers are channelled from a programme to a public service informational website where there are then links to a commercial site? Should the producer get a share of any e-commerce revenue? Not according to a certain broadcaster we're dealing with at the moment. But we want to wake up and share the coffee, not have it stolen from under our noses.

A programme's contents can now be refashioned as audio or text for both the web and mobile telephones. Yet another new media issue that needs sorting. The classic answer is leave everything to a free and fair business negotiation. Not according to Out of the Box, the report from David Graham & Associates which accompanied the recent white paper. It points out that we do not yet have the right economic conditions to leave such rights issues to the market alone.

There's a small concentration of broadcasters and an unconcentrated number of producers leaving a balance of power tipped in the broadcasters' favour. The communications white paper was virtually silent on this (and several other) issues. Sadly, it was published just six months before a general election and discretion became the better part of valour.

But if a new regulator eventually emerges prepared to spend more time on industry economics and less time on the precise scheduling of the evening news, there may be hope yet. Then both VFPs and the rest of us mere mortals can begin to construct a new legal framework between creators and buyers.

 Peter Bazalgette is creative director of Endemol Entertainment UK.

webTitle: Media: What are New Dads like?

fields.headline: What are you like?
fields.standfirst: New Dads
fields.trailText: New Dads
fields.body:
Besides being in the first flush of fatherhood, New Dads have also adopted the "new man" take on parenting. That means they don't think a woman's place is in the home, they enjoy spending time with the family and feel children should be allowed to express themselves freely. There are 1.2m New Dads in the UK with one or more children under four years old.

So how liberated are they?

Their average age is 32 and they are marginally more likely to live in the south of England than elsewhere. They are ambitious at work, but also like shopping for clothes and are always on the lookout for ideas to brighten up the home. New Dads spend an average of more than nine hours a week travelling and they also think cannabis should be legalised.

Do they get a chance to watch television?

When they're not changing nappies, New Dads need a laugh. More than a third of them watch Never Mind the Buzzcocks while King of the Hill is also popular. Comedy dramas such as Cold Feet and Grafters are watched by more than a quarter of this group. DIY is a strong theme and they are quite keen on home improvement shows such as Changing Rooms and Home Front. More than two-fifths of New Dads have access to satellite or cable channels.

What's the New Dad take on advertising?

"I like some of the funny ads - most beer ads are good. I am a bit worried about all the adverts that bombard kids, especially at Christmas - they pick up on new things so quickly," reflects a typical New Dad's concern.

Do they get a chance to sit down and read the paper?

The Times and the Sun are the most popular reads for this group, with men's monthlies such as FHM and GQ also popular. They are more likely to read Men's Health and Auto Trader than your average testosterone-powered male.

How do you spot a New Dad?

He'll probably have a pushchair. However, if he's been let out without the baby then comments such as: "We did a lot of travelling before we started a family but we still look forward to getting away and still like going to different places. The thing is everywhere has to be kid-friendly now," are good giveaways.

 Data compiled by MediaCom.

webTitle: Budget help to lift 1m children out of poverty

fields.headline: Budget help to lift 1m children out of poverty
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is to kickstart Labour's re-election campaign with a Budget next month designed to lift a million children out of poverty.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is to kickstart Labour's re-election campaign with a Budget next month designed to lift a million children out of poverty.

The Budget will spurn demands for an across-the-board cut in income tax in favour of a £3bn pre-election package focused on helping families with children.

A new measure aimed at providing financial support for parents with infants under one is to form part of a three-pronged approach designed to tackle child poverty in a second Labour term.

It will be buttressed by an increase from £8.50 to £10 a week for the children's tax credit (CTC) - the replacement for the married couple's allowance - and an uprating of the working families tax credit (WFTC), the tax break for the low paid.

With recent polls showing support for the government falling among women voters, the Budget will also extend paid maternity leave from 18 to 26 weeks and increase statutory maternity pay.

The chancellor will outline his strategy in Downing Street today in a joint presentation with the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, which will stress that Labour's extra cash for families is to be accompanied by a tougher line on fathers who shirk their parental responsibilities. Mr Darling will single out the minority of parents who seek to evade their duties, saying that they are denying their children their right to the best start in life.

The Treasury is still finalising the details of the Budget, which is expected to pave the way for an election in early May.

But Mr Brown has already decided against a 1p cut in income tax - the measure traditionally favoured by Conservative chancellors in the run-up to polling day - in favour of a targeted approach.

Sources have indicated that a headline-grabbing reduction in income tax would use up almost all the money that Mr Brown has set aside for tax cuts, and would not be an effective way of helping the less well-off.

Although many City analysts believe that the strength of the government's finances will result in a budget surplus of £15bn this year, Mr Brown is concerned by the signs of weakness in the global economy. Money has already been earmarked for pensioners and motorists, and the chancellor is determined that the Budget should not provide an excuse for the Bank of England to raise interest rates. "We don't want to take risks with economic stability," one source said. "We aren't looking at massive giveaways."

Within his self-imposed constraints, the chancellor will argue today that priority should go to families. Under Labour, the number of children living below the poverty line has fallen from 4m to 3m, but Mr Brown believes that further fiscal action is needed to shave a further 1m off the total in the next parliament.

The prime minister is said to be in full agreement with the budget strategy, which marks a determined attempt by Labour to appeal to its core vote while at the same time safeguarding its reputation for economic prudence. Government strategists believe that the Conservative strategy of offering £8bn of tax cuts has backfired, with voters sceptical about whether the opposition's figures add up.

Instead, they will counter critics who say that Labour has not done enough for its heartlands by pointing out that every family with children gets a minimum of £15.50 a week through child benefit and that the working families tax credit can be worth an extra £50 a week for those on low incomes.

In the Budget, Mr Brown will be relying on the increased generosity of the children's tax credit and the extra help for parents with young children to appeal to voters in middle England. The CTC will be worth £10 a week for many families, but will be tapered away for the better-off. However, under the proposals in the Budget, it will only be when families earn more than £41,500 year that they will receive nothing.

The new tax credit to help families with very young children has been under consideration for several months. Mr Brown has rejected calls for a tax break payable for the first three years of a child's life on the grounds of cost, but is determined to press ahead with a more limited scheme for children in their first year, when households see their finances suffer from an in crease in expenditure and a reduction in income.

Over the next month, officials will decide whether the extra cash will be delivered universally through child benefit, or added to the CTC or WFTC. The weekly sums involved have yet to be decided. While most of the focus in the Budget will be on working families, parents who are not working will not lose out.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, will today set out Tory plans to abolish tax on pensioners' savings as the first stage of its £8bn package of wider tax cuts due to be outlined. Mr Portillo yesterday claimed the reform would encourage savings.
