It will be buttressed by an increase from £8.50 to £10 a week for the children's tax credit (CTC) - the replacement for the married couple's allowance - and an uprating of the working families tax credit (WFTC), the tax break for the low paid. With recent polls showing support for the government falling among women voters, the Budget will also extend paid maternity leave from 18 to 26 weeks and increase statutory maternity pay. The chancellor will outline his strategy in Downing Street today in a joint presentation with the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, which will stress that Labour's extra cash for families is to be accompanied by a tougher line on fathers who shirk their parental responsibilities. Mr Darling will single out the minority of parents who seek to evade their duties, saying that they are denying their children their right to the best start in life. The Treasury is still finalising the details of the Budget, which is expected to pave the way for an election in early May. But Mr Brown has already decided against a 1p cut in income tax - the measure traditionally favoured by Conservative chancellors in the run-up to polling day - in favour of a targeted approach. Sources have indicated that a headline-grabbing reduction in income tax would use up almost all the money that Mr Brown has set aside for tax cuts, and would not be an effective way of helping the less well-off. Although many City analysts believe that the strength of the government's finances will result in a budget surplus of £15bn this year, Mr Brown is concerned by the signs of weakness in the global economy. Money has already been earmarked for pensioners and motorists, and the chancellor is determined that the Budget should not provide an excuse for the Bank of England to raise interest rates. "We don't want to take risks with economic stability," one source said. "We aren't looking at massive giveaways." Within his self-imposed constraints, the chancellor will argue today that priority should go to families. Under Labour, the number of children living below the poverty line has fallen from 4m to 3m, but Mr Brown believes that further fiscal action is needed to shave a further 1m off the total in the next parliament. The prime minister is said to be in full agreement with the budget strategy, which marks a determined attempt by Labour to appeal to its core vote while at the same time safeguarding its reputation for economic prudence. Government strategists believe that the Conservative strategy of offering £8bn of tax cuts has backfired, with voters sceptical about whether the opposition's figures add up. Instead, they will counter critics who say that Labour has not done enough for its heartlands by pointing out that every family with children gets a minimum of £15.50 a week through child benefit and that the working families tax credit can be worth an extra £50 a week for those on low incomes. In the Budget, Mr Brown will be relying on the increased generosity of the children's tax credit and the extra help for parents with young children to appeal to voters in middle England. The CTC will be worth £10 a week for many families, but will be tapered away for the better-off. However, under the proposals in the Budget, it will only be when families earn more than £41,500 year that they will receive nothing. The new tax credit to help families with very young children has been under consideration for several months. Mr Brown has rejected calls for a tax break payable for the first three years of a child's life on the grounds of cost, but is determined to press ahead with a more limited scheme for children in their first year, when households see their finances suffer from an in crease in expenditure and a reduction in income. Over the next month, officials will decide whether the extra cash will be delivered universally through child benefit, or added to the CTC or WFTC. The weekly sums involved have yet to be decided. While most of the focus in the Budget will be on working families, parents who are not working will not lose out. The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, will today set out Tory plans to abolish tax on pensioners' savings as the first stage of its £8bn package of wider tax cuts due to be outlined. Mr Portillo yesterday claimed the reform would encourage savings.

fields.headline: Thriving new media shares? Which ones?
fields.standfirst:
Christopher Gasson on the web companies which have worked out how to turn a profit

More net news
fields.trailText: Christopher Gasson, publishing company broker with Bertoli Mitchell, on the web companies which have worked out how to turn a profit.
fields.body:
One of the curious features of the meltdown in internet stocks since April last year is that the sector of the economy which is most directly affected by the internet has continued to thrive, with share prices sharply up over the past year.

The sector in question is professional information publishing: reference and current awareness services for heavy information users such as lawyers, doctors, researchers and bankers. During the period between January 2000 and January 2001, the average increase in share prices of the seven leading companies in the professional information sector (Thomson, Reed Elsevier, McGraw-Hill, Reuters, VNU, Wolters Kluwer and Dun & Bradstreet) has been 15.4%. Over the same period Nasdaq fell by 30.7%, and the media sector as a whole fell by 12.2%.

The internet grew out of the professional information sector. Research scientists needed to pursue information across databases held in different geographic locations from a single point of access, so they developed the protocols which made the internet happen. Searching for specific or related pieces of information remains the prime functionality of the internet: that it can be used to sell pet food or find buyers for unwanted holidays is a spin-off benefit.

But the most devastating aspect of the internet is that it removes all barriers to entry into the publishing market. With 1.5m pages published for free on the internet every day against 500,000 pages a day produced by the paid-for print publishing industry, information is now a commodity which people are extremely reluctant to pay for.

To make things worse for the major professional information publishers, there is also the threat of disintermediation. Most professional information publishers do not have unique access to the material they publish. They simply republish material produced by law courts, stock exchanges and research institutions. Much of this is now available for free from competing websites or through Napster-like peer-to-peer email networks.

So how have these companies, which have hitherto seen their content as their crown jewels, managed to flourish as this content has become a ubiquitous commodity?

They certainly had a few advantages over those trying to sell pet food or unwanted holidays. They did not have to buy traffic - they already had an established user base which could be switched to the new medium. They did not have to invent a market or a new business model like many of the more outlandish consumer web businesses.

Most importantly, they have redefined themselves. A close reading of their annual reports shows that most of them no longer see themselves as content-centred publishing businesses, but as customer-centred "information service" businesses.

It is an immensely important change of mindset.

Traditionally, publishers have looked for growth at the margins of their markets. They have made a colossal investment in intellectual property, then squeezed as much money as possible from this investment by selling the same content as many times as possible at different price points and in different formats. Newspaper publishers have cut prices, done bulk sales deals and recycled news into freesheets. Book publishers have put hardbacks into paperback. Film companies have released first run films on video.

Before the arrival of the internet, many professional information publishers were reaching the limit beyond which they could not increase prices without losing so many subscribers that the total takings would actually fall.

The arrival of the internet has enabled them to increase the service element of their content massively, through bundling together rafts of related products, interlinking them and making them cross-searchable.

The largest such project is Reed Elsevier's Science Direct which brings together 1,200 scientific journals in a single database. Butterworths Tolley, Croner, and Sweet & Maxwell have applied a similar approach to legal and regulatory publishing. The Oxford English Dictionary online is another example of a mature product which has been spiced up by added web functionality.

The major institutional libraries and the information managers in the law firms and banks appreciate the added functionality of these products and have been prepared to pay substantially more for them, either directly through price increases or through a greater commitment to renewal (subscriptions to databases such as Science Direct are an all or nothing commitment - you cannot remove the elements of the package you don't want and hope to reduce your subscription).

Peripheral customers have balked at the price rises or at the greater commitment to renewing subscriptions, but this is no great loss. The price-sensitive end of the market was always likely to fall for the attractions of free information elsewhere on the web.

Right now, with free content proliferating and ad-rates falling, this strategy of focusing on information services for the high-end customer looks like the only way any content owners are making money from the web.

Whether the strategy will continue to pay dividends in future will depend on whether the publishers can continue to add to the service element of their products faster than the internet commoditises them. It is a Sisyphean task.

In theory the demand for a higher level of service will always be there. Businesses will always want to be better informed than their competitors. The internet makes this more difficult because everyone has access to the same high level of information. However, it does not stop people being prepared to pay more in order to stay ahead of their competitors.

In practice, however, it may not be the publishers who meet this need. While people in the industry talk about products which are more precisely tailored to the needs of their individual customers, the day when they start producing publications which have a circulation of one copy may never come. Instead, it will be the consultancy firms - who are not shy of paying good salaries to people who can add value to information - who benefit at the expense of the more tight-fisted publishers.

The old slogan of the early days of internet was "information wants to be free". When the big money started to pour into the internet, this was dismissed as a hippy dream, but today it looks prophetically true. The only thing one can rely on is that people will always pay for people.

 This is an extract of a paper by Christopher Gasson given to the International Press Institute's 50th annual congress in New Delhi on January 29. Christopher Gasson is a publishing company broker with Bertoli Mitchell.

Cg@bertolimitchell.co.uk

webTitle: Lack of infrastructure threatens broadband business

fields.headline: The last mile is the longest
fields.standfirst:
The government's vision of a nation covered in low-cost broadband cabling has taken a bashing from BT, Oftel and the finance markets. David Teather explains how a dream turned sour

More net news
fields.trailText: The government's vision of a nation covered in low-cost broadband cabling has taken a bashing from BT, Oftel and the finance markets. David Teather explains how a dream turned sour.
fields.body:
Broadband Britain is in deep trouble. Over the past two weeks, the politically driven efforts to loosen British Telecom's grip over its local network, seen as the key to wiring the nation's homes for affordable high-bandwidth services, have suffered repeated blows. One by one, some of the company's largest rivals - notably Kingston Communications which had earmarked £1bn - have abandoned plans to install their own equipment in BT exchanges.

The government's repeated promises of "widespread availability" of broadband services by the summer are now looking increasingly hollow. For those in new media who view broadband as the panacea for their current woes, this is not good news. No matter how whizzbang the applications, without the infrastructure they remain little more than interesting ideas.

The break up of BT's monopoly over the so-called "last mile" to homes and businesses is vital because it would enable its rivals to install DSL (digital subscriber line) equipment, upgrading the old network of copper wires for broadband use. The argument for breaking up BT's monopoly is that competition will force it to speed up its own investment in the network and, crucially, will lower prices. Welcome to the world, in telecoms jargon, of unbundling the local loop.

The process has become steeped in controversy, however. Besides Kingston's withdrawal, last week saw Thus - the renamed Scottish Telecom - shelving plans to build its own network, and two weeks ago Redstone Telecom, another stock market-listed supplier, sharply reduced its investment plans. They join a growing list of companies, including US telecoms giants MCI Worldcom and Global Crossing, dropping their plans to deploy DSL.

BT, naturally, is reluctant to give up market share. The alternative is to buy capacity from BT on a wholesale basis, an option currently taken by Video Networks, the video-on-demand company which markets the Home Choice service.

Video Networks currently pays BT around £600 for every customer connected to DSL and another £60 a month per line. Its revenues are less than £30 a customer. If the company can bundle in other services, including multi-channel TV, games, telephony and high speed internet, says chief executive Simon Hochhauser, then the gap could be closed. But for most the sums simply don't add up.

BSkyB, which is running a service in Hull with Kingston, providing pay TV and DSL lines, privately admits that the prospect of launching a national service is receding, at least for the time being. A series of things have gone wrong. Some blame can be placed with BT, some with the industry regulator Oftel and a good chunk with the stock and capital markets.

The process of unbundling has been painfully protracted. David Edmonds, the Oftel director-general, has described dealing with BT as "trench warfare". Decidedly low-tech arguments about how the limited space in exchanges is allocated have rumbled on. Oftel has been accused of going soft on BT and BT has been accused of dragging its feet.

Among the issues still to be resolved is BT's insistence that other companies' equipment must be housed in separate rooms in its exchanges. Richard Greco of Bulldog, a DSL company backed by the old British Gas firm Transco, claims the cost of fitting out a room is in the region of £250,000. Alternatively, BT is proposing to charge £900 every time a rival company wants access to its own equipment in an exchange. "We are going forward but are effectively operating on faith, hoping that Oftel will take action over this madness," says Greco.

The first exchanges to be opened to competition have now been made available. But they have been released in small tranches, drawing complaints that those offered so far are not in lucrative urban areas and are widely dispersed, making it virtually impossible to draw up business plans. The first 25 opened for competition received a derisory response. Orders for space were placed in only 14, with an average of one or two operators per site instead of the anticipated seven or eight.

Several weeks ago, Oftel called an emergency meeting at which it pressed BT to bring forward the timetable for offering exchanges and launched an inquiry into the costs for companies wanting space. It didn't stop the likes of Kingston dropping out. The company said the timetable was still too piecemeal to allow development of a viable national network.

But perhaps the most significant stumbling block is out of either BT's or Oftel's hands. For Redstone, the decision to retrench and focus on a few towns instead of large parts of the country was due to investors' loss of confidence in the sector. Capital markets have virtually closed to telecoms companies which have borrowed to the hilt over the past two years.

Business development director Bob Cushing said Redstone had originally hoped to raise up to £150m to finance its plans for a national DSL service. As conditions worsened, however, Redstone's advisers warned against taking the debt on. "The terms aren't attractive, and as we don't urgently need the cash it didn't make sense," he says.

Ironically, the number of companies pulling out of the process has actually made local loop unbundling more attractive for the remaining few. Less competition for space means it will be easier to build a regional or national network of DSL lines.

For many of the media companies developing broadband services there is a need for pragmatism. "We've always had a strong belief that the timetable would be 18 months or so behind what BT was telling us so we have built that into our business models," says John Varney, director of technology at Granada Media.

Next month, Granada launches a joint venture with Boots the chemists, which is billed as a broadband business but will operate in effect as a TV channel and sister website until the infrastructure catches up. The future is still coming, but it is further away than many had hoped.

webTitle: Media: The demise of the Daily Poem

fields.headline: The final stanza
fields.standfirst:
The Daily Poem is another Express casualty. Harry Eyres, its editor, says the execution is a blow to literary democracy

Special report: the Express takeover
fields.trailText: The Daily Poem is another Express casualty. Harry Eyres, its editor, says the execution is a blow to literary democracy.
fields.body:
Four and a half years ago, when Richard Addis asked me to become poetry editor of the Daily Express, I started to plant a garden above Blackfriars Bridge. It was a challenge: the soil and exposure of a mid-market tabloid were not favourable to the tender shoots of verse. But poetry, I thought, could prove a hardy perennial: it has outlasted and outfaced dictators and death camps, just as Shelley's cunning poem Ozymandias has the last laugh on the megalomaniac pharaoh.

Why should shy poems only show their faces in obscure journals? Wordsworth and Coleridge strutted their stuff in the Morning Post 200 years ago. And why shouldn't newspapers allow a space for something with a deeper bearing on life than the frenetic immediacy of "news"?

A recent initiative particularly inspired me - Judith Chernaik's Poems on the Underground. If poems could provide spiritual balm for passengers mind-numbed by advertisements for cold remedies, then a comfy plot between Orlando Murrin's tasty recipes and the Daily Express puzzle was a luxury.

What kind of poems to choose? Readers would no doubt give feed-back, but in the meantime I scoured my memory-bank of a few hundred poems, anthologies and new volumes from small as well as better-known presses. I knew from the beginning that I wanted to mix classics with a broad range of contemporary verse.

I looked forward to introducing some of the best (not necessarily best-known) of today's poets - Michael Longley, Connie Bensley, Ian Duhig, Maura Dooley, Colin Falck - and to receiving flak from readers who'd been wrongly taught at school that all poetry must rhyme. Knowing that poetry can inspire fear, and even hatred, I started writing a commentary on each poem: not a factual blurb, but an attempt to guide readers to the poem's heart.

Doreen Eaton, from Broughton Astley, Leicestershire, was one of several readers to respond positively: "Like many others I am only learning about poetry and with others have come up against the 'what is poetry and what isn't' argument..."

But the richest resource was one that took me by surprise. Poems from readers started to come in, first in dribs and drabs then in several fat brown envelopes a week. My shrewd section editor, Nigel Billen, and I decided on a softly-softly approach: don't say we're accepting readers' poems, don't say we're not. In the end more than 60% of the poems I chose came from readers. In fact, we were probably the most democratic poetry space in print journalism.

I had received, and published, poems from children - nine-year-old Joseph Toth's stirring Between Colour and Race and the beautiful Shell Song by Anna Aged 4 - as well as adults including octogenarians and schizophrenics. Some of the best have come hand-scrawled, in one case on yellowing tissue paper; some of the worst have come beautifully presented with self-satisfied CVs.

Looking back I realise that we have tapped into a rich vein of unpublished or hardly published verse, often more vital than the smart and knowing poetry which dominates the major presses.

These are poets - such as Efosa Ebowe - not afraid to speak prophetically about corruption or - such as Valentine Evans or Alison Brumfitt - about ecological disaster. There have been superb love poems - I remember the beginning of JCM Hepple's Waking on a Winter Morning and the passionate songs of obsession by Julie Whitby. A high proportion of the poems I've found most satisfying have been by women in their 60s and onwards: marvellously layered, self-aware perspectives on life by Christine Bress, Connie Bensley, Ruth Bidgood and Beata Duncan.

Looking back on the four-and-a-half year life of the Daily Poem from this moment of its sudden and brutal execution, I am pleased to have brought excellent poets to the kind of wide, unspecialised readership which poetry seems to have lost and which it desperately needs to regain.

In editing the Daily Poem I have held on to what many might think an over-serious or elevated view of poetry as a touchstone of emotional and spiritual truth and reality. I've published many humorous poems but I have not thought that poetry in a newspaper must inevitably aspire to the condition of light verse or doggerel. Unfortunately emotional reality does not look as if it will be a highly-valued commodity for the new regime in Blackfriars Road.

The day before I received the letter informing me of the Daily Poem's demise, the Daily Express carried the first issue of what is promised as a new supplement, OK! Express. This appears to focus on the curious category of the sub-celebrity. Worship of bland inanity could hardly be more removed from the stringently truth-telling power of poetry.

I am fiercely proud to have served that power, and deeply sad that the many readers who have responded with such warmth and lack of pretension have had something which they valued taken away from them.

I looked forward to introducing some of the best (not necessarily best-known) of today's poets - Michael Longley, Connie Bensley, Ian Duhig, Maura Dooley, Colin Falck - and to receiving flak from readers who'd been wrongly taught at school that all poetry must rhyme. Knowing that poetry can inspire fear, and even hatred, I started writing a commentary on each poem: not a factual blurb, but an attempt to guide readers to the poem's heart. Doreen Eaton, from Broughton Astley, Leicestershire, was one of several readers to respond positively: "Like many others I am only learning about poetry and with others have come up against the 'what is poetry and what isn't' argument..." But the richest resource was one that took me by surprise. Poems from readers started to come in, first in dribs and drabs then in several fat brown envelopes a week. My shrewd section editor, Nigel Billen, and I decided on a softly-softly approach: don't say we're accepting readers' poems, don't say we're not. In the end more than 60% of the poems I chose came from readers. In fact, we were probably the most democratic poetry space in print journalism. I had received, and published, poems from children - nine-year-old Joseph Toth's stirring Between Colour and Race and the beautiful Shell Song by Anna Aged 4 - as well as adults including octogenarians and schizophrenics. Some of the best have come hand-scrawled, in one case on yellowing tissue paper; some of the worst have come beautifully presented with self-satisfied CVs. Looking back I realise that we have tapped into a rich vein of unpublished or hardly published verse, often more vital than the smart and knowing poetry which dominates the major presses. These are poets - such as Efosa Ebowe - not afraid to speak prophetically about corruption or - such as Valentine Evans or Alison Brumfitt - about ecological disaster. There have been superb love poems - I remember the beginning of JCM Hepple's Waking on a Winter Morning and the passionate songs of obsession by Julie Whitby. A high proportion of the poems I've found most satisfying have been by women in their 60s and onwards: marvellously layered, self-aware perspectives on life by Christine Bress, Connie Bensley, Ruth Bidgood and Beata Duncan. Looking back on the four-and-a-half year life of the Daily Poem from this moment of its sudden and brutal execution, I am pleased to have brought excellent poets to the kind of wide, unspecialised readership which poetry seems to have lost and which it desperately needs to regain. In editing the Daily Poem I have held on to what many might think an over-serious or elevated view of poetry as a touchstone of emotional and spiritual truth and reality. I've published many humorous poems but I have not thought that poetry in a newspaper must inevitably aspire to the condition of light verse or doggerel. Unfortunately emotional reality does not look as if it will be a highly-valued commodity for the new regime in Blackfriars Road. The day before I received the letter informing me of the Daily Poem's demise, the Daily Express carried the first issue of what is promised as a new supplement, OK! Express. This appears to focus on the curious category of the sub-celebrity. Worship of bland inanity could hardly be more removed from the stringently truth-telling power of poetry. I am fiercely proud to have served that power, and deeply sad that the many readers who have responded with such warmth and lack of pretension have had something which they valued taken away from them.

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: • If the idea of spending a weekend skiing with leading dot.com entrepreneurs floats your boat, then perhaps you could get yourself to Crans Montana in Switzerland for a weekend at the end of March. Special invites have already gone out to 30 leading internet lights to join James Bennett of the European Technology Forum and Charlie Muirhead of iGabriel - both James Bond on snow - on the slopes. And the trip's a snip at £800. The idea, says the invite, is to do some good skiing with other leading innovators, such as Martha Lane Fox, Brent Hoberman and Mark Bernstein (Gameplay). So that's Martha in designer ski garb swishing down the slopes. Surely it's about time someone installed better ski-slope webcams, this could be engrossing viewing.

 If the idea of spending a weekend skiing with leading dot.com entrepreneurs floats your boat, then perhaps you could get yourself to Crans Montana in Switzerland for a weekend at the end of March. Special invites have already gone out to 30 leading internet lights to join James Bennett of the European Technology Forum and Charlie Muirhead of iGabriel - both James Bond on snow - on the slopes. And the trip's a snip at £800. The idea, says the invite, is to do some good skiing with other leading innovators, such as Martha Lane Fox, Brent Hoberman and Mark Bernstein (Gameplay). So that's Martha in designer ski garb swishing down the slopes. Surely it's about time someone installed better ski-slope webcams, this could be engrossing viewing.

 A domain name battle looms at ITV, with the news that Granada and Carlton have started development on an ITV website to claw back some dignity against the mighty BBC Online. Intent on going global, Granada now freely bandies around the domain name ITV.com, not realising how easy it is for us to check that ITV.com is already registered to one Nick Rosen of the Online Research Agency. Rosen registered the domain back in 1994, thinking that one day he would use it to set up an interactive TV channel, and in spite of legal letters from ITV, has never once been bullied into selling it. Fight the good fight Nick. So, ITV will either have to be content with ITV.co.uk, or dig very deep into its pockets to make Rosen an offer he can't refuse.

 Colonel Sanders must have been turning in his grave last week, worrying that his secret formula for Kentucky Fried Chicken was in enemy hands. The press had a field day but in the end the recipe remained under lock and key. What about the internet? Clearly no one has ever bothered entering that famous phrase "KFC secret recipe" in a search engine. I did, and I got 1,500 results. So if anyone has a burning desire to know the secret ingredient then you heard it here first - according to the wisdom of the web, it's half a cup of salt. Yuck. Amazing what you find on the internet.

 I have to ask, does anyone know what is going on at AltaVista Europe? As news leaked of two senior departures last week, all points of contact for AltaVista in Europe battened down the hatches. A conversation with the press office went something like this: "Hello, can you tell me if any more people are leaving AltaVista?" - "Sorry, we can't comment on that." "Well, what about the rumours that you're closing the European arm?" - "Er, we can't comment on that either." "Okay, so, who can comment?" - "No one at all in the UK, sorry." The mind boggles. Everything is being dictated by parent internet baron CMGI from the US, and bosses in the UK are walking. Is there no end to AltaVista's troubles?

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com.

fields.headline: My new media
fields.standfirst: Shaa Wasmund
fields.trailText: Shaa Wasmund, CEO of mykindaplace.com.
fields.body:
Favourite sites?

Currently my favourites are every single estate agent website in London because I'm trying to find a house. I use Winkworth, KFH and Hugh Grover for Islington. The sites are really useful because they save you a huge amount of time by not having to visit estate agents in person. Unfortunately, though, the problem still remains of trying to find a flat that you like. After that, I go to Small Luxury Hotels of the World to see where I can run away to.

Last online purchase? CDs from HMV and food from Sainsbury's. I do all my food shopping online. Anyone who would rather stand in a queue at a supermarket instead of sitting in front of a computer for five minutes must be crazy.

Most recent technological faux pas?

When I haven't understood a technological term that someone has used in a meeting and everyone looks at me like it's the most obvious thing in the entire world. That's OK because I don't have a problem asking: "What's an SSL line?"

Main news source on the web?

FT.com, CNN and BBC Online.

Most persistent spam emailer?

Lastminute.com but maybe it's my fault and I should just take myself off.

Time spent on the web? I'm on and off all day long, and probably spend an hour and half a day at the weekend.

Next boo.com? I thought it was going to be Letsbuyit, but they've had a bit of a rescue bid. I think they all suffer from the same problems of overstaffing and overspending on the marketing budget.

Least useful site on the web?

lastminute.com - it drives me mad. It's like going into a sweet shop and having a million different choices. It's overwhelming and I can't find anything.

Which screensaver do you use?

None. They've never appealed to me.

Most irritating thing about the web? When you've had your fantastic fast internet connection at work, and you go home and it's so much slower. This isn't the web's fault - it's the lack of technology being introduced by BT and NTL to provide the same service at home as you get at work.

Do you still bother with old media? Absolutely. You can't replace a good magazine in the bath or a Sunday newspaper.

 Shaa Wasmund is the CEO of Mykindaplace.com.

fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.trailText: John Kampfner: Godric Smith, the civil service number two in the Downing Street press office, was collecting his notes when the phone rang last Tuesday afternoon. It was a political correspondent asking for a comment on a new almighty row over Europe.
fields.body:
Godric Smith, the civil service number two in the Downing Street press office, was collecting his notes when the phone rang last Tuesday afternoon. It was a political correspondent asking for a comment on a new almighty row over Europe. This had everything: the single currency, tax, integration - and Germans. The story was that Tony Blair had agreed with Chancellor Schröder that the Euro would eventually lead to fiscal harmonisation. It had to be true, the Germans had briefed on it.

There were only a few minutes before the 4pm afternoon lobby, which Smith was due to take in the now-familiar absence of Alastair Campbell. After the most traumatic week in the spin-life of this government, this was the last thing any of them needed.

The latest fracas stemmed from a dinner between Blair and Schröder in Berlin on Monday night, one of those lightning bilateral visits that often go unnoticed by the papers. The event passed off smoothly, or so they thought. Both sides put out what is known as a "dry line", in other words as little information as possible, noting they had discussed Anglo-German ties, relations with the US as the new administration settles in, Russia, and - obliquely - future European cooperation. They also produced a joint statement on football transfer fees. The political spin was that the Prime Minister was getting back to real business after the Mandelson saga.

The following lunchtime, German and foreign correspondents in Berlin were invited to a briefing by Michael Steiner, Schröder's chief foreign policy adviser. Steiner's account of the previous evening's meeting, which was relayed by the press corps back to London, was somewhat different.

Blair, he suggested, had agreed with the German Chancellor's view that, once part of the euro, the UK would accept the need for common tax rates. This was the exact reverse of Blair's oft-stated public line, and red rag to a bull. Several lobby members were in high excitement when Smith met them in the usual turret meeting room. They hadn't had a good euro bust-up since Nice, more than a month ago - and on that occasion, Britain wasn't even at the centre of it.

Before leaving for the Commons, Smith spoke to Patrick Sawer, Blair's foreign policy man in his private office, the other member of the foursome at the Berlin dinner. He told him Schröder had referred to tax in passing, but Blair had said nothing in reply. Therefore, the conclusion was, no discussion on tax had taken place. That was enough for a holding position for the lobby.

Shortly after, Steiner was contacted and an explanation was sought. The Germans asserted that lines must have got crossed. A clarification was issued. Steiner, it was said, had also been briefing on the Franco-German summit that was to take place in Alsace on Wednesday evening with President Chirac, and his mentions of tax referred to that meeting. The soft-spoken Smith hoped this provided enough ammunition to kill the story.

It largely worked. The broadcast media by and large ignored it. Only some papers carried the story. The Telegraph had the most - a page lead on its foreign pages, stating that Blair was "embroiled in an embarrassing row"; the Times ran a single column at the bottom of page 16, headlined "German gaffe on the Euro"; the Independent had a small piece on page 2, and even the Daily Mail put it on page 4. Had it not been for the Alder Hey controversy, and more fallout from the Mandelson affair, things could have been a lot worse.

So anxious is the government about Europe that it works from the assumption that any story on the subject is bound to be negative. As for Steiner, I have met him several times. He is extremely smart and well aware of the internal British debate. But he has more than once expressed the view to me that, as long as Britain remains outside the euro, its influence will diminish.

German officials are also convinced that the British will accept this in the long run. For once, I suspect, Steiner's candid and perceptive view of British policy got the better of diplomatic niceties, spin and double spin. And for once, the Westminster lobby was prepared to give all involved the benefit of the doubt.

webTitle: Merseyside off limits for Bulger two

fields.headline: Merseyside off limits for Bulger two
fields.trailText: James Bulger's killers are expected to be banned by the parole board from ever returning to Merseyside as a condition of their release later this year.
fields.body:
James Bulger's killers are expected to be banned by the parole board from ever returning to Merseyside as a condition of their release later this year.

Robert Thompson and Jon Venables are also certain to be barred from approaching any members of the Bulger family, including Denise Fergus and Ralph Bulger, the parents of the two-year-old they abducted and murdered in February 1993 when they were 10. The pair will probably have to agree never to contact each other again.

The likely conditions emerged yesterday as the parole board held a preliminary hearing to fix details of the separate hearings in a few months that will decide whether the two killers, now 18, will win their freedom this summer.

They are expected to be released on licence, taking up new identities fashioned for them by the Home Office, and resettled somewhere in England away from their former Merseyside homes.

The hearing yesterday at a secret location, thought to be somewhere in London, is the first step towards their release. The process was set in train after the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, decided last October that their tariff - the minimum term they should serve for retribution and deterrence - should expire immediately.

The two were represented by lawyers at yesterday's hearing but were not present themselves. They will give evidence along with other witnesses at their full hearings .

The preliminary hearing was held to decide on such details as who should give evidence and what reports need to be prepared. One item on the agenda is the outcome of a Home Office inquiry into claims in a Sunday newspaper that Thompson tried to strangle a fellow inmate with a flex.

Robin Makin, solicitor for James Bulger's father Ralph, last night criticised the decision to go ahead with the preliminary hearing before theoutcome of his high court challenge to Lord Woolf's recommendation of a tariff of less than eight years and its acceptance by the home secretary, Jack Straw. A three-judge court, headed by Lord Justice Rose, vice-president of the court of appeal criminal division, is scheduled to hear the case on February 15 and 16.

Mr Bulger's lawyers will argue that Lord Woolf gave disproportionate weight to the teenagers' rehabilitation in the local authority secure units where they are serving their sentences, and that Mr Straw acted unlawfully in announcing in advance that he was "bound to accept" whatever the lord chief justice recommended. Mr Makin said it was ironic that Mr Straw would have to defend Lord Woolf at the hearing, "when they are at loggerheads over penal policy".

Lawyers for the Home Office and Lord Woolf are expected to argue that he took his decision in his capacity as a judge and is therefore not subject to judicial review.

Mr Makin said he had been contacted by the probation service, which wanted to see Mr Bulger "in a few weeks" to hear his views on parole for his son's killers. Comments from the family will be part of the evidence presented to the parole board before its decision.

James's mother, Denise Fergus, who lives in Kirkby, Merseyside, is to lead a protest march that will end with a memorial service in Kirkby on February 10, two days before the eighth anniversary of his death. Marchers are expected to carry banners calling for Thompson and Venables to be denied parole.

On their release they will be protected by a unique lifetime blanket ban on media stories about their new identities. Newspapers that opposed the ban, imposed last month by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the high court's family division, have decided not to appeal against it.

webTitle: John Lewis to snap up e-tailer

fields.headline: John Lewis to snap up e-tailer
fields.standfirst:
Retail chain sets sights on buy.com's British arm

More net news
fields.trailText: Store chain John Lewis is expected to step up its online retail operations today with an announcement that it has bought the troubled British arm of e-tailer buy.com, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Store chain John Lewis is expected to step up its online retail operations today with an announcement that it has bought the troubled British arm of e-tailer buy.com.

The department store and supermarket group and the British offshoot of American internet company buy.com are understood to have finalised the terms of the deal at the weekend.

A link-up with buy.com would enable John Lewis to expand online more rapidly. The group would have access to an established management team and tested technology solutions. John Lewis intends to have a wide range of products on offer at the website by Christmas.

The deal is the latest example of how established retailers are taking over dot.coms, which internet analysts once thought might undermine bricks-and-mortar outlets.

Jungle.com is now part of Great Universal Stores, and recently Kingfisher bought CD e-tailer Streetsonline.com.

Last year John Lewis bought a 40% stake in internet company Last Mile Solutions (LMS) for £35m.

LMS is setting up a grocery supply service and will start delivering food from Waitrose - John Lewis' supermarket brand - to consumers this spring.

John Lewis also has a waitrose.com site, and its johnlewis.co.uk operation has already increased its range of products this year. It currently has some 1,500 lines available on the web.

A statement about the proposed buy.com deal is expected after John Lewis's general council meeting today.

Buy.com's UK offshoot specialises in computer hardware, software and office supplies, and has a range of 30,000 products available online. Its US parent has been looking for a partner for the British business since last year.

The company, part-owned by Rupert Murdoch through his eVentures offshoot - an investment unit he set up with Japanese dot.com investment specialist Softbank - has said its business model is based on partnerships with offline companies.

It is thought buy.com and johnlewis.co.uk will keep separate websites but will take advantage of cross-marketing and site links.

Buy.com, which announced last week it had clinched a deal with an unnamed buyer, has found business tough since the internet bubble burst. The company reported a loss of $27.4m (£18.6m) in the last quarter and has been a member of the 99% club - a band of dot.coms that have seen their share prices lose 99% of their value. It closed its Australian operation in November.

Last night Murray Hennessy, chief executive officer of buy.com UK, refused to comment on the John Lewis deal.

John Lewis also has a waitrose.com site, and its johnlewis.co.uk operation has already increased its range of products this year. It currently has some 1,500 lines available on the web. A statement about the proposed buy.com deal is expected after John Lewis's general council meeting today. Buy.com's UK offshoot specialises in computer hardware, software and office supplies, and has a range of 30,000 products available online. Its US parent has been looking for a partner for the British business since last year. The company, part-owned by Rupert Murdoch through his eVentures offshoot - an investment unit he set up with Japanese dot.com investment specialist Softbank - has said its business model is based on partnerships with offline companies. It is thought buy.com and johnlewis.co.uk will keep separate websites but will take advantage of cross-marketing and site links. Buy.com, which announced last week it had clinched a deal with an unnamed buyer, has found business tough since the internet bubble burst. The company reported a loss of $27.4m (£18.6m) in the last quarter and has been a member of the 99% club - a band of dot.coms that have seen their share prices lose 99% of their value. It closed its Australian operation in November. Last night Murray Hennessy, chief executive officer of buy.com UK, refused to comment on the John Lewis deal.

webTitle: Media: Journalists should learn integrated newsgathering

fields.headline: Journalist, integrate thyself
fields.trailText: Chris Cramer: The introduction of bi-media working at BBC News was just a foretaste of what was coming and has now developed into a key part of the survival of the fittest in the media.
fields.body:
The newsroom cartoonist at the BBC summed up the corporation's management changes in 1991 when he sketched a picture of a one-man band. Though in place of musical instruments this one was carrying a camera, recording machine, notebook and pencil. He also had a broom for sweeping tucked away in a convenient place.

This caricature of the latest insanity by broadcast bosses has stuck for many years. The analogy has been used many times to denigrate the notion of multiskilling in the broadcast industry.

How would it be possible, the critics argued, for journalists to operate both for radio and for television news? What pen-pushing-news-manager-turned-beancounter had dreamed up the absurd notion that television correspondents and radio practitioners could work as one?

As it turned out, the introduction of bi-media working at BBC News was just a foretaste of what was coming and has now developed into a key part of the survival of the fittest in the media.

Back in 1991 at the BBC, it was a practical way of ensuring that the best and brightest from the news ranks were able to report for both the Today programme on Radio 4 and the Nine O'Clock News on BBC TV. And it was also designed to ensure that licence payers' money was not unduly wasted by one part of the BBC not knowing what the other was doing.

If ever evidence was needed of this lack of coordination, it was produced when news managers discovered that one BBC radio journalist had travelled out of Heathrow airport on the same aircraft as a BBC TV journalist - one in club class, the other in economy - to cover the same story. They stayed in different hotels, covered the story without meeting, and met back at Heathrow as they collected their luggage.

This grotesque lack of coordination necessitated change at the BBC, and since then newsgathering staff for radio and TV have operated as one integrated department. Many of the BBC's finest radio correspondents - Fergal Keane, Matt Frei - are now household names on television, while their counterparts in the television division routinely file for radio.

Fast forward 10 years to today and the industry now faces a new challenge. How to ensure that the best of journalism gets to the widest possible audience with the most efficient use of resources?

This month at CNN, we have started to roll out new ways of working for the 1,000 or so newsgatherers who provide content for our 34 different services around the globe. Journalists will now acquire the skills and resources to report for all platforms - television, radio and new media. The difference is that we will assign on a daily basis who does what, not who does everything.

There is now a recognition across the industry that reinvention and change is the only way forward. Newspapers are embracing the web and learning to use video. Television and radio services must develop content for pagers, mobile phones and the web. To do this, journalists and the systems they work with must be equipped to provide information to these services - fully integrated systems and fully integrated journalists.

For example, in Atlanta, London and Hong Kong, CNN staff are developing "cross-platform" writing, a simple system designed to enable journalists to create content for all known platforms and also store this content, in tagged form, ready for use on platforms and services not yet developed. It requires a tight writing discipline with each paragraph of text treated as a component part of a story - and then extracted automatically for web, SMS, digital text, handheld device and Wap usage.

Elsewhere in the industry the days are fast disappearing where newsgatherers work only for TV, radio or interactive. This will mean more newsgatherers rather than fewer.

Meantime, this newsgathering reinvention goes hand in hand with the introduction of compact, hi-tech, inexpensive equipment. Look for the quick deployment of more small, high-quality DV cameras and laptop editing equipment, enabling the likes of Sky, ITN, BBC and CNN to deploy smaller reporting teams, one or two people at a time.

More conventional newsgathering teams and equipment will still remain for those assignments deemed necessary, such as reporting from war zones and hostile environments. But the days of routinely dispatching three- and four-person reporting teams with cases of bulky equipment are over.

This cannot be a one-size-fits-all strategy and it would be folly to dismiss or lose the industry's exceptional and distinctive skills, but it is the way ahead. As news organisations rush to embrace the new media world they will have to ensure that they have the skills and technology available to gather and provide content, or they could find themselves crippled by outdated practices.

 Chris Cramer is president of CNN International Networks.

fields.headline: Doctor: Organs scandal 'not my fault'
fields.standfirst:
Dick van Velzen protests innocence

Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: The doctor at the heart of the Alder Hey scandal has claimed he never knowingly removed organs from children without their parents' consent. Dick van Velzen, currently under police protection in Holland, told BBC News: "It's not my fault."
fields.body:
The doctor at the heart of the Alder Hey scandal has claimed he never knowingly removed organs from children without their parents' consent. Dick van Velzen, currently under police protection in Holland, told BBC News: "It's not my fault."

Refusing to go on camera, but allowing his voice to be taped, Professor van Velzen said from Amsterdam: "I've never taken organs without parents' permission. I have carried out post-mortems, either with parental consent or on behalf of a coroner. "People forgot to tell the parents what the post-mortem actually is. It's terrible. It's not my fault."

Prof van Velzen, 51, said he inherited a run-down, dilapidated system when he started work at the Alder Hey children's hospital in Liverpool.

"The support that was needed, that was promised, that was agreed to by NHS management...the support to re-establish care for parents in that hospital where it had been absent for years...that was not forthcoming. "That was not my choice. That was the management's choice. The main apology I can offer parents is that I have not resigned on their behalf earlier."

The President of the Royal College of Pathologists, Professor John Lilleyman, said he found Prof Van Velzen's line of defence "surprising".

He said it failed to address the most serious findings of the official inquiry report that he had taken material specifically against parental wishes and that he had falsified autopsy reports.

"I think the manner and scale of what went on at Alder Hey during what the report described as the Van Velzen years was quite extraordinary and really cannot be defended or excused in any way as acceptable professional practice, even by the standards of the time," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"I am not clear whether he is withdrawing his previous admissions to the Redfern inquiry but if he is, he should make it explicit why he is withdrawing them."

Police have been brought in to investigate possible criminal charges against the pathologist over organ retention at Alder Hey. A warrant was also issued for his arrest in Canada after children's organs were found in Halifax, Nova Scotia, where he went after leaving Liverpool.

Professor van Velzen's denial comes as health officials prepare for an emergency summit to combat a feared collapse in the number of transplants following the Alder Hey scandal. Health secretary Alan Milburn will hold the meeting with surgeons, health chiefs, business representatives, unions and parents "as soon as possible" in a bid to rebuild public confidence as donations are feared to have dropped by more than half.

Liver transplant surgeon John Buckels, of the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Birmingham, said the centre "had not had a single donor for 10 days".

"The drop in organ donations could inevitably put people at risk if last week is anything to go by," he said. "We already have a shortfall and a situation where some patients deteriorate and die, and inevitably that will get worse."

The Royal Brompton Hospital in west London, another leading transplant centre, also said it had not carried out any transplants over the last week and a half. Dr Michael Wilks, chairman of the British Medical Association's medical ethics committee, said it was "extremely worrying" to hear that the number of organs being donated for transplant has dropped suddenly in the wake of the Alder Hey report.

Pioneering heart surgeon Sir Magdi Yacoub has voiced concerns that the scandal could lead to a potentially fatal drop in donors. A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said it would draw up plans for the meeting today and hoped to hold it in London in the next few weeks. Measures under discussion include putting donor cards in people's pay packets and other ways of raising awareness.

fields.headline: A decade of diplomacy
fields.standfirst: The Press Complaints Commission celebrates its 10th birthday with a star-studded party this week. But is it only the stars who are satisfied?  Roy Greenslade  reports
fields.trailText: The Press Complaints Commission celebrates its 10th birthday with a star-studded party this week. But is it only the stars who are satisfied? By Roy Greenslade.
fields.body:
Just in case you haven't noticed, the Press Complaints Commission will celebrate its 10th anniversary on Wednesday at what the Sun calls "the star-studded party of the year". Prince Charles, Prince William and Camilla Parker Bowles are expected to rub shoulders with George Michael, former Spice Girl Geri Halliwell and supermodel Claudia Schiffer, a sprinkling of soap stars, senior politicians and most of the national newspaper editors.

What the wildly exaggerated Sun story didn't say is that the stars who will attend have one thing in common: they have all complained to the PCC. It also overlooked the fact that the guests will include a selection of complainants who are not famous.

One of them is Christopher Livesey, an Accrington lad who suffered from press harassment at a time when the PCC was drawing up guidelines to protect Prince William. Lord Wakeham, PCC chairman, famously remarked that both boys deserved exactly the same right to privacy.

It is ironic that press coverage of the party should encourage the perception that the PCC pays attention only to complaints from the famous and near-famous. It does not, but it has to be remembered that, as far as national papers are concerned, the majority of complainants tend to be high profile because, of course, they are the subjects of most stories.

Indeed, the PCC came into existence because of pressure from politicians and other members of the establishment upset by the particularly bad behaviour of papers in the 1980s.

Several MPs were pressing for laws to protect privacy and to provide a statutory right of reply. The government responded in 1989 by appointing a committee, chaired by David Calcutt QC, to consider whether the MPs might be right. While it was hearing evidence, the then home office minister, David Mellor, showed his feelings by warning that "the press - the popular press - is drinking in the Last Chance Saloon". Calcutt's report echoed that sentiment.

Self-regulation should have one more chance. The Press Council should be replaced by the PCC which would have 18 months to prove that it could work effectively. If not, Calcutt warned that he would push for legislation.

This threat alarmed newspaper owners enough for them to hold a historic meeting at which they put aside their enmities to agree a united response. Sent to represent my then boss, Robert Maxwell, I witnessed the industry's most powerful figures wrestling with the problem. I detected a difference in emphasis between those who controlled broadsheets - especially Conrad Black (director and chairman of the Daily Telegraph) and Andreas Whittam Smith (editor and chief executive of the Independent), who made the best contributions - and those responsible for tabloids. Neither side wanted legislation; they feared that serious investigative journalism was at risk if a law was enacted.

It was decided that if editors were to respect the PCC, they needed a proper set of guidelines, a code, so that everyone - journalists and public - knew where they stood.

Editors then met to agree on a code. In what turned out to be a shrewd move, though I was motivated by mischief, I nominated the then editor of the News of the World, Patsy Chapman, to take the chair. Her paper was widely considered as second only to the Sun as the greatest sinner, and it was obvious that if she approved some kind of ethical code it would stand a good chance of being accepted by everyone.

That is just how it turned out. With great tact, Chapman chaired a series of editors' meetings, drawn from a variety of national and regional papers. What emerged was the editors' code of practice, which has been the most effective brake on press misdeeds since newspapers were first forced to set up a self-regulatory regime in 1953.

The PCC's job therefore was to ensure that editors obeyed their own code, an apparently straightforward task which was to prove a great deal more complex and, eventually, beyond the skills of its first chairman, Lord McGregor. He got a taste of what to expect on his first day when Buckingham Palace asked him to go to Sandringham immediately to see how Prince Charles and Princess Diana were being hounded by the press. He refused, but it was a significant pointer to problems ahead.

The PCC had a far from promising start, almost collapsing in 1993 when Calcutt made another powerful plea for a statutory body and Mirror group's chief executive, David Montgomery, briefly withdrew his papers from membership because McGregor not only criticised the Daily Mirror for using pictures of Princess Diana exercising in a gym, but called for an advertising boycott. Behind-the-scenes diplomacy by the Daily Mail's editor-in-chief, David English, saved the day: a wiser, veteran press chief prevented a rogue publisher from destroying the PCC. Has self-regulation ever worked so well?

That episode certainly indicated that McGregor might not be up to the job. His rush to judgment when the Sunday Times serialised the Andrew Morton book on Diana, lambasting it for "dabbling their fingers in the stuff of other people's souls", proved the point.

McGregor might well have got into more trouble, and jeopardised the PCC's future, had he not had an able director in Mark Bolland. Gradually, in spite of the hiccups, the PCC gained respect and adjudications were taken seriously by editors. They fought hard to ensure complaints were not upheld, but complied with the rule that they must publish them in full when they were.

When McGregor retired in 1995, I was downcast when Lord Wakeham got the chairmanship. Surely this former Tory party minister was the wrong man for the job? He would be compromised by his party allegiance, not to mention his string of directorships. He would find editors altogether less amenable to his behind-the-Speaker's-chair brand of fixing.

In fact, Wakeham turned out to be an inspired choice. His first major test came in his first year when the News of the World published a picture of Countess Spencer in a clinic, a clear breach of the editors' code.

Wakeham spoke to Rupert Murdoch, convinced him of the gravity of the offence and Murdoch then repudiated editor Piers Morgan in public. The PCC's authority was established, and it's fair to say that no editor has violated the code so flagrantly since.

Bolland went off to work for Prince Charles, and his successor, Guy Black, quickly formed a good working relationship with Wakeham. They also built a dependable team at their office just off Fleet Street, the last link between national papers and their former home.

Diana's death in 1997, with its reminder of the activities of photographic stalkers, was a turning point for the PCC. The code on the use of pictures was tightened along with extra measures to protect children.

There have been other landmarks, too, among the 23,000 cases dealt with in the decade: an adjudication against the Mail on Sunday for intruding into the privacy of the prime minister's daughter; a complaint upheld against the News of the World for publishing a kiss-and-tell story about Coronation Street actress Jacqueline Pirie; the humbling criticism of Morgan, this time as Mirror editor, after the share-tipping fiasco.

Perhaps the most useful development in trying to decide whether intrusion is justified has been the PCC's concept of "proportionality". Just because a person is famous, and has previously appeared in papers or magazines, they cannot be said to sacrifice all rights to privacy.

But Wakeham and Black would be the first to admit that the code is not perfect. In a sense, it never will be, and perhaps it never should be. It has to be elastic enough to take account of unpredictable events, and it still has to allow for editors to have the freedom to be wrong. The public interest test is often a matter of fierce debate.

Similarly, self-regulation itself remains suspect for many people. The PCC is funded by the newspapers it polices. Its only sanction is censure. Most lawyers think it flawed in concept and in practice, but they would, wouldn't they?

Two of the PCC's long-running leading critics, Labour MP Clive Soley and Mike Jempson, director of the media ethics body Presswise, readily concede that press behaviour has improved over the past 10 years. "It would be churlish not to say so," says Soley. But he points to PCC failings that many other people often mention to me, especially those who have complained unsuccessfully. First, the PCC prefers to act as a conciliator rather than a judge. It seeks to find a compromise in which the paper often comes out best, publishing a small correction or a letter, which people find unsatisfying. The punishment has not met the crime.

Second, Soley believes it is too rarely proactive, a charge backed by Jempson, who thinks it unfair that neither third parties nor groups of people are able to complain. He is particularly exercised by the unfair press treatment of asylum seekers who have no way of answering through the PCC the distortions about them.

Jempson is also right when he says that people find it difficult to mount their evidence against papers. In many cases, it is their word against the journalist's, "yet there is no mechanism for the commission to get at the truth". Therefore papers too often tend to be given the benefit of the doubt.

These are genuine grievances that demand attention. But looking at last year's PCC statistics I noted that most complaints, as usual, were about accuracy in reporting. Then again, the percentage relating to accuracy (58%) was the lowest in 10 years - a better birthday tribute the PCC than this week's party.

In fact, Wakeham turned out to be an inspired choice. His first major test came in his first year when the News of the World published a picture of Countess Spencer in a clinic, a clear breach of the editors' code. Wakeham spoke to Rupert Murdoch, convinced him of the gravity of the offence and Murdoch then repudiated editor Piers Morgan in public. The PCC's authority was established, and it's fair to say that no editor has violated the code so flagrantly since. Bolland went off to work for Prince Charles, and his successor, Guy Black, quickly formed a good working relationship with Wakeham. They also built a dependable team at their office just off Fleet Street, the last link between national papers and their former home. Diana's death in 1997, with its reminder of the activities of photographic stalkers, was a turning point for the PCC. The code on the use of pictures was tightened along with extra measures to protect children. There have been other landmarks, too, among the 23,000 cases dealt with in the decade: an adjudication against the Mail on Sunday for intruding into the privacy of the prime minister's daughter; a complaint upheld against the News of the World for publishing a kiss-and-tell story about Coronation Street actress Jacqueline Pirie; the humbling criticism of Morgan, this time as Mirror editor, after the share-tipping fiasco. Perhaps the most useful development in trying to decide whether intrusion is justified has been the PCC's concept of "proportionality". Just because a person is famous, and has previously appeared in papers or magazines, they cannot be said to sacrifice all rights to privacy. But Wakeham and Black would be the first to admit that the code is not perfect. In a sense, it never will be, and perhaps it never should be. It has to be elastic enough to take account of unpredictable events, and it still has to allow for editors to have the freedom to be wrong. The public interest test is often a matter of fierce debate. Similarly, self-regulation itself remains suspect for many people. The PCC is funded by the newspapers it polices. Its only sanction is censure. Most lawyers think it flawed in concept and in practice, but they would, wouldn't they? Two of the PCC's long-running leading critics, Labour MP Clive Soley and Mike Jempson, director of the media ethics body Presswise, readily concede that press behaviour has improved over the past 10 years. "It would be churlish not to say so," says Soley. But he points to PCC failings that many other people often mention to me, especially those who have complained unsuccessfully. First, the PCC prefers to act as a conciliator rather than a judge. It seeks to find a compromise in which the paper often comes out best, publishing a small correction or a letter, which people find unsatisfying. The punishment has not met the crime. Second, Soley believes it is too rarely proactive, a charge backed by Jempson, who thinks it unfair that neither third parties nor groups of people are able to complain. He is particularly exercised by the unfair press treatment of asylum seekers who have no way of answering through the PCC the distortions about them. Jempson is also right when he says that people find it difficult to mount their evidence against papers. In many cases, it is their word against the journalist's, "yet there is no mechanism for the commission to get at the truth". Therefore papers too often tend to be given the benefit of the doubt. These are genuine grievances that demand attention. But looking at last year's PCC statistics I noted that most complaints, as usual, were about accuracy in reporting. Then again, the percentage relating to accuracy (58%) was the lowest in 10 years - a better birthday tribute the PCC than this week's party.

webTitle: Dublin's rich add twist to tale of two cities

fields.headline: Dublin's rich add twist to tale of two cities
fields.standfirst: Starving Irish immigrants of the 19th century have been replaced by a new elite, helping turn Liverpool into a millionaires' playground
fields.trailText: Starving Irish immigrants of the 19th century have been replaced by a new elite, helping turn Liverpool into a millionaires' playground
fields.body:
They are two cities of roughly the same size, with similar cultures and accent, 140 miles apart - yet separated by a frequently stormy sea.

In the mid 19th century, tens of thousands of starving immigrants poured into Liverpool from Dublin to work in the city's docks and workshops as the area became one of the world's great trading posts.

Now, in a remarkable reversal, Ireland's dynamic new entrepreneurs and Dublin's cash-rich property elite are pouring tens of millions into Liverpool and helping to transform a down-at-heel city into a millionaires' playground. It has become a place to dump surplus capital and make money work faster than in overheating Ireland.

They are buying up flats by the hundred, helping to fuel an unprecedented property boom, investing in new port facilities to serve high-speed ferries, and even planning supermarket distribution depots - to serve Ireland, not England.

The historic connections between the cities are being further strengthened by cut-price air travel and express ferries - making it much faster, and cheaper, for Liverpudlians to get to Dublin than to London.

Since the cities twinned in 1998, David Tinsey of the Liverpool chamber of commerce said the links between them have strengthened to such an extent that their economies are almost merging.

"Dublin is not thought of as a foreign city," he said. "People here consider Dubliners to be kith and kin. The links are natural. As the economy in Dublin peaks, business people are looking elsewhere for prime areas to invest. London is expensive and a more difficult market to penetrate."

Across the Irish Sea, Phil Sweeney, director of sales and marketing for the Prem Group, one of Dublin's largest property concerns, agreed. They are taking out leases on scores of Liverpool apartments and are now opening serviced offices in the city.

"A lot of people in Dublin are sitting on serious wealth and it is getting harder and harder to find investment opportunities over here," she said. "Development in the city is just not encouraged any more. We have lost a lot of our tax incentives, which makes cities outside Dublin - particularly Liverpool - an attractive proposition."

Part of the attraction is the more favourable fiscal regime in a UK outside the eurozone: taxes levied on properties valued between £25,000 and £500,000 are small compared with Irish taxes of 15% on similarly priced homes.

As a result, the chief executive of one large Liverpool property company said he knows of at least one Irishman who is borrowing £30m of mortgage cash each year to buy flats in Liverpool.

The type of investment and talent coming across the Irish Sea is also diversifying, taking in sectors other than the traditional areas of property and construction.

Mr Tinsey points to supermarket distribution and the professional services sector as a prime example of the shift. High profile Dublin residents such, as fashion designer John Rocha, are also taking an interest. He has chosen to launch his second major hotel interior design project in Liverpool.

The timing of the Irish interest in Liverpool is no coincidence. The city council and key players in the private sector point to a change in attitudes to Liverpool and to a new business confidence taking root.

Tom Bloxham, whose Manchester-based Urban Splash has been at the forefront of residential property development in the north west, said: "Liverpool has not been seen as a business-friendly city historically. But all this is changing. New investment capital is coming in and a chunk of it is coming from Ireland."

Paul Bolton of property developers the Charlton group agreed: "We have strong relationships with a number of Irish firms and they have an appetite for rental properties in the city centre in particular."

Mr Bolton said that Dublin's new-found business confidence is rubbing off on Merseyside. By investing in the city, which would benefit from a similar "can do" ethos as the Irish capital, he predicted that cash from Dublin could be a significant factor in Liverpool's future success.

Charlie Parker, executive officer for regeneration at Liverpool city council, said investors from Ireland and beyond are beginning to take Liverpool seriously. "It is very well placed as a gateway to east and west. It has benefited from its location in the past but we are now seeing different benefits. Add this to cheaper property and cheaper labour and we have an attractive package for new investment."

If the cash currently flowing from Ireland does turn into a flood, Dublin could once again be the engine for Liverpool's economy. There is an element of history repeating itself said local historian Steve Burns - albeit with Irish money rather than labour.

webTitle: UK and Italy move to stem illegal entrants

fields.headline: UK and Italy move to stem illegal entrants
fields.trailText: A joint Anglo-Italian initiative to stem the flow from the Balkans of tens of thousands of illegal entrants into Europe through the "Sarajevo route" will be followed this week by further measures to strengthen the "fortress Europe" approach to migration.
fields.body:
A joint Anglo-Italian initiative to stem the flow from the Balkans of tens of thousands of illegal entrants into Europe through the "Sarajevo route" will be followed this week by further measures to strengthen the "fortress Europe" approach to migration.

The United Nations has estimated that 10% of illegal entrants to Europe come via the Balkans route, with migrants paying up to £2,700 to make the journey. More than 50,000 migrants are estimated to have passed through Bosnia in the first 10 months of last year.

Britain was leading the way in the crackdown on human trafficking, the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, said yesterday. "The prime minister has taken a very, very close personal interest in this," she added.

Tony Blair yesterday pledged to target gangs involved in human trafficking and impose longer sentences on those caught, deploy more police and immigration officers in Bosnia to step up border checks, and provide funds for a voluntary repatriation scheme.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, will tomorrow renew his drive to "modernise" the 1951 UN convention on refugees. The British initiative - which could see the European Union agreeing only to take in refugees at moments of severe crisis - is believed to have won the backing of the Germans and stirred considerable interest among other European governments. Under Mr Straw's scheme individual asylum seekers could be restricted to claiming refugee status in the first safe country they reach, without being allowed to set foot in Europe.

British officials are also expected to criticise the French authorities at an Anglo-French summit on Friday for their failure to take action to stem the flow of illegal entrants from Calais across the channel. MPs on the Commons home affairs select committee said last week they had been appalled to discover hundreds of young people living in a Red Cross warehouse at Sangatte, near Calais, while waiting to try to enter Britain illegally. Some had made repeated attempts.

Mr Blair's decision to put his weight behind measures to tackle illegal migration reflects the recognition in Downing Street of the politically explosive potential of the issue in the run-up to the general election. He also backed calls to open up opportunities for legal migration into Europe.

"Every day we hear of the horrors illegal immigrants endure at the hands of the people-traffickers," said Mr Blair, in a joint article in the Observer with Guiliano Amato, the prime minister of Italy. "The catalogue of death in recent times speaks for itself - 58 Chinese at Dover last year, hundreds drowned yearly crossing the Mediterranean to Spain, Italy and Greece. There is evidence that traffickers have thrown women and children, many of whom cannot swim, into the Adriatic in the middle of the night simply to avoid detection by police patrol boats."

The two countries also agreed to a joint effort within the EU to identify more effectively and return people who arrive illegally in EU states. Assistance for voluntary repatriation programmes is to be stepped up. The joint statement said they were also both prepared to press for tougher penalties - currently 10 years imprisonment in Britain - for those who engage in human trafficking and transporting illegal migrants.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, criticised the initiative. "It is not for us to assist the Italians in protecting their frontiers," she said. She called for asylum seekers to be returned to the last safe country they had travelled through.
