fields.headline: Grim war on human traffickers
fields.standfirst: Few bright spots in a long battle against untouchable bosses with resilient networks
fields.trailText: Few bright spots in a long battle against untouchable bosses with resilient networks
fields.body:
Hands cupped over headsets, the eavesdroppers squinted in concentration, awaiting another elliptical conversation in a foreign tongue. Even when translated the transcripts would yield little, for when using mobile phones the human traffickers always spoke in code.

Not this time. A Slavic accent came on the line. "Pronto?" A pause, then an oriental accent replied: "Si, pronto." They were speaking Italian.

The Croat had excellent Italian but not his Chinese colleague. Using dialect or allusions - the traditional techniques to baffle eavesdroppers - were not options. Words had to be enunciated slowly and clearly. A van would take the group from Ljubljana in the morning and drop them at the motorway service station outside Trieste by 3pm. "D'accordo, ciao," signed off the snakehead.

It is not difficult to imagine the grins in Trieste's police headquarters. A few months later the gang, led by Josip Loncaric, was broken up by Slovenian and Italian police. They had discovered an achilles heel of transnational trafficking.

That is one of the few bright spots in a grim outlook for Britain's efforts to spearhead a European Union war against illegal immigration. The government hopes that coordinated assaults can cut the influx and allay voter concern that illegal immigration is out of control.

However interviews with traffickers, migrants, investigators, analysts and magistrates in five countries reveal an adaptable foe positioned to resist the challenge. Europe is facing a long war of attrition.

When British immigration liaison officers take up their posts in Vienna, Rome, Budapest and Zagreb in the spring they will find networks capable of shooting or bribing their way out of most difficulties.

Last November Hungarian police at the Ukrainian border uncovered a cache of guns with silencers, radio equipment tuned to police frequencies, night-vision glasses, binoculars, hand grenades and motorised rubber dinghies.

Last summer French police broke up a Chinese smuggling ring which laundered £170m through two bureaux de change - enough to corrupt officials for decades.

"Profits are recycled into bribes. You get a lot of guards on tiny salaries getting rich and driving fancy cars," said Duc Tran of the International Organisation for Migration (IOM), in Zagreb.

More formidable still is a modus operandi which has evolved to make the bosses untouchable and their networks resilient. Rather than build the monolithic hierarchical cartels favoured by drug traffickers, they tend to sub-contract to freelancers in transit countries, like multinational companies.

"It is best to envisage smuggling groups as loosely structured organisations that consist of constantly shifting relationships," according to an IOM report written by Prof Ronald Skeldon, of the University of Sussex.

An Italian parliamentary report identified three categories. At the top are regional bosses, especially in China, the Middle East and the Indian sub-continent. They find clients, forge alliances, set prices, stipulate conditions and authorise payments.

At the middle level are bosses in transit countries, especially Turkey and the Balkans, who organise safe houses, commission false documents, choose routes, pay bribes and hire local criminals as drivers, guides, lookouts and guards. Drugs, tobacco and arms are included in some shipments, as favours to other gangs. Fugitive mobsters sometimes use the routes.

At the the lowest level are minor smugglers in transit and destination countries valued for their local knowledge. Paid per job, they are expected to maintain equipment, establish rapport with corrupt officials, monitor beaches, train and bus stations, and choose points of handover.

Few smugglers remain outside the system. "The days when we cut our own deals with passengers is over. Now it's all middle men," lamented one veteran Albanian smuggler in the port of Vlore.

Often waiting in the destination country are representatives of the origin country boss, who will detain the migrants until relatives pay the outstanding debt. Alternatively, the migrants might be put to work in sweatshops or as prostitutes. "They operate like companies, except they use violence and torture as means of persuasion," said Tana De Zulueta, an Italian senator.

By such segmentation, specialisation and flexibility has human trafficking become the world's fastest growing criminal business. Employees know little, if anything, about their ultimate bosses. Identifying them, gathering evidence and obtaining convictions is a herculean task.

Routes are well established: Chinese via Belgrade, where former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic was happy to generate visa payments and annoy the west; migrants and asylum seekers from the Middle East, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka via Sarajevo, where Bosnian authorities obliged fellow Muslims. Last year more than 50,000 are estimated to have passed through on the way to western Europe.

Three overland routes snake into Italy and Austria via Croatia, Slovenia and Hungary. Suffocations in trucks and drownings in the Sava river are common. Others board semi-inflatables for moonlit crossings of the Adriatic from Vlore or Split. More than 130 drowned last year.

An Anglo-Italian initiative will intensify pressure on Yugoslavia and Bosnia to clamp down. Hopeful of western aid, they have already started. Croatia and Slovenia are praised by the Home Office for their efforts. The long-term goal is to make the Balkans stable enough for asylum seekers to stay there.

In the meantime, the government wants joint police operations to hunt down the bosses in the transit countries, one by one. An expanded role for Europol is envisaged. Wire taps, surveillance and informants are to penetrate the networks. The fall of Josip and Gloria Loncaric is cited as the way ahead.

Police believe the networks have been left vulnerable by their expansion. "Debriefing their clients can yield gems of information," said one British intelligence source.

However, one Croatian investigator said: "If we succeed in disrupting the networks they'll raise their prices to cover the costs. And clients will pay up, they always do."

How net closed on a smuggler

The rise and fall of a Sino-Balkan trafficking network has been hailed as a model breakthrough which European police and immigration authorities should study and replicate.

Twenty years ago a Croatian taxi driver, Josip Loncaric, started delivering fruit and veg to the Italian border and branched out into smuggling people. When Yugoslavia broke up, demand and profit soared. Loncaric bought a fleet of cars and vans and transported hundreds of Albanians and Yugoslavs.

Chinese criminals started importing countrymen into Trieste, in north-east Italy. Loncaric, 43, relocated to Slovenia and formed an alliance with the Chinese after marrying Wang Xuemei, 32, a boss's niece. He bought an Albanian airline - plus a football team and string of properties - and business boomed.

He employed 200 people to smuggle into the EU clients from China, the Philippines, Bangladesh and eastern Europe. More than 5,000 entered Italy last year.

An Italian court sentenced him to six years in absentia for aiding and abetting illegal immigration, but authorities could do little except intercept the occasional convoy.

That changed in 1998 when anti-mafia specialists in Trieste joined forces with Slovenian and British investigators. Wire taps and surveillance led them to a Loncaric lieutenant, Tomo Fodor, who agreed to become an informant in return for leniency.

Last July Slovenian police arrested Loncaric as dozens of accomplices were lifted in Italy. His wife was caught in Trieste in November. Both are expected to face trial this year. The weekly convoys into Medjimurje, Loncaric's Croatian base, are no more, said Bozena Katanec, of Croatia's interior ministry.

webTitle: Charge for nursery place rises to £6,000 a year

fields.headline: Charge for nursery place rises to £6,000 a year
fields.trailText: The cost of childcare has risen to an average of almost £6,000 a year per child, according to the most comprehensive survey to date, published today.
fields.body:
The cost of childcare has risen to an average of almost £6,000 a year per child, according to the most comprehensive survey to date, published today.

A typical nursery place for a two-year-old costs more than £110 a week. It was £80 a week in 1997, the last time the cost was reviewed.

In London the cost is £135 a week. The national research, collated for the Daycare Trust, the national childcare charity, was obtained by questioning 120 children's information services on weekly prices for a full-time place, typically 8am-6pm, for a two-year-old.

A childminder, often seen as a more affordable option, was £89 on average, or £110 in London.

A year-long study by the childcare commission, set up to advise the government, last week recommended parents should be offered "generous financial assistance" to enable them to stay at home for the first three years of a child's life.

Although the commission, whose recommendations are being scrutinised by the Treasury, failed to come up with a figure, family groups believe it should be at least £150, nearly half the average £337 weekly income for women, to enable them to have the choice of giving up work.

Last night, Harriet Harman, the former social security secretary and chairman of the commission, said the research gave weight to its recommendations - which include tax relief on the first £2,000 of childcare expenses, worth £440 a year.

"Childcare is a huge expense," said Ms Harman.

"We're saying, give people extra support in the early years because this is just so expensive and they can pay it back through tax once they return to work."

Parents on lower incomes, up to £22,000 for one child and £30,000 for two children, do have the opportunity of help for childcare costs through the working families tax credit. But critics argue those on incomes just above are penalised, and that the ceiling of a maximum of £70 a week for one child, or £105 for two, should be reviewed.

"This survey shows the sacrifices some parents are making to ensure that their child has access to quality childcare. But for many other parents, the cost of childcare is simply beyond their reach," said Stephen Burke, director of the Daycare Trust.

"It is critical that parents on lower incomes can afford the cost of a typical nursery which clearly now exceeds the childcare tax credit ceiling.

 More than a quarter of new fathers have wanted to escape to the pub as they struggle through the first few months of parenthood, according to a survey out today.

Nearly one in five new mothers has contemplated running back to their parents. And 10% of all parents have wanted to escape forever, the poll of 300 parents for the National Childbirth Trust found.

fields.headline: Summit to promote organ donations
fields.trailText: Pay packets, credit cards and census returns could play a part in a government drive to encourage organ donation, under proposals to be discussed at an emergency summit in the next few weeks.
fields.body:
Pay packets, credit cards and census returns could play a part in a government drive to encourage organ donation, under proposals to be discussed at an emergency summit in the next few weeks.

The health secretary Alan Milburn announced the conference yesterday amid fears that the Alder Hey body parts scandal could discourage families from donating organs, exacerbating serious shortages in the number of organs available. At least 6,000 patients are awaiting transplants.

Patient and professional groups, health chiefs, business leaders and parents will all play a part at the London summit. It will look for possible solutions to the shortage of donors, such as putting donor cards in pay packets and allowing people to register via returns for the next census.

People can already volunteer as donors when they apply for a passport or driving licence or register with a new doctor. Some credit card companies include a question on their application forms.

But the conference will stop well short of endorsing the opt-out "presumed consent" model of donation practised in Spain, where people are assumed to have agreed to organ donation unless they explicitly withdraw their consent.

The Department of Health said the summit would tackle the increasing gap between the number of people awaiting treatment and the number of organs available. A dramatic fall in road accident fatalities and the ability to help patients who might previously have been untreatable have contributed to the disparity.

It will also help to make "absolutely clear" the difference between agreeing to organ donations for transplants and organs being retained after a postmortem examination.

Mr Milburn said the 8m donor card holders needed to have the confidence that they would be treated with dignity and respect.

"Although at the moment the Alder Hey scandal does not appear to have affected donation of organs, we do not want to become complacent," he said. "I want to step up our drive to get more donors so that vital medical advances are not halted and people whose lives could so easily be saved with a transplant are not left to die unnecessarily."

The announcement came as leading transplant surgeons voiced their fears that the Alder Hey scandal could lead to a fatal drop in donations. The heart surgeon Sir Magdi Yacoub, of the Royal Brompton Hospital, in London, said he was concerned there had been no transplant operations at the Brompton over the past 10 days.

Sue Sutherland, a renal transplant surgeon and chief executive of UK Transplant, the NHS group which runs the country's transplant programme, added: "We are concerned that Alder Hey may have a negative effect on people's willingness to donate."

At present around a quarter of relatives refuse to allow organ donation. They are legally entitled to withhold consent even if their loved ones have registered as donors.

A Department of Health spokeswoman in effect ruled out the introduction of presumed consent.

"The summit will look at many issues, but I think there's a feeling that [the current method] is the most appropriate way of doing it," she said.

A spokeswoman for the British Medical Association, which first mooted the presumed consent model, said they would only favour its introduction "as and when the public supported it".

fields.headline: Top of the Pops makes a comeback, minus ageing DJs
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC is capitalising on renewed interest in music TV by relaunching its flagship chart show, Top of the Pops, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC is capitalising on renewed interest in music TV by relaunching its flagship chart show, Top of the Pops.

As the huge ratings for ITV's hit show Popstars demonstrate that plastic pop is alive and well, the BBC has decided to rescue its music showcase from a "graveyard slot", up against Coronation Street on Fridays. The programme, first broadcast in 1964, will get a new look when it moves studios later this year. Executives are considering whether to give it a new time slot, possibly its original home of Thursday.

The relaunch has been prompted by the BBC's move to broadcast a fourth weekly episode of EastEnders. TOTP is being forced to give up its studio at Elstree in Hertfordshire to make way for increased production of the soap.

A temporary home has been found at the Riverside studios in west London. The relaunch will take place once a permanent base has been secured.

The revival is a remarkable turnaround: TOTP faced the axe a few years ago. A new executive producer, Chris Cowey, has succeeded in restoring its credibility: now it is slicker, less chart-led, and has ditched its association with ageing Radio 1 disc jockeys. A US network wants to make its own version, and a successful BBC2 spin-off, Top of the Pops Plus, may prove to be the model for reviving the BBC's ailing Saturday morning children's output.

An appearance on TOTP is still coveted by the music industry: the manufactured band featured in Popstars hopes to be invited onto the show if, as expected, their first single is a hit. One of the remaining episodes of Popstars will be devoted to the TOTP debut. "It's stillthe holy grail of the pop world," said a source at LWT, which makes the ITV show.

At the weekend, millions saw the final choice of the Popstars band line-up revealed. They were picked from almost 3,000 by LWT's controller of entertainment, Nigel Lythgoe, record company executive Paul Adam, and public relations consultant Nicki Chapman.

They are Kym Marsh, 24, and Suzanne Shaw, 19, both from Lancashire; Danny Foster, 21, from east London; Myleene Klass, 22, from Norfolk ,and Noel Sullivan, 20, from Cardiff.

fields.headline: Channel 4 hives off entertainment arm
fields.standfirst:
BBC to relaunch top 20 show that dates back to 1960s, while C4 paves way for partial sell-off of FilmFour and E4

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: BBC to relaunch top 20 show that dates back to 1960s, while C4 paves way for partial sell-off of FilmFour and E4.
fields.body:
Channel 4 plans to separate its commercial ventures such as FilmFour and E4, in a move that will pave the way towards their partial sell-off.

The move was welcomed by the Conservative party, which has pledged to privatise Channel 4 if it wins the election.

The restructuring is also designed to answer critics who say that Channel 4 is abusing its position as a public broadcaster to invest in commercial enterprises.

Channel 4 has set up a subsidiary, 4 Ventures Ltd, to take control of the loss-making film channel FilmFour, the new entertainment channel E4, as well as other joint ventures. The terrestrial television business will remain separate.

The new division will have separate accounts and a managing director. It will not be floated on the stock market, but Michael Jackson, the chief executive of Channel 4, said he might eventually offer shares in the business.

"We have no plans to float 4 Ventures, but I do not rule out offering shares in the joint ventures and possibly in the whole," said Mr Jackson.

Last year David Elstein, the former chief executive of Channel 5, pointed to a £250m "hole" in Channel 4's accounts - the difference between the broadcaster's total revenue and the smaller amount invested in programmes for the main terrestrial channel.

Mr Jackson said that Channel 4's new structure, which will take effect later this year, would make the business more open. "It's about transparency. It is important to understand we are protecting and ring-fencing our investment in Channel 4, not weakening it."

Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary, who has led calls for Channel 4's privatisation, gave a partial welcome. "About time too," he said. "But this is a defensive mechanism."

Channel 4 is a hybrid: it is run by a publicly appointed board which does not have to answer to shareholders, yet raises revenue through advertising and other commercial ventures. It has a public service obligation to invest in British production and serve a diverse audience. Its remit is under review by the government.

While FilmFour has a clear public service in that it provides a showcase for British films, the case for E4 has not been clearly made. The channel, which was launched last month and is showing the first British run of the US series Friends and ER, appears to be a highly commercial operation.

Yet it is bound to lose a large amount of money in the short term that, critics argue, should be used for Channel 4's main programming budget.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, recently warned Channel 4 about its commercial expansion.

"Channel 4's argument is that FilmFour and E4 will become self-sustaining. We have to hold them to that."

Greg Dyke, the director general of the BBC, admitted yesterday that the corporation was considering an expansion in its commercial activities by taking a stake in a pay-for-view sports channel. It would infuriate rivals, but could help the BBC win back sports rights. In a BBC interview with David Frost to mark a year in post, he said savings of £25m and £30m had already been achieved, which would be re-invested in programmes.

fields.headline: Revolution in text message shopping
fields.trailText: 8.30am: A revolution in shopping is taking place with text messaging on the 40m mobile phones across Britain. By Amy Vickers
fields.body:
A revolution in shopping is taking place and it's happening with text messaging on the 40m mobile phones across Britain.

The text messaging shopping service Scan has just passed the landmark figure of half a million customers, 50,000 of whom are regular shoppers.

The service has spread like wildfire, with word of mouth being the biggest driver of new customers.

Scan's own research shows that more than 70% of customers go on to recommend the service to friends.

"It's created a frenzy. We get requests 24 hours a day, and people think it's so convenient," said Robert Hamilton, the self-styled 'sultan' of Scan.

"The feedback we've been getting has been phenomenal with one customer raving about how he bought an album while he was fixing his chimney pot. His comment was 'Rooftop shopping rules'."

Another Scan shopper told how she impressed her boyfriend in bed: "When I was in bed with my boyfriend, he said he wanted a CD really badly so I grabbed my phone sent a message to Scan and told him, 'It's on the way'. He was shocked and amazed."

To order a CD, video, DVD or book, a user has to send a text message to a pre-set phone number with the name of the product wanted and Scan immediately sends back a quote.

Customers then can purchase the item simply by texting Scan back with the word "buy".

The service is free to use, as is delivery, all customers have to pay is the 10p cost of sending the text message.

Text messaging has become an overnight success with more than 8.6bn text messages being sent in the UK last year.

Mobile owners that get the text messaging bug soon become obsessed with it, according to research.

Particularly interesting is research from Mori that says that people aged between 15 and 34 are more attached to text messaging than they are to email, and of these 13% said they wouldn't be able to live without it.

Useful link
www.scan.com

fields.headline: ITC rules NatWest ad misleading
fields.trailText: 8.30pm: An attempt by NatWest to cash in on the disastrous PR suffered by rival Barclays has backfired, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
An attempt by NatWest to cash in on the disastrous PR suffered by rival Barclays has backfired after TV regulators ruled its ad was misleading.

In a reference to Barclays' programme of branch closures, NatWest's commercial claimed it had scrapped its branch closure plans and abolished monthly fees on personal overdrafts.

The Independent Television Commission banned the campaign in response to complaints.

Eighteen customers complained that, when the ads were on air last summer, branch closures were still going ahead and the bank had not yet abolished its overdraft fees.

The ITC also banned an ad for the alcoholic drink Reef.

The commercial showed a group of young women confronting a bunch of men in a bar and performing a tribal dance.

More than 100 viewers complained the dance shown in the ad appeared to be the haka, the ceremonial dance performed by Maori men, which is a sacred part of Maori culture.

The ITC ruled the ad crossed the boundary between poor taste and serious offence.

A campaign for Brandt Appliances, in which adults were shown smashing up cookers and fridges so they could treat themselves to new Brandt Appliances, was banned from being shown during children's programming.

126 viewers complained it was too violent and could promote domestic violence.

But a commercial for Ikea, in which fictional staff were ordered to sniff their own armpits, was cleared.

The ITC ruled the commercial was unlikely to cause real offence.

fields.headline: Media monkey's diary
fields.trailText: • This week, Monkey was delighted to receive a press release from the ITC trumpeting the appointment of a new director of strategy, economics and finance. Robin Foster, for it is he, was formerly director of strategy at the BBC. A job he left - along with his boss Patricia Hodgson - around the time that Greg Dyke arrived and starting cutting out corporate bureaucracy. But it is heartwarming to see that Hodgson, now the chief executive of the ITC, has not let these funny ideas go to her head, and has found him a place at the government-funded watchdog. Now he's writing the ITC's response to the BBC's digital channels, which he helped her devise originally while at the BBC.
fields.body:
 This week, Monkey was delighted to receive a press release from the ITC trumpeting the appointment of a new director of strategy, economics and finance. Robin Foster, for it is he, was formerly director of strategy at the BBC. A job he left - along with his boss Patricia Hodgson - around the time that Greg Dyke arrived and starting cutting out corporate bureaucracy. But it is heartwarming to see that Hodgson, now the chief executive of the ITC, has not let these funny ideas go to her head, and has found him a place at the government-funded watchdog. Now he's writing the ITC's response to the BBC's digital channels, which he helped her devise originally while at the BBC.

 On rising early last week Monkey happened to see old friend Peter Salmon appearing on Breakfast News to praise the BBC's latest boxing triumphs: signing Audley Harrison and winning Lennox Lewis's next heavyweight contest. What a shame that the new head of sport got a bit confused and found himself talking about soccer instead of sparring. The BBC's new-found enthusiasm for boxing has raised some wry smiles among the old stagers. They remember only too well that John Birt explicitly decreed, circa 1993, that boxing was no longer a suitable sport for Auntie's airwaves ... just as Prince Naseem began his rise.

 Battle of the wits in adland. Saatchi & Saatchi is currently having its reception renovated, with large workman's boards obscuring the entrance. Its oh-so-clever sign "Bill posters will not be prosecuted" was unfortunately taken at face value by rival agency TBWA up the road. At 7am on Thursday, Trevor Beattie's mob pasted up a huge poster covering the boards. Inside a large arrow pointing left, it read "You'll get a better reception at TBWA".

 Andrew Neil is a man who takes great pride in his appearance - even if others are not quite so appreciative of his efforts. At a bash held in the swanky surroundings of the Dorchester Hotel in London to celebrate rising Scotsman sales, he sported a pair of yellow-rimmed spectacles that would have seemed slightly unusual even on the sportiest of street kids. Monkey applauds such fashion smarts, but has yet to be updated by the style desk about the addition of an orange tie. It must be what the young people are wearing in Scotland this month.

 After their recent row over the ITV news contract, Sky and ITN have temporarily buried the hatchet in the name of charity. The pair have supplied film for the Community Channel, which is promoting the aid appeal for the India earthquake. It's nice to see we can all be friends sometimes.

 While the Popstars starlets are poised to take over the celebrity world, the world of celebrities has been waiting with bated breath for the revelation of their new rivals. Away from home for last week's hastily scheduled midweek edition, singer Liam Gallagher and his girlfriend Nicole Appleton suddenly realised they had forgotten to set the video. If you're desperate, Liam, Monkey has a copy you can borrow.

Its oh-so-clever sign "Bill posters will not be prosecuted" was unfortunately taken at face value by rival agency TBWA up the road. At 7am on Thursday, Trevor Beattie's mob pasted up a huge poster covering the boards. Inside a large arrow pointing left, it read "You'll get a better reception at TBWA".  Andrew Neil is a man who takes great pride in his appearance - even if others are not quite so appreciative of his efforts. At a bash held in the swanky surroundings of the Dorchester Hotel in London to celebrate rising Scotsman sales, he sported a pair of yellow-rimmed spectacles that would have seemed slightly unusual even on the sportiest of street kids. Monkey applauds such fashion smarts, but has yet to be updated by the style desk about the addition of an orange tie. It must be what the young people are wearing in Scotland this month.  After their recent row over the ITV news contract, Sky and ITN have temporarily buried the hatchet in the name of charity. It's nice to see we can all be friends sometimes.  While the Popstars starlets are poised to take over the celebrity world, the world of celebrities has been waiting with bated breath for the revelation of their new rivals. Away from home for last week's hastily scheduled midweek edition, singer Liam Gallagher and his girlfriend Nicole Appleton suddenly realised they had forgotten to set the video. If you're desperate, Liam, Monkey has a copy you can borrow.

fields.headline: Equitable out of trouble
fields.standfirst: Today's deal with the Halifax could improve future returns for all policy holders, writes deputy city editor Jill Treanor
fields.trailText: Today's deal with the Halifax could improve future returns for all policy holders, writes deputy city editor Jill Treanor.
fields.body:
Equitable Life's announcement today is designed to do two things - sell the assets of the company to the Halifax, raising a total of £1bn, and at the same time put all of its 1m policy holders on an equal footing.

To achieve the latter, Equitable is aiming to encourage the 90,000 holders of its guaranteed annuity rate (GAR) policies to agree to forgo any future guarantees in return for a one-off payment.

This will cost around £1.5bn, money already set aside by the mutual life insurance company.

This is intended to stop any bickering between holders of these policies - the minority - and the majority who do not hold GAR policies. Policy holders will be consulted on the proposed idea in a document this summer.

It is because a way is starting to be found to limit the scale of the bill for the liabilities of the GAR policies that the sale process for Equitable could be revived after it was first abandoned in December.

Halifax's £1bn will be paid in two stages. The first £500m will cover the operating assets, information technology and highly regarded sales force who will be rebranded the Halifax Equitable.

The second £500m will require the agreement of policy holders to the compromise over the guaranteed annuities. This £500m is itself split into two payments, linked to the performance of future sales by the sales force.

The deal has been welcomed by the financial services authority. It could improve the future returns to all policy holders who had faced the prospect of lower payoffs because of the emergency policy by Equitable to sell equities and buy bonds instead, so that the responsibilities to GAR holders could be met. Their funds will now be managed by Clerical Medical, the fund management arm of the Halifax.

Another bidder, GE, an arm of the General Electric company in the US, is trying to enter the race, but the support of the regulators and the determination of Equitable's board to support the Halifax bid appeared to suggest yesterday that GE's protestations will fall on deaf ears.

webTitle: Halifax agrees price for Equitable buyout

fields.headline: Halifax agrees price for Equitable buyout
fields.trailText: Halifax, Britain's largest mortgage bank, today agreed to pay £1bn for troubled mutual life insurance company Equitable Life.
fields.body:
Halifax, Britain's largest mortgage bank, today agreed to pay £1bn for troubled mutual life insurance company Equitable Life.

The deal could offer hope to the 450,000 with-profits policyholders at Equitable, who have been wondering what to do with their money after the company ran into trouble over its handling of guaranteed annuity policies.

The Halifax offer - which beat off a last-minute challenge from US financial services group GE Capital - will create a banking and life insurance giant called Halifax Equitable.

Equitable was forced to seek a buyer last July after judges ruled that it had acted unlawfully in cutting bonuses to holders of guaranteed annuity rate (Gar) policies. The ruling left the mutual with a big hole in its capital, estimated at upwards of £1.5bn.

The Equitable's chief executive, Chris Headdon, said that the transaction is good for Equitable's policyholders, bringing £1bn into its life fund.

"That's real money that's coming into the fund for the benefit of policyholders," he said. "It gives us a real incentive for us to resolve this guaranteed annuity issue."

Mr Headdon said that the Halifax offer has been accepted by the board. "This is a good result for policyholders after a long period of uncertainty," he added.

The transaction will accelerate Halifax's diversification away from low-margin mortgages towards higher-growth long-term savings, effectively doubling Halifax's funds under management.

The Equitable, the world's oldest mutual insurance company, was forced to close to new business in December when UK insurer Prudential pulled out of talks to rescue the group, causing outrage among Equitable's 90,000 holders of Gar policies.

Halifax, which already owns life insurer Clerical Medical, will initially pay £500m for Equitable's operating business, including its fund-management operation, administration systems and 400-strong sales force. The first £500m payment by the Halifax will be due to be paid on March 1.

The chief executive of Halifax, James Crosbie, said that the deal would turn Halifax into one of the top three long-term savings businesses in the UK.

The mortgage bank will pay a further £500m, conditional on Equitable reaching a settlement with its policyholders, including holders of Gar policies.

Equitable and its policyholders have been struggling to resolve the dispute over these policies. One solution would be for the holders of Gar policies to accept a fixed increase in their policy value in exchange for giving up their guaranteed annuity entitlement.

Mr Headdon said that the group will sound out policyholders on this proposal and, if finalised, it would be circulated to all members for a vote at a general meeting in the middle of the year. The proposal would also need court approval.

Mr Headdon said that the impact of the Halifax deal would be relatively modest initially. "But once we get the Gar deal that is the point at which the investent freedom (of Equitable) will change quite markedly."

In December, when Equitable closed its doors to new business, it had to adopt a more risk-averse investment strategy, which it estimated would reduce returns by about between 0.5 and 1% each year.

Mr Headdon said that GE had also put in a proposal, but around two-thirds of its offer was essentially a financing deal. GE, the financial services arm of General Electric, reportedly offered £425m pounds for Equitable's operational assets, plus £850m as a loan to the with-profits life fund.

"The real value delivered to policyholders from their (GE Capital) proposal is clearly very much lower than the Halifax transaction," Mr Headdon said.

The financial services authority, which oversees all UK financial services, welcomed the announcement.

But shadow paymaster general Richard Ottaway said that the deal should not spell the end of an inquiry into the problem faced by policyholders.

He said: "The Halifax offer is good news for Equitable Life policyholders and we welcome this move, which should ease the concerns of millions of people affected by the company's recent difficulties.

"However, despite today's announcement, serious questions still remain over the Treasury's conduct and supervision of the life assurance sector in 1998.

"It is still essential that the financial services authority continue their investigation into their handling of the matter," Mr Ottaway added.

webTitle: NZ soldiers reap few rewards on Tolkien movie

fields.headline: NZ soldiers reap few rewards on Tolkien movie
fields.trailText: New Zealand's soldiers who were hired out as extras for the film of The Lord of the Rings have been paid a wage of just 74p an hour
fields.body:
Striking screenwriters and Hollywood actors could spare a thought for the brave soldiers of New Zealand. According to reports emerging down under, the armed forces appear to have been the only group not reaping the economic benefits caused by the big budget production of The Lord of the Rings. New Zealand's soldiers were hired out as orcs and hobbits in the trilogy for just £5.96 a day - a sweat-shop style hourly wage of only 74p an hour.

The New Zealand defence force admitted that the army also helped with less creative, more manual tasks such as set-building and project management. "For us it was an excellent exercise in planning and logistic development," said spokesperson Warren Inkster. Their work during the filming in New Zealand last year was "prior to our deployment to East Timor when we had to put all those skills to the test," Mr Inkster added.

The defence force was paid $NZ205,666 (£62,280) for 10,459 staff days, working out at $NZ19.66 per person per day. But Mr Inkster told The Australian newspaper that the payment was to compensate for the defence force's expenses and did not go to officers, who were paid their normal wages.

webTitle: Hunt for US girl ends in Greece

fields.headline: Hunt for US girl ends in Greece
fields.trailText: A 15-year-old American girl missing for a year after allegedly being lured to Greece by a 35-year-old German she met on the internet is to return home at last.
fields.body:
A 15-year-old American girl missing for a year after allegedly being lured to Greece by a 35-year-old German she met on the internet is to return home at last.

The hunt for Lindsay Erin Shamrock, from Mulberry, near Tampa, Florida, ended last week when police officers found her living with the man in Salonika, northern Greece. The German has been charged with abduction and sexual assault.

The case has reinforced the fear of how vulnerable people can be fooled or manipulate over the internet.

Ms Shamrock's parents bought her a computer in 1999 and she soon started communicating with a German living in Greece called Franz Konstantin Bähring, who used the screen name Kon.

The parents tried to end the relationship and changed their telephone number to stop him contacting her. Friends of Mr Bähring, later arrested, allegedly arranged a plane ticket for the teenager to meet him in Greece.

Friends of the girl claim that she communicated with them towards the end of last year, saying that she was living in Greece and that she was fine.

"Any parent who has a child using the internet, whether monitored or not, needs to know this can happen," the girl's mother, Stephanie Lavoie, told a news conference in Salonika. "The internet can be evil."

Mr Bähring denies doing anything wrong, and says he hoped to marry the girl.

webTitle: North Korea 'ready to join the web'

fields.headline: North Korea 'ready to join the web'
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: North Korea, one of the last countries outside the world wide web, is about to discover the joys of the internet, thanks to some fraternal help from China.
fields.body:
North Korea, one of the last countries outside the world wide web, is about to discover the joys of the internet, thanks to some fraternal help from China.

According to a report in the online edition of China's official People's Daily yesterday, Pyongyang is awaiting the go-ahead to go online.

It will doubtless come from North Korea's supreme leader, Kim Jong-il, who is "paying close attention" to the industry".

China is seen as North Korea's benevolent big brother, dispensing technical know-how and encouraging its isolated neighbour to move into the hi-tech world. Mr Kim paid a highly publicised visit to Shanghai last month to study economic reforms and visited computer firms.

As yet there are no public internet connections to North Korea, but some officials in Pyongyang are believed to have limited access. The Korean Central News Agency can be accessed only on a Japanese website.

The Beijing report says, perhaps tongue in cheek, that North Korea is now seeking "to overtake [the] world IT industry" despite "its late start".

In another reference to its backwardness, the paper says that personal computers appear to be a rarity in North Korea, that few people know anything about them, and that limited telephone-line capacity and outdated equipment has hindered the development of a computer network.

Last month North Korea published pictures of young programmers studying at its computer centre in Pyongyang, which was set up 10 years ago, saying that computer studies were part of the curriculum at all colleges and secondary schools. The centre is said to train tens of thousands of IT technicians every year.

Given recent years of economic stagnation and near-famine, observers doubt if such claims tally with reality.

fields.headline: From Bauhaus to cow house
fields.standfirst: While Europe's leading architects were designing concrete barracks, Hugo Häring was building fine, welcoming homes - for farmyard animals.  Jonathan Glancey on a forgotten genius
fields.trailText: While Europe's leading architects were designing concrete barracks, Hugo Häring was building fine, welcoming homes - for farmyard animals. Jonathan Glancey on a forgotten genius
fields.body:
It may sound like a joke, but a 1920s cow shed on the outskirts of Lübeck in eastern Germany has been one of the major influences on Modern mass housing. The cow shed in question was built by Hugo Häring (1882-1958), the subject of a small yet fascinating exhibition at the Royal Institute of British Architects in London. In the design of this remarkable structure it is possible to see the genesis of the humane Modern Movement housing, particularly of the 1970s, and the work of, say, Ralph Erskine at Byker in Newcastle and Edward Cullinan in suburban London. The reaction against prefab concrete, orthogonal geometry (architect-speak for straight lines) and the barrack-like architecture prescribed by architects over-influenced by the machine aesthetic of the Bauhaus led to a more relaxed, bricky, even tweedy social housing in the 1970s.

Häring was a rarity at the time: in his 40s when he designed the cow shed, he was an architect who thought that the new machine aesthetic should be flexible enough to be shaped by circumstances. "There was naturally no room for influences of another kind,for folk-art, earthy traditions, Saxon gables surmounted with horses' heads," he wrote in an article about the cow shed published in 1925. "But, even so, the building seems to belong more essentially to its site and landscape than older structures."

Häring may well have been the inspiration - one of them, at least - for the character of Professor Otto Silenus in Evelyn Waugh's Decline and Fall. Silenus is the humourless young architect commissioned by the interminably fashionable Margot Beste-Chetwynde to demolish her stately pile and replace it with a machine for living. His mission, he says, is to eradicate the human element from architecture; he proposes a house without a staircase, which would spoil the purity of his white, geometric design. His only claim to fame prior to the Beste-Chetwynde commission, we learn, is a design for an unbuilt bubble-gum factory published in an obscure European journal. At the time of the novel Häring would have only been known by a very few avant-garde British architects for his cow shed and his sausage factory (1925-6) at Neustadt, Holstein. John Betjeman was assistant editor of the Architectural Review when Waugh, his friend, was writing Decline and Fall. It is only too easy to imagine them sniggering at the latest funny designs for cow sheds and sausage factories.

The Lübeck cow shed is a fine building, at once modern and related to its surroundings. You expect it to have been turned into a museum or gallery. But no: today it is a handsome home to a colony of pigs. The cows gave way to pigs in the 1970s, when architects in Britain were finally learning to design housing estates fit for humans. Häring's next best work was for adairy farm, designed in 1943 for friends in his native Biberach.

But he also turned his attention to housing for humans, and it's a great shame that he never realised his postwar designs for low-cost courtyard estates. These would have been so much more humane than most of the mass-housing that was built across Europe after 1945. Writing of Häring's courtyards, Peter Blundell Jones and Nasser Golzari, curators of the RIBA show, highlight their qualities: "Often he managed to give the inhabitants of tiny houses a range of differently orientated views into contrasting room-sized courts. It was a world of pedestrians and bicycles with small alleys between rows and occasional larger avenues for motor vehicles."

We didn't get Häring homes; instead we got huge estates and tower blocks that made no one happy, except their bow-tied designers, town councillors in search of CBEs and photographers specialising in Sunday supplement images of urban grit. It does seem strange that an architect who made his name through farm buildings might also have made one of the greatest housing designers of the second half of the 20th century. Although a believer in order and geometry, he sought his angles in what he saw as the ever unfolding laws of Nature. Criticising Bauhaus designers, and the early precise white designs of Le Corbusier, he wrote: "The unity we achieve in many things on the grounds of geometric figures is only a unity of form, not a unity in terms of life. A polished metal sphere is certainly a fantastic [sensation] for our spirit, but a flower is a life-experience."

In the quiet and largely unsung work of Hugo Häring can be experienced the possibilities of a humane modern architecture to be shared by all - cows, pigs, and sausage-eating people. His contribution remains relevant. Where there's muck there's brass, and maybe even gold, waiting to be uncovered by future British architects, who may yet get the chance to build a new generation of social housing.

fields.headline: Where there's smoke suddenly there's Blair
fields.standfirst: Partnership approach is bridging regional divide
fields.trailText: Remember those days back in the 60s and 70s when the TV crews camped in Downing Street awaiting the arrival of the CBI and the TUC for a crunch meeting with Harold Wilson or Ted Heath? The presenter would solemnly announce that last-ditch talks were under way to save British Leyland, Upper Clyde Shipbuilders, Rolls-Royce or some other loss-making company, and all sides were prepared to work through the night to put together a rescue plan. This was the era of beer and sandwiches; governments believed it was their duty to play a central role in the running of the economy.
fields.body:
Remember those days back in the 60s and 70s when the TV crews camped in Downing Street awaiting the arrival of the CBI and the TUC for a crunch meeting with Harold Wilson or Ted Heath? The presenter would solemnly announce that last-ditch talks were under way to save British Leyland, Upper Clyde Shipbuilders, Rolls-Royce or some other loss-making company, and all sides were prepared to work through the night to put together a rescue plan. This was the era of beer and sandwiches; governments believed it was their duty to play a central role in the running of the economy.

All this was supposed to have changed with the arrival of "new" Labour. Businesses, not governments, created jobs, we were told. There would be no picking winners, no interference in decisions made for commercial reasons. The cabinet believed in the workings of the free market, the need to be internationally competitive and was not going to rescue lame ducks.

Labour wanted to be associated with the cool and trendy, with Tracey Emin, Noel Gallagher (who, believe it or not, was at the time cool and trendy) and with clean, green manufacturing jobs on business parks. It did not want to be associated with John Constable, Noddy Holder and smokestack industry. Mushy peas were out, seared tuna in.

Now, with an election looming, the government is furious that Corus did not go through the full consultation machinery but left ministers in the dark about their plans for cutting 6,000 jobs in areas of high unemployment.

From the prime minister downwards, the message has gone out that Corus is an example of unacceptable capitalist behaviour. The company has agreed to a classic 70s ploy - a two-week cooling-off period in which there will be talks aimed at saving as many jobs as possible. Presumably, soon we can expect to see Tony Blair emerge from No 10 in a Gannex raincoat and sucking on a pipe, en route to his new holiday destination of the Scilly Isles.

Actually, this Damascene conversion to interventionism is purely cosmetic. The government's industrial strategy is based on the notion that the traditional industries of Britain - steel, cars, textiles, metal-bashing in all its forms - are on their way out. It believes that the future lies at the hi-tech end of the spectrum, where firms are competing on quality, not price.

Official figures for manufacturing show this is the direction in which industry has been moving. Production of hi-tech goods such as mobile phones has been growing strongly while the weakest-performing sector has been textiles, which is being wiped out by lower-cost goods from developing countries. The strength of the pound has merely accelerated this process but, far from regretting this trend, the government sees it as inevitable.

At present, however, it is not expedient to say this, so with breath-taking hypocrisy the government is attacking Corus for doing precisely what it has said modern, dynamic companies should be doing.

None of the measures that might save jobs at Corus - at a price - appeals to ministers. One option would be to throw up a protective wall around Britain, using high tariffs to prevent foreign steel entering the country and thereby ensuring a buy-British policy, even if localisation meant accepting economic inefficiency. Yet the government believes in free trade and is bound by the rules of the World Trade Organisation.

In the the days of beer and sandwiches, direct government intervention, through public ownership or subsidies, would have had support around the cabinet table. But no longer, not least because every billion pounds spent saving jobs in steel is a billion that cannot be spent investing in health or education. The state-subsidy route would also be outlawed by EU law.

Below, Ed Balls and John Healey describe what the government is doing to beef up regional policy, which is an important weapon in coping with shocks to local economies. But those at the sharp end argue that regional policy cannot compensate if macro-economic policies are out of kilter. Yet there is not the slightest evidence that the government is going to change its macro-economic framework or even chide the Bank of England for keeping inflation below its target for almost two years.

There is one final option. As far as supporters of the single currency are concerned, Labour is paying the price for refusing to join monetary union and even more jobs will be lost unless it decides now to enter at a lower exchange rate. But, if the strength of sterling were the real reason for the loss of jobs in manufacturing, then presumably there should have been an expansion of jobs in industry during the almost uninterrupted decline in the pound's value since 1945. As the chart shows, this has not been the case.

Also, under current arrangements for setting interest rates, a lower exchange rate is no free lunch. All the indications are that the Bank would respond to a big devaluation of sterling by pushing up interest rates as a hedge against imported inflation. Inside monetary union, Britain would be faced with the Irish problem - excess demand that would have to be mopped up using higher taxes or lower public spending. Exporters might gain at the expense of businesses with a purely domestic focus.

Certainly, one problem for Corus is the structural decline in UK manufacturing, which has affected domestic demand for steel and forced the company to compete in tough overseas markets, where sterling's level has been a factor.

However, the idea that joining monetary union will safeguard jobs in any threatened sector is a fallacy. In essence, Labour's industrial policy is no different from Mrs Thatcher's; the strong survive global competition, the weak go to the wall. The logic of the government's policy is that in 20 years' time there will not be a single steelworker in Britain but that it doesn't matter because we will be able to buy all the steel we want more cheaply from low-cost producers while increasing exports from sectors where we are strong. But don't expect logic - or much honesty - over the next few months when, metaphorically at least, Tony will be smearing HP sauce on his steak and chips, and taking his labrador for a walk.

fields.headline: Quake victims turn on 'greedy' builders
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Anger against unscrupulous builders in Gujarat rose yesterday as officials blamed them for worsening the death toll in the January 26 Indian earthquake, which the authorities now fear could eventually be more than 30,000.
fields.body:
Anger against unscrupulous builders in Gujarat rose yesterday as officials blamed them for worsening the death toll in the January 26 Indian earthquake, which the authorities now fear could eventually be more than 30,000.

The state's home minister, Haren Pandya, said 80% of the buildings in the commercial capital, Ahmedabad, had breached construction standards. Many blocks of flats less than a year old collapsed while much older buildings were shaken but undamaged.

The number of confirmed deaths is expected to jump today when demolition crews clear the ruins of larger blocks and uncover more bodies. Almost 67,000 are injured.

By yesterday accusations of murder and fraud had been lodged in Ahmedabad against the owners and structural engineers of 21 construction companies.

Experts said greedy companies made a practice of using poor material, flouted architectural standards,and were part of a cycle of corruption and inefficiency involving officials and politicians.

"The chain is builder, officials, politicians. The riches go to the top," an architect, Ravindra Vasavada, said. "For politicians it is a permanent bank."

The federal minister for urban development, Jagmohan, said laws had been violated across the state. "People don't care, they compromise to cut costs," he said.

The authorities have declared 90 buildings in Ahmedabad unsafe. "At least 69 buildings have collapsed partially or fully. In some cases they were just six to eight months old," the police commissioner, PC Panday, said.

A survey by engineers after the quake showed that in many cases pillars were not secured to the foundations with steel reinforcements, as the law requires. Sinking the pillars into concrete without steel reinforcement saves 20-25% on building costs but made buildings much weaker.

The authorities fear that the eventual death toll in the state could be 35,000. There are more than 600,000 homeless.

At the Parijat building in Ahmedabad, marked for demolition, hundreds of residents scrabbled for their belongings yesterday before the wreckers came.

Surrounded by mountains of twisted motorcycles, crumpled cars, clothes, school bags, refrigerators and kitchen utensils, Sudhakar Kamath, 60, looked for the owner of the building company that sold him his flat late last year. His family survived, but he lost his home.

"I have been cheated. I gave him my life savings," he said. "Will he be punished?"

AP

• Divers entered a flooded coal mine in eastern India yesterday to rescue 35 miners trapped since Friday, a spokesman for Coal India Ltd said. At least 100 miners were working in the Bagdih mine when water gushed in from a neighbouring flooded pit through a breach in the coal seam. Sixty-five were rescued immediately but no contact has been made with the others.

Reuters

fields.headline: Starting up
fields.standfirst: In search of a pleasant and productive work environment
fields.trailText: In search of a pleasant and productive work environment.
fields.body:
Last week an ePay survey from executive recruitment group Futurestep suggested that the gap is closing between internet and traditional companies when it comes to executive compensation. Although executives in internet businesses still lag behind their counterparts in traditional businesses, the gap in pay is now less than 10%.

The clear suggestion is that equity benefits in the form of stock options are not the incentive that they were 12 months ago. As the founders of rools we are two of the lowest paid members of staff. We are obviously still driven by the dream of creating an exciting new-tech business.

It is not our own motivation that we have to worry about, but that of other team members. This has become more of an issue with the recent slump in the fortunes of the whole dot.com sector and the massive reduction in value of stock options. New starters are looking for comparable salaries, not content any more to sacrifice cash for equity.

One of the ways we are compensating for this effect is by offering our staff other benefits. One of our more innovative ideas is to offer additional time off.

We borrowed the idea from a company in the US. It is a sizeable oil exploration company that closes its entire office every second Friday. The company's stock price is soaring and they have people queuing up to work for them, such has been the attraction of free time. Their business appears to be thriving despite the apparent reduction in actual time worked.

Our "golden Fridays" are a watered-down version of the same scheme. Members of the team are given one Friday off per month. We manage these golden Fridays so that there is adequate cover in every functional area. In that way the business and our customers do not suffer.

We are only testing the initiative at the moment and we are monitoring its effect closely. We are still small enough to withdraw such policies fairly quickly if we find things are not going as planned. So far, however, the results have been positive. Productivity has not been hit as people are working slightly longer - and harder - to compensate for the additional time off.

Feedback from staff has - unsurprisingly - been positive. It has been particularly appreciated by a member of staff with a new baby; he values the extra time he can spend at home.

It also fits with the culture that we are building for the business and the vision we have for how we wish to work. The internet explosion of recent years has seen hundreds of dot.com companies try out many fresh ideas. Some of these have been adopted by mainstream businesses - the widespread adoption of dress-down Fridays, for example. We are trying to make working life more pleasant and productive. We will let you know how it goes.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of rools, a service that enables teenagers to shop online

fields.headline: UK will miss greenhouse target
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Britain will miss its internationally agreed targets for reducing the greenhouse gases which cause global warming, independent energy analysts warn today.
fields.body:
Britain will miss its internationally agreed targets for reducing the greenhouse gases which cause global warming, independent energy analysts warn today.

The government has committed itself to reducing emissions of CO2, the main greenhouse gas, to 20% below their 1990 levels by 2010. But a report from Cambridge Econometrics published today predicts Britain will miss this target by a "considerable margin".

"CO2 emissions will increase over the next decade and in 2010 will be only 6.5% lower than in 1990," the report's author, Charlie Hargreaves, said.

The main culprits are road users and households, say the researchers. Thanks to the so-called dash for gas, CO2 emissions from power generators in 2010 are expected to be 23% lower than in 1990, while more efficient use of energy will allow industry to cut emissions by more than 15%.But households and car owners will have to become more energy efficient as well if Britain is to meet the targets it agreed at the Kyoto climate change talks in 1997.

"While the 20% target is still within reach, its achievement requires yet further policy initiatives," Mr Hargreaves said.

UN scientists believe that the world's average temperature will rise by 6C this century, even after implementation of the Kyoto framework targets, which many countries have yet to sign up to.

webTitle: BA back in profit but still facing trouble

fields.headline: BA back in profit but still facing trouble
fields.trailText: British Airways will show today that it is back on track when it reports pre-tax profits of nearly £60m compared to a £67m loss for the same period last year.
fields.body:
British Airways will show today that it is back on track when it reports pre-tax profits of nearly £60m compared to a £67m loss for the same period last year.

Analysts now believe BA could produce end-of-year profits of £200m compared to a pre-exceptionals loss of £244m last time, its first deficit since privatisation 13 years ago.

Yesterday the airline's goal of attracting premium class passengers was given a boost when it was voted best airline for in-flight service in a survey of 2,500 British business travellers by Company Barclaycard.

Confidence in the group's future has been reflected by the shares which had reached a high of 455p at the end of last week, compared with a year low of 257p.

The good news has come too late for the architect of the recovery, chief executive Bob Ayling, who was forced out after losing the board's confidence.

His successor Rod Eddington stands to take credit for a heavy cost cutting programme instigated by Mr Ayling. It involved a reduction in planned capacity increases and concentration on business travellers.

The new Australian boss is expected to announce details of a rights issue and give an update on plans for the disposal via flotation of Go, its low-cost, loss-making subsidiary.

He might also give further details of BA's bid in a consortium to take control of the British air traffic control system. This weekend there were threats by the controllers' union to take strike action should the proposed 51% part-privatisation go through.

Although BA is on a more profitable trajectory it is by no means out of trouble yet. Traders say the company has one of the weakest balance sheets of any FTSE 100 company and there is talk of any rights issue being heavily discounted.

The European markets continue to be loss-making for BA and the crucial north American trade is expected to be hit hard by the US economic slowdown.

webTitle: Nanjing blood donors get credits for giving

fields.headline: Blood donors get credits for giving
fields.trailText: China's chronic shortage of blood supplies has forced one of its biggest cities to institute a commercial scheme which allows donors to claim "blood credits" if they later require a transfusion.
fields.body:
China's chronic shortage of blood supplies has forced one of its biggest cities to institute a commercial scheme which allows donors to claim "blood credits" if they later require a transfusion.

Launched in Nanjing, the scheme entitles those who give 800ml or more blood to an unlimited free transfusion in the event of medical need. Those giving less than 800ml earn up to three times the amount given. Relatives are entitled to a transfusion equal to the amount the donor has given.

The regulations require anyone receiving a transfusion who has not given blood to pay for it, but a refund can be earned by giving blood within a year. The young and elderly are exempt from these requirements.

Nanjing, capital of the rich Yangtze valley province of Jiangsu, hopes that the scheme will solve a shortfall of blood supplies made worse by efforts to crack down on the widespread practice of selling blood.

A blood donation law which took effect in October 1998 was supposed to ban all blood donations for money. Last year the health ministry said 3m donors had given blood without payment, but there was still a serious shortfall.

Zhang Wenkang, the health minister, said: "Illegal blood transactions exist in some regions and... current screening technology is unable to detect blood tainted with viruses.

Public opinion has been shaken by recent instances of HIV and hepatitis being spread by infected blood. Newspapers have discovered several poor peasant communities who have relied on the sale of blood for years.

Better-off areas are not immune from medical malpractice either. In Zhejiang - like Jiangsu a relatively rich coastal province - the local authorities found in December that disposable needles and blood transfusion supplies were being bought from doctors, rinsed out and then resold to local hospitals.

The blood crisis reflects wider problems in Chinese health provision since the shift to a market economy after the death of Mao Zedong. Underfunded hospitals and doctors regularly over-prescribe to increase their income, and patients may be denied treatment if they cannot pay.

In a recent critique of declining standards, the well-known economists Hu Angang and Meng Qingguo argue that China's health lags considerably behind the targets set when the economic reforms began. While the GDP has risen by 580% in the past 20 years, the provision of hospital beds relative to population size has risen by just 18%.

Public opinion has been shaken by recent instances of HIV and hepatitis being spread by infected blood. Newspapers have discovered several poor peasant communities who have relied on the sale of blood for years. Better-off areas are not immune from medical malpractice either. In Zhejiang - like Jiangsu a relatively rich coastal province - the local authorities found in December that disposable needles and blood transfusion supplies were being bought from doctors, rinsed out and then resold to local hospitals. The blood crisis reflects wider problems in Chinese health provision since the shift to a market economy after the death of Mao Zedong. Underfunded hospitals and doctors regularly over-prescribe to increase their income, and patients may be denied treatment if they cannot pay. In a recent critique of declining standards, the well-known economists Hu Angang and Meng Qingguo argue that China's health lags considerably behind the targets set when the economic reforms began. While the GDP has risen by 580% in the past 20 years, the provision of hospital beds relative to population size has risen by just 18%.

webTitle: Briton admits to bombings in Riyadh

fields.headline: Briton admits blasts
fields.trailText: A British man has confessed on Saudi Arabian TV to bombings which killed another Briton and injured several others.
fields.body:
A British man has confessed on Saudi Arabian TV to bombings which killed another Briton and injured several others.

Alexander Mitchell told the Saudi Arabian news that he and two others, a Canadian named as William Sampson and an unnamed Belgian, had followed orders and exploded two bombs in the capital, Riyadh, last year.

The first, on November 17, killed 47-year-old Christopher Rodway, from Gloucestershire, and injured his wife, Jane, 50. The second, five days later, injured three Britons and an Irish woman working for the Al-Salam aircraft company, owned by Boeing.

The news bulletin broadcast pictures of Mitchell and what it claimed was an Arabic translation of his confession. An Arabic voice-over said: "I confirm and confess that I received orders to carry out the bombing here in Riyadh on November 17 against Christopher Rodway, a British citizen. William Sampson, a Canadian, helped me carry out the bombing." He did not say who ordered the attacks but the other two men also spoke of their involvement.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said: "Officials are urgently seeking confirmation of the developments."

fields.headline: Commons touch
fields.standfirst: As parliamentary secretary to two MPs, Philipa Coughlan tells Mabel Msonthi what it's like at the heart of Westminster
fields.trailText: As parliamentary secretary to two MPs, Philipa Coughlan tells Mabel Msonthi what it's like at the heart of Westminster
fields.body:
From her swish Thames-side offices at Portcullis House, it's unsurprising that Philipa Coughlan, parliamentary secretary to Liz Blackman (MP for Erewash) and Nick Palmer (MP for Broxtowe), views her job as being at the heart of UK government. Coughlan, 38, has a varied political position. It is also an insecure one. The lives of parliamentary secretaries are inextricably linked to the successes of the MPs they serve and, with a general election approaching, it's easy to see why Coughlan and others like her might be nervous about their job prospects six months from now.

Yet much of Coughlan's day is comparable to that of any number of PAs. "I would say that 60% of my job is administrative, with faxing, filing and sorting post dominating my tasks on a daily basis," she says. "I prioritise the mail and wherever possible begin research on the various subjects that constituents have written to their MP about."

The ability to act on your own initiative is clearly integral to her position. "I am certainly more than a secretary in the old-fashioned sense of only typing and making the tea; this is a comprehensive role encompassing research on behalf of the MPs so that their lives are made easier," she says, adding that she also drafts press releases for the MPs in advance of their speeches in parliament, thus acting as a press officer as well.

Coughlan's working hours as not as arduous as you might assume. She works part-time from Monday to Wednesday, partly because of a dis ablity following a car accident several years ago, and partly to fit in with her child-care arrangements. "My hours do vary and if one of the MPs comes into the office at 4pm and suggests we work on a document for the following day, I might not leave until 8 or 9pm," says Coughlan, observing that a strict 9-to-5 office mentality would be inappropriate in this field.

So is it all glamour and hobnobbing with people of influence in the corridors of power? "I'm constantly asked if I spend my time chatting to the likes of Tony Blair in the canteen, but obviously I don't. You do see ministers and MPs all the time in the offices in Westminster, but once I'm back in the constituency, the emphasis is on the local people and sorting out their grievances; that's the main focus."

"The best aspect of the position is that my bosses allow me to attend meetings on their behalf where I take detailed notes and relay information back to them," she says, citing the forthcoming TUC pre-budget conference as an example. "I don't feel nervous because I'm genuinely interested in the issues being debated. The recent meetings before the anti-hunting bill in January, for example, were of particular concern to me as it's an issue I like to keep abreast of."

Having a penchant for politics is not a prerequisite for the job, but Coughlan believes it keeps her enthusiasm for the position alive. "I have always been a political animal, having been interested on a local and national level for many years. If you didn't possess a natural interest in politics, this job would be far harder."

Coughlan first met Palmer through their work together on a political magazine in 1995 -1997. She helped him on his parliamentary campaign in 1997 and when he was elected, he offered her a job as his parliamentary secretary, a position she immediately realised was a "fantastic opportunity".

However, Peter Mandelson's recent fall from grace has highlighted the insecurity of political support staff. But Coughlan is unconcerned. "If there is a general election in May, I envisage that my bosses will be re-elected so I am not particularly anxious about my personal job security. I would accept my fate if I was out of a job in early spring," she says. "You have to remember that there is a great deal of networking in this sector, so obtaining a position in other organisations with a political slant would not be difficult if we were all out of a job tomorrow.

"I can't help feeling a frisson of pride, surrounded as I am by information that will go towards drafting bills that could become part of this country's history," says Coughlan, adding that the pace of politics can be tiring, but the sight of Big Ben, looming in the foreground as she approaches her offices, provides her with regular reassurance that she made the right career choice.

fields.headline: Eco-warriors win propaganda battle
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Airport authorities triumphed in the struggle to build a new runway. But the protesters won the propaganda war.
fields.body:
Airport authorities triumphed in the struggle to build a new runway. But the protesters won the propaganda war.

They dragged out the public inquiry in Manchester for 101 days and prepared for battle when the government gave the go-ahead for the scheme in 1997.

Airport executives cheered up when the National Trust, which had opposed the scheme right through the public inquiry, changed its mind. But then the former Beirut hostage Terry Waite grabbed the headlines when he arrived to lead a protest march.

Matters came to a head in April 1997, when a judge granted a possession order to the airport and its contractors. A month later Randal Hibbert, the under-sheriff of Cheshire, moved in with bailiffs, specialist tree-climbers and tunnellers to evict protesters in an operation codenamed Fulcrum.

During the four-week eviction campaign Martin Bell, the Independent MP for nearby Tatton, declared himself an opponent. It did not stop the evictions. On June 16 the last protester was dug out after 408 hours in one tunnel.

Construction work began soon after, with the airport continuing to stress its environmental responsibility.

In three years, 300,000 tonnes of concrete and 55,000 tonnes of asphalt have been laid while the airport stressed the benefits contained in the £17m "green" package.

More than 37,000 newts, frogs and toads collected from 48 ponds have been moved to 97 new and restored sites; 150,000 trees have been planted in 50 hectares of woodland; 25 hectares of grassland have been sown. The river Bollin, on whose banks so much of the protest took place, has been diverted through a tunnel with pathways for mammals, nesting holes for birds and resting places for fish.

The inquiry inspector praised the airport's "green charter" as "impressive, comprehensive and wide-ranging".

But Jeff Gazzard, the protesters' spokesman, remained unconvinced by the need for the new runway. "It's a pity all this countryside has been given over to satisfy people's seemingly endless desire to go to Majorca for two weeks," he lamented. "There has not been the influx of new business that was promised. This is a holiday airport."

webTitle: Hackers get data on world leaders

fields.headline: Hackers get data on world leaders
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Computer hackers are reported to have obtained confidential information in Switzerland - including private phone numbers and credit card details - on 27,000 of the world's political and business leaders, including Bill Gates, Bill Clinton, and Yasser Arafat.
fields.body:
Computer hackers are reported to have obtained confidential information in Switzerland - including private phone numbers and credit card details - on 27,000 of the world's political and business leaders, including Bill Gates, Bill Clinton, and Yasser Arafat.

The information about people who have attended the World Economic Forum, staged each year in Davos, were on a CD-ROM shown to a Zurich newspaper, SonntagsZeitung.

It seems to have been obtained by unnamed campaigners against globalisation, who hacked into the foundation which puts on the annual meeting. SonntagsZeitung said that credit card firms began freezing the affected accounts at the weekend.

More damaging, the material is said to include travel information for some of the participants, who are surrounded by high security. Some of it was published on the internet as the forum met last week.

The newspaper said the people on the 80,000 pages of material included President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, the former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic, the former US secretary of state Madeleine Albright, the French finance minister, Laurent Fabius, and Gianni Agnelli of Fiat.

The data included telephone numbers, email addresses, payment details, hotels, room numbers, and arrival and departure times. About 1,400 names had credit card details - even those of spouses.

The paper ran some items past the stunned deputy head of a pharmaceutical multinational, who confirmed their accuracy.

"We are taking this incident very seriously and are bringing in outside experts to clear up what happened," Charles McClean, a forum spokesman in Geneva, was quoted as saying.
