webTitle: EU to offset Bush cuts in family planning funds

fields.headline: EU to offset Bush cuts in family planning funds
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: Britain and its EU partners are poised to fill some of the gap created by President George Bush's decision to end US payments to international family planning organisations which provide abortion services.
fields.body:
Britain and its EU partners are poised to fill some of the gap created by President George Bush's decision to end US payments to international family planning organisations which provide abortion services.

This year's funding is unaffected, but later the UN Population Fund and the International Planned Parenthood Federation are likely to suffer badly, and many other organisations will also be affected.

About 80,000 women die annually from unsafe abortions. EC sources said the commission, the world's biggest overseas aid provider, could not provide core funding but could support individual projects.

Clare Short, the international development secretary, is due to discuss the matter with the EU commissioner for development, Poul Nielson, in London this week.

Ms Short, one of an informal quartet of like-minded female EU development ministers, is anxious for Britain to play active role in global population policy, but officials stressed that she wanted to avoid a row with Washington.

Her Dutch colleague, Eveline Herfkens, has also urged a "quick and strong" European response to President Bush's cuts.

Brussels already gives family planning organisations €47m (£30m), mostly for contraception and educational work in Asia.

 The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, said on ABC television's This Week that his personal views on the issue differed from the White House's, but he added: "This is the policy of the government."

webTitle: Commuters face chaos in tube strike

fields.headline: Commuters face chaos in tube strike
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Millions of commuters face travel chaos this morning as tube drivers mount the first of three one-day strikes in a row over safety.
fields.body:
Millions of commuters face travel chaos this morning as tube drivers mount the first of three one-day strikes in a row over safety.

London Underground gave warning that industrial action would cripple services because the organising union, Aslef, represents 80% of drivers, although some trains will run. The strike began last night, but will bite today as the 3m passengers who take the tube daily switch to alternative transport.

The AA warned that roads in the capital and across the south-east could become jammed as people switched to their cars, with roads up to a third busier than normal. Firms warned that the strike would cost business around £3.5m.

Government officials had hoped to forestall industrial action after progress in talks with Bob Kiley, the capital's transport commissioner, over the public-private partnership (PPP) plans for the tube.

Mick Rix, Aslef's general secretary, said yesterday: "We are sorry that London Underground management has still not seriously addressed the continuing safety concerns on the tube and that tomorrow's strike has to go ahead despite the apparent progress made last week."

The Rail Maritime and Transport Union is unable to join the strike because the high court ruled last week that there were irregularities in its ballot.

The industrial action coincides with a threat from air controllers to strike over the Easter holiday unless the government abandons plans to part-privatise the air safety network.

webTitle: UK and Italy move to stem illegal entrants

fields.headline: UK and Italy move to stem illegal entrants
fields.standfirst:
Special report: European integration
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A joint Anglo-Italian initiative to stem the flow from the Balkans of tens of thousands of illegal entrants into Europe through the "Sarajevo route" will be followed this week by further measures to strengthen the "fortress Europe" approach to migration.
fields.body:
A joint Anglo-Italian initiative to stem the flow from the Balkans of tens of thousands of illegal entrants into Europe through the "Sarajevo route" will be followed this week by further measures to strengthen the "fortress Europe" approach to migration.

The United Nations has estimated that 10% of illegal entrants to Europe come via the Balkans route, with migrants paying up to £2,700 to make the journey. More than 50,000 migrants are estimated to have passed through Bosnia in the first 10 months of last year.

Britain was leading the way in the crackdown on human trafficking, the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, said yesterday. "The prime minister has taken a very, very close personal interest in this," she added.

Tony Blair yesterday pledged to target gangs involved in human trafficking and impose longer sentences on those caught, deploy more police and immigration officers in Bosnia to step up border checks, and provide funds for a voluntary repatriation scheme.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, will tomorrow renew his drive to "modernise" the 1951 UN convention on refugees. The British initiative - which could see the European Union agreeing only to take in refugees at moments of severe crisis - is believed to have won the backing of the Germans and stirred considerable interest among other European governments. Under Mr Straw's scheme individual asylum seekers could be restricted to claiming refugee status in the first safe country they reach, without being allowed to set foot in Europe.

British officials are also expected to criticise the French authorities at an Anglo-French summit on Friday for their failure to take action to stem the flow of illegal entrants from Calais across the channel. MPs on the Commons home affairs select committee said last week they had been appalled to discover hundreds of young people living in a Red Cross warehouse at Sangatte, near Calais, while waiting to try to enter Britain illegally. Some had made repeated attempts.

Mr Blair's decision to put his weight behind measures to tackle illegal migration reflects the recognition in Downing Street of the politically explosive potential of the issue in the run-up to the general election. He also backed calls to open up opportunities for legal migration into Europe.

"Every day we hear of the horrors illegal immigrants endure at the hands of the people-traffickers," said Mr Blair, in a joint article in the Observer with Guiliano Amato, the prime minister of Italy. "The catalogue of death in recent times speaks for itself - 58 Chinese at Dover last year, hundreds drowned yearly crossing the Mediterranean to Spain, Italy and Greece. There is evidence that traffickers have thrown women and children, many of whom cannot swim, into the Adriatic in the middle of the night simply to avoid detection by police patrol boats."

The two countries also agreed to a joint effort within the EU to identify more effectively and return people who arrive illegally in EU states. Assistance for voluntary repatriation programmes is to be stepped up. The joint statement said they were also both prepared to press for tougher penalties - currently 10 years imprisonment in Britain - for those who engage in human trafficking and transporting illegal migrants.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, criticised the initiative. "It is not for us to assist the Italians in protecting their frontiers," she said. She called for asylum seekers to be returned to the last safe country they had travelled through.

fields.headline: Bulger pair anonymity 'dangerous'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bulger case
fields.trailText: The chairman of the press complaints commission has reopened the debate over the anonymity granted to James Bulger's killers, saying it sets a "very dangerous" precedent.
fields.body:
The chairman of the press complaints commission has reopened the debate over the anonymity granted to James Bulger's killers, saying it sets a "very dangerous" precedent.

Lord Wakeham said the ruling should be reviewed regularly, warning it could signal the start of a "very, very slippery slope" of restrictions.

Speaking on the BBC's Breakfast with Frost programme yesterday, Lord Wakeham said no one was entitled to privacy for its own sake.

The high court ruling, on Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, both 18, protects them from being identified after they are released. Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the family division of the high court in London, said she believed their lives would be at risk if the media revealed their new identities.

Sean Sexton, solicitor for James's mother Denise Fergus, said he welcomed Lord Wakeham's comments. He said important information about the killers, including the newspaper allegation that Thompson attempted to strangle a fellow inmate, would never be known to the parole board or to the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf.

He said important information about the killers, including the newspaper allegation that Thompson attempted to strangle a fellow inmate, would never be known to the parole board or to the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf.

fields.headline: Gadafy speech 'to prove Libyan's innocence'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: The Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, will today produce the evidence he claims proves the man convicted of the Lockerbie bombing is innocent.
fields.body:
The Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, will today produce the evidence he claims proves the man convicted of the Lockerbie bombing is innocent.

In a move which will heighten tensions between the African state and the west, Colonel Gadafy will use a speech to demonstrate Abdel Baset al-Megrahi was not involved in the destruction of the Pan Am jumbo jet.

Col Gadafy has said the evidence is so explosive it will leave the judges in the Lockerbie trial with three options: to resign, apologise and free Megrahi, or kill themselves.

The prime minister, Tony Blair, and the US president, George Bush, have called on Col Gadafy to accept the ruling of the court and admit Libya's part in the biggest act of mass murder in British history.

It is widely believed the Libyan leader will produce a document saying the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command (PFLP-GC), extremists based in the Syrian capital, Damascus, was responsible.

During the trial, William Taylor QC, defence counsel for Megrahi, tried in vain to persuade Syria to release such a document.

Syria and Iran were initially suspected of engaging the PFLP-GC to blow up the jumbo in retaliation for the shooting-down of an Iranian airbus in the Persian Gulf by a US warship, the Vincennes, in July 1988, killing all 290 on board. Lockerbie followed in December 1988.

Yesterday the leader of the PFLP-GC, Ahmed Jibril, told a Saudi newspaper that his group was not involved in Lockerbie, and threatened to sue the US government for libel.

The newspaper, al-Watan, said Jibril "voiced his readiness and that of other PFLP-GC officials to counter the fabricated accusations in front of any neutral body and said they were now waiting for the [Megrahi] appeal to look into the possibility of filing a defamation and slander suit against the US".

At the weekend there were street protests in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, over last week's verdict at the Scottish court in the Netherlands, which saw Megrahi convicted of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 20 years, and the acquittal of his co-accused, Al-Amin Khalifa Fhimah.

fields.headline: 'We told you - no more scoops'
fields.standfirst:
Geneive Abdo, the Guardian's correspondent in Iran, was forced to leave at the weekend under threat of prosecution. She explains the country's problem with freedom of expression, and recounts her own experience

More about Iran
fields.trailText: Geneive Abdo, the Guardian's correspondent in Iran, was forced to leave at the weekend under threat of prosecution. She explains the country's problem with freedom of expression, and recounts her own experience.
fields.body:
It was an interview with a journalist imprisoned for speaking his mind that precipitated my departure. Akbar Ganji sees himself as Iran's leading practitioner of free expression, and is accordingly forthright.

But when the Guardian published my interview with him 10 days ago, his allies in and around the government of President Mohammad Khatami apparently decided that western-style press freedom was a step too far.

In the interview Ganji warned of a possible social explosion in Iran in reaction to the theological "fascism" being exercised there, a reference to the conservative clerical establishment's tenets.

A small volatile figure, Ganji was confirmed as a reformist hero when a hardline court sentenced him last month to 10 years for dissent. After the interview he could not be discredited, so I had to be.

First, his friends and family accused me of deliberately distorting his views, though they had approved for publication the translation of the statements he had written in response to questions smuggled to him in Evin prison in Tehran.

They also threatened legal action under the harsh press laws already used to such effect against pro-reform journalists like Ganji and his three cellmates.

Next, I was told by the director general for foreign press in the ministry of culture and Islamic guidance in Tehran - the most influential institution still run by the reformers - that it was illegal to interview a political prisoner. If this is a crime in Iranian law, no one has been able to identify it to me on the statute books.

My husband, Jonathan Lyons, the Reuters bureau chief in Tehran, had taken part in the interview process with me. His agency was informed by letter that the matter was under investigation and that Reuters should prepare itself for the consequences.

Doubtful that we could rely on any official protection against being prosecuted by the authorities as criminals, we took the official warnings seriously. After all, one international press watchdog said recently that Iran had become the world's biggest prison for journalists. And just a few days ago 18 operatives from the intelligence ministry had been convicted of the murder of secular dissidents.

Telling almost no one and fearful of arrest at the airport's three guardposts, we slipped out of Tehran on the first available flight before dawn on Friday.

Yesterday Reuters said: "We reject the allegations against Reuters and against Jonathan." The agency's report on Ganji's views, which ran on January 22 under the headline "Iranian reformer warns of political explosion", was "a fair representation of Ganji's remarks", Reuters added.

Meanwhile I realised, the morning after we arrived in London, just how close our close call had been. I was harshly condemned in the official Iran Daily, the newspaper of the state news agency Irna. The paper is run by allies of President Khatami.

"Expulsion in this case is not an option," it stated. "The lady has breached Iranian law in publishing fabrications and distortions. She is not a diplomat and does not enjoy immunity from prosecution."

The strongly implied threat of jail for an accredited foreign correspondent sounded more like the rhetoric of the conservative press than that of an organ of a reformist government whose movement purports to be built on a platform of free expression and overseen by a philosopher-president.

More than any single event during my years in Iran, this experience brought home to me the autocratic tendencies of a reform movement that claims a democratic mantle - and how serious are the obstacles to political development in a country with a centuries-old history of authoritarian rule and limited experience of democracy's give-and-take.

"I am so sorry this has happened to you," said an Iranian intermediary in the affair. "This shows that once in power the reformers would behave just like the conservatives."

Western critics of the Islamic republic established in Iran 20 years ago argue that Islam is incompatible with democracy, a view I reject. But having tested the theory as a correspondent in Iran since 1998, my conclusion is that the sceptics are partly correct.

Too often the reformers have proved to be more interested in preserving the revolutionary political system and their own limited power than in implementing their stated goals of religious and political diversity, of social justice and freedom of expression - the elements, in short, of a healthy civil society. Dissenting voices threatened their status quo.

Mr Khatami's landslide election nearly four years ago gave many Iranians promise and hope.

To them he had swiftly become the smiling mullah who would shape an Islamic democracy. The expectations raised by western governments and Iranians knew few limits. He would oversee the rule of law and social justice. He would end repression against political dissenters. He would back the budding free press.

In turn, the argument went, his policies would make it easier for western governments to engage in a full detente with Iran, ending 20 years of hostility.

But, proving ineffectual at governing, he has ended up preserving more elements of the system than many a conservative might have been able to do.

Several crusaders for reform who were once his staunch supporters are now in prison under harsh sentences made public in January by a revolutionary court. At least 30 progressive newspapers and journals have been shut. Student demonstrators for democracy are serving long prison sentences, removing them from the political scene.

Newly elected MPs who say they are aligned with Mr Khatami are repeatedly overruled on key legislation, either by the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, or the conservative body of clerics and jurists empowered by the constitution to decide if bills conform with Islamic law.

My Guardian reports on these developments in the past eight months - and several interviews I did with prominent conservatives - set in motion a campaign against me by the reformers, unhappy at critical western press portrayals of their movement.

This picked up pace as President Khatami's political fortunes declined, to the point that he admitted that he lacked the political powers to do his job in the way he had hoped.

Soon after returning from holidays in early January, I had a phonecall from a senior Iranian official who monitors the foreign press, angry at one of my stories.

"We told you, no more scoops," he said. Within a month I was gone.

fields.headline: Grim war on human traffickers
fields.standfirst:
Few bright spots in a long battle against untouchable bosses with resilient networks

Special report: European integration
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Few bright spots in a long battle against untouchable bosses with resilient networks.
fields.body:
Hands cupped over headsets, the eavesdroppers squinted in concentration, awaiting another elliptical conversation in a foreign tongue. Even when translated the transcripts would yield little, for when using mobile phones the human traffickers always spoke in code.

Not this time. A Slavic accent came on the line. "Pronto?" A pause, then an oriental accent replied: "Si, pronto." They were speaking Italian.

The Croat had excellent Italian but not his Chinese colleague. Using dialect or allusions - the traditional techniques to baffle eavesdroppers - were not options. Words had to be enunciated slowly and clearly. A van would take the group from Ljubljana in the morning and drop them at the motorway service station outside Trieste by 3pm. "D'accordo, ciao," signed off the snakehead.

It is not difficult to imagine the grins in Trieste's police headquarters. A few months later the gang, led by Josip Loncaric, was broken up by Slovenian and Italian police. They had discovered an achilles heel of transnational trafficking.

That is one of the few bright spots in a grim outlook for Britain's efforts to spearhead a European Union war against illegal immigration. The government hopes that coordinated assaults can cut the influx and allay voter concern that illegal immigration is out of control.

However interviews with traffickers, migrants, investigators, analysts and magistrates in five countries reveal an adaptable foe positioned to resist the challenge. Europe is facing a long war of attrition.

When British immigration liaison officers take up their posts in Vienna, Rome, Budapest and Zagreb in the spring they will find networks capable of shooting or bribing their way out of most difficulties.

Last November Hungarian police at the Ukrainian border uncovered a cache of guns with silencers, radio equipment tuned to police frequencies, night-vision glasses, binoculars, hand grenades and motorised rubber dinghies.

Last summer French police broke up a Chinese smuggling ring which laundered £170m through two bureaux de change - enough to corrupt officials for decades.

"Profits are recycled into bribes. You get a lot of guards on tiny salaries getting rich and driving fancy cars," said Duc Tran of the International Organisation for Migration (IOM), in Zagreb.

More formidable still is a modus operandi which has evolved to make the bosses untouchable and their networks resilient. Rather than build the monolithic hierarchical cartels favoured by drug traffickers, they tend to sub-contract to freelancers in transit countries, like multinational companies.

"It is best to envisage smuggling groups as loosely structured organisations that consist of constantly shifting relationships," according to an IOM report written by Prof Ronald Skeldon, of the University of Sussex.

An Italian parliamentary report identified three categories. At the top are regional bosses, especially in China, the Middle East and the Indian sub-continent. They find clients, forge alliances, set prices, stipulate conditions and authorise payments.

At the middle level are bosses in transit countries, especially Turkey and the Balkans, who organise safe houses, commission false documents, choose routes, pay bribes and hire local criminals as drivers, guides, lookouts and guards. Drugs, tobacco and arms are included in some shipments, as favours to other gangs. Fugitive mobsters sometimes use the routes.

At the the lowest level are minor smugglers in transit and destination countries valued for their local knowledge. Paid per job, they are expected to maintain equipment, establish rapport with corrupt officials, monitor beaches, train and bus stations, and choose points of handover.

Few smugglers remain outside the system. "The days when we cut our own deals with passengers is over. Now it's all middle men," lamented one veteran Albanian smuggler in the port of Vlore.

Often waiting in the destination country are representatives of the origin country boss, who will detain the migrants until relatives pay the outstanding debt. Alternatively, the migrants might be put to work in sweatshops or as prostitutes. "They operate like companies, except they use violence and torture as means of persuasion," said Tana De Zulueta, an Italian senator.

By such segmentation, specialisation and flexibility has human trafficking become the world's fastest growing criminal business. Employees know little, if anything, about their ultimate bosses. Identifying them, gathering evidence and obtaining convictions is a herculean task.

Routes are well established: Chinese via Belgrade, where former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic was happy to generate visa payments and annoy the west; migrants and asylum seekers from the Middle East, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka via Sarajevo, where Bosnian authorities obliged fellow Muslims. Last year more than 50,000 are estimated to have passed through on the way to western Europe.

Three overland routes snake into Italy and Austria via Croatia, Slovenia and Hungary. Suffocations in trucks and drownings in the Sava river are common. Others board semi-inflatables for moonlit crossings of the Adriatic from Vlore or Split. More than 130 drowned last year.

An Anglo-Italian initiative will intensify pressure on Yugoslavia and Bosnia to clamp down. Hopeful of western aid, they have already started. Croatia and Slovenia are praised by the Home Office for their efforts. The long-term goal is to make the Balkans stable enough for asylum seekers to stay there.

In the meantime, the government wants joint police operations to hunt down the bosses in the transit countries, one by one. An expanded role for Europol is envisaged. Wire taps, surveillance and informants are to penetrate the networks. The fall of Josip and Gloria Loncaric is cited as the way ahead.

Police believe the networks have been left vulnerable by their expansion. "Debriefing their clients can yield gems of information," said one British intelligence source.

However, one Croatian investigator said: "If we succeed in disrupting the networks they'll raise their prices to cover the costs. And clients will pay up, they always do."

How net closed on a smuggler

The rise and fall of a Sino-Balkan trafficking network has been hailed as a model breakthrough which European police and immigration authorities should study and replicate.

Twenty years ago a Croatian taxi driver, Josip Loncaric, started delivering fruit and veg to the Italian border and branched out into smuggling people. When Yugoslavia broke up, demand and profit soared. Loncaric bought a fleet of cars and vans and transported hundreds of Albanians and Yugoslavs.

Chinese criminals started importing countrymen into Trieste, in north-east Italy. Loncaric, 43, relocated to Slovenia and formed an alliance with the Chinese after marrying Wang Xuemei, 32, a boss's niece. He bought an Albanian airline - plus a football team and string of properties - and business boomed.

He employed 200 people to smuggle into the EU clients from China, the Philippines, Bangladesh and eastern Europe. More than 5,000 entered Italy last year.

An Italian court sentenced him to six years in absentia for aiding and abetting illegal immigration, but authorities could do little except intercept the occasional convoy.

That changed in 1998 when anti-mafia specialists in Trieste joined forces with Slovenian and British investigators. Wire taps and surveillance led them to a Loncaric lieutenant, Tomo Fodor, who agreed to become an informant in return for leniency.

Last July Slovenian police arrested Loncaric as dozens of accomplices were lifted in Italy. His wife was caught in Trieste in November. Both are expected to face trial this year. The weekly convoys into Medjimurje, Loncaric's Croatian base, are no more, said Bozena Katanec, of Croatia's interior ministry.

That changed in 1998 when anti-mafia specialists in Trieste joined forces with Slovenian and British investigators. Wire taps and surveillance led them to a Loncaric lieutenant, Tomo Fodor, who agreed to become an informant in return for leniency. Last July Slovenian police arrested Loncaric as dozens of accomplices were lifted in Italy. His wife was caught in Trieste in November. Both are expected to face trial this year. The weekly convoys into Medjimurje, Loncaric's Croatian base, are no more, said Bozena Katanec, of Croatia's interior ministry.

webTitle: Snow and flooding cause road chaos

fields.headline: Snow and flooding cause road chaos
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Heavy snow and flooding caused chaos last night in Scotland and the north of England, and motorists face the prospect of more delays today, with further snowfalls and rain expected across the country.
fields.body:
Heavy snow and flooding caused chaos last night in Scotland and the north of England, and motorists face the prospect of more delays today, with further snowfalls and rain expected across the country.

Scotland continuesd to be worst hit after a weekend of snow, with falls of 13cm reported yesterday in the south of the country.

Roads were blocked, and the Pennines were also affected by flurries.

Drifting snow in Fife, Tayside and the Borders closed minor roads while main routes were barely kept clear by snowploughs and gritting machines.

Flooding and heavy snowfalls made many roads impassable yesterday in Grampian, where routes around the Strathdon area were badly affected. The road near the Glenshee skiing area was closed. Grampian police said the situation was "horrendous" but added that motorists had become used to bad conditions in winter.

Hundreds of people were left without electricity after snow fell on power lines in the north.

A spokesman for Hydro-Electric said that about 1,400 customers were initially forced to do without power but around 700 had been reconnected.

Sporting events were also affected by the snow. Yesterday's Premiership football fixture between Newcastle United and Southampton at St James' Park was postponed.

Rainfall in East Anglia left many minor roads impassable. Sixteen millimetres fell in Honington in Suffolk.

fields.headline: New logo at heart of New Labour's bemusing image problem
fields.standfirst:
Special report
New Labour in power
fields.trailText: It appears all things to all people, and could keep you guessing for ever. New Labour's new logo may be well intentioned, but it seems to raise more questions than it answers.
fields.body:
It appears all things to all people, and could keep you guessing for ever. New Labour's new logo may be well intentioned, but it seems to raise more questions than it answers.

The emblem, which adorns a new array of Labour party merchandise, left some people scratching their heads in bewilderment as they attempted to decipher its message.

Is it a man with a parachute? Why does the heart have a hole in it? What's the seagull supposed to mean? Is it a child's scribble?

The logo has been created by a team of designers at the party's Millbank headquarters, and has been launched as an addition to the red rose introduced as Labour's symbol by Peter Mandelson when he was the party's head of communications in 1986.

A Labour Party spokeswoman explained yesterday that the meaning behind the brightly coloured image in pink, mustard, orange and black, incorporating a little figure, a heart and a cross, was one of caring and participation.

"It is bright. It is colourful. It is a new image. It has got a cross on it, which clearly represents voting. It's about voting Labour with your head and with your heart," said the spokeswoman.

She emphasised that the red rose remained the definitive Labour symbol, quashing fears that it might be phased out to make way for the new abstract design.

"This is not something that will be widely used on conference platforms. It is simply a merchandising logo. People seem to be happy with it. I believe it is selling quite well."

Labour supporters can buy the heart logo on keyrings and stickers, latte mugs, cufflinks, and trendy "skinnifit" T-shirts.

The design failed to impress Richard Sedley, joint head of design for internet design and branding company, cScape, who felt it lacked impact and reflected a sense of confusion over Labour's identityy.

He said: "There is a clarity in what they are trying to say about caring and participation.

"But these values are something that every political party would lay claim to. There is no unique selling point. Its main virtue is its lack of offensiveness, but as a consequence it doesn't seem to be a particularly powerful image."

The appeal of the new logo was also lost on Derek Draper, Mr Mandelson's former aide, who launched an advertising agency, Farm Communications, in 1999.

He said: "It is clear that they are trying to conjure up associations with various charities in the hope that subliminally people will therefore see the Labour party as a benign force for good.

"The problem is that the Labour party is supposed to be about more than that.

"What the government needs is a meaningful identity that gets the support of the heartlands, not a heart logo that is just a meaningless corporate identity. I think we will find this is a quick fix design to make some ready money."

Mr Draper warned further that things could get even worse if certain members of the cabinet took a shine to the logo's new line in clothes: "Let us pray John Prescott does not model the skinnyfit T-shirt."

fields.headline: Mandelson says he seeks justice, not revenge
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson warned yesterday that Labour would be damaged if he was "falsely branded as a liar", but expressed confidence that those who had accused him of telling an untruth would realise their honest mistake once the facts became known.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson warned yesterday that Labour would be damaged if he was "falsely branded as a liar", but expressed confidence that those who had accused him of telling an untruth would realise their honest mistake once the facts became known.

The ousted cabinet minister spoke exclusively to the Guardian after flying back from a week's break in the United States determined to clear his name, and buoyed by new memos casting doubt on the case against him.

But he was also anxious to dismiss fears among ministers and government officials that he is in a dangerous and volatile mood and bent on revenge. He insisted he would be conciliatory and do nothing to harm the Labour party or his friends in politics.

"My party's interests mean everything to me, and they always have done," Mr Mandelson said.

There had been reports that Mandelson was gunning for the head of the home civil service, Sir Richard Wilson, the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, and the Downing Street chief of staff Jonathan Powell.

The three men were seen as responsible for deciding Mr Mandelson was guilty of misleading Number 10 over whether he had telephoned Mike O'Brien, the home office minister, to discuss a passport for Srichand Hinduja, the Indian billionaire.

An inquiry, set up by the prime minister to review whether passport applications by SP and GP Hinduja were properly dealt with, has been criticised as a "kangaroo court", partly because of Sir Anthony's close links to the Home Office.

But Mr Mandelson, who is due to meet his lawyers today to discuss the inquiry, said yesterday: "I believe I can be confident in the objectivity of the Hammond inquiry. If our party stands for anything it stands for natural justice and I hope I am allowed to benefit from that belief.

"All I want to do now is explain my actions and describe events in the light of new information that has emerged."

A memo dated January 11 written by a Northern Ireland Office official - and leaked to the Sunday Times - records that Home Office minister Mike O'Brien was uncertain whether the telephone conversation with Mr Mandelson about SP Hinduja's passport application had taken place. The memo to Mr Mandelson reads: "I am told that you raised the issue with Mike O'Brien either in a telephone call or a personal note. Mike O'Brien does not remember precisely how you raised it."

A second typewritten note dated October 5 1998, from Mr O'Brien to Mr Mandelson concerning Mr Mandelson's questions over the Hinduja passport, also does not refer to a phone call, saying only "you were in contact with my office last week".

After Mr Mandelson told the Observer that the contacts over the Hinduja passport had been through his private office, the home secretary Jack Straw subsequently contacted Number 10 to insist there had been a phone call. Following Mr Mandelson's resignation Mr O'Brien also gave interviews saying there had been a phone call between himself and Mr Mandelson.

Mr Straw said the existence of the phone call made Mr Mandelson's resignation inevitable because an untruth had been told.

Mr Mandelson's fate may now turn on whether there is clear documentary evidence in the Home Office that a phone call did occur.

"This is clearly a difficult situation for me and everyone else," Mr Mandelson told the Guardian yesterday. "No doubt the Tory party would like me to be in a dangerous and volatile mood, but I am going to disappoint them."

"My frame of mind is quite different. My colleagues are still my colleagues, my friends in politics are still my friends and I will do nothing to harm them or the party. The party's interests mean everything to me, they always have done."

But, he added, in an apparent reference to Mr Straw and other ministers - such as the international development secretary Clare Short - who have accused him of not telling the truth: "I do not think it's great for the party for me to be falsely branded as a liar, as someone who told an untruth.

"Those who believe this are mistaken - no doubt their mistake is an honest one, based on the facts as they saw them. But I hope they will look at all the circumstances and the chain of events again and realise the facts were not as they perceived them."

Despite offers from both the BBC's Panorama and ITV's Trevor McDonald programme to put his side of the story, the former Northern Ireland secretary is planning to keep a low profile until the outcome of Sir Anthony's inquiry.

webTitle: CJD link to blood Britain sold abroad

fields.headline: CJD link to blood Britain sold abroad
fields.standfirst:
CJD link to exported blood

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Blood products donated by three people who were later struck down with the human form of BSE have been sold to 11 countries, amid mounting concern that Britain could soon be blamed for exporting the fatal human condition as well as the cattle disease.
fields.byline: James Meikle and Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Blood products donated by three people who were later struck down with the human form of BSE have been sold to 11 countries, amid mounting concern that Britain could soon be blamed for exporting the fatal human condition as well as the cattle disease.

Thousands of patients worldwide, and an unknown number of haemophiliacs in Britain, might have received treatments with the products between 1996 and last year. The risk of infection - which health department officials insist is only theoretical - has now been closed off by restricting blood sources to the US.

But advisers fear some hospital trusts are still taking unjustifiable gambles by allowing old surgical instruments to be sent abroad to countries with shortages of equipment. One source said Britain should shut off such supplies and behave "like a village with the black death".

Cattle in scores of countries are already thought to have been exposed to the risk of BSE through exports of animal feed between 1988 and 1996. Last night Malcolm Tibbert, chairman of the Human BSE Foundation which represents the families of victims, said:"Lessons of the past have not been taken on board. It is bad enough we have vCJD in this country, and it is clear BSE was exported, but this would take it to another level."

It was now more than 12 years since concerns about spreading disease through blood or vaccine were raised, he added.

The number of vCJD victims in Britain could now have reached 94. Thirteen have been blood donors, and their blood has been used in transfusions for 23 people as well as in other products. The government is considering changing advice that doctors should not normally inform patients exposed to a theoretical risk of contamination because there is no test, no cure and no treatment.

The Irish authorities announced just before Christmas that polio vaccine administered in 1998-99 had included albumin from a British vCJD victim who had given blood in both 1996 and 1997. Babies and pre-school children received most of the 83,500 doses administered. The Irish government was informed by manufacturer Evans/Medeva.

Brazil received nearly 45,000 vials of albumin, used to restore and maintain blood volume in patients, but a senior official of the country's national agency for medical surveillance said she had never received any formal notification of problems.

There has been no response from the Brazilian company that sold the product on behalf on Bio Products Laboratory, part of the NHS's blood service, which sent products to Dubai, India, Turkey, Brunei, Egypt, Morocco, Oman, Singapore and Russia.

Immunoglobulin, which helps replace antibodies, and factor VIII, a clotting agent, were also exported. The blood service said it was impossible to say how many patients might be involved or treatments administered. One patient might receive a number of treatments from the same batch, and some batches were replaced in 1998-99 after the first two "risky" donors were identified. Some batches were discarded by hospitals and all had now passed three-year expiry dates.

Such plasma-derived products were made up from a large number of individual donations, a typical starting pool involving 24,000. "There is no scientific evidence to suggest that vCJD can be transmitted through plasma or plasma-related products, nor through blood donations in general," a spokesman said.

BPL had informed appropriate regulatory bodies abroad that vCJD patients had donated blood. It had also written to wholesalers in each country and had confirmation they had told their relevant ministries. "We have tried our very best," said a spokesman. Since 1998 most plasma used here has come from the US.

Concerns over donations of equipment were raised recently when it was discovered that an endoscope, used for examining internal organs, just sent to India might have been used on a vCJD patient. The patient was found subsequently not to have had vCJD.

The Department of Health said guidelines suggested such sales abroad should not take place. But individual trusts might choose to help hospitals in other countries.

Where it went:

Ireland polio vaccine 83,500 doses

Brazil albumin 44,864 vials, immunoglobulin 80 vials

Dubai albumin 2,400 vials

India albumin 953 vials

Turkey immunoglobulin 840 vials

Brunei albumin 400 vials

Egypt albumin 144 vials

Morocco albumin 100 vials

Oman immunoglobulin 100 vials

Russia factor VIII 23 vials

Singapore immunoglobulin three vials

webTitle: Second runway lets Manchester rival Gatwick

fields.headline: Second runway lets Manchester rival Gatwick
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Manchester International Airport is poised to overtake Gatwick as the second largest in the country with the opening of its controversial second runway today - the first built in Britain for 20 years.
fields.body:
Manchester International Airport is poised to overtake Gatwick as the second largest in the country with the opening of its controversial second runway today - the first built in Britain for 20 years.

The £172m project, stretching for almost two miles into the Cheshire countryside, is expected to increase capacity from 18m passengers a year to more than 40m by 2016.

With demand for air travel set to grow rapidly, it is certain to intensify the debate over where to build new runways and terminals elsewhere - particularly in the overcrowded south-east.

Backed by north-west MPs, publicly owned Manchester is pressing for better south-north transport links to take the strain off greater London. But much depends on a detailed government review of air transport, likely to come in a white paper after the election.

Ministers are acutely aware of the political sensitivity of the issue, with Conservatives already identifying unrelenting growth in the south- east, particularly plans for hundreds of thousands of new homes - and a deteriorating quality of life in the region as a key election issue.

The findings from the lengthy planning inquiry into the case for a fifth terminal at Heathrow are now due to be in the hands of ministers although a decision is unlikely before the election. Nationally, government forecasts point to a doubling of traffic over the next 15 years with passenger volumes at British airports likely to rise to 333m in 2015 and to more than 400m by 2020.

Any attempt by BAA, operator of Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted, to further expand south-east airports - or develop new ones, such as Alconbury in Cambridgeshire - will run into strong opposition from environmental groups, Conservatives and local councils.

But business organisations, such as the London Chamber of Commerce and Industry, have urged ministers to bite the bullet and accept that fudging could seriously undermine Heathrow's position as the fourth busiest in the world. The chamber says runway capacity at all three London airports will be exhausted within 10 years.

But Manchester Airport plc, owned by the 10 councils in Greater Manchester, is urging the government to adopt an alternative strategy - based on expansion in the Midlands and the north, where growing airports could provide a considerable boost to flagging local economies.

It already owns Humberside airport and is poised to buy from the National Express group the fast-expanding East Midlands airport, which is vying with Stansted as the country's largest cargo airport. It has also set its sights on Newcastle airport and, being likely to buy Bournemouth airport, the company is poised to rival privatised BAA as Britain's second largest airport operator.

Geoff Muirhead, chief executive of Manchester Airport, said it was preparing to overtake Gatwick as Britain's second-biggest airport by 2012. "Millions of people travel to London for flights and millions from the north-west fly down to London [for them]. We have to grab those people and make direct flights from Manchester our priority."

But much depends on a detailed government review of air transport, likely to come in a white paper after the election. Ministers are acutely aware of the political sensitivity of the issue, with Conservatives already identifying unrelenting growth in the south- east, particularly plans for hundreds of thousands of new homes - and a deteriorating quality of life in the region as a key election issue. The findings from the lengthy planning inquiry into the case for a fifth terminal at Heathrow are now due to be in the hands of ministers although a decision is unlikely before the election. Nationally, government forecasts point to a doubling of traffic over the next 15 years with passenger volumes at British airports likely to rise to 333m in 2015 and to more than 400m by 2020. Any attempt by BAA, operator of Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted, to further expand south-east airports - or develop new ones, such as Alconbury in Cambridgeshire - will run into strong opposition from environmental groups, Conservatives and local councils. But business organisations, such as the London Chamber of Commerce and Industry, have urged ministers to bite the bullet and accept that fudging could seriously undermine Heathrow's position as the fourth busiest in the world. The chamber says runway capacity at all three London airports will be exhausted within 10 years. But Manchester Airport plc, owned by the 10 councils in Greater Manchester, is urging the government to adopt an alternative strategy - based on expansion in the Midlands and the north, where growing airports could provide a considerable boost to flagging local economies. It already owns Humberside airport and is poised to buy from the National Express group the fast-expanding East Midlands airport, which is vying with Stansted as the country's largest cargo airport. It has also set its sights on Newcastle airport and, being likely to buy Bournemouth airport, the company is poised to rival privatised BAA as Britain's second largest airport operator. Geoff Muirhead, chief executive of Manchester Airport, said it was preparing to overtake Gatwick as Britain's second-biggest airport by 2012. "Millions of people travel to London for flights and millions from the north-west fly down to London [for them]. We have to grab those people and make direct flights from Manchester our priority."

fields.headline: Doomed Barak woos Arab voters
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ehud Barak held out an olive branch to Israel's Arab citizens yesterday in a frantic attempt to contain what promises to be a defeat of biblical proportions in tomorrow's prime ministerial elections.
fields.body:
Ehud Barak held out an olive branch to Israel's Arab citizens yesterday in a frantic attempt to contain what promises to be a defeat of biblical proportions in tomorrow's prime ministerial elections.

Four months after police shot dead 13 Arab protesters - citizens of the Jewish state - Mr Barak yesterday came as close as he ever has to an apology. "As prime minister, I bear overall responsibility for everything that occurs during my tenure in office," he said in a statement. "No Israeli citizen should have to be killed in any demonstration."

But Mr Barak's belated expression of remorse may have arrived too late to persuade 500,000 Arab voters to end a polling day boycott that, together with the desertion by leftwing voters, looks set to seal his defeat against the hardline Likud leader, Ariel Sharon. With Mr Sharon leading by as much as 21 percentage points in opinion polls ahead of tomorrow's vote, the Barak team have been feverishly trying to overcome a call by Arab leaders to boycott the vote, or cast a blank ballot.

They also face a low turnout among leftwing voters, who have abandoned Mr Barak because of his often brutal response to the four-month uprising in the West Bank and Gaza, in which more than 330 Palestinians have been killed.

"I am going to cast a white [blank] ballot because I have no other choice," said Danny Grimblat, who braved chilling rain on Saturday night to join a few hundred people at a Peace Now demonstration in Jerusalem.

"Barak is no better than Sharon. Under Barak the occupation got meaner, and Palestinians must think that Israelis no longer support peace because of how Barak dealt with the intifada."

The twin boycott movements have sharply accelerated Mr Barak's freefall. He lost the centre because of four months of frightening bloodshed, and the left and Israeli Arab voters are unhappy about choosing between Mr Barak and Mr Sharon.

At the Peace Now demonstration, speakers pleaded with the crowd to relent. "It is forbidden to sit at home. We will be punishing all of us, not just Ehud."

But unless there is a miraculous shift in opinion, Mr Barak is headed for the most crushing defeat in Israeli history, barely 20 months after coming to power in a record landslide. Most observers say he has only himself to blame. Israelis see the former army chief of staff as an aloof and arrogant figure.

Although Israeli casualties in the intifada are a fraction of Palestinian losses, Israelis lost faith in Mr Barak's powers to protect them after seeing nightly footage of the shooting at Gilo, a Jewish settlement on the edge of Jerusalem.

Although Mr Barak sent in tanks to pulverise the handful of gunmen in the neighbouring Palestinian town of Beit Jala, the gun battles symbolised Israelis' darkest fears: despite their overwhelming military advantage in the region, they stood isolated, and alone.

"I do not feel easy with what happened in Gilo - all the killing and the security problems," said Rina Raz, a tourism ministry employee.

Ms Raz, left a widow at age 18 when her soldier husband was killed in the 1967 war, is sticking by Mr Barak. "I am very afraid there will be a war in April if Ariel Sharon wins, and I know what war means."

But the paradox is that most Israelis now see Mr Sharon as their protector, despite warnings from Jordan, Egypt and the Palestinian leadership last week that he could plunge the region into war. Israelis are backing Mr Sharon precisely because they expect he will respond with even more force to Palestinian violence.

In the face of defeat Mr Barak is strongly defending his peace policies. He said last week he was a lone firefighter, who had thrown himself on the blaze of Palestinian grievances before all of Israel went up in flames.

Key facts

 In the latest opinion polls, Ehud Barak is between 17 and 21 percentage points behind Ariel Sharon

 The Israeli Arab community, which does not include those in the West Bank or Gaza, represents slightly more than 12.3% of Israel's electorate

 The "Russians" in Israel, who make up 18% of the electorate, are said to hold the balance in the elections. Most came to Israel after the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989

fields.headline: Media hounding Vaz, says Cook
fields.standfirst:
Foreign secretary attacks campaign of 'innuendo'

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Foreign secretary attacks campaign of 'innuendo'.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday went to the defence of the minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, claiming he was being hounded by a media which had failed to sustain a single allegation against Mr Vaz. 1 Mr Cook said: "I have seen nothing in any of the stories that have been produced about Mr Vaz that are not innuendo and guilt by association."

He added: "Keith Vaz has been hounded over the past two weeks. Not one single fact has emerged of where it is alleged that he has broken the ministerial code of conduct. It really is time they brought down the curtain on this unedified, unjustified, hounding."

He said the issues should be left to be resolved by the inquiry being conducted by Sir Anthony Hammond QC. Sir Anthony is examining whether Mr Vaz acted improperly in talking to the Home Office about passports for the Hinduja brothers.

Mr Vaz's fate may, in fact, be sealed tomorrow when the select committee on standards and privileges meets in private to cross-examine three of the key witnesses who claimed Mr Vaz improperly took cash for favours in the mid-1990s.

Allegations have been levelled against Mr Vaz by a lawyer, Sarosh Zaiwalla. However, Mr Vaz's lawyer, Geoffrey Bindman, has insisted: "None of these payments ever came to Mr Vaz personally. They relate to charitable donations, dinners and a constituency calendar."

In apparently good news for Mr Vaz, his election agent for his Leicester East constituency party denied Mr Vaz had in 1997 failed to hand to the local party over £15,000 worth of donations from three businessmen.

The donations, intended for the party's election campaign, were recorded in the register of members' interests.

The Sunday Telegraph had quoted the treasurer of Mr Vaz's local party, Piara Singh Clair, saying he had no record in the party accounts of these payments in the run-up to the election.

However, Keith Bennett, Mr Vaz's agent during the election, said the money had been channelled through a separate account and had not gone missing. Labour yesterday refused to publish the Leicester East local party account into which the three donations of £5,000 eventually went. It said no requirement existed for it to do so until the provisions of the Political Parties Funding Act becomes law on February 16.

Mr Vaz also denied stories that he was depressed and intending to stand down as a minister at the next election. He has also explained his plans to buy a £900,000 house, saying the money would have been raised through his own funds, as well as that of his wife and his mother.

In practice it appears as if Mr Vaz is going to have to continue to absorb a string of allegations him until the Hammond inquiry and the select committee publish their reports settling the issue once and for all.

Mr Cook claimed yesterday that Mr Vaz was under attack from the rightwing press because of his pro-European views. He said Mr Vaz's position was different to that of Mr Mandelson "since Peter accepted at the time of his resignation that there had been a difference between him and another minister as to whether a conversation took place. There is no similar allegation against Mr Vaz," Mr Cook said.

John Redwood, the Conservative campaign spokesman, called on Mr Vaz to stand down. "He is surrounded by so many unhelpful stories and allegations that it would be best if he resigned," he said.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed Case against Fhimah fatally flawed, page 5, February 1, we gave a misleading account of the passage of the bomb which blew up the plane over Lockerbie. It was not transferred to the jumbo jet at Frankfurt but put on a feeder flight there and transferred to Flight 103 at Heathrow.
fields.body:
In a report headed Case against Fhimah fatally flawed, page 5, February 1, we gave a misleading account of the passage of the bomb which blew up the plane over Lockerbie. It was not transferred to the jumbo jet at Frankfurt but put on a feeder flight there and transferred to Flight 103 at Heathrow.

In our obituary of the second world war fighter pilot Johnnie Johnson, page 22, February 1, we confused our victory celebrations. It was VE Day (not VJ Day) that came in May 1945. Victory over Japan followed in August of that year.

In an article headed London skyline graced by first red kite for over a century, page 9, Society, January 17, we said that the bird was believed to be extinct in Britain by the end of the 19th century and that Spanish birds were introduced to mid-Wales in 1989 to restore the species. The Welsh Kite Trust (Ymddiriedolaeth Barcudiaid Cymru) insists that although the kite population in mid-Wales dwindled to a handful of breeding pairs it always maintained a talon hold, never dying out completely. It has now increased to 250 breeding pairs, representing the native British blood line. See www.kitecountry.co.uk

Homophone corner, from a profile of the chief inspector of prisons, page 8, G2: "But according to Home Office whisperers, he's a loose canon..."

In our review of the new Mel Gibson film, What Women Want, page 12, Friday Review, February 2, we said "Mel is accidentally electrocuted in his bathroom and subsequently discovers that he has the ability to hear what women are thinking." To electrocute is to kill by electric shock, or [US] to execute in the electric chair (Collins dictionary).

webTitle: Popstars' rise to fully fledged phenomenon

fields.headline: It's all over bar the pouting
fields.standfirst: On Saturday night, the Popstars were finally - officially - revealed to the world.  Gareth McLean  and  Matt Wells  chart the show's rise from mere hit to fully fledged phenomenon
fields.trailText: On Saturday night, the Popstars were finally - officially - revealed to the world. Gareth McLean and Matt Wells chart the show's rise from mere hit to fully fledged phenomenon
fields.body:
In Australia, Popstars was dubbed "train-crash television". Such a label might exceed the boundaries of taste here, but it gives you an idea of the emotional, psychological and occasionally physical carnage that has made it the most compulsive show on TV.

Since it debuted on ITV last month, Popstars has consistently increased its audience. Last Wednesday's stroll down the boulevard of broken dreams attracted 10m viewers, 1.4m more than saw the ditching of Darius Danesh after his rendition of Britney Spears's Baby One More Time - which was quite possibly one of the ugliest moments on British television.

Popstars is this season's Must-See TV, the first piece of watercooler television of the new year. It is the talk not just of the playground and student common room, but of offices, pubs, steamies and Age Concern day centres everywhere. Popstars can lay claim to being one of those old-fashioned, universal television hits.

Combining soap-opera narrative with the candid cameras of reality TV and the old-fashioned talent show, Popstars appeals to both the viewer's kind heart and malicious mind. We applaud Claire, the Big Glaswegian Girl, for her determination and ambition, cry when she gets knocked out, and boo the arrogant Darius for his silly beard and sillier spiritual babble. We wish Warren well as he cries in the toilets and rue Raymond's penchant for port. We watch in slack-jawed disbelief as the tuneless prove they are just as inept at dancing - truly Stars In Their Minds - and we marvel at those who can get to that high note in Reach For The Stars.

And we do it all from the safety of our sofas, envying the brass neck of those who were brave enough to give it a go. While the tagline on the Popstars website may be overstating things somewhat - "Everyone wants to be a popstar" - there can't be many of us who haven't thought about it, even if we only got as far as dancing in front of the mirror, hairbrush in hand, miming to Barry Manilow's Copacabana.

Of course, the prize is the biggest lure of all, one which is potentially bigger than anything Chris Tarrant has to offer - national and perhaps international fame. Ask a class of seven or eight-year-olds what they want to be when they're older and rather than train drivers or astronauts, doctors or farmers, the majority will answer either a pop star or a footballer. Some might even be forthright and savvy enough to simply respond: "I want to be famous."

In a society which claims to be meritocratic, celebrity is seen as a way out of mediocrity. In a society in which Posh and Becks are idolised, is it any wonder there are recruitment crises in health care, law enforcement and education? Such professions simply don't present nearly enough opportunities to meet Madonna.

Watching Popstars is a way of reminding yourself that the big hand of fate could appear from nowhere; it is vicarious adventure. To paraphrase Popstars' Suzanne, it's like getting yourself a lucky lottery ticket.

Little surprise then that Popstars has also generated a level of unrelenting media interest, the like of which hasn't been seen since Big Brother. It should be remembered, however, that that show provided the press with rich pickings and near constant internet coverage, while Popstars is only on once or twice a week.

Press interest centred immediately on the character of Nigel Lythgoe, LWT's flouncy-haired head of entertainment, and once the Guardian had solemnly declared him a "cult figure" (after just one programme), the tabloids had the excuse they needed to dive in.

During the first three weeks of transmission, a torrent of torrid tales appeared. According to one particularly fanciful story in the Daily Star - which appears not to have been discouraged by an excited LWT publicity department - the harassed executive had resorted to changing his route home from work because of threats from rejected hopefuls. Then, as the series developed and characters emerged, stories moved on to the wannabe pop stars themselves.

The Sunday Mirror revealed the "secret" location where the chosen band members were holed up, and they then had to be moved in a cloak-and-dagger operation to avoid the paparazzi. And when the Sunday People revealed the name of the final five, ITV network bosses hurriedly rescheduled subsequent programmes to bring the official unveiling forward. Extra repeats were scheduled for weekday nights, and a two-programme special aired last Saturday looking at the choosing of the final line-up.

Today, the country's media is descending upon Heathrow airport in London for a (doubtless) frenzied press conference with Suzanne, Noel, Myleene, Danny and Kym - the final five. It has been an extraordinary media event, and one which is entering a whole new phase, with the rest of the series emulating the formula of MTV's does-what-it-says-on-the-tin, Making The Band.

The show's success has even surprised ITV, which has been accused of under-ambition by scheduling at Saturday teatime. A peak-time, mid-week slot would almost certainly have guaranteed higher audience figures than Saturday early evening, but had the show bombed, it would have done so from a far greater height.

ITV marketing bosses deny the charge, saying that Popstars has succeeded in its aim of delivering a strong audience into the key Saturday-night schedule. But John Hardie, director of marketing at the ITV network, concedes that from the first rushes of the auditions, ITV knew it had a hit.

"When you saw the raw footage of the auditions and people being rejected or accepted, you realised that this was something incredibly powerful and dramatic. We decided that we would go massive on it."

As well they might. In New Zealand, where the format originated, Popstars was big, but once it crossed the Tasman Sea, it was huge. In 2000, it was one of Australia's biggest television shows and the band the show created, Bardot, went on to land a number one single and a number one album. The girl band - not to be confused with Bardo, the 1982 British Eurovision entry - have since embarked on national and Asia-wide tours, and their song, Higher Than Heaven, was used as the theme tune for Olympics coverage on Australian television.

Realising that young viewers often dictate household viewing habits and that ITV wasn't courting the youth market as successfully as Channel 4 or BBC2 (its attempts at youth programming can resemble a drunken uncle dancing at a wedding reception), the network threw huge money at it. The "Nigel, pick me" posters became talking points themselves, as did the trailers which littered ITV for weeks before transmission. The strategy worked.

But what does the band have to look forward to? After months of auditions, rehearsals and recording - and today's press conference - the real work starts now. While helped along by the fact they feature in what is essentially a twice-weekly hour-long advert for themselves and their wares, the band have, as the song says, many rivers to cross. For every S Club 7, there is a 911, so they should bear in mind the wise words of Karen Carpenter: "We've only just begun."

And whether anybody is actually drinking the juice that sponsors the show is anyone's guess. After watching Popstars, it's not a soft drink you need, it's a good stiff brandy.

 Popstars, tonight, 11.30pm, ITV

We wish Warren well as he cries in the toilets and rue Raymond's penchant for port. We watch in slack-jawed disbelief as the tuneless prove they are just as inept at dancing - truly Stars In Their Minds - and we marvel at those who can get to that high note in Reach For The Stars. And we do it all from the safety of our sofas, envying the brass neck of those who were brave enough to give it a go. While the tagline on the Popstars website may be overstating things somewhat - "Everyone wants to be a popstar" - there can't be many of us who haven't thought about it, even if we only got as far as dancing in front of the mirror, hairbrush in hand, miming to Barry Manilow's Copacabana. Of course, the prize is the biggest lure of all, one which is potentially bigger than anything Chris Tarrant has to offer - national and perhaps international fame. Ask a class of seven or eight-year-olds what they want to be when they're older and rather than train drivers or astronauts, doctors or farmers, the majority will answer either a pop star or a footballer. Some might even be forthright and savvy enough to simply respond: "I want to be famous." In a society which claims to be meritocratic, celebrity is seen as a way out of mediocrity. In a society in which Posh and Becks are idolised, is it any wonder there are recruitment crises in health care, law enforcement and education? Such professions simply don't present nearly enough opportunities to meet Madonna. Watching Popstars is a way of reminding yourself that the big hand of fate could appear from nowhere; it is vicarious adventure. To paraphrase Popstars' Suzanne, it's like getting yourself a lucky lottery ticket. Little surprise then that Popstars has also generated a level of unrelenting media interest, the like of which hasn't been seen since Big Brother. It should be remembered, however, that that show provided the press with rich pickings and near constant internet coverage, while Popstars is only on once or twice a week. Press interest centred immediately on the character of Nigel Lythgoe, LWT's flouncy-haired head of entertainment, and once the Guardian had solemnly declared him a "cult figure" (after just one programme), the tabloids had the excuse they needed to dive in. During the first three weeks of transmission, a torrent of torrid tales appeared. According to one particularly fanciful story in the Daily Star - which appears not to have been discouraged by an excited LWT publicity department - the harassed executive had resorted to changing his route home from work because of threats from rejected hopefuls. Then, as the series developed and characters emerged, stories moved on to the wannabe pop stars themselves. The Sunday Mirror revealed the "secret" location where the chosen band members were holed up, and they then had to be moved in a cloak-and-dagger operation to avoid the paparazzi. And when the Sunday People revealed the name of the final five, ITV network bosses hurriedly rescheduled subsequent programmes to bring the official unveiling forward. Extra repeats were scheduled for weekday nights, and a two-programme special aired last Saturday looking at the choosing of the final line-up. Today, the country's media is descending upon Heathrow airport in London for a (doubtless) frenzied press conference with Suzanne, Noel, Myleene, Danny and Kym - the final five. It has been an extraordinary media event, and one which is entering a whole new phase, with the rest of the series emulating the formula of MTV's does-what-it-says-on-the-tin, Making The Band. The show's success has even surprised ITV, which has been accused of under-ambition by scheduling at Saturday teatime. A peak-time, mid-week slot would almost certainly have guaranteed higher audience figures than Saturday early evening, but had the show bombed, it would have done so from a far greater height. ITV marketing bosses deny the charge, saying that Popstars has succeeded in its aim of delivering a strong audience into the key Saturday-night schedule. But John Hardie, director of marketing at the ITV network, concedes that from the first rushes of the auditions, ITV knew it had a hit. "When you saw the raw footage of the auditions and people being rejected or accepted, you realised that this was something incredibly powerful and dramatic. We decided that we would go massive on it." As well they might. In New Zealand, where the format originated, Popstars was big, but once it crossed the Tasman Sea, it was huge. In 2000, it was one of Australia's biggest television shows and the band the show created, Bardot, went on to land a number one single and a number one album. The girl band - not to be confused with Bardo, the 1982 British Eurovision entry - have since embarked on national and Asia-wide tours, and their song, Higher Than Heaven, was used as the theme tune for Olympics coverage on Australian television. Realising that young viewers often dictate household viewing habits and that ITV wasn't courting the youth market as successfully as Channel 4 or BBC2 (its attempts at youth programming can resemble a drunken uncle dancing at a wedding reception), the network threw huge money at it. The "Nigel, pick me" posters became talking points themselves, as did the trailers which littered ITV for weeks before transmission. The strategy worked. But what does the band have to look forward to? After months of auditions, rehearsals and recording - and today's press conference - the real work starts now. While helped along by the fact they feature in what is essentially a twice-weekly hour-long advert for themselves and their wares, the band have, as the song says, many rivers to cross. For every S Club 7, there is a 911, so they should bear in mind the wise words of Karen Carpenter: "We've only just begun." And whether anybody is actually drinking the juice that sponsors the show is anyone's guess. After watching Popstars, it's not a soft drink you need, it's a good stiff brandy.  Popstars, tonight, 11.30pm, ITV

fields.headline: A rumble in the jungle
fields.trailText: Your review of Congo (A walk on the wild side, January 31) doesn't mention the most obvious thing about the first programme - that much of it was filmed outside the country known as the Congo.
fields.body:
In her review of the new BBC2 series Congo (A walk on the wild side, January 31), Nancy Banks-Smith was led to understand that Colonel Gore-Browne built his estate in the Congo jungle, and that his daughter and son-in-law, the Harveys, were murdered there.

I knew Gore-Browne and stayed with him at his estate. This was a very long way from the Congo jungle. It was in Zambia, then Northern Rhodesia. He had no connections with the Congo. He was an honoured Zambian citizen, and on his death had a state funeral there.

There was no "jungle" at Shiwa, and Lorna, his daughter, was not murdered there, but hundreds of miles away in Zambia.
Barbara Hall
London

 Your review of Congo doesn't mention the most obvious thing about the first programme - that much of it was filmed outside the country known as the Congo. Shiwa Ngandu, for example is in Zambia. Other parts were filmed in Gabon and Angola, and by the looks of it, in Tanzania.

I suspect that very little filming actually occurred in the Congo - not surprising as there is no government in much of the area and a civil war.
George Matthews
Wimborne, Dorset

fields.headline: Screen grabs
fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Coming to a box near you
fields.body:
Scottish readers will tonight see the first episode of the excellent new BBC1 Adrian Mole adaptation (shown elsewhere last Friday). The production saw a surreal moment during filming, according to Stephen Mangan, who plays Adrian. He was in a costume warehouse being fitted when he heard the voice of Michael Caine filtering through from the next cubicle. "I toyed with the idea of going next door and showing him my 'hilarious' impressions of him ('spears at me', 'bloody doors off', etc)," he says, "but sensibly decided against it at the last moment."

The BBC is many things. Including, it would seem, the last bastion of lank-haired Hippiedom. At least that's the suspicion aroused by February 13's edition of Blood On The Carpet, the series celebrating great corporate fiascos. The show compares the original Woodstock festival with its disastrous 1999 namesake (scene of fights, riots and all-round bad vibes). The makers get a little carried away, claiming the second Woodstock outing marked the "death of the hippie dream". Were the last three decades just, like, a bad trip, man?

Also starting on the Beeb later this month, a series on the inexorable rise of Britain's middle classes. Starting at the turn of the last century, when only one in five could lay claim to the moniker, the programme follows its "rise and sprawl" up to the present day, when the middle classes now make up three quarters of the nation. It could be one of the landmark series of the year - or the most expensive piece of navel gazing in history.
