fields.headline: Iannis Xenakis
fields.standfirst: Composer who brought a passion for maths to his music
fields.trailText: Composer who brought a passion for maths to his music.
fields.body:
Listening to the music of Iannis Xenakis, who has died aged 78, is like being flung back into some fierce atavistic world before culture existed.

The passion in a work such as Eonta is not altogether human - it has the impersonal quality of a natural force, untrammelled by conventions of language or style. Such magnificently innocent music is bound to be out of place in our oblique, knowing age, so obsessed with its past, so fastidiously ironic, so concerned, in its art, to layer ambiguity upon ambiguity. That Xenakis could have denied this pervasive cultural trend for 40 years is an amazing feat. Perhaps only someone who had no need of the western tradition, someone whose roots lay elsewhere, could have done it.

Xenakis's spiritual roots lay in Ancient Greece, his musical ones in Greek orthodox chant; in fact he once described himself as "an Ancient Greek living in the 20th century." The solitariness that implies seemed to be written into his fate - the name Xenakis actually means "little stranger" in Greek. And a stranger is indeed what he remained throughout his life - literally so, in that from 1947 he lived as a political refugee in France. He fled there from Greece, where he had been sentenced to death in absentia for joining the fight against British troops sent to preserve the country from encroaching communism.

Xenakis was born in Romania and at the age of 10 was taken to Greece by his wealthy Greek parents. He later took an engineering degree at Athens Polytechnic. During the second world war he joined the resistance against the German occupation, losing part of the left side of his face, including his left eye, in a street battle.

After the war he fled to Paris where the great designer Le Corbusier got to hear about this formidably gifted young refugee with a passion for, and a sophisticated understanding of, engineering and mathematics, and took him on as an assistant. Xenakis soon found himself involved in some of the master's most important projects, including the convent at la Tourette and the Philips pavilion for the 1958 World's Fair in Brussels.

It must have seemed as if architecture had claimed him. But all through the late 40s and 50s Xenakis was nursing an ambition to combine his mathematical passions with his musical one. Not until the mid-50s did he discover convincing ways of doing this. One was to dispose sounds in "clouds of points", crepitating bursts of pizzicato strings and wind: mass events whose detail is random but whose overall shape can be grasped by the ear.

The effect is beguiling and suggestive, like raindrops or migrating birds. Another way was to create "curved spaces" in sound, analogous to the curved surfaces of a building such as the Philips pavilion: swarms of "glissandi" - pitches moving up and down by "sliding" (like an air raid siren) and moving in many directions at once.

It's now a familiar part of the modernist composer's arsenal, but in 1955, when Xenakis's opus 1 Metastasis for orchestra was premiered, it must have seemed shocking. As must his Concerto PH, a piece he composed for the Brussels Fair using amplified burning charcoal as his single sound source. By this time Xenakis was 32 and had lost "much time and also much hope." But through the 60s he laboured to bring more and more mathematical tools into music.

Xenakis would have been the first to admit that not all these experiments worked. As the decades passed he relied less and less on calculation and more on intuition, bringing human empathy to his work. But although the rigour may have been relaxed, the passion and strangeness of the music intensified. Through the 1980s and until his death he continued to produce four or five pieces a year, in all sizes and in all media, including Bohor, where he used the sounds of both jingling jewellery and freight cars coupling; the percussion ensemble The Pleiades, and several vast multi-media works involving lights and music created for outdoor sites such as Persepolis.

In between, he found time to direct a research institute in Paris, and to write a formidably difficult book called Formalised Music. As he became older, honours came to him from all round the world including France's Academie des Beaux Arts (1984); Italy's Turin Critics Prize (1990); and Japan's Kyoto Prize (1997), but some how he never quite became part of the contemporary music establishment. This softly-spoken and exceptionally courteous man was wrapped in an essential solitude.

In some ways his lack of formal musical training was a strength, freeing him from the constraints of good taste and craftsmanship and setting him apart from such an eminently tasteful modernist as Boulez, who once summed up Xenakis thus: "Fantastic brain - absolutely no ear." But his isolation imposed an obligation to be entirely self-created, musically speaking.

There's no doubt Xenakis succeeded in creating a cohesive and instantly recognisable musical world of his own; more debatable is the size and scope of that world. If in many of his pieces - Eonta, Tetrus, Ais - too much seems to have been sacrificed in order to return to a kind of primal innocence, the price seems worth paying; they are certainly among his best and show the enduring worth of Xenakis's improbable and heroic enterprise, one often dedicated to political prisoners and "the thousands of the forgotten".

He is survived by his wife Francoise and daughter Mahi.

 Iannis Xenakis, composer and architect, born May 29 1922; died February 4 2001

webTitle: Leader: why left-handed people die younger

fields.headline: Lefties die young
fields.standfirst: Rightists may have a hand in sinister cull
fields.trailText: A left-handed academic from North Dakota has revealed that left-handers tend to die younger than right-handers. Is the higher death rate of lefties attributable to their so-called cack-handedness? Or to the discrimination they suffer?
fields.body:
One by one the world's deepest secrets yield to researchers. A left-handed academic from North Dakota has revealed that left-handers tend to die younger than right-handers. The "generally" right-handed population, he asserts, lasts on average to 68.7 years old. The generally left-handed live to just 65. Perplexingly, though, "extremely" left-handed people have an average death age of 67.4. And the ambidextrous fare best of all: their average age of death is just short of 70.

Since this confirms earlier research in California, it can probably now be added with some confidence to the stock of human knowledge. Except that it leaves many questions unanswered. Is the higher death rate of lefties attributable to their so-called cack-handedness? Or to the discrimination they suffer when classed as cack-handed - or as "sinister", "maladroit" or "lacking dexterity?" The professor rather limply suggests that they must just be "wired slightly differently." Would that also explain why, according to left-hander websites, Gerald Ford, Ronald Reagan, George Bush the elder and Bill Clinton were all south-paws - not to mention Ross Perot? No, as with all the best research, there is only one safe conclusion to be drawn from these findings. We need more research.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Book Of The Week | Mapping The Town | Nature
fields.body:
It sounds pretty tame today, but a black dancer dolled up in nothing but flamingo feathers brought Paris to a juddering halt in 1925. It was American cabaret artist Josephine Baker, letting loose her famous danse sauvage in La Revue Nègre. She went one better a few weeks later, dancing topless with a skirt fashioned from bananas. Josette Simon recalls the heady decadence of the period when she reads Ean Wood's biography of the dancer as Book Of The Week (9.45am, Radio 4).

The 1801 census recorded Cardiff's population as 1,870 men, women and children. Two generations later the amount of coal passing through its docks had turned this one-time Roman fort into the world's largest port. As Julian Richards discovers in a new series of Mapping The Town (11.0am, Radio 4), successive Marquesses of Bute spotted the opportunity and, in the wistful words of one local historian, turned the Severn Estuary into the Persian Gulf of its day.

Mark Carwardine turns to new technology in an effort to discover how huge flocks of starlings manage their complex aerobatics before settling down for the night. In Nature (9.0pm, Radio 4) he talks to a computer modeller who thinks he's found the answer. But that still leaves many uncertainties about why birds flock at all. White-fronted geese will take turns to act as sentries but those on the outside get less to eat. What's in it for them?

webTitle: Interview: David Johansen of  the New York Dolls

fields.headline: 'My mind is as blank as fresh snow'
fields.standfirst: David Johansen has outlived three other members of the New York Dolls. He tells  John Aizlewood about life without punk, drugs and booze
fields.trailText: David Johansen has outlived three other members of the New York Dolls. He tells John Aizlewood about life without punk, drugs and booze
fields.body:
From a distance, with his full beard, his floppy hair and his milk-bottle spectacles, David Johansen resembles one of Michael Bentine's Potties, rather than someone who changed the face of modern music.

Closer in, the 51-year-old Staten Islander's face is a patchwork of lines, more ram-raided than lived-in. Yet when he unleashes his Jaggeresque grin, he is once more the raffish whippersnapper who fronted the New York Dolls, the band that invented punk.

Then there is his voice. A life time of chain-smoking and a love of the grandiloquent has deepened it to part drawl, part stomach rumble. On this rainy afternoon he sips tea at the bar of his hotel overlooking Hyde Park. "Do you know," he says, "I haven't got a thing on my mind. It's as blank as a fresh coating of snow. People always ask how I'm feeling. I say, 'OK', but I haven't really thought about it."

In the late 1960s, the insurance salesman's son made his way to Manhattan, where he has lived ever since - for the past 15 years with his second wife, photographer Kate Simon. By 1972 he had dabbled in acting and sung in local bands, before being invited to join Actress, which mutated into the New York Dolls.

"The East Village was a hotbed of revolution - there were so many radical fringes," says Johansen. "It was the dawn of feminism, of macro- biotics, of gay liberation; we took all those elements and put them into music. Everything was about liberation and how far you could go with it." New York had never seen anything like the Dolls. They dressed beyond mere gender, they covered songs by Sonny Boy Williamson and Otis Redding, they were briefly managed by Malcolm McLaren, and they drank and drugged their way to oblivion.

"Before us," growls Johansen, "rock stars were in gilded cages and untouchable. I brought it down to the street: if I can do this, you can do this."

The New York Dolls broke up in 1975 after two albums. Johansen fronted a live version of the band for another two years, then stumbled along as a solo performer until 1984. He lived close to an Irish bar called Tramps and spent so much time there that he thought he ought to make some money from it. So he invented a pompadoured alter ego, Buster Poindexter, and played on the quiet Monday evenings. Before long Poindexter was a local hero.

"At that time I was in a van 300 nights a year travelling back and forth across the States, sucking a bottle of gin opening for heavy metal acts in hockey rinks," he says. "Soon, doing Poindexter weekly, I was making as much as I was on the road officiating at what I called Hitler Youth rallies. What was I doing it for? When I was Poindexter, I could say whatever I wanted. As lead-ins to songs, I extrapolated on odd scenarios, saying I went to a party with Noel Coward and [the reggae singer] Eek A Mouse. I started getting an audience who'd read a book."

Actor Bill Murray was a fan ("He was fascinated by these stories - he's a bit demented himself") and invited Johansen to resurrect his dormant thespian career in Scrooged. A role in Married to the Mob and a host of television parts followed. "I did Let It Ride with Richard Dreyfus; it was great because we were in Miami for the whole winter, but by the last week of the filming even the top actors were going, 'I'll never work again.' I was thinking, 'I can't wait to get out of here because I've got a gig.' Music is my love and to me acting is more mercenary. I don't pound the pavements for roles: if it happens, it happens. I hate that auditioning thing."

Poindexter was not a clean-living creation. A decade ago, he hosted a TV series in Los Angeles and the lifestyle took its toll. "You know when you read that someone has to leave a show or a tour because they had 'nervous exhaustion'? Well, I had one of those and discovered that I was quite close to death. I always assumed that my lifestyle was going to take me at an early age, but when it was actually occurring I was, 'Not yet!' I pulled back." He claims not to have touched alcohol or hard drugs since. Poindexter paid the bills and painting filled the hole left by drugs and drink. Last year, in Woodstock, Johansen had his first exhibition.

Dylan wanted to bat for this but I told him not to make me his cause celebre for the time being. Literally the next day, the Chesky label called, asking if I could make a record that week because they had studio time. We recorded it in a church smelling of dried old wood and incense. Once again, Johansen has become a standard-bearer of traditional American music. "In New York they think of me as somebody who is doing something that will happen in five years, but everybody likes this record. A lot of stuff I do is fairly stubborn, and that's a character defect of mine, but I'm using a universal language in this particular area of my creativity."

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: O brother, where art thou?
fields.trailText: Radio 3's Sunday Play
fields.body:
You have to wonder what John Ford was thinking when he called his sunny 17th-century tale of incest and murder most foul 'Tis Pity She's A Whore. Why not a pity, John, or, for consistency's sake, Tis Pity She's Whore? And why not just cut to the chase and call it 'Tis Pity She's My Sister, which is really the nub of the matter?

Things syntactical were soon forgotten, however, in a very fine adaptation of the Young Vic's production of the play for Radio 3's Sunday Play slot. Jude Law (now there's a chap who doesn't have a good face for radio) starred as Giovanni, the bookish young student who falls in love with his sister Annabella, played by Eve Best. When he says "Sister, I would be private with you", he doesn't just mean that the servant should close the door on her way out.

What this production managed to bring out so well was the play's moral complexity, a dimension often overlooked because of the blood-bath drama at the end when Giovanni cuts his sister's heart out mid-kiss (not a metaphor - he scoops it out with his knife). She calls him "unkind", which shows admirable restraint under the circumstances.

Law and Best (now there's the name of a private detective agency if ever I heard one) played the lovers sweetly and gently, a world of corruption and vice all around them. As suitors presented themselves to Annabella, ranging from the twerpy Bergetto (he loves her "as much as parmesan cheese", which is a big deal in Parma) to the duplicitous rotter Soranzo, it was hard not to see a kind of purity in the doomed lovers' affections.

That's down to Ford's skill as a writer within the sensationalist genre of revenge tragedy, and to David Lan's subtle production, all silky sound effects: footsteps on paving stones; illicit kisses between the siblings; the crumpling of bedsheets. These moments were contrasted with the double-dealings of Soranzo, the authority of the church ("Death waits on thy lust", is how Giovanni's confessor, the Friar, reacts in the first scene), and the high hopes of the unknowing father. "I would not for my wealth my daughter's love should cause the spilling of one drop of blood," he says, not knowing that gallons of the stuff will soon flow in the last 10 minutes. Those minutes were more gory, in sound only, than in any production of the play I've seen, especially the slurpy ripping out of the heart.

As terribly intimate as the forbidden love it revealed, this was wonderful radio. It proved that to hear the life drain from a love that the siblings "would not change for Elysium", and to feel the blood and guts of a visceral drama such as Ford's, can sometimes be better than seeing it.

webTitle: How I learned to love the bomb

fields.headline: How I learned to love the bomb
fields.trailText: Correspondent | Jim Davidson's Generation Game | Love In A Cold Climate | Bloody Foreigners
fields.body:
Five hundred miles south of Moscow, there is a town which doesn't appear on any map. It is home to 20,000 people and is Russia's most important strategic nuclear missile base. The military men there sing like performers in a Mel Brooks musical, drink vodka on picnics and live in a luxury akin to a Blackpool guesthouse. As Correspondent (BBC2, Saturday) revealed, this isn't even the half of it. The missileers - or rocketchiki - who inhabit the town with their families are each responsible for an arsenal roughly equivalent to the UK's entire nuclear capability. They get paid $60 a month. Sometimes, on their days off, they moonlight as cab drivers. This is the bad news. The good news is that they don't let women become missileers in Russia. "They are programmed to preserve peace", explained a pre-pubescent male rocketchiki. "Men are more programmed for destruction and war."

The ladies are allowed to be support staff, "in communications". Presumably that means they answer the phones (though not the big red one, obviously). Well, thank goodness for that. We wouldn't want any peaceful ladies with their fingers poised on the big red buttons now, would we? Not when we can have spotty adolescents with destruction on their minds. Praise the Lord and pass the ammunition.

Not that they accept any old (or young) bloke as missileers. They have to undergo psychological tests. Tatiana the Psychologist (evidently a permitted lady's job) examines their biorhythms and penchants for colour. "On the basis of people's attitudes to colour, one can determine their emotional state and qualities", she explained. You can also make a guess at what shade of eyeshadow suits them.

All of this is enough to get you digging that bunker in the back garden or tuning into Jim Davidson's Generation Game (BBC1, Saturday). Until you realise that the Generation Game is a lot more clear and present and disturbing than the threat of an errant missile blowing up London. It's amazing such low-rent shows still manage to attract contestants when Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? offers ginormous prizes for relatively little trouble. And they write the cheques so very neatly. It is, one supposes, horses for courses. Or, more accurately, idiots for apt humiliation.

Love In A Cold Climate (BBC1, Sunday) was chockful of ghastly idiots. While prettily period and consummately Costume Drama, it was hard to get involved in this adaptation of Nancy Mitford's novels. Characters saying things like, "When you go to London, you'll be too busy to think about badgers," didn't help matters, despite the valiant efforts of a formidable cast, including an understated Celia Imrie, a mavenish Sheila Gish, and the excellent Alan Bates, who played the disagreeable Lord Alconleigh like a labrador with irritable bowel syndrome. Fey, frivolous and whimsical it may be, but the main problem with Love In A Cold Climate is that its milieu, as represented in costume drama, has been so parodied. It takes too much effort to regard it seriously: I kept expecting French and Saunders to pop up from behind a bush asking after Lady Fortington-Smythe. That there were Twitterers (first, second and third, no less) in the cast list says it all about this adaptation. Dishwater dull with a couple of silver spoons.

Omid Djalili's Bloody Foreigners (Channel 4, Sunday) is the kind of documentary that those who viciously carp on about asylum seekers should be dragged away from their Oswald Moseley shrines and forced to watch. Travelling from Hull to Dover, Djalili's exploration of life for asylum seekers was uncompromising, emotional and powerful stuff. Aside from the slightly dubious Let's Pretend To Be An Asylum Seeker ploy - which still revealed stark and unpleasant truths about their plight - this was a mature, thoughtful programme. By detailing complaints that Turkish refugees are "all perverts", then showing pictures of a delightful Hull resident flashing her breasts, Bloody Foreigners exposed Britain's institutionalised, ingrained racism and hypocrisy, for which we are all responsible. (It's not as if Britain was built on the bones of people in the developing world, or that we sold weapons to dictators, or are happy buying goods made in the third world now, is it?) It was sickening and shameful and should be compulsory viewing.

fields.headline: TV picks of the day
fields.trailText: Scarlet Empress | Live Skiing: The World Championships | Bounty Hunters
fields.byline: Paul Howlett, Simon Burnton and Camilla Redmond
fields.body:
Films

Scarlet Empress (Josef Von Sternberg, 1934) 10.45am, Carlton Cinema Dietrich in one of her classic roles, as the young Catherine the Great in Von Sternberg's witty, captivating chapter of Russian history. The German princess, exiled to Moscow to marry mad Grand Duke Peter, organises a coup and ascends the throne. Intrigue, adventure, and Marlene Dietrich imperious in Russian uniform.

1492: The Conquest Of Paradise (Ridley Scott, 1992) 2.30pm, Studio Scott's account of Columbus's voyage across the "sea of darkness" to the New World does full justice to the epic enterprise: an apparently madcap scheme issuing from the pragmatism of the Spanish court, where Sigourney Weaver's Queen Isabella holds sway. With its battle scenes of dreamlike savagery it treats the distant past with the style and energy of Scott's all-conquering Gladiator.

Mrs Dalloway (Marleen Gorris, 1997) 3.35am, Sky Premier Vanessa Redgrave's Clarissa Dalloway, radiant politician's wife, is preparing for one of her famous parties, but wandering in reveries of youthful romance. In flashback, Natascha McElhone, as her younger self, is wooed by Peter (Alan Cox); and coming to the party is the mature, still ardent Peter (Michael Kitchen). Eileen Atkins' adaptation of Virginia Woolf's novel, in an elegantly evoked 20s London, is wistful and touching.

The Shooting (Monte Hellman, 1967) 4.35am, FilmFour One of two extraordinary existential westerns created by Hellman and Jack Nicholson during a seven-week sojourn in the Utah desert, courtesy of $150,000 funding from their mentor Roger Corman. Millie Perkins sets a little band - bounty hunter Warren Oates, cowboy Will Hutchins and gunslinger Nicholson - on the trail of an unidentified man. It's a quest without reason in a brutal, near silent world.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Skiing: The World Championships British Eurosport The second and final week of the World Championships starts with the men's combined title, decided over three races spread across the day. The competition hasn't disappointed so far, with fans being treated to exactly what they want: falls, surprises and home wins. America's Daron Rahlves has been the eyebrow-raiser so far, but a win today may be beyond him.
Simon Burnton

History

Bounty Hunters 8pm, History Channel Starting with the modern-day USA's practice of paying rewards for the recapture of suspected felons who skip bail, this documentary delves into the origins of the bail system. Scenes stretching all the way back to medieval England are enthusiastically reconstructed, moving on to slave-trade America where a recaptured serf could be worth up to $450. The brutality and greed of the professional manhunters (at a time when a weekly wage was just a few dollars) are disapprovingly described. And are today's bounty hunters so far removed from their predecessors?
Camilla Redmond

webTitle: Take five: the daily news quiz

fields.headline: Take five: the daily news quiz
fields.trailText: Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.com).
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.com).

A1 American rap artist Eminem starts his controversial British tour in Manchester on Thursday. His daughter is called

(a) Kayley (b) Keeley

(c) Hayley (d) Helen

A2 Which university banned Eminem's music from the student radio station last week?

(a) Salford (b) Southampton

(c) Sheffield (d) Sunderland

A3 Which British female singer contributed to Eminem's hit single Stan?

(a) Dido (b) Dino

(c) Dado (d) Dada

A4 Eminem has an ongoing rivalry with which rap act?

(a) Snoop Doggy Dogg (b) Dr Dre

(c) Insane Clown Posse (d) Vanilla Ice

A5 In which year were the sugar-coated chocolates M&Ms first sold?

(a) 1941 (b) 1952

(c) 1964 (d) 1978

Entries must reach Take Five, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by Wednesday February 14. The winner will be notified by February 23. One entry per person. No purchase necessary.

The daily online news quiz can be found at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/quiz

fields.headline: Whistling in the dark
fields.standfirst: Thorpe Hamlet, Norwich
fields.trailText: Thorpe Hamlet, Norwich
fields.body:
Cold sunlight crashed right through the canopy and cast a latticework of shadow which was every bit as stark as the woodland above. But at least the brightness triggered a sense of release in the birds, and you could hear the high see-saw notes of great and coal tits mingled with the song of robin, nuthatch and stock dove. Yet there were no melodious soloists, like a thrush for example, to give the sounds the structure or the verve of a true dawn chorus. It was more like the discordant racket that's produced by an orchestra as it tunes up for the concert.

And any hint of spring it might have contained was instantly contradicted by the appearance of the wood itself. Last year's foliage from the oaks and sycamores covered the ground, and during the winter these dead leaves have rotted down to assume an even deeper sense of decay. They now form a continuous dank mat, and the last downpour cratered it with pock marks. Any individual leaves left lying above the mulch have been eaten away to a mere skeleton of veins that crumbles at the first touch.

At the centre of the wood I came across an old lime that had been knocked down by winter storms. The sheer force of the fall had ripped out the main roots and had lifted up what amounted to a bomb crater's worth of soil onto its side. The disc of earth measures at least three metres across and it contains sufficient nutrients to allow the prostrate tree to throw out hundreds and hundreds of tall thin suckers. All of this regrowth is now tipped with green nibs that have the bitter taste and the sharp scent of sap and new life.

fields.headline: Gentleman of Verona
fields.standfirst: Acclaimed novelist  Tim Parks thought he was a Man United fan for life - until he found himself shouting obscenities from the terraces of a struggling Italian club. In an introduction to his new column in G2, he describes the birth of an obsession
fields.trailText: Acclaimed novelist  Tim Parks thought he was a Man United fan for life - until he found himself shouting obscenities from the terraces of a struggling Italian club. In an introduction to his new column in G2, he describes the birth of an obsession
fields.body:
Hellas Verona, vinci per noi! " I still remember my amazement when I first heard myself shouting those words. "Hellas Verona, win for us!" It's a kind of liturgy. Next you yell: " Hellas Verona, segni per noi! " I yell it with all my heart. Self-control ebbs away. "Hellas Verona, score for us!" Then the Curva Sud, the end of the stadium where the hardcore fans hang out, bursts into the triumphal march from Verdi's Aida. Only we sing: " Alè, forza Verona alè, forza gialloblù, gialloblù, gialloblù! " Because the team plays in blue and yellow. The moment the song breaks up, ten thousand arms are raised: " Napoli, Napoli, vaffanculo. " Fuck off, Napoli. The ritual insult is absolutely necessary. " Roma vaffanculo, Vicenza vaffanculo, Juventus vaffanculo ": it's our pre-match warm-up.

You sit down exhausted, pleased with yourself and trembling with nerves. There are 90 nail-biting minutes ahead, played as ever on the brink of the relegation zone. Serie A, where we are now, is paradiso , Serie B is purgatorio , Serie C is the inferno. The Italians have a way of mixing sport, bureaucracy and metaphysics. One Sunday at half-time, the guy beside me offers this word of wisdom: "There are three things a man fears in life: the horns [meaning your wife has betrayed you], death and relegation." He sighs: "The first two are inevitable but with the third you've got a chance." Have we really got a chance against Naples? They've just won three in a row. We've lost two and drawn one. " Hellas Verona, vinci per noi!"

The team was formed almost a century ago in Verona's poshest school, the Liceo Classico Maffei. The game was still new to this part of the world. Preparing for their first match, the players didn't know what to call themselves. Then the Greek teacher, with an extraordinary sense of what football was to become - at least in Italy - suggested the name Hellas, the Greek word for patria , homeland, country. Your team becomes the expression of the community you belong to, the group that gives you your identity. And in Italy this homeland can only be local. "Did you watch the national team last night?" I ask a sports journalist. "No," he replies, and explains, "I'm a Brescia supporter."

So for the boys in the Curva Sud, their hellas is Verona: " Solo contro tutti, " they shout. Alone against the world. And today, when the Napoli players come out on to the pitch in the freezing cold that's flowing down from the Alps, everybody puts on a small white mask, the kind dentists use, to protect against the presumed smell of unwashed Neapolitans. With fantastic bad taste, some fan club has provided them. It's a gesture of isolation, separation. This is the territory of the secessionist Lega Nord.

But can this ever be my team, my home? The first times I sat in the Verona's Bentegodi stadium, I felt cold, indifferent. I was born in Manchester. I watched my first games at Old Trafford. I fell under the spell of the Stretford End. The Italian word for enchantment is incanto , which literally means "into song". You fall into the song, or chant, of the fans. It's an old story. Perhaps the best and briefest account I've ever read was sent to me by email the day after I first published an article on Hellas Verona's website (www.hellasverona.it). It came from one of those unlucky fans who live not where they love: "My name is Eugenio, I'm from Asti, Piedmont, and my family is from Tuscany. One day, when I was small, they took me to see Juventus-Verona. I don't remember anything about the game. I spent the whole time watching the Brigate Gialloblù [the hardcore always call themselves brigate , brigades]. They sent shivers up my spine. That night I decided that I would become one of them."

Parents should definitely think twice when they choose which is to be their children's first football game. Enchanted by Hellas Verona, Eugenio has spent a fortune in petrol and train tickets over the past 20 years. " Alè forza Verona, alè " may not sound much like the song the sirens sung, but the effect seems to be the same. "Yesterday I did a blood test," someone wrote to the club's website chatline, "and I'm Hellas positive for ever."

So how can you change allegiance, or infection? How did I find myself one Sunday afternoon chanting, " Hellas Verona, vinci per noi "? One of the least funny moments in Ali G's first video comes when he asks Major General Perkins whether a soldier never thinks of changing sides. "Like I've always been with Man U," Ali says, "but when I sees they aren't going to do the double, I goes over to the Arsenal." This simply doesn't work. There have probably been more soldiers who have changed sides this century than football fans.

Maybe the example Ali should have used was girlfriends or wives. "I sees me Julie in't lookin' fit so I finds meself a new bitch." Everybody knows how to split up and divorce. It was you who chose your wife, wasn't it, so why shouldn't you change her when she loses her charm? No one will be surprised. But switching from Man U to Arsenal would be a mutation of quite a different order. "The players can come and go," sings the Curva Sud, "the president and the trainer, but we will always be here, rain or shine, Brigate, Brigate Gialloblù."

It was a game against Juventus that finally shifted something in my psyche. I'd been in Italy about 12 years by then (20 now). For a couple of seasons I had been a desultory spectator at the Bentegodi. I had the excuse of my son, Michele, who was now just about old enough to sit through a game. Anyhow, the ground was unusually full that day, and when Juventus scored I realised why. The Curva Nord, the "guest area", exploded with joy. That was to be expected. These people had bought their tickets in Turin. But then large areas of the more expensive stands were on their feet too, cheering and waving their black and white scarves. These people must be Veronese, born and bred. Yet they were supporting Juventus, a team synonymous with money and power - a team, in short, like Man U.

The Curva Sud rose as one man, beside themselves with rage, hurling their bodies against the perimeter fences. " Bastardi! " they shrieked. " Traditori! " My son too, in his shrill voice, was shouting, " Bastardi! " He meant it. Verona is a small club, it needs all the help it can get. "We know your names!" the fans began to chant. "We have your addresses!"

Then, caught up in the intensity of the emotions, I made a weird association. I have their addresses too, I thought. They are the addresses of all those well-to-do families whose children I gave English lessons to when I first arrived in Verona, families who paid late, cancelled at the last minute, asked if you had a proper hanger for their fur coats, departed without warning for Cortina or Buenos Aires and, in general, lived lives of enviable and obtuse complacency. People like that, I told myself, can't bring themselves to support a team that might go into Serie B, so they whore after the interminable success of the wealthy giants.

It was a ridiculous association, of course. There is no reason to suppose that there is any relationship between the kind of families who hire an English teacher as a fashion accessory and people so insecure that they need to support a big team far away, or who merely, as tiny children, got taken to their first game in the wrong town. But, however absurd, the thought served to forge a sick link between an old personal resentment and the fortunes of Hellas Verona. In a moment I was on my feet beside my son, shouting, " Juve, Juve, vaffanculo. " Very soon I would stop bothering to tune into the World Service to see what United were up to. Verona had become my destiny.

Today's game begins. Napoli are sharp and eager. They have the look of the team who know they can win. In the Curva Nord opposite us, their fans unfurl a banner that says: "Veronese, laboratory mice." No one is quite sure what this is supposed to mean. The Veronese respond with an enthusiastic rendering of " Brucia il meridione " - "Burn the south" - this despite the fact that half of our players are southerners and quite probably many of those singing.

By half-time, with the energy of desperation, Verona have taken over the game. On a sodden pitch, Napoli resort to the catenaccio , eight men in the box. They'll be happy with a draw. Their goalkeeper saves once, twice, three times. But football is par excellence the sport of those who thirst for injustice. Twelve minutes from time, just as Verona's pressure has reached its climax, Napoli hazard a counterattack. A shot from 30 yards curls inside the top corner. One-nil. "Serie B, Serie B, Serie B," shriek the Neapolitans.

How many times have I asked myself whether I haven't invested too much emotion in this sport? What gloom! I can't believe it. The circus of substitutions and time-wasting fouls begins. Betrayal, death, relegation. Until, to everybody's amazement, when all seems over, in a goalmouth scramble, Verona equalise. And in the second minute of injury time, they snatch the winner. Total euphoria. One Veronese player (Sicilian) is sent off for throwing his shirt in the air, another (Romanian) for punching an opponent. Meantime I and my son tumble over in a vast group embrace. " Gialloblù, gialloblù, gialloblù!" Never do I feel more at home in Italy than at the Stadio Bentegodi.

 Tim Parks' monthly column, following the fortunes of Hellas Verona FC, begins in G2 next Tuesday. His latest book, Destiny, is published by Vintage Press, price £6.99.

fields.headline: No 1812 Bernard Rayner
fields.trailText: Rayner? Any relation to Clare? No, this is Mr Bernard Rayner, Trafalgar Square's last pigeon feed seller.
fields.body:
Rayner? Any relation to Clare? No, this is Mr Bernard Rayner, Trafalgar Square's last pigeon feed seller.

Well, they both flog things for birds. Fair point. But so far as I know they've never even met.

Worth a shot though, eh? So anyway, what's up with the bird man? It looks as though Mr Rayner is about to be out of a job.

Migration? No.

Can't get the corn nowadays? That's not it either.

Tuppence a bag not providing him with an ample pension? No. And lawks-a-mercy, guvnor, that'll be 30 pence a tub nowadays.

So the pigeons would rather nip to Starbucks for a caramel Frappuccino? No. Well, maybe. But actually it's because London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, loathes pigeons. He says they are "rats with wings" and he has decided to strip Mr Rayner of his licence to sell bird seed, because they disgust him so very much.

But how can he? Pigeons are so sweet and round and cooey. They're like little dapper gents running around in grey overcoats. They're so very feathery and plump and ooh, so cute . . . That's as may be - although frankly, I'm not entirely sure about the overcoats thing - but pigeons can cause an allergic reaction in the lungs, known as pigeon fancier's lung.

Look, I never said I fancied them. I just said they were cute. No, you divot, the disease is called 'pigeon fancier's lung' because it is a common complaint among those who keep pigeons. But they can also spread TB, flu, Lyme disease and encephalitis.

Can't we all. And then there's the fact that it costs £100,000 a year to clean around a tonne of pigeon droppings from Nelson's column and the vicinity.

And how much will it take to get rid of Ken Livingstone from Nelson's column and the vicinity? You've got him for three years yet, baby.

webTitle: Biomedica in gene pact with academics

fields.headline: Biomedica in gene pact with academics
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Drug development company Oxford Biomedica is to get exclusive access to a gene associated with nerve repair under an agreement with a team of scientists at King's College London.
fields.body:
Drug development company Oxford Biomedica is to get exclusive access to a gene associated with nerve repair under an agreement with a team of scientists at King's College London.

The company believes the gene could be crucial in developing treatment for spinal injuries and for nerve damage in diseases such as diabetes.

The gene, known as RAR2, was identified by a team at King's College headed by Professor Malcolm Maden. The college has patent protection for the gene, which means it can decide who carries out research on it.

In a deal to be announced today, Oxford Biomedica is paying £180,000 to King's College for access to the gene. To help cement a long-term relationship, King's is investing £150,000 in Oxford Biomedica shares at 73p each.

Alan Kingsman, chief executive of Oxford Biomedica, said: "The combination of our technologies opens up some very exciting commercial opportunities and sits well with Biomedica's increasing activity in the field of neurological diseases."

Biomedica specialises in gene therapy - adding genes to the body to attack diseases. Its technology allows genes to be delivered to specific areas.

King's is one of a number of institutions that have obtained patents over genes - a controversial practice which critics say amounts to a claim of ownership over parts of the human body.

King's College will get royalties on any medicines launched by Biomedica using RAR2. The company has two products in clinical trials: MetXia, for breast and ovarian cancer, and TroVax, for colorectal cancer.

 NMT, the Scottish medical devices company, is to announce that its catheters will be manufactured by an Indian company, Eastern Medikit, for a three-year period.

fields.trailText: Judge whose landmark ruling allowed the defence to screen potential jurors for prejudice in the Kray trial.
fields.body:
By the time he retired as a Lord Justice of Appeal at the end of 1986, Lord Justice Lawton, who has died aged 89, was known throughout the profession - and probably by a good number of those who had appeared before him - as "Fred".

He was brought up in a penal environment, the son of a prison governor who had originally been a warder. When Lawton appeared to be academically bright, his father suggested that he consider the Bar as a profession. It was an amazingly bold step for a time when it was much more of an elitist society than it is today.

Lawton was educated at Battersea Grammar School and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge. There, he became involved in fascist politics, and in 1936 was adopted as the British Union of Fascists' candidate for Hammersmith North. The war intervened before any election, and that ended Lawton's association with the far right. He served in the war with the London Irish Rifles before being invalided out in 1941 following an accident in training.

Called to the Bar as a member of Inner Temple in 1935, he had been pupilled to JP Eddy, a man regarded as an excellent pleader but one who did no criminal work. He then had the fortune to join Lord Birkett's chambers where, little by little, he established a criminal practice. In his latter days as a junior, Lawton practised more in the civil courts but then found that, as a silk, he could make more money doing criminal cases. In his last years at the Bar most of his civil work was in defamation. He was highly thought of as a pupil-master, and those who passed through his hands included Margaret Thatcher.

He was appointed silk, something he believed he owed to Norman Birkett, in 1957, the year he became a member of the Bar Council, which he served for 14 years. From that year, until 1961, he was recorder of the city of Cambridge, and in 1968 he became deputy chairman of Cornwall quarter sessions, holding the post until it was abolished three years later. Cornwall was one of the few places where solicitors could appear at quarter sessions, and Lawton found the standard of advocacy of the senior partners of local firms perfectly adequate while noting that contested cases were often handled by the less experienced assistants. He advocated common training and that all who qualified should work as solicitors, for the first five to seven years of their practice, before deciding to join the Bar.

Lawton was appointed to the high court bench and assigned to the queen's bench division in 1961, and was presiding judge on the western circuit from 1970 to 1972.

During this time, his best-remembered criminal cases involved the Richardson gang from south London, and the second trial of the Kray brothers. (The first Kray trial, presided over by Justice Melford Stevenson, had ended with the convictions in 1969 for the murders of Jack "The Hat" McVitie and George Cornell by Reggie and Ronnie Kray respectively.) The second case involved the death of Frank Mitchell whom the Krays helped escape from Dartmoor prison. The prosecution alleged that they had ordered his murder

These were the days before the Contempt of Court Act of 1981 which allowed judges to blackout the reporting of trials for months on end. Lawton was faced with the problem that, after the first trial, certain newspapers had written profiles of the Krays in unflattering terms. He therefore allowed the defence to cross-examine potential jurors about what they had read and the likelihood of prejudice. This was almost unheard of in England. It was not something which he enjoyed or wished to repeat. The trials resulted in the acquittal of the Krays.

During the trial much had been heard about the lax control of Mitchell in Dartmoor. He had been tacitly allowed to visit public houses, and women had been provided for him. Lawton, as the son of a martinet governor, found the evidence difficult to accept.

In the civil field, Lawton is perhaps best remembered for the case, Dering v Uris, in which the writer, Leon Uris, was sued for defamation over allegations he made about the plaintiff's conduct in a concentration camp during the war. Because of Lawton's former political views, doubts were expressed in Israeli newspapers over his suitability to handle the trial. They were quickly dispelled.

Lawton was appointed a Lord Justice of Appeal in 1972, and almost immediately clashed with the director of public prosecutions (DPP) on the question of whether the first supergrass, the robber Bertie Smalls, should have been allowed to go free in return for the evidence he would give against his colleagues. Lawton thought he should not, regarding such a bargain as distasteful, but the House of Lords took a more Olympian view, saying it was really a matter for the DPP.

As a member of the criminal law revision committee, from 1959-86 and its chairman for the last nine years, he recommended the abolition of the right to silence. He was a member (1957-58) of the departmental committee on proceedings before examining justices and of the interdepartmental committee on the court of criminal appeal (1964-65).

After his retirement Lawton wrote regularly for and to the Times. He disliked the way more cases and parts thereof were being heard in camera, and the Juries Act which limited the ages between which jurors could sit. He believed that lengthy summings-up confused juries rather than helped them and regretted the loss of the peremptory challenge. He also appeared regularly as a judicial pundit on television programmes, including one arguing for the release of Myra Hindley.

A highly accomplished after dinner speaker and a talented mimic, Lawton was a substantially built man with a large fruity voice which belied his background. On his retirement he commented that if he had been a dog he would have been put down years earlier - he suffered from an arthritic hip in later life. Lord Lane, then the Lord Chief Justice, took a rather different line. "If Fred has ever made a mistake I have yet to come across it. He has in the words of the Collect for Whit Sunday 'a right judgement in all things'."

His wife Doreen, whom he married in 1937, died in 1979. They had two sons.

 Right Honourable Sir Frederick Horace Lawton, lawyer, born December 21 1911; died February 3 2001

fields.headline: Powell disputes abortion policy
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Not everyone in George Bush's cabinet agrees with the president's decision - one of his first on taking office - to end US funding of family planning agencies offering abortion services.
fields.body:
Not everyone in George Bush's cabinet agrees with the president's decision - one of his first on taking office - to end US funding of family planning agencies offering abortion services.

His secretary of state, Colin Powell, said yesterday that his personal views differed from White House policy.

When asked on ABC's This Week whether he supported the policy, he replied: "It is the policy.

"I have other views that are my personal views, but this is the policy of the government."

Unlike many Republicans, Mr Powell defends a woman's right to choose an abortion.

In response to Mr Bush's ruling, Britain and its EU partners are poised to fill some of the gap.

This year's funding is unaffected, but the UN Population Fund and the International Planned Parenthood Federation are likely to suffer badly later on, as will many other groups.

About 80,000 women die annually from unsafe abortions. EU sources said the European Commission, the world's biggest overseas aid donor, could not provide core funding but it could support individual projects.

Clare Short, the international development secretary, is due to discuss the matter with the EU commissioner for development, Poul Nielson, in London this week.

Ms Short wants to avoid a row with the US but is anxious for Britain to play an active role in population policy, officials said.

Her Dutch colleague, Eveline Herfkens, has also urged a "quick and strong" European response to Mr Bush's cuts.

Brussels already gives family planning groups €47m (£30m), mostly for contraception and educational work in Asia.

fields.headline: Islanders take on US navy
fields.standfirst: Puerto Ricans seek damages for cancer rates
fields.trailText: The inhabitants of a Caribbean island which the US navy has used for 60 years as a bombing range, including firing depleted uranium shells, are seeking $100m (£68m) in damages for an abnormally high cancer rate.
fields.body:
The inhabitants of a Caribbean island which the US navy has used for 60 years as a bombing range, including firing depleted uranium shells, are seeking $100m (£68m) in damages for an abnormally high cancer rate.

Figures compiled in 1990-94 show that the 9,300 islanders of Vieques are 27% more likely to get cancer than those on Puerto Rico, just to the west.

But Dr Rafael Rivera-Castao, who lives on the island, says the rate has risen since then.

"I estimate that the cancer rate here is now 52% more than the Puerto Rico average."

The navy says the island offers the only terrain suitable for its military exercises.

John Arthur Eaves, the lawyer pressing for damages for one-third of islanders, said "I think $100m may turn out to be at the lower end of the scale of what we might get from the navy.

"We have already spent $7m on preparing this case, which we wouldn't have done if we didn't think we had a very good chance of winning."

Nilda Medina, of the Committee for the Rescue and Development of Vieques, said: "For years we have denounced the relationship between the military contamination and the exaggerated levels of cancer on Vieques.

"The heavy metals and other chemical components from explosives dangerous to human health combined with the radioactive uranium projectiles jeopardise the life of Viequenses today as well as future generations."

There was no way to guarantee that the next bomb would not hit one of the uranium shells, dispersing radioactive particles into the air.

Vieques became a cause célèbre 21 months ago after a misdirected shell killed a civilian security guard, and became the catalyst for a re-examination of Puerto Rican relations with the US.

Puerto Rico has been a territory for more than a century and its commonwealth status gives islanders US citizenship, albeit with reduced rights and duties: they cannot vote in presidential elections and do not have to pay federal taxes.

In the most recent referendum on the issue they rejected the idea of becoming the 51st state, but few of them have any interest in independence, despite a new Puerto Rican self-confidence reflected in the success of its sportsmen and such musicians as Ricky Martin.

Anti-American slogans are daubed throughout Vieques, an 18-mile long island on which civilians are confined to the middle third. Yesterday, as every Sunday, protesters rallied in the main town, Isabel Segunda, before driving in a convoy around the island blowing car horns and protesting through loudhailers.

Quite apart from the indignity of their existence on a virtually occupied land, they claim that the navy's presence prevents the development of the island, where tourism is among the few sources of income.

The bombing was halted after the death of the security guard when dissidents camped out on the range, defying the US and its allies, including Britain, to carry on.

They were removed last May after an agreement with Bill Clinton for a referendum in November on whether the navy should stay or go in 2003. President Bush, eager to show empathy with Hispanics, said he would respect the deal.

Bombing resumed last year, but with dummy shells. Puerto Rico's new governor, Sila Calderon, who took office last month, campaigned on an anti-navy platform and tried to persuade Mr Clinton in the last days of he presidency to halt the bombing for good.

Ms Calderon has threatened to remove Puerto Rican guards from the entrance to the firing range and to hold an earlier, rival referendum. She says the bombing noise has produced an usually high rate of heart disease.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Chechens free US doctor
fields.body:
Chechens free US doctor

An American worker for Médecins sans Frontière held hostage in Chechnya for a month was freed yesterday 15 miles south of the capital, Grozny.

Aid work by the UN, the European Union and other organisations was suspended after the 38-year-old's abduction. Russia denied that ransom had been paid.

AP, Moscow

Hackers breach Davos security

Hackers broke into the World Economic Forum's computer systems during last week's annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, and stole the credit card details of guests and members.

The forum admitted the breach after the unidentified hackers told the Swiss newspaper Sonntags-Zeitung.

Reuters, Geneva

Surfer survives shark attack

An Australian surfer bitten by a shark yesterday managed to escape, treat himself, and walk off for help.

Mark Butler, 40, is in a serious but stable condition after losing a lot of blood in the attack off the coast of northern New South Wales.

Reuters, Sydney

Boy, 11, killed in arcade fracas

A boy of 11 was stabbed to death, allegedly by another 11-year-old, after a row in a video arcade, the police in Springfield, Massachusetts, said.

The victim was stabbed in the chest on Saturday night in front of witnesses.

AP, Springfield

Guerrillas 'will behead hostage'

Muslim rebels renewed a threat yesterday to behead an American held for five months on Jolo islands in the southern Philippines.

Abu Sayyaf guerrillas said Jeffrey Schilling's execution would disprove claims that he was a "walk-in" - a willing hostage.

Reuters, Manila

webTitle: Comment: genetic engineering - the new natural selection?

fields.headline: Our genes are doomed
fields.standfirst:
Unless we embrace genetic engineering, we will become a sickly and frail species

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Unless we embrace genetic engineering, we will become a sickly and frail species.
fields.body:
According to yesterday's Mail on Sunday, the Queen has "sparked a furious row" by investing in a bio-pharmaceutical firm, ReNeuron. One of the firm's alleged crimes is that it has supported legislation allowing the cloning of human embryos.

Whatever the merits of this particular case, the fact remains that, if mankind is to escape an enfeebled future, we must embrace this scary technology. Detractors are quick to remind us of the dangers of designer babies once we remove our parents from their role as exclusive providers of our genes. But, like it or not, if humanity is not to become an endangered species, we must face up to the challenges of genetic engineering.

The reason is the same one that brought us here - natural selection. Over millions of years, the simple mechanism that Darwin first described - let the strong survive and the weak perish - has turned us into the successful animals we are today. Every gene in our bodies has been passed, baton-like, from parent to offspring over millions of years. But our genes are not unchanged by their passage through the generations. Replication of our chromosomes introduces errors called mutations.

All children acquire a few mutations on top of those inherited from their parents. Occasionally these will make our children run a little faster or think more quickly than ourselves, but mostly, they will do harm. Our genes have been finely tuned to do a particular job inside our cells. Mutations are, by and large, random. Just as random tinkering with your car engine is likely to leave you stranded the next morning, random tinkering with your genes is like to leave your offspring similarly stranded.

In our brutal past, defective genes would have been weeded out by natural selection, their owners suffering disease, predators or infertility. Modern medicine has changed all that. In the west at least, many of us survive and lead active lives with gene mutations that would have been fatal to our ancestors. I'm not talking about single-gene defects like cystic fibrosis or muscular dystrophy that remain devastating, but the far more frequent mutations that predispose us to ailments like diabetes, heart disease or cancer.

A few hundred years ago, a child with diabetes would have been lucky to survive to adult life. Thanks to insulin injections, diabetics now have nearly as much chance as the rest of us to leave their genes to the next generation. The same is true for scores of other diseases. Infant mortality in Palaeolithic times was probably higher than 50%. Bad genes, or bad combinations of genes, didn't make it through to the next generation. Now we see most of our offspring provide us with grandchildren, whatever their genetic inheritance. Where does this leave Darwinism?

Natural selection needs the grim reaper. Without his cruel separation of the fit from the weak, we will grow weak. We are healthier and will live longer than our parents, but our genes are not improving. Modern medicine, and improved living conditions, rescue us from our imperfect genetic inheritance.

In Britain we spend less on healthcare than almost any other wealthy country, but 6.7% of everything we earn goes to keeping us alive. Each government promises to spend more. Health advisers may pin their hopes on lifestyle changes to reduce the burden of disease, but most of the risk for cancer and heart disease is in our genes. As our genes become more faulty, our bodies will require more and more medical intervention. Use it or lose it is the advice of physiotherapists to those with mobility problems. It applies equally well to genes.

The provision of healthcare has brought about the greatest shift in selective pressure on the human species since we came down from the trees. The grip of the grim reaper has been loosened and our genes are free to roam the murky paths towards ill-health.

The consequences will take many generations to be realised, but they are inevitable. There is no way to stop mutations accumulating in our genes. As long as we have a health service to carry the burden, genes that introduce disease will multiply. We will become enfeebled parasites of our health systems. It's as inevitable as taxes.

Where will it all end? Is it our fate to become a frail and sickly species with chromosomes shot through with mutations? Perhaps the end will come when the NHS waiting list embraces the entire population and the burden of healthcare finally exceeds our capacity to provide it.

Many of the founding fathers of genetics were proponents of eugenics as a means of improving the human stock. If the horrors of that particular vision are not to be repeated we must find an ethical way of ridding our bodies of faulty genes.

ANDi, the first GM monkey, is a step towards that solution. The same technology that inserted a jellyfish gene into his chromosome will be used to correct defective human genes. We must see ANDi, not as a danger, but as our only hope for the future.

 Johnjoe McFadden is reader in molecular microbiology at the University of Surrey and author of Quantum Evolution, published by HarperCollins.

Is it our fate to become a frail and sickly species with chromosomes shot through with mutations? Perhaps the end will come when the NHS waiting list embraces the entire population and the burden of healthcare finally exceeds our capacity to provide it. Many of the founding fathers of genetics were proponents of eugenics as a means of improving the human stock. If the horrors of that particular vision are not to be repeated we must find an ethical way of ridding our bodies of faulty genes. ANDi, the first GM monkey, is a step towards that solution. The same technology that inserted a jellyfish gene into his chromosome will be used to correct defective human genes. We must see ANDi, not as a danger, but as our only hope for the future.  Johnjoe McFadden is reader in molecular microbiology at the University of Surrey and author of Quantum Evolution, published by HarperCollins. j.mcfadden@surrey.ac.uk

webTitle: Washington ups stakes in row on defence project

fields.headline: Missile shield is moral requisite, US tells allies
fields.standfirst:
Washington raises stakes in row on defence project

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Bush administration has said that its plan for a national missile defence shield is a constitutional, and even moral, imperative, dramatically raising the stakes in the most significant dispute about international security policy since the end of the cold war.
fields.body:
The Bush administration has said that its plan for a national missile defence shield is a constitutional, and even moral, imperative, dramatically raising the stakes in the most significant dispute about international security policy since the end of the cold war.

In his first visit abroad since taking office, the US defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, said no president could responsibly leave Americans undefended against threats that were known to exist.

"It is not so much a technical question as a matter of a president's constitutional responsibility... It is in many respects a moral issue," he told a top level security conference in Munich at the weekend.

He also expressed Washington's serious concern about EU plans for a joint rapid reaction force. This and the US national missile defence (NMD) project will dominate transatlantic relations for years to come.

Both issues will be high on the agenda for Robin Cook's visit to Washington today - the first by a British minister since George Bush took office - and during Tony Blair's trip to the US later in the month.

Washington will press ahead with the NMD project, even though technical problems have left the new administration undecided about what kind of system to go for. This could delay a decision, something which the British government will welcome.

Asked in Munich whether Britain would allow America to upgrade the Fylingdales early warning station on the North Yorkshire moors, the defence secretary, Geoffrey Hoon, said: "We share of course [US concern about emerging threats]. The US is our closest ally."

But he said the type of system the White House would choose "still has to be decided".

Mr Rumsfeld argued that the NMD system would make the US less isolationist by making it less vulnerable, and therefore more prepared to help its allies in a crisis. The systems the US would help its allies to deploy in Europe were a threat to no one, least of all the Russians, he insisted.

Denying that the missile shield would destroy existing arms control agreements, including the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty, he said Moscow knew that the systems being considered were designed to "deal with handfuls of things [missiles], not thousands".

That cut little ice with Sergei Ivanov, head of the Russian national security council and one of President Vladimir Putin's closest advisers. He told the Munich conference yesterday: "The destruction of the 1972 ABM treaty... will result in annihilation of the whole structure of strategic stability and create prerequisites for a new arms race, including in outer space."

In Britain the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence are both far from convinced by the American argument for a missile defence system. Mr Blair says that Britain could mediate between Washington and Moscow in an attempt to resolve the dispute.

But it was left to the German government - keen to raise its profile as a bridge between Russia and the US, as well as between Nato and the EU and Moscow - to express the concern of the European allies as well as the Russians.

"A lot of questions remain open," Gerhard Schröder, the chancellor, told the conference. "What is the threat scenario and the technological feasibility?"

His foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, warned that the international consequences of the NMD plan would be far reaching. Cooperation with Russia was of "overriding importance", he said.

His remarks were echoed by Rudolf Scharping, the German defence minister, who said Russia was also an "important security partner" of the EU.

Mr Rumsfeld said the EU's plan to undertake joint military operations threatened to inject instability into the alliance.

"Actions that could reduce Nato's effectiveness by confusing duplication, or by perturbing the transatlantic link, would not be positive," he said.

Washington's concern, which was echoed by all the Americans taking part in the conference, is heightened by Turkey which, although a non-EU member of Nato, wants a full say in European military operations. Ankara's demands are blocking EU-Nato consultation arrangements.

Mr Rumsfeld raised the prospect of the US providing the technology to enable its European allies to set up a missile defence shield to counter what he called "the raw and random violence of the outlaw regime or the rogue nation armed with missiles and weapons of mass destruction".

The prospect of an "allied missile defence" could be part of a deal extended even to Russia, which has proposed a collection of regional anti-missile systems. Moscow, Mr Ivanov made clear yesterday, is as concerned about "rogue regimes" and missile-armed terrorists as the US.

The options

 Rockets based in Alaska would hit incoming missiles. Early warning would be given by bases in Fylingdales and Thule (Greenland)

 Satellites, linked to stations such as Menwith Hill, Yorks, would detect incoming missiles, which would be hit by space-based weapons

 Incoming missiles would be attacked by high-flying aircraft

 Missiles based on land or ships would attack incoming weapons in launch phase, soon after they were fired

fields.headline: Littlewoods in merger talks
fields.standfirst: Moores family seeks link with GUS to turn ailing empire into revived retail force
fields.trailText: Moores family seeks link with GUS to turn ailing empire into revived retail force.
fields.body:
The ailing Littlewoods catalogue and store group has approached Great Universal Stores with a view to arranging a takeover that could create a new force in retailing.

A takeover by GUS would provide an exit route for the wealthy Moores family, which has controlled Littlewoods for nearly 80 years but is said to have grown weary of the group's recent lack of success.

The approach to GUS chairman Sir Victor Blank follows the shelving by Littlewoods of a planned stock market flota tion and the appointment of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney as financial adviser.

An increasingly difficult trading environment with pressures on all aspects of the company's business forced Littlewoods to a£15.5m interim loss.

Yesterday neither side would comment on the proposed deal. David Tyler, finance director at GUS, said: "We never comment on market speculation."

Sources close to GUS - whose empire spans Argos, home shopping and credit information together with the luxury Burberry label - confirmed an approach had been made. However, they warned that discussions were at a very early stage.

"A general approach was made by Littlewoods and GUS has asked them to come back with detailed proposals. These are very early days and the outcome is uncertain," one source said. There were opportunities for rationalisation and an eagerness to tackle joint problems.

Pressure on the 32 members of the Moores family who hold shares in the company rose last month when the business reported a disappointing 2.1% rise in sales for the crucial Christmas shopping weeks. That small growth in volume came at a high price because Littlewoods had undertaken a price-cutting campaign that drastically reduced margins.

It is estimated Littlewoods sales in the first five weeks of 2001 came in 25% under budget as it fought to compete with expanding discounters such as Matalan and New Look.

About 200 jobs have been shed at Littlewoods, whose catalogue business has been struggling to compete against internet services.

Littlewoods' ventures on the net, mainly through a joint venture with fellow retailer Arcadia, have brought little success. There has been speculation that Arcadia wants to pull the plug on the loss-making operation.

Retail experts say a tie-up between Littlewoods and GUS would provide a range of areas for rationalisation. Like Littlewoods, GUS offers home shopping, and delivery services through White Arrow. But a takeover would also generate competition concerns over the combined volume of the two home shopping businesses.

A winter trading statement by GUS last month showed its Argos brand growing 6% but home shopping fell 5% for the second year in a row. Its shares have recently been given a battering because of the potential impact of a slowdown in the US economy on its Experian business.

GUS has been trying to focus on its core business by lining up its Burberry fashion business for a separate stock market flotation and winding down its property and finance arms. It has also been trying to develop its call centre business, which it is now offering to outside customers such as car maker Vauxhall.

webTitle: Safe bet Coral denies SEC filing is danger sign

fields.headline: Safe bet Coral denies SEC filing is danger sign
fields.trailText: Coral Group, Britain's third-largest bookmaker, last night insisted the company was in good financial shape despite reports that it has been forced into an urgent refinancing.
fields.body:
Coral Group, Britain's third-largest bookmaker, last night insisted the company was in good financial shape despite reports that it has been forced into an urgent refinancing.

A strong turnout of punters for last year's Coral Cup at Cheltenham seems to support that.

Information filed with the securities and exchange commission (SEC) in the United States, however, appears to show Deutsche Bank had to inject £10m into Coral to prevent the bookmaker from breaching its banking covenants. Deutsche is the parent of Morgan Grenfell Private Equity, which owns Coral.

The SEC documents also show the company slumped to a £48.3m loss, taking the total pre-tax loss to £52.5m for the full year.

Coral says in the documents: "On October 11, 2000, after the end of the fiscal 2000, the company issued an additional 10m shares of £1 each to the parent.

"The company's directors do not believe that the current capital structure of the group is optimal and are currently assessing alternative refinancing structures."

Sources close to Coral denied the losses, saying there was no question of being close to breaching its financial undertakings and that the phrase "alternative structures" referred to a sale or flotation.

They insist the £10m pay-out by Morgan Grenfell had been planned and came from a fund set aside to develop Coral's Eurobet online betting operations.

A senior source within Coral said: " Morgan Grenfell are very happy with the way the business is performing and continue to believe there is significant value there."

fields.headline: Lonesome males of the Galapagos
fields.trailText: Celebrity is not usually associated with middle-aged giant tortoises from the Galapagos Islands, but then few have been so influenced by humanity's whims as Lonesome George and Pepe.
fields.byline: Jo Tuckman on the Galapagos Islands
fields.body:
Celebrity is not usually associated with middle-aged giant tortoises from the Galapagos Islands, but then few have been so influenced by humanity's whims as Lonesome George and Pepe. They have no choice but to live out their lives lumbering torhythms set by invaders from the outside world.

To George fame came in 1971. He was discovered on the tiny uninhabited island of Pinta, the last surviving member of his sub-species. Now he lives under the scrutiny of scientists who hope against hope that he will pass on his genes to a new generation.

Pepe is unique in another sense, the last domesticated tortoise on the Galapagos, which teemed with the pets until conservationists impounded his contemporaries. The tourism boom finally fenced him in.

Three weeks ago the tanker Jessica ran aground near the islands, leaking almost 950,000 litres of oil. It was feared that the islands' many unique species would be damaged, but ecologists expect the archipelago to make a full recovery.

Pirates and whalers began the onslaught on tortoises when they realised that they made excellent fresh meat supplies on board their ships, because they can survive for six months without food and water.

But it was the goats introduced to the Galapagos by the early settlers that really did it for George's clan, destroying the ecological balance on the islands, 600 miles from mainland Ecuador, where it evolved over millennia.

By the time George was discovered rearing programmes were replenishing the gene pool of other tortoise sub-species, but his case was different. Unless a mate could be found his group faced extinction.

George was taken to the Charles Darwin Research Centre on Santa Cruz island and provided with a harem from related sub-species, but he was just not interested. Thirty years later the last Geochelone elephantopus abingdoni is as lonesome as ever.

Pepe grew up on San Cristobal island in the 1920s, in an era when it was common to whip baby tortoises out of their natural habitat and take them home. In 1959 the Galapagos National Park was formed and park officials rounded up all the domesticated tortoises they could find. All, that is, except Pepe, who was by then in the charge of Franciscan missionaries, who were allowed to keep him.

Eventually he became the island's mascot, and he lumbered around freely until the early 90s, when tourism began to interfere with his routine.

Since then he has lived in a small enclosure, where younger visitors ride on his saddle-shaped back.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

A review of the Co-op's businesses by a government-appointed commission is to recommend more than 50 changes to the mutually owned company. In a report out on Thursday the commission will recommend the setting up of a Co-op Foundation to invest a proportion of profits in growth areas; a credit union for low earners without bank access; care homes; and co-operative housing schemes.

Former rivals Punch Taverns and Whitbread are to expand their budget-hotels venture, Punch Travel Inns. The companies originally planned 50 Travel Inns next to Punch pubs but will now double that number by 2003.

France Telecom is launching a convertible bond issue, exchangeable into 5% of Orange's share capital, to support the flotation of its mobile phone division. The bond issue will come ahead of the Orange float. FT risks being accused of trying to tempt investors to the offer.

Sunday Express

Oil companies BP and Shell are about to report record profits totalling £18bn while claiming they cannot afford to cut the price of petrol. Petrol protesters want the Chancellor to impose an oil profits windfall tax.

Sunday Business

A cost-cutting drive at Amazon.com is likely to mean redundancies at its British base in the Thames valley. Amazon is Britain's most visited website, but the US group last week revealed an unexpected slump in sales and shed 1,300 US jobs.

The Lord Mayor of the City of London, David Howard, has suggested a merger of the stock exchange and the Liffe futures exchange.

Sunday Times

The Financial Times is considering ways to charge for its FT.com online service.

Asda is to install jewellery counters in its 240 stores. Wal-Mart , which owns Asda, is the world's biggest jeweller. Its US sales of gold, silver, watches and costume jewellery topped £3bn last year.

US share dealing service Charles Schwab is considering taking a stake in Alliance & Leicester and puttingdealing counters in A&L's 314 branches.

Sunday Telegraph

Pubs entrepreneur David Bruce, who founded the Firkin chain, is raising £10m to build a chain of unbranded freehouses in London. He plans a string of 25 pubs for drinkers who are bored with branded outlets.

Upmarket store Liberty is planning to scrap its high-fashion collection, together with its e-commerce and mail order operations, to concentrate on its core retailing business.

IoS

Mobile operator One2One is preparing to phase out its pre-paid phone business, which accounts for 77% of its 8m-strong customer base.

BSkyB is expected to confirm this week that it now has more than 5m digital and analogue customers.

Mail on Sunday

Hoare Govett, one of two stockbrokers to the Iceland supermarket group, warned Iceland's then chairman, Malcolm Walker, against his controversial £13.5m share sale before Christmas.

German drugstore group Schlecker has approached Kingfisher with an offer to buy its 700-branch Superdrug business. The British chain could fetch up to £300m.

Finals Rio Tinto. AGMs Treatt. EGMs L Gardener Group, Grampian.

Tuesday

Interims BOC (Q1), Epic Group, Galen Holdings (Q1), Ryanair (Q3). Finals Amvescap, Henderson TR Pacific.

AGMs Baggeridge Brick. EGMs None scheduled.

Wednesday

Interims Antisoma (Q2), Northamber, Regent Inns.

Finals BSkyB, BWD Securities, Eagle Eye Telematics.

AGMs Foreign & Colonial Pep & ISA, Granada Compass, Granada Media. EGMs Gartmore Shared.

Thursday

Interims BT. Finals AstraZeneca, Barclays, ICI, Mersey Docks & Harbour, Royal Dutch/Shell, Signet Group, Unilever.

AGMs API Group, Dunedin Smaller Cos, Greencore Group, Henderson Strat. EGMs None scheduled.

Friday

Interims None scheduled. Finals None scheduled.

AGMs Burndene Investments, Just2Clicks.com.

EGMs Transense Technology.

Indicators this week Today

UK Official reserves (Jan). UK Provisional M0 (Jan). UK Service sector PMI. UK BoE's Plenderleith to appear before theTreasury Committee. EU ECB Noyer speech.
