UK Industrial production (Dec). UK Manufacturing production (Dec).

Wednesday

Thursday

fields.headline: BT denies Cellnet hang-up
fields.standfirst: Float said to be on track despite rumours of Spanish deal
fields.trailText: Float said to be on track despite rumours of Spanish deal.
fields.body:
BT yesterday insisted it would be pushing ahead with the flotation of its Cellnet mobile phone business despite speculation that the plan could be shelved in favour of a £50bn merger with Telefonica Moviles of Spain.

The British group intends to float 25% of BT Wireless, which includes the Cellnet group, because it is under pressure to find ways of cutting its £30bn debt mountain. But, with investor demand for mobile phone companies sagging, BT told a meeting of top institutional shareholders that it had opened its mind to other strategies.

A spokesman for BT said last night: "We do not comment on speculation or rumour." But sources said the financial environment was constantly changing and that all options - including a tie-up with the Spanish company - were under consideration.

BT will come under further pressure to reveal its latest thinking on this issue when it reports its third-quarter financial figures on Thursday. It has already admitted that it is looking at other options after an earlier decision to list on the stock market its Yell directories business.

A link with Telefonica would offer a range of advantages to BT Wireless, including the opportunity to expand instantly across continental Europe. The Spanish company has also made important inroads into fast-expanding markets in Latin America such as Brazil and Argentina.

But Moviles is a young company that was only recently floated on the stock market and is still 98% owned by Telefonica.

The Spanish government last year halted a planned group merger between Telefonica and KPN of the Netherlands, and a proposed tie-up between BP and Telefonica.

Apart from the domestic opposition to a deal among Spanish politicians there would also be the need to convince potentially sceptical European regulators.

The international expansion would coincide with BT coming under further pressure at home after losing a battle with the domestic industry regulator, Oftel, last week over phone charges.

David Edmonds, head of Oftel, said BT was still "profiting excessively" from its residential phone business, and he extended by one year price controls that should have expired in August this year.

Oftel also reduced the prices BT charges competing telecoms companies for using its network.

But a recent BT-commissioned survey claimed the company's charges were nearly one-quarter below those of its rivals.

webTitle: Leader: Mandelson and friends need patience

fields.headline: Patience is a virtue
fields.standfirst:
Mr Mandelson and friends should cool it

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: It is said to be the fervent wish of Sir Anthony Hammond, who is conducting the inquiry into the Hinduja affair, that the rest of the world would shut up and let him get on with his job. Some hope. Two issues combined this weekend to make that impossible.
fields.body:
It is said to be the fervent wish of Sir Anthony Hammond, who is conducting the inquiry into the Hinduja affair, that the rest of the world would shut up and let him get on with his job. Some hope. Two issues combined this weekend to make that impossible. One was the agitation over the foreign office minister Keith Vaz, which was fuelled by a cascade of fresh allegations in the Sunday newspapers. The other was the controversy over the forced resignation of Peter Mandelson, which was fuelled by Peter Mandelson and his friends.

The Vaz affair now closely resembles repeated press campaigns during John Major's government, when tabloid newspapers went after erring ministers and refused to relent until they had got their scalps. The charges against him this weekend were many and lurid, ranging from allegations (strongly denied) about money gone missing in his constituency party to reports that the minister was about to resign, or that colleagues had urged him to go. Some of these are Hinduja-linked, and therefore Sir Anthony's territory; others would rather belong to the continuing inquiry into Mr Vaz's activities by the parliamentary ombudsman, Elizabeth Filkin. Already firmly defended by Tony Blair, Mr Vaz was even more stoutly championed yesterday by his boss at the Foreign Office, Robin Cook, who complained of innuendo and guilt by association, and suggested that Mr Vaz's real offence in the eyes of his persecutors was his enthusiasm for Europe. But that will not wash. If and when the truth is disentangled from the fantasy and fabrication, it may well become clear that the networking for which Mr Vaz is famous took him into territory which wiser men would have avoided.

Meanwhile, the matter of Peter Mandelson, which had fallen quiet at the end of last week, was brought back to the boil, partly by the fallen minister himself but more by the assiduous friend who has cast himself as Emile Zola to Mandelson's Dreyfus: the novelist Robert Harris. "Nothing I will ever do will ever be designed to harm the government or the party" Mr Mandelson told the Independent on Sunday. But that misses the point. The Titanic was never designed to strike an iceberg and sink on its maiden voyage, but miscalculations in steersmanship sank it nevertheless. And Mr Harris's attack on the former Home Office man chosen to head the inquiry - "can anyone seriously believe he is going to exonerate Mandelson, with all the vast embarrassment for the home secretary that would entail?" - sits oddly with Mr Mandelson's own promise to await Sir Anthony's verdict in the confidence that his name will be cleared.

Mr Mandelson's friends can hardly expect Tony Blair to declare at this stage: "I was wrong. It's all been a huge, appalling mistake. I want Peter back in my government instantly". Any outcome now which shows that the minister was unjustly treated will harm the reputation of Mr Blair and his government; but an instant recantation would ruin it. Mr Mandelson's interview with the Guardian today suggests a cooler approach. Both Dreyfus and Zola should stick to it.

webTitle: Two die in fall down lift shaft

fields.headline: Two die in fall down lift shaft
fields.trailText: Two men yesterday fell 150 feet to their deaths down a 15-storey tower block lift shaft after a fight is believed to have broken out at a party.
fields.body:
Two men yesterday fell 150 feet to their deaths down a 15-storey tower block lift shaft after a fight is believed to have broken out at a party.

It is thought the force of the men, aged 27 and 25, crashing into the lift doors caused them to spring open.

The health and safety executive is investigating whether there was a fault with the lift doors.

The 11 other people who went to the party in Shirley, Southampton, were yesterday questioned by detectives.

A mother who lives in the block, who did not wish to be identified, said: "My daughter was at the party and a lot of the girls are in a terrible state, just sitting around crying. It is a shocking thing that these two lads should die like that.

"The lift doors should never have opened. They are just not designed to do that."

The bodies of the men were recovered by firefighters and taken to hospital where post-mortem examinations were held yesterday.

Another resident, Harry Jacobs, 18, said: "We were just told that a fight had broken out and these two men had fallen down the lift shaft. It is shocking, really. There are loads of kids living in the block and the fact that the elevators should be so dangerous is crazy."

webTitle: British soldier kicked to death by gang in Austria

fields.headline: British soldier kicked to death by gang in Austria
fields.trailText: Police in Austria were last night hunting a gang who stamped on and kicked to death a member of the British army bobsleigh team outside an Innsbruck disco.
fields.body:
Police in Austria were last night hunting a gang who stamped on and kicked to death a member of the British army bobsleigh team outside an Innsbruck disco.

Corporal Derek Osbourne died from his injuries after the attack by six or seven men. A fellow soldier who went with him to the club escaped with minor injuries.

Austrian police said the gang kicked Mr Osbourne's head and stamped on it leaving him unconscious in a pool of blood, before escaping in a white van.

He was among a group of 50 soldiers in Innsbruck for a British army bobsleigh tournament. The Ministry of Defence in London said that Cpl Osbourne, 31, served with the Kings Own Royal Border regiment, based at Catterick. He was married with a baby son and came from Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria.

Cpl Osbourne and a fellow soldier, neither of whom were in uniform, had been in the disco celebrating the end of the one-day bobsleigh championship on Saturday.

Police said an argument broke out and the soldiers were attacked after leaving the Antico disco at 3.30am. Lieutenant Colonel Marius Meisinger said: "There was a quarrel between two British men and a group of men, thought to be Turkish or Yugoslavian, outside the Antico disco. There was shouting, we don't know the reason for the quarrel.

"The group of six or seven people attacked the British men and one of them fell down and was lying on the ground. The gang kicked him in the head and stamped on his head with their feet. They only attacked his head, so he was very badly injured," he said.

Both the British soldiers were taken to the University Clinic in Innsbruck, where Cpl Osbourne died within hours.

Lt Col Meisinger said he died from his head injuries. "The gang of men left the location of the crime in a white van soon afterwards."

"Our officers were not able to catch them at the scene and we are still looking for them," he added.

News of the tragedy was broken to the British soldiers taking part in the tournament at their base at Igls, a resort used for the 1976 Olympics.

Army spokeswoman Major Anna Kimber, speaking from Innsbruck, said: "People here are devastated, their thoughts are for his family and friends."

Cpl Osbourne had been in Innsbruck for a week - a member of one of 12 two-man bobsleighs from the British army preparing for the tournament.

The top six soldiers from Saturday's race were to have gone forward to a bobsleigh tournament this Friday and Saturday between the army, navy and air force. The race has now been cancelled.

Lt Col Meisinger said Innsbruck, home to 120,000 people, had seen just two murders in all of last year: "We are completely shocked by this, all over the country."

Lt Col Mike Griffiths, commanding officer of Kings Own Royal Border Regiment, said: "He was a highly professional soldier, much respected by all ranks in the regiment."

fields.headline: Summit to promote organ donations
fields.standfirst: Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: Pay packets, credit cards and census returns could play a part in a government drive to encourage organ donation, under proposals to be discussed at an emergency summit in the next few weeks.
fields.body:
Pay packets, credit cards and census returns could play a part in a government drive to encourage organ donation, under proposals to be discussed at an emergency summit in the next few weeks.

The health secretary Alan Milburn announced the conference yesterday amid fears that the Alder Hey body parts scandal could discourage families from donating organs, exacerbating serious shortages in the number of organs available. At least 6,000 patients are awaiting transplants.

Patient and professional groups, health chiefs, business leaders and parents will all play a part at the London summit. It will look for possible solutions to the shortage of donors, such as putting donor cards in pay packets and allowing people to register via returns for the next census.

People can already volunteer as donors when they apply for a passport or driving licence or register with a new doctor. Some credit card companies include a question on their application forms.

But the conference will stop well short of endorsing the opt-out "presumed consent" model of donation practised in Spain, where people are assumed to have agreed to organ donation unless they explicitly withdraw their consent.

The Department of Health said the summit would tackle the increasing gap between the number of people awaiting treatment and the number of organs available. A dramatic fall in road accident fatalities and the ability to help patients who might previously have been untreatable have contributed to the disparity.

It will also help to make "absolutely clear" the difference between agreeing to organ donations for transplants and organs being retained after a postmortem examination.

Mr Milburn said the 8m donor card holders needed to have the confidence that they would be treated with dignity and respect.

"Although at the moment the Alder Hey scandal does not appear to have affected donation of organs, we do not want to become complacent," he said. "I want to step up our drive to get more donors so that vital medical advances are not halted and people whose lives could so easily be saved with a transplant are not left to die unnecessarily."

The announcement came as leading transplant surgeons voiced their fears that the Alder Hey scandal could lead to a fatal drop in donations. The heart surgeon Sir Magdi Yacoub, of the Royal Brompton Hospital, in London, said he was concerned there had been no transplant operations at the Brompton over the past 10 days.

Sue Sutherland, a renal transplant surgeon and chief executive of UK Transplant, the NHS group which runs the country's transplant programme, added: "We are concerned that Alder Hey may have a negative effect on people's willingness to donate."

At present around a quarter of relatives refuse to allow organ donation. They are legally entitled to withhold consent even if their loved ones have registered as donors.

A Department of Health spokeswoman in effect ruled out the introduction of presumed consent.

"The summit will look at many issues, but I think there's a feeling that [the current method] is the most appropriate way of doing it," she said.

A spokeswoman for the British Medical Association, which first mooted the presumed consent model, said they would only favour its introduction "as and when the public supported it".

fields.headline: I'm hooked on this drama
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: On Thursday evening I sped home from the office in the hope of getting back for an episode of the kind of television I don't usually watch, a detective series called Kamenskaya. Set in Moscow, it's based on the recent novels of Alexandra Marinina, about a woman police major in the Russian equivalent of Scotland Yard.
fields.body:
On Thursday evening I sped home from the office in the hope of getting back for an episode of the kind of television I don't usually watch, a detective series called Kamenskaya. Set in Moscow, it's based on the recent novels of Alexandra Marinina, about a woman police major in the Russian equivalent of Scotland Yard.

I got hooked on Wednesday, with the start of a story about mysterious death threats to brides. It bears no more resemblance to the grim, corrupt reality of Moscow detective work than Inspector Morse does to the squalor and tedium of murder investigations in the Oxfordshire constabulary, but it's no worse, either - well-acted, well-shot and well-scripted.

Kamenskaya is broadcast on NTV, Russia's largest independent TV channel. We can watch it in London because a few years ago the channel's main owner and founder, Vladimir Gusinsky, borrowed the money to beam NTV channels across Russia and to western Europe and Israel, where it now has a large audience among ex-Soviet immigrants. With a small satellite dish, a decoder and about £11 a month, you can pick up a good clear signal.

But for how much longer? NTV is under attack. Gusinsky is under house arrest in Spain while Moscow tries to extradite him; the company's finance chief, Anton Titov, is being held in a 37-to-a-cell remand prison. Officially, the investigations are about unpaid tax. Unofficially, what is going on is intimidation, sanctioned by the Kremlin, to smother NTV's relatively independent line in its current affairs programmes, and help the giant semi- private gas monopoly, Gazprom, to take it over.

It's an uncomfortable feeling, sitting at home in free London watching a familiar TV channel fighting for its independence in unfree Russia. I've become used to flipping through the stations, switching from the BBC talking about Mandelson to NTV reporting on the latest massacre in Chechnya, from a weatherwoman on the Thames Embankment warning of a night-time frost to an NTV account of tens of thousands of people in Vladivostok without heat or electricity in temperatures below minus 10. Lately, NTV has been reporting more and more on itself, and whether it will be free to go on reporting these things.

There's an unwholesome tradition for western commentators to patronise eastern European broadcasters under threat - to present them as naive, worthy souls who don't really understand what television is about, but go on bravely making their appeals for justice and freedom from candlelit studios, bless them.

Westerners laud NTV's excellent current affairs output while ignoring or dissing the rest. "Like other Russian channels, it mostly broadcasts the usual pap of quiz shows and Hollywood cast-offs," sniffed the Economist this week. "Unlike the others, it has lively and critical news and current affairs programmes." Like other Russian channels? Like British channels, surely.

The future of NTV is not just about the freedom of Russian journalists to report the truth. It is also about creativity and the freedom of Russians to build something new, rather than simply scavenging among the ruins of the Soviet world.

Gusinsky is more of a democratic liberal than Vladimir Putin, but not much. He has been involved in dubious business dealings, and on occasion his support of politicians - Boris Yeltsin in 1996, Yuri Luzhkov in 2000 - has led to odious distortions in NTV broadcasts. He's no Vaclav Havel, but nor is he like the great majority of Russian oligarchs with whom he is often lumped - parasites who have never created anything, but simply taken over existing Soviet structures and scooped up the revenue.

For all his faults, Gusinsky gathered together the talent and funds to make something genuinely new and Russian that Russians could be informed and entertained by - and now Gazprom wants it, with President Putin's tacit blessing. A deputation of NTV journalists went to see Putin, the former KGB agent and friend of Tony Blair, in the Kremlin last week. They came back depressed, saying he seemed to believe that NTV was a nothing but a tool of Gusinsky's political whims.

Victor Shenderovich, NTV's chief satirist, was there. "Putin is a man of the system," he said. "The first half of his conscious life was spent in the system of opposing sides, one enemy against another. This was the most terrifying thing I discovered: that he can't allow the idea that I might say something simply because that's what I think." The evidence is growing, if the horrors of Chechnya were not enough, that Putin is not a man to whom Blair should be cosying up.

james.meek@theguardian.com

I got hooked on Wednesday, with the start of a story about mysterious death threats to brides. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Hunt protester bitten by fox
fields.body:
Hunt protester bitten by fox

A hunt saboteur who tried to rescue a fox being chased by hounds at Dulford, Devon, was taken to hospital after the fox bit his hand. Nine people were arrested after violence broke out between protesters and members of the East Devon hunt.

Hypothermia hits film crew

A Japanese film crew member in her 30s was recovering in hospital from hypothermia yesterday after being winched from a cave on the Scottish island of Mull. She and two colleagues had been living in the cave while they filmed a programme on outdoor survival techniques.

House boat man drowns

A man in his 30s or 40s drowned when he fell off his house boat after an evening drinking with friends, police said. His body was recovered from the river Wensum in Norwich.

Teenager shot dead in car

Francis Burke, 19, was killed and Michael Kielty, 19, was wounded early yesterday when a gunman opened fire on a car with three men inside parked near a Liverpool nightclub. Police appealed for witnesses.

Boy swept to death in sea

A teenage boy was swept to his death as he walked along the North Sea coastline at South Gare, Co Durham yesterday. He was with two sisters and another boy, all from Middlesbrough, who were washed into the water. They were swept ashore before rescuers arrived.

Kilshaws seek US lawyer

The couple in the transatlantic adoption row said last night they would use the internet to look for an American lawyer to fight their their case in the US.

Alan and Judith Kilshaw returned to their home in Buckley, north Wales, after appearing on televison with a Californian couple who claim they "bought" the twins in the case first.

Five share £11m rollover jackpot

Five winners shared Saturday's £11.5m national lottery rollover jackpot, with numbers 2, 15, 16, 17, 25, 26. The bonus number was 44. One person won the Lottery Extra jackpot of £2,988,486, with numbers 1, 13, 22, 27, 28 and 47, and there was one winner of the £250,000 Thunderball jackpot, with 4, 11, 19, 20, 31, and thunderball 4.

webTitle: Bluebird's wreck found in Coniston Water

fields.headline: Bluebird's wreck found in Coniston Water
fields.standfirst: Campbell family divided over salvage scheme
fields.trailText: Divers have found the wreck of Bluebird, the boat in which Donald Campbell died while attempting to break the world water speed record more than 30 years ago.
fields.body:
Divers have found the wreck of Bluebird, the boat in which Donald Campbell died while attempting to break the world water speed record more than 30 years ago.

Underwater surveyor Bill Smith, who led the team which pinpointed the position of the jet-powered boat, 150ft below the surface and submerged in silt, is proposing to film a salvage operation for a BBC documentary if Campbell's relatives give their permission.

Cambell was the holder of the world land and water speed records when he died on January 4 1967 while trying to break his record on Coniston Water in the Lake District.

Shortly after Bluebird reached 300mph it somersaulted and crashed, killing Campbell instantly. The craft was first found by navy divers days after the tragedy, but his body was never recovered and attempts to locate the boat again failed.

A team led by Mr Smith found Bluebird while testing aquatic surveillance equipment shortly before Christmas. Despite opposition from some of Campbell's family, including his widow, Tonia Bern-Campbell, a BBC spokesman said the documentary of the proposed salvage attempt, called The Mission, was likely to be shown in April. He added that any family difficulties "would have to be resolved amicably first".

Mrs Bern-Campbell, 64, who learned of the project this year, criticised the plans as "terribly sad". She said: "They can't do this without my permission. I have not given it and and I knew nothing about it.

"The reason I don't want that boat up is because Donald always said, 'The craft stays with the skipper'. Therefore, as we never found him and he's somewhere in that lake, I did not want it up."

Other family members, including Campbell's nephew Don Wales and his daughter Gina, who broke the women's water speed record in 1984, are involved in the project and are reportedly less opposed to the plans.

Mr Wales, who holds the British electric car speed record, said: "A survey of the lake is being conducted. Gina and Tonia will have to act together.

"They've have had their differences in the past and I want to keep them together."

Mr Smith, who is a friend of Gina, said: "The tail end has sunk a little bit on the bottom. There's a lot of silt and a lot of mess but the best bit, the union jack is still there on the tail after all this time."

On the Campbell family's disagreement he said: "It's not my show, it's Gina's boat. It's entirely up to her what we do. We've all got a family and we know what families are like. It's none of my concern. Let them get on with it.

"Whether it stays there or comes up has to be a family decision. I want to make sure everyone is on board before we go forward."

Coniston residents spoke yesterday of their reservations at the proposals to bring the boat, and possibly Campbell's body, to the surface.

Mike Humphreys, custodian of the Ruskin museum in Coniston, which has an exhibition dedicated to Campbell, said: "The feeling in the village is that it would be wrong for someone to make commercial gain out of it.

"When Donald Campbell died the villagers were very sad and took him into their hearts. He was a hero and his body and Bluebird should be left in peace."

One woman, who did not want to be named, said from the village's Black Bull pub: "I strongly feel that Donald should be left in his grave, like all water disasters before him and most since."

David Coxon, manager of Coniston Boating Centre, said: "There are always 10 to 12 divers in the lake every day, searching and searching like mad. It has become like looking for the holy grail, trying to find Donald Campbell's boat.

"I know Tonia and she is always coming back to this place. The memories are very strong and she speaks about him a lot. I'm not convinced trying to get Donald out is the best thing to be done."

webTitle: Leader: Israel may soon regret picking Sharon

fields.headline: A change for the worse
fields.standfirst:
Israel may soon regret picking Mr Sharon

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli electorate has a momentous choice to make tomorrow. All the signs are that it is going to make the wrong one. Few seem to doubt that Ariel Sharon will be the country's next prime minister; the residual question exercising pollsters is the margin of his victory.
fields.body:
The Israeli electorate has a momentous choice to make tomorrow. All the signs are that it is going to make the wrong one. Few seem to doubt that Ariel Sharon will be the country's next prime minister; the residual question exercising pollsters is the margin of his victory. Sadly, Mr Sharon needs no introduction. From his infamous role in the 1982 Lebanon invasion to his deliberately provocative, personal intrusion into Arab East Jerusalem last September, the ex-general and Likud leader has been a consistently prominent foe to peace, a confrontational rejectionist to match the hardest of Hamas or Hizbullah hardliners.

His election platform places "security" before all else and demands an absolute end to all Palestinian violence (as defined by himself) before any talks about anything at all with Yasser Arafat's representatives can proceed. Mr Sharon would effectively scrap all the work that has been done before and since last July's Camp David summit, freezing the peace process and petrifying the status quo in the occupied territories. He has already commenced verbal hostilities with Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak, the leading Arab "moderate". His predicted triumph already has Syrian commentators claiming that Damascus was right all along to oppose a deal with the "Zionist entity". Iraq's Saddam Hussein, who thrives on polarisation, must be hoping Mr Sharon wins big-time. At home, Ehud Barak's would-be nemesis has been busy courting the ultra-Orthodox parties, reportedly promising to safeguard their divisive privileges and narrow, inward-looking interests against the prime minister's mooted secular "civil revolution".

For these among other reasons, Mr Sharon is the wrong choice tomorrow. But, voters may cry, how can we support Barak? In his strategy for dealing with the Palestinians, he is commonly held to have been duped. He has made no progress with the new Syrian leader; his Lebanon withdrawal last year brought no Jordanian-style rapprochement with Beirut. After less than two years in the job, he is seen as inconsistent and impulsive, an unbiddable loner who never understood the party political game, who failed to deliver his promises to boost education and jobs, and while trying to appeal direct to the people, seemed to have lost their address. Never mind that Mr Barak was severely handicapped by Israel's anarchic multiparty system and impractical elections laws. And never mind the significant, albeit inconclusive progress that was made. In their disappointment, Israeli voters forget that Mr Barak moved his country closer than any previous leader to a historic overall agreement finally securing the borders of the Jewish state and officially ending its "war" with the Arabs.

It is this same nationally shared forgetfulness that may account for current reported voter apathy, despite the crucial nature of this choice. It is this collective amnesia that condemns (and readily shoots down) rock-throwing Palestinian teenagers, oblivious to the violence and excess that repeatedly attended Israel's own fight to establish and defend its right to independent existence. It is a forgetfulness that blames Mr Arafat, blames US mediators and the UN, blames meddling Europeans, blames blind hate and history, but never seems to recognise each individual Israeli's present responsibility for the injustices of the past for which Israel was itself to blame. Until Israelis, instead of running to hide behind the likes of Mr Sharon, fully understand and accept, once and for all, the need to give ground and make amends, there will be no "security", no peace - and no rest.

webTitle: Clintons pay for gifts and new office

fields.headline: Clintons avert criticism by paying for gifts and new office
fields.trailText: The Clintons are going some way to removing the whiff of impropriety that accompanied their departure from the White Office this month. They have agreed to reimburse friends and supporters for around $86,000 (£58,000) worth of the $190,027 in gifts that they decided to take with them; and Mr Clinton will find $300,000 towards the rent of at least $665,000 a year for his new offices in Manhattan.
fields.body:
The Clintons are going some way to removing the whiff of impropriety that accompanied their departure from the White Office this month. They have agreed to reimburse friends and supporters for around $86,000 (£58,000) worth of the $190,027 in gifts that they decided to take with them; and Mr Clinton will find $300,000 towards the rent of at least $665,000 a year for his new offices in Manhattan.

The money for the presents will cover only those received in the Clintons' final year.

Denise Rich, the songwriter, Democratic contributor and former wife of the fugitive tax fraudster Marc Rich, who was pardoned controversially in one of Mr Clinton's final acts as president, will receive a cheque for $7,373 to cover two tables and chairs.

A Mr Jack Nicholson of Beverley Hills, California, will get $350 in return for a golf club.

"As have other presidents and their families before us, we received gifts over the course of our eight years in the White House and followed all the gift rules," the Clintons said. "To eliminate even the slightest question, we are taking the step of paying for gifts given to us in 2000."

The former president said that the Clinton Presidential Library Foundation would pay part of the rent for his offices in Carnegie Hall Tower, in space formerly occupied by Talk magazine. The building has views of Central Park and its occupants include the comedians Jerry Seinfeld and Eddie Murphy.

Republicans in congress had threatened to oppose Mr Clinton's plans for the offices because of the cost.

"I'm not going to let the taxpayer get gigged [done over] on this," said the former president, who starts a new part-time career today as a speech-maker in Florida, a job for which banking forum Morgan Stanley Dean Witter will pay him $100,000.

"I mean, it's New York. I also pay higher taxes in New York and I'm glad to be here. But I don't want the taxpayer to be taken for a ride," he said.

Republican congressman Ernest Istook, from Oklahoma, who chairs the sub-committee that deals with the budget for former presidents, said: "Even if he got people to donate $300,000 a year, he's still asking taxpayers to pay $400,000 every year for his presidential penthouse."

webTitle: Letters: winners and losers on the underground

fields.headline: Looking for winners and losers on the underground
fields.trailText: Before we celebrate too soon (Prescott gives way in row over tube, February 3) we need to see the final outcome of further talks. Compromises are one thing, a compromised railway is quite another.
fields.body:
Before we celebrate too soon (Prescott gives way in row over tube, February 3) we need to see the final outcome of further talks. Compromises are one thing, a compromised railway is quite another.

The government is still making ominous noises and clings obstinately to public-private partnership. Is it saving face or saving the underground? The one hope for a sane outcome is that the government can't afford, to have Bob Kiley walk away.

A successful tube system needs to meet three essential criteria: accessibility, safety, affordability. Independent expert opinion advises that these criteria can best be met through a single chain of command, with new development and modernisation funded partly through a bond issue. But the government has decided that PPP is best.

Experience with the railways has demonstrated that differentiated management and objectives has drastically failed to meet any of these criteria. But the government has decided that PPP is best.

Ken Livingstone brings in Bob Kiley to do for London what he successfully achieved in New York and Boston. But the government has decided that PPP is best.

Londoners don't want it. Underground staff don't want it. But the government has decided that PPP is best.

The government will sign up to the deal and then pass the buck to Livingstone. When things go wrong, they will say the underground is his responsibility. And the mayor will say: "We told you so. Government saddled us with this system we didn't really want or believe in." So much for democratic accountability and common sense!

New Labour, in its anxiety to jettison all appearance of socialism, has lost its marbles. What more can one say?
John Stone
Thames Ditton, Surrey

 There should be compromise in negotiations; John Prescott is not losing, Ken Livingstone is not winning. The result of their decisions will be the win-win we all need for a better transport system in the city: they are both winners.
Paul Bonett
Brighton
PaulB@bee1.fsnet.co.uk

 All that has been gained as a result of the recent tube talks is that we will now have a unified management structure. The central and most fundamental issue has not changed. The funding by PPP is to go ahead with only slight modifications. There will be no bond issue for the modernisation which would save billions over PPP. So the core argument is still valid and there is no victory yet for anyone.
Brian Lake
Deal, Kent
brian.lake1@virgin.net

 As a Labour party member, I have just received the party's booklet The Choices for Britain. Choice three is: "Investment in public services v cuts and privatisation". I think this means privatisation is a Tory choice and a bad thing.
Rob Wall
Bedford

But the government has decided that PPP is best. Experience with the railways has demonstrated that differentiated management and objectives has drastically failed to meet any of these criteria. But the government has decided that PPP is best. Ken Livingstone brings in Bob Kiley to do for London what he successfully achieved in New York and Boston. But the government has decided that PPP is best. Londoners don't want it. Underground staff don't want it. But the government has decided that PPP is best. The government will sign up to the deal and then pass the buck to Livingstone. When things go wrong, they will say the underground is his responsibility. And the mayor will say: "We told you so. Government saddled us with this system we didn't really want or believe in." So much for democratic accountability and common sense! New Labour, in its anxiety to jettison all appearance of socialism, has lost its marbles. What more can one say? John Stone Thames Ditton, Surrey  There should be compromise in negotiations; John Prescott is not losing, Ken Livingstone is not winning. The result of their decisions will be the win-win we all need for a better transport system in the city: they are both winners. Paul Bonett Brighton PaulB@bee1.fsnet.co.uk  All that has been gained as a result of the recent tube talks is that we will now have a unified management structure. The central and most fundamental issue has not changed. The funding by PPP is to go ahead with only slight modifications. There will be no bond issue for the modernisation which would save billions over PPP. So the core argument is still valid and there is no victory yet for anyone. Brian Lake Deal, Kent brian.lake1@virgin.net  As a Labour party member, I have just received the party's booklet The Choices for Britain. Choice three is: "Investment in public services v cuts and privatisation". I think this means privatisation is a Tory choice and a bad thing. Rob Wall Bedford

fields.headline: No credit
fields.trailText: The analogy John O'Farrell draws between high street banks and the World Bank (Don't bank on it, February 3) is misplaced. The World Bank is not a bank at all.
fields.body:
The analogy John O'Farrell draws between high street banks and the World Bank (Don't bank on it, February 3) is misplaced. The World Bank is not a bank at all. Its highly paid and untaxed officers face no risks on the loans they peddle; they can dispense shaky advice to their customers without being held accountable.

My own bank, in common with the World Bank, devotes a significant proportion of its resources to trying to make people think it gives a damn about anything apart from its own self-interest. The depressing fact is that they seem to succeed.
Perran Penrose
Liskeard, Cornwall
perran@penquite.com

fields.headline: Seats in the sunshine
fields.trailText: £40 for 90 minutes of football (Letters, February 3)?
fields.body:
£40 for 90 minutes of football (Letters, February 3)? For an initial outlay of £20 (child's season ticket) my dad and I can go to Durham County Cricket Club, sit in the seats of our choice, get a suntan and watch a full day's sport at an average cost of £15 a match - dad's ticket, travel, scorecard, sandwiches - and still have change for a bag of chips on the way home.

 In advocating an honour for John Profumo to acknowledge his good works (?) over the past 40 years (Leader, February 2), you appear to have overlooked the fact that he was awarded a CBE in 1975 for charitable services.
Peter Barnes
Milton Keynes

 Presumably, with their new-found social conscience, hunt supporters all over the country will be flocking to the steelworkers' cause...
Ian Wilson

fields.headline: Mandelson's memory test
fields.trailText: You quote Peter Mandelson (Scargill to take on Mandelson, February 3) as claiming that "Arthur Scargill is the man who destroyed the coal industry and betrayed every man and woman in Britain in the process". Shouldn't he have learned by now that he can't rewrite history with another vacuous sound bite?
fields.body:
You quote Peter Mandelson (Scargill to take on Mandelson, February 3) as claiming that "Arthur Scargill is the man who destroyed the coal industry and betrayed every man and woman in Britain in the process". Shouldn't he have learned by now that he can't rewrite history with another vacuous sound bite?

In the last 16 years many facts have emerged to disprove the Tories' concerted campaign of disinformation and outright lies, but for the sake of brevity two facts should suffice. First, throughout the strike, the NUM president represented the democratic decisions of the union members who elected him. And second "the Ridley plan" has been proven as a secret and carefully coordinated strategy to destroy the coal industry, initiated long before the NUM responded with industrial action.

There are probably a few members of the parliamentary Labour party who'd be better able to talk to Peter Mandelson about "betrayal". But unless the national Labour party publicly dissociates itself from his comment, I'm sure many of the millions who supported the miners in 84-85 will see this as one betrayal too many. Living as I do in the marginal constituency of Enfield Southgate, unless I am assured otherwise, I will no longer vote for a party which supports such an outrageous view of a struggle I am proud to have been part of.
Anne Thomas
Former chair, Enfield Miners' Support Group anne.thomas@blueyonder.co.uk

 So Peter Mandelson will fight the election by championing "the achievements of the most successful Labour government in history".

Has he forgotten Attlee's postwar Labour government, which: a) recovered from a dreadful war; b) set up the NHS; c) found state money to abolish secondary school fees and raise the school leaving age; d) saved the railways and coal mines from collapse by investing public money when private money was withheld; e) built the Royal Festival Hall with public money (compare with the dome); f) commissioned Britten to write Billy Budd; and much more.

The memory of Mandelson, grandson of Herbert Morrison, shows no sign of improving.
Ron Wallace
Hitchin, Herts

 Most of us enjoy a good conspiracy theory and the Hinduja affair is generating its fair share (Was there a plot to get rid of Mandelson?, February 2). To add to such theories, in whose interest is it to cast aspersions on Sir Richard Wilson, head of the civil service and cabinet secretary, who is the one person in this affair unable to answer back ?

Reportedly Sir Richard was asked by the prime minister to ascertain what was known at that point about the now infamous phone call. I don't know whether or not this is true, but whatever the case it was for the prime minister to determine any further action. Sir Richard has always been a staunch and vocal advocate of civil service impartiality and would have undertaken this task, as he does any other, within that framework.

We will all hopefully be wiser once Sir Anthony Hammond has reported. In the meantime, the government should now accept the recommendation of July 2000 from Lord Neill that the prime minister should become the ultimate judge of the requirements of the ministerial code instead of prevaricating as it did in its response last year. This would be helpful, not only to the government but to senior civil servants.
Jonathan Baume
General secretary, Association of First Division Civil Servants

fields.headline: Vocational guidance
fields.trailText: Much spin is being put on the teachers' pay increase (Teachers label 3.7% pay rise inadequate, February 3). In my case, it amounts to £1,841 a year.
fields.body:
Much spin is being put on the teachers' pay increase (Teachers label 3.7% pay rise inadequate, February 3). What the public has not been told is that under new regulations, governing bodies are removing recruitment and retention allowances from thousands of teachers in the capital as from March 31. In my case, it amounts to £1,841 a year.

I calculate that I will gain £684 via the paltry increase in the London allowance and £1,019 as a result of the 3.5% increase. As with many other teachers, my annual pay packet will actually be depleted by about £137.
Ray Sirotkin
London
ray@lta.demon.co.uk

 Your leader (February 3) rightly said, "Full professional status must be restored." However, professionalism is not only about salaries, and certainly not about limiting working hours, as one union claimed.

Two recent articles in Guardian Education (I quit, January 9, and Heads will roll, January 23) clearly indicated that what prevents teachers feeling that they are professionals is a lack of "scope for creativity" or of "room for using initiative".

Until the government stops bombarding schools with decisions about what they teach, and when and how they teach it, teachers will continue to find that no professional judgment is called for, and one of the main reasons for them taking up their vocation will be missing.
David Fielker
London
david@lecture.demon.co.uk

 Your leader manages to discuss (and commend) the pay award, without any mention of conditions of service. Most teachers will tell you that it's not primarily pay levels which produce the widespread disenchantment, the low morale and the consequent shortages; it's the long hours, and the ever more prescriptive government controls (to say nothing of the authoritarian inspection regime).

If the government was serious about recruiting and retaining teachers, it would be looking to restore their professionalism, by giving them back some control over what they do. Will it do this?
Alan Robinson
Griffydam,Leicestershire

 I am a newly qualified teacher in inner London. Despite the pay increase in April, I cannot afford a first home, let alone a second one (1m Britons own second homes, February 3). A one-bedroom shoe box of my own would be a luxury.
Emma Grove
Upminster, Essex
emma.grove@ukgateway.net

webTitle: Michele Hanson: A dog for all seasons

fields.headline: A dog for all seasons
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson: Rosemary's heavenly new flat has one drawback. A large basset hound lives upstairs, which would be fine, except that it lives mainly alone, rarely goes out, shits on the floor and barks loudly and often.
fields.body:
Rosemary's heavenly new flat has one drawback. A large basset hound lives upstairs, which would be fine, except that it lives mainly alone, rarely goes out, shits on the floor and barks loudly and often.

Its owner bought it because a big, wrinkly dog looks so darling and squidgy as a puppy, but she hasn't quite got the hang of looking after it. Meanwhile the dog and Rosemary's neighbours are nearing meltdown.

This is the third large dog in our immediate neighbourhood, to my knowledge, that is stuck indoors. It is all the rage. Buy a big, wrinkly, butch dog, cram it into a poky flat and watch it grow fat and deranged. Outside the house I meet an obese boxer being hauled along. It never goes to parks. "It's eight," the owner says. "It doesn't need to any more."

Just opposite the park, I see another trapped boxer staring miserably out of its front window at the lovely green grass across the road. Neighbourhood spies tell me that on lucky days it is allowed to throw itself about the back yard. I'm keen to give the owners a kicking, but obviously I mustn't. All I can do is take their dog for a walkie when I'm passing.

This is a high-risk activity. I only dare do it occasionally. The dog is raving mad to get out and play with my dog, murder any other passing dogs and pounce on children. I need two assistants to guard the park gates and warn the public. Soon this dog will be too mad to go out at all. A tragic story.

I suspect only the young buy huge dogs for odd personal reasons and keep them stuck indoors. The elderly would never do such a thing. Last week Sylvia came trudging over the icy Heath, in biting winds and drenching rain, with asthma and a hacking cough, because her large dog must have its daily walkie. And she is 80 years old. She is not the only pensioner staggering about with a dog. There are hordes of us, wheezing, limping and struggling around in all weathers.

For those who foolishly refuse to follow our example, here is a cautionary tale. In New York in the 60s, two large dogs kept in an apartment devoured their owner for breakfast. Walking is good for the dog and you.

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: * Not a day goes by when WPM is not mithered by the Post Office. Last week it was those self-adhesive stamps, on Tuesday it was that parcel of rancid Cornish pasties she had forgotten to collect. Now they tell her that in merely licking a stamp one consumes a whacking 5.9 calories.
fields.body:
* Not a day goes by when WPM is not mithered by the Post Office. Last week it was those self-adhesive stamps, on Tuesday it was that parcel of rancid Cornish pasties she had forgotten to collect. Now they tell her that in merely licking a stamp one consumes a whacking 5.9 calories.

"Licking 127 stamps is the same as eating a chicken pie with mashed potato and baked beans," said the Mirror. Which of course isn't strictly true. Otherwise the chicken pie industry would surely be thrown into chaos. However it is nice to learn that the considerable girth amassed over the festive season had less to do with afternoons spent watching It's A Wonderful Life while shovelling Wagon Wheels into my gob, and more to do with the tedious hours I passed slurping stamps for the boss's Yuletide greetings. Needless to say, WPM has been licking nothing but the second-class variety all week. Surelyone gets fewer calories for 19 pence?

*And there's more. Post Office Travel Services (really, I should get a court order out on these people) contacted WPM to ask whether she had ever suffered from Wind Up, Wind Down Syndrome. Nothing that Setler's Tums can't handle, she said, with a cheeky wink (never one to miss a cheap gag).

Our friends at the PO were not amused. What they were actually talking about was their shiny new survey which has exposed the shocking truth that more than half of UK workers leave less than 24 hours to prepare for their holiday. They are, apparently, so stressed by their pre- holiday frenzy that they waste half their vacation "unwinding", rather than "relaxing", the fools.

WPM herself remains somewhat perplexed by the question: "What is the difference between "unwinding" and "relaxing"?" And furthermore: "Do Post Office Travel Services extend to licking the stamps for my postcards in order that WPM might look splendid in my bikini?"

*Perhaps the answer to all our holiday woes (except the one about how to keep sand out of your pants) may be found at Business Travel 2001, an exciting travel fair which sadly chose not to make any kind of Space Odyssey-type joke in its marketing bumph.

There will be around 200 stands with representatives from major travel sectors, just raring to assist anyone who is in charge of company travel. The event runs from February 6-8, admission is £20. £30 will buy you a seminar ticket.

Call 020 8710 2144 for ticket details. Business Travel 2001 will be held at the National Hall, Olympia, London.

*"I am not a number" is the mantra WPM so often chants to herself as she makes her morning rush-hour trek to the office. Not only do I find that this almost guarantees extra space on the number 45 bus (after all, who wants to sit next to the mumbling girl in the corner?), but it also reminds me that I am more than just part of The Office Machine.

But it seems that WPM is wrong, for our website of the week is ContactDetails.com, which actively encourages us to register for a CD-ID which will make us forever traceable. This is allegedly perfect for companies or individuals keen to maintain up-to-date contact information on members, colleagues, friends and contacts and will be extremely useful to the recruitment and admin sector. The service is especially useful for temps who may frequently be job-hopping, and indeed for those who are forever changing address, mobile phone number or email address, the fickle little beggars. You know who you are.

*It must be a matter of days since WPM last criticised the couch-potato tendencies of the average office worker. However, it seems her words fell on deaf ears. News reaches WPM's paper-loaded corner of the world that PAs and admin staff are now looking for jobs from the comfort of their couch. Apparently agencies are, like, sooo last millennium. During a six-week period of tracking interactive TV, 48,000 PAs looked on Sky, NTL, Telewest and ONdigital for jobs, making this the second most popular searched-for role. Interestingly, though, the most searched for role was in the building and construction industry. Let this be a lesson to you laggards. Spend too much more time on the sofa, and you'll end up will a builder's bum and tum. Not helped, of course, by the need to lick stamps for all those job applications.

fields.headline: The inside track:
fields.standfirst: Working in politics
fields.trailText: Working in politics
fields.body:
A new breed of secretary emerged in the House of Commons following Labour's election in 1997. The role became more political, involving research and campaigning. This was no sinister conspiracy to set the party stamp on Westminster - merely an attempt to make a very tedious job more interesting.

Odd as it may seem, the old school of Commons secretaries are not that interested in politics. They will vote in elections for the party of the MP they work for, but they do so out of loyalty as much as conviction.

The job itself is hard. Offices at Westminster are uncomfortable and cramped and are not a place for tech-heads. They never really came to terms with the fax, and have been slow to embrace email. The work of the secretary involves letters, and more letters: letters from constituents aggrieved at the failure to obtain planning permission for their gazebos, or angry about the euro, plus a sprinkling who've been abducted by aliens. All must be replied to.

The money is not fantastic. The MP's secretarial allowance of £51,572 usually pays at least two secretaries, and perhaps the travel expenses of unpaid researchers. "I could earn far more in the private sector," the secretary of a shadow cabinet minster once told me. But she works for her husband. Such partnerships are not unusual.

Old-school secretaries have usually been recruited by word of mouth, and go from one MP to another as retirements and lost elections dictate. This is an enclosed world, where reptutations are built up, and there is some competition when an assistant becomes available. After Michael Portillo lost his seat in 1997, his secretary found a new job in the Commons within hours rather than days.

The Commons secretary is the link to the constituency, the local party, the local people and their problems. A secretary who knows the constituency well is probably worth several thousand votes, significant in a marginal. In a few months we will see how the new breed have coped.

After Michael Portillo lost his seat in 1997, his secretary found a new job in the Commons within hours rather than days. The Commons secretary is the link to the constituency, the local party, the local people and their problems. A secretary who knows the constituency well is probably worth several thousand votes, significant in a marginal. In a few months we will see how the new breed have coped.

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 19. Leading a team
fields.trailText: 19. Leading a team
fields.body:
It's not unusual for PAs and office administrators to lead project teams. The challenge is not only to direct the project, but also to ensure a happy, productive team. Support group European Management Assistants has some excellent advice for those leading from the front: a team is made up of individuals, so treat them as such. Find out what motivates them (we're all different) and - most importantly - don't have favourites. That's the quickest way to destroy a team.

* Be sure your team knows exactly what the plan is. Give them definite timescales and be clear about your expectations. Woolly requests and "as soon as possible" deadlines will frustrate and confuse them.

* Delegate. What's the point of having a team if you don't let them get involved? Team members need to contribute and grow in responsibility.

* Be honest. Bring issues out into the open and cultivate an air of trust. Never try to manipulate the team. They're on your side - work with them.

* Loyalty is very important. Let them take credit for their work, praise them to senior staff, and stand up for them at all times. When they see your loyalty to them, they will return it.

* Don't keep information to yourself in the belief that it makes you more important. Giving it to others makes your team stronger and more effective - and the credit for a good job will go to all of you.

*Remember that you are the team's role model, and they will follow your behaviour. If you're consistently late or slapdash, they will be too.

* Give them regular feedback about their progress. It helps to keep their motivation up. Always thank team members for their work and efforts.

* Don't assume that because you're the leader, you should necessarily be best at everything. Welcome feedback and ideas from the group. Don't feel threatened when someone comes up with a brilliant idea - seize it and run with it. Burying it because you didn't think of it is a dangerous game and will ensure no one ever offers another idea.

* It's not easy to build a group of individuals into a team, but when it works it's extremely motivating for all concerned. It's a great way for PAs to demonstrate a different set of skills, and does wonders for your image within the organisation.

 By Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

webTitle: Diane Taylor talks to one of David Mulcahy's victims.

fields.headline: 'When the woman in the witness box began to cry, I cried too'
fields.standfirst: On Friday, David Mulcahy was found guilty of raping and murdering three women, and attacking 12 others. Police believe he may be Britain's worst serial rapist.  Diane Taylor talks to one of his victims
fields.trailText: On Friday, David Mulcahy was found guilty of raping and murdering three women, and attacking 12 others. Police believe he may be Britain's worst serial rapist. Diane Taylor talks to one of his victims.
fields.body:
Court number one at the Old Bailey is crowded. The trial of David Mulcahy for multiple rapes and murders is drawing to a close. The crimes of which this man has been accused are so grotesque that members of the jury have been visibly shaken by the details. The air prickles with anticipation about the imminent verdict.

In the public gallery, Mulcahy's friends and foes alike are breathing a little faster. He looks relaxed in the dock, scribbling furiously in an A4 notebook. With his glossy, mousy hair neatly cut, his cheap grey suit and bland face, he could easily be a middle manager from M&S.

In one corner of the gallery, a woman fixes the defendant with a stare. Jess (not her real name) is writing too. She is deeply absorbed in the trial because Mulcahy is the man to whom she says she lost her life.

Mulcahy's friend John Duffy was jailed for murder in 1988. Ten years later, he confessed to other, similar offences and implicated his old schoolfriend in many of them. On Friday, Mulcahy was given three life sentences for murdering Alison Day, 19, from east London, Dutch schoolgirl Maartje Tamboezer, 15, in Horsley, Surrey and Anne Lock, 29, at Brookmans Park, Hertfordshire. He was also convicted of seven rapes and five attempted rapes, in what was called the worst series of rapes and murders this country has ever witnessed.

Jess was raped by Mulcahy in 1983, slap bang in the middle of a rape spree the men described as "going out hunting". Mulcahy has not been charged with raping Jess, although she went straight to the police afterwards. A police doctor collected forensic evidence and prescribed her the morning after pill, then she heard nothing. Four years later, police invited her to an identity parade where she picked out Mulcahy - but again she heard nothing.

When the case was reopened in 1998 following Duffy's confession, Jess thought the details of the crime against her would at last be aired in court. But in July the Crown Prosecution Service told her that in her case there was insufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction. The forensic evidence from the night of the rape had not been passed on by the police. So Jess sat discreetly in the public gallery, conducting her own private cross-examination of Mulcahy.

"At first I was terribly nervous about seeing him and the first time he made eye contact, I just looked away. But I became bolder and started to stare him out. When he was questioned about identity parades, I stared really hard at him. He fumbled a bit and said that nothing significant had emerged.

"So many details of the rapes were identical to mine. When the woman in the witness box began to cry, I cried too, because I felt totally empathetic with her, even physically. The two men burned some of the women after they had killed them and soon after the jury were shown forensic evidence of charred limbs, I came out in a rash. When it came to the evidence about the murders and the box the rape victims had testified in was empty, I felt desperately sad."

It was in July 1983 that Jess was raped. She was a gifted arts student about to complete her university degree. She was walking briskly down a south London street at around 11pm on her way to visit her boyfriend when a man asked her the time. Twenty yards further down the road, another man grabbed her from behind, placed his arm around her neck and held a knife to her back.

In a state of terror, she was dragged off the road and down on to a piece of land next to railway sidings. "He held me against a wall, blocking me with his body. My attention was focused on the knife and all I could think of was that I was going to die. The attack was obviously premeditated and I had a sense of leaving my body. In a situation like that you can't scream and you are immobilised because your body is flooded with adrenalin."

Instinct told her to keep talking to the man. He said to her: "My name is Dave and I've never touched a woman before" - the same eerie remark he made to other victims. A kind of surreal small talk was established between them and at last Mulcahy loosened his grip. At this point Jess tried to escape but he came after her, more aggressive than before, and dragged her along to another piece of ground before swiftly, angrily, raping her.

Like Jess, many of the victims were dragged along the ground during the men's "hunting" session, in a sick parody of cavemen trapping their prey.

"I know feminists say rape is about power and not about sex," Jess says, "but I think that's simplistic because these men objectified everything and chose their victims very carefully. And it's rubbish to say women have fantasies about rape. There was nothing erotic about that podgy, thick, dirty, beer-smelling man forcing himself on me."

After going to the police, Jess decided she just had to get on with her life. "I kept telling myself that I hadn't been murdered, I hadn't been mutilated, and I should just think of the whole thing as a one-night stand. I remember telling a friend about it soon afterwards in a very upbeat way, insisting chirpily that I wasn't going to be a victim."

In terms of recovery, that was the worst possible thing to do. "I had some very damaging therapy sessions, first with a woman who gave me internal examinations to see if I had a phobia about having things stuck up my vagina, then with a psychologist who advised me to go out and have lots of flings and take risks with sex. I now know that what I should have had was a period of bereavement, with no sex at all."

Jess has discovered more helpful therapies since her initial disastrous experiences and some healing has taken place, but she still feels unable to get emotionally or physically close to a man, and even has avoidance strategies to stop herself getting too close to friends, family or colleagues. She is now a successful professional but says: "I feel maybe I would have been more successful if it hadn't been for the rape. Somehow it has held me back from going after the things I want in my career. I'm more inclined to do what others want me to do."

It is almost as if her innermost energy is being perpetually sapped by the attack. "If a friend phones me, I don't always return the call. I can't manage that leap of energy to make a connection with people. If I go to a party, I'm happy to dance but I don't want to talk to people I don't know. In some way all this has affected my language, too - at times I just lose words. And if I come across someone I feel is more powerful than me, I can't bear to be in the same room as them."

Her outwardly confident, cheerful persona belies the inner desolation. "For a while I had terrible dreams about half-dead, rotting animals. A friend of mine who had also been raped [by another man] had almost identical dreams."

But Jess doesn't want revenge on the man who raped her. "I feel grief rather than anger, grief for the loss of my own life, for the loss of the other victims' lives and for the outcome for the rapists. What a mess for all of us who have lost our lives.

"Even in the beginning I didn't really feel anger because I could see that this man was in a disturbed state. I have wept a lot, but particularly hearing the details of deaths and mutilations in the trial, the whole thing feels almost beyond anger. Being raped means the end of your life as you knew it before. From that moment on, things are radically different and part of that is about a lost innocence. I think that's a feeling all women who have been raped share."

She has applied to interview Duffy and Mulcahy in jail; she wants to hear them talk about the rapes and the murders to make them real. "I need to have that sense that these events really happened, rather than having them just a suppressed memory. Watching Duffy give evidence and confess to everything in court, I believe he really has changed. He seems to be utterly truthful and no longer has anything to lose."

At one point, Jess's job took her inside a category A jail to work with violent offenders, including rapists. "I stood up in front of them and said: 'I'm a rape victim and I believe in forgiveness.' One of the men stood up and said: 'I want to say that I know I did wrong and I am sorry, I regret it and I hope I never do wrong again.' One by one, all the other men stood up, too, in a strange kind of solidarity. The feeling was incredible. All of them were able to be honest about themselves in a way you only can when you have gone beyond ego. These men need to be taken out of circulation but a therapeutic environment is what they need to heal so that we, their victims, can heal too."

fields.headline: Sex sells
fields.standfirst: And nowhere is that more true than on TV. Now, Channel 4 is trying to both fulfil its minority remit and pull in ratings with a programme about the Kama Sutra
fields.trailText: And nowhere is that more true than on TV. Now, Channel 4 is trying to both fulfil its minority remit and pull in ratings with a programme about the Kama Sutra
fields.body:
In Tom Stoppard's play, Artist Descending A Staircase, a sculptor agonises about how to justify a career as an artist when there are millions starving around the world. He eventually solves this moral quandary by creating edible art.

The chief executive of Channel 4, Michael Jackson, faces a similar dilemma. How does he balance the stuff the network was set up to do - such as ethnic programmes - with the kind of thing that brings the ratings in - documentaries about sex? This tension between the sleazy and the serious has increased since Channel 4 was required to sell its own advertising, necessarily becoming more commercial. This week, Jackson comes up with the perfect solution, as elegant in its way as culinary sculptures: a documentary series about ethnic sex.

Position Impossible (Wednesday, 9pm, Channel 4) is a three-part documentary about the Kama Sutra. The series is a perfect example of Channel 4 in the position it now adopts to give pleasure: The Clown Who Swallowed A Thinker. On Jeremy Isaacs's Channel 4, this series would have been called The Pleasures Of The Gods, a buy-in from Indian TV, hosted by an unknown Asian sexologist. On Michael Grade's Channel 4, it would have been called The Kama Sutra, presented by Dr Raj Persaud, and the Daily Mail would have called for the series to be banned. On Michael Jackson's Channel 4, its name plays with the title of a Tom Cruise movie, the frontman is the comedian Sanjeev Bhaskar from Goodness Gracious Me, and the Daily Mail last week called Channel 4 the "station of the thinking middle-classes". Styles and times change.

But the history of television can no more be reversed than virginity may be reclaimed. Most resembling a Michael Palin travelogue with a dirty mind, Position Impossible is about as good as populist documentary can be.

The use of comedians to front factual films - the type of series in which Leslie Ash swims with whales - has been one of the most depressing developments in television. The pert have become more important than the expert. If there's ever again a history of classical music on TV, it will be called Menuhin Behaving Badly and be presented by Martin Clunes.

Sanjeev Bhaskar, though, brings the practice into good repute. Intelligent and Indian, he has at least two qualifications which many of his notional rivals to host the show do not. And, crucially, his night job is incorporated into the structure. The narration - which would normally be voiceover - is here delivered as a stand-up routine. This works, because sex is a frequent subject for comedians and because, with commendable humility, it removes any possible suggestion that Bhaskhar might think he's James Cameron.

Admittedly, those worried about Channel 4's fulfilment of its remit to make alternative and minority programmes may fret when this investigation of eastern culture by a prominent Indian begins in Penzance.

Bhaskhar is there to meet a teacher of tantric sex. This practice - in which male orgasm is subject to an almost Virgin Trains-type delay - was made famous in the west by the pop star Sting, who claimed in interviews to keep the wife waiting five hours. Mocked by the press and presumably hassled by groupies waving stop-watches, he later joked on an American talk show that the five hours included a movie and a meal.

John, the Penzance instructor in tantric sex, is, appropriately, a shaggy man, who takes Bhaskar to see a phallic stone set in the Cornish landscape. John embraces the granite prick before his assistant, Hannah, lies beneath it with her legs spread. She explains that she is taking "the male energy of the stone into my inner flute". Around the country, men who were at school with Hannah will be regretting their rejection of her invitation to come around for some music practice. John explains that semen is "a libation offered to the gods". This is presumably the kind of thing that President Clinton discussed with his spiritual advisor, Reverend Jesse Jackson.

If the calculation was that the viewers needed an English setting to draw them into an Indian series, then this tactic is not only depressing but undermined by the fact that the Eastern sequences are far superior. At the Indian holy city of Varanasi, Bhaskar begins a serious reflection on the history of attitudes to sex. How was it that India created a rare religion in which sex was not a sin and the only transgression was to give insufficient pleasure? He even manages to treat the Kama Sutra as literature rather than sniggering: "It's the poet in him who has the last word when it comes to love", he says of the mysterious fourth-century author.

Frequently sharp - Bhaskar complains about the "cultural appropriation" of the Penzance tantrics who greet each other with a namaste but couldn't speak another word of the language - Position Impossible is set to make pillow talk better informed. For example, the one in which the woman does the splits is inspired by the god Vishnu, who walked across the world in three giant strides. And the explanation that people in Indian erotic engravings are not standing on their heads - they are lying on the floor, but viewed from above as if by an overhead camera - may reduce the pressure on the orthopaedic departments of the NHS.

 Position Impossible, Wednesday, 9pm, C4

fields.headline: Wonders and blunders
fields.standfirst: 2: Antony Gormley
fields.trailText: 2: Antony Gormley
fields.body:
Wonder: National Theatre
Blunder: Charing Cross Station
The National Theatre, which I pass every day on my way to the studio, remains an extraordinarily uncompromising presence along the riverside. Denys Lasdun's fantastic use of raw concrete manages to balance a delicate and precise surface with strength of volume and mass. At night the transparency of the building and the way its occupants are visible from the riverside is absolutely beautiful. I know there is criticism of the circulation but the drama of the balconies in relation to the full height of the glazed hallway is very exciting.

I see it as an important incident in the narrative of buildings on the South Bank: a distinct modernist moment that manages to be bold and discreet in equal measure. It remains one of the best arguments for the use of concrete for architecture in the northern hemisphere, allowing through its careful mixture of white and portland cement a rare luminosity which has stood the test of time. I use a similar mix in my concrete sculptures, which owe a lot to the inspiration that the National Theatre has given me.

If you stand on Waterloo Bridge it is possible to see both the National Theatre and Charing Cross Station, my least favourite building, at the same time. Terry Farrell's rebuilding of the station shows all the problems of postmodern London architecture during the 1980s building boom. I have counted over 10 different wall finishes or surface claddings on the building, from different stones and steels to mirror and glass. It is as if the station was built as a lexicon of ways to clad a steel frame building. It has an Odeon-style glitz which is all about surface and nothing about structure. The structural relevance of the arch, which is so important in Kings Cross station, is here entirely rhetorical. There is no way in which the external forms connect with the internal experience - I find it confused and confusing.

fields.headline: Wembley to stay for now
fields.trailText: Wembley stadium will not be demolished until funding for the new national stadium is definitely in place, according to Sir Rodney Walker.
fields.body:
Wembley stadium will not be demolished until funding for the new national stadium is definitely in place, according to Sir Rodney Walker.

Walker, chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited since his predecessor Ken Bates failed to secure the £410m backing required last year, hopes to secure funding from the City within two months so that work can begin in May.

"Under the terms of the lottery funding agreement with Sport England, they have title over the existing stadium to secure their £106m and until such time that I can demonstrate that the new stadium will be built, I simply do not have the right to begin demolishing the [old] stadium," he said.

Stan Collymore's debut as a second-half substitute for Real Oviedo ended in a 1-0 defeat at Las Palmas.

Celtic's Henrik Larsson scored a hat-trick in his team's 3-0 win at Hearts to make it 35 for the season and re-open a nine-point gap over Rangers, whom they meet at Parkhead next Sunday.

England's coach Sven-Goran Eriksson appeared on BBC TV yesterday and said that he will not tolerate a drinking culture among his players.

webTitle: Halifax comes to the rescue of Equitable policyholders

fields.headline: Halifax comes to the rescue of Equitable policyholders
fields.standfirst:
£1bn bailout deal clinched as bidding war breaks out

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A £1bn rescue deal for Equitable Life was clinched last night in a move that could rectify the plight of its 1m beleaguered policyholders.
fields.body:
A £1bn rescue deal for Equitable Life was clinched last night in a move that could rectify the plight of its 1m beleaguered policyholders.

Halifax, the former building society, stepped in to save the country's oldest mutual insurer even though a number of previous bidders had walked away, deterred by a £1.5bn deal to restore the status of 90,000 guaranteed annuity policy holders.

Equitable will today announce a proposal aimed at resolving the situation for these policyholders and put a lid on the liabilities that Equitable faces.

The deal was clinched despite the eleventh-hour intervention by GE Capital, the financial services arm of General Electric of the United States. It was expected to try to meet the management of Equitable Life this morning in an attempt to get a fair hearing for its £400m offer.

Even under the Halifax deal, the Equitable will continue to exist as a mutual insurer because it will retain the liabilities of the guaranteed annuities. Policyholders will be consulted on the proposals and will then have to vote on the deal before it is finalised.

Under the terms of the scheme thrashed out last night, Halifax will enter a two-legged agreement with Equitable to inject a total of £1bn into the crucial fund that pays out to policyholders.

The first payment of £500m will cover the cost of Equitable's £30bn fund management arm, its administration and highly regarded sales force. The next £500m will be paid in stages, provided Equitable is able to find a way to cap its liabilities to the guaranteed annuity policyholders.

Halifax's package could improve the position of the 200-year-old institution's policyholders who were warned in December that their future returns could be substantially lower as a result of a ruling last summer by the law lords that it had treated holders of guaranteed annuity policies unfairly by ignoring the guarantees and cutting their payouts.

This ruling prompted Equitable to put itself up for sale in July but it initially gave up on the auction in December when Prudential, the last remaining bidder, walked away.

Hopes of a sale were revived early this year, however, when the financial services authority, the City regulator, started to act as an intermediary and explored ways to cap the liabilities owed to the guaranteed annuity policyholders.

Under the Halifax deal, those policyholders will have to agree to one-off payments from the £1.5bn pool of cash already set aside by Equitable. Some of them could receive hundreds of thousands of pounds.

All of the 1m Equitable policyholders could find their position restored by the money injected, which would shore up the fund.

This would then be managed by Clerical Medical, the Halifax's fund management arm.

It is hoped that Clerical Medical's fund managers will not need to engage in the emergency policy adopted by Equitable, to sell its equities and buy bonds, which is expected to damage the long-term performance of the fund.

It was not clear last night what could be done for the thousands of policyholders who decided to pay the 10% penalty to move their policy to another insurer but who now might prefer the Halifax outcome.

Equitable said in a statement that the sales process had "one purpose and one purpose only - to generate value for policyholders now and in the future".

Halifax plans to employ Equitable's sales staff but will not try to maintain the brand.
