fields.headline: A rough reception
fields.standfirst:
Secretaries and front desk staff are increasingly in danger of attack from angry clients. Kate Hilpern reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Secretaries and front desk staff are increasingly in danger of attack from angry clients. Kate Hilpern reports
fields.body:
Last week's news that violence and abuse against NHS staff has risen by a fifth in 12 months made shocking reading. "There is no doubt that many frontline staff continue to face a serious risk of being physically assaulted and/or verbally abused while serving the public," said the study's author, Adam Geldman. But their experience of a dangerous workplace is part of a much bigger picture, with secretaries and receptionists particularly at risk.

"My two fellow receptionists and I are increasingly on the receiving end of swearing, spitting and threats. Once, we even had a toilet and basin hurled across the room by a family who were fed up of not being given a new one," says 35-year-old Emma, who works for the housing department of a local council. She has become so used to such scenes that she accepts it as "part of the job".

"As receptionists, we are not only the first point of contact for clients, but in their eyes, we represent our employer," she explains. "So if they're feeling angry or aggressive at the council, it's us they tend to pick on. Sometimes, their aggression has been brewing for months and the moment we ask, 'How can I help you?' it all floods out."

According to the TUC report Violent Times, one in five workers is subjected to such violent attacks and verbal abuse every year. Meanwhile, the latest British Crime Survey reports 1.2m incidents of work-related violence annually. "Just as the most common victims include support staff - rather than those working with obviously dangerous people - the most common work environments in which assaults happen aren't obviously dangerous either. Schools, libraries and councils have all become higher risk areas than ever before," says Sarah Simpson, training director for the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, the charity for personal safety, named after the young estate agent who disappeared without a trace in the course of her work.

"Statistics show that public-sector workers are most at risk, since they offer aid to people under particular emotional strain," says Tom Mellish of the TUC. But incidents of workplace violence are also occurring more frequently in the private sector - especially in those companies that offer a service.

Consider Susan Fox, a 25-year-old PA at an insurance firm. She was threatened by a client who refused to wait until the managing director had finished his telephone call. "He shouted at me, came very close to me and made signals with his hands as if he wanted to strangle me. It was terrifying. Thankfully, a colleague heard and came in, at which point the client stopped. But it took me several weeks to completely calm down from the incident."

The Health and Safety Commission (HSC), which has launched a new initiative to tackle the problem, defines workplace violence as any incident in which someone is assaulted, threatened or verbally abused in circumstances relating to their work. "Some people assume an incident only counts as violence at work if they wind up in hospital or at least black and blue. In reality, it encompasses a whole range of abuse, none of which is acceptable," explains a spokesperson. "This misunderstanding is one of the reasons we have started a three-year programme to raise awareness of the prevalence of workplace violence."

The millennial attitude of the "customer as king" is one of the reasons for the increase in incidents, according to Simpson. "The Customer's Charter, the Traveller's Charter, the Patient's Charter are all initiatives that make the public want a result and want it now. When that doesn't happen, they feel they have a right to become hostile," she explains. In addition, she believes life is more stressful. "Even getting to an office can be annoying. My journey in this morning involved late trains and battling through crowds. If you've already got an axe to grind at your destination, and then you have to face that kind of trip to get there, it can cause aggression."

The growth of office burglaries in broad daylight is also significant. With cutting-edge computer equipment becoming a regular feature of today's workplace, there's more to steal than there was a decade or two ago. Burglars pose as clients, enter the office and grab what they can. If you, as a receptionist, follow your instinct to try to stop them when you realise what's happening, you may find yourself on the receiving end of violence.

It doesn't help that many managers aren't even aware of their responsibilities. There are five pieces of legislation relevant to violence at work, including the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 which stipulates that managers have a duty to protect staff from danger "as far as is reasonably practicable".

"But many employers think health and safety has nothing to do with personal safety. A lot don't react until something terrible happens," says Simpson.

Tunbridge Wells borough council is a case in point. It wasn't until an incident in 1997 that it developed a detailed policy covering definitions of violence, security measures, the council's legal obligations, reporting procedures and support systems. "A member of the public entered the finance office, picked up the VDU screen and threw it across the room. No one was hurt, but it made us realise how inadequate our procedures were," explains a spokesperson.

In fact, the council had already installed panic buttons, but the victim had felt too scared to use it - something that the Suzy Lamplugh Trust claims is all too common. "If a secretary is not familiar with using it, it's not second nature. And in order to be an effective security measure, it must be second nature," says Simpson. A further problem is that if the panic button makes a noise, it can exacerbate the perpetrators' aggression. Likewise, if it doesn't make a sound, the victim can't be sure if it has worked. The solution, managers are increasingly realising, is a button that lights up when activated.

Other proactive measures that employers are taking include risk assessments. Mellish explains: "They ask what kind of incidents cause violence at work. Is the layout putting people at extra risk - for instance, by leaving receptionists working in a public area alone? If clients face lengthy waits, could the waiting area be made more comfortable? Is there a common element in the circumstances that give rise to violence and could that element be acted on? Is there a policy in place that encourages staff to report incidents of violence, so that security measures can be constantly evaluated?"

Particularly forward-thinking managers offer frontline staff training in how to recognise the signs of aggression and diffuse potentially dangerous situations. The way you sit, stand and relate to a person can, for instance, have an effect. Hands on the hips or fidgeting hands can be seen as confrontational - as can too much eye contact or moving closer to the person even if it's to put a hand on them in an attempt to calm them down. Staff are also taught that they have a right to walk away. At London Underground, frontline employees put up posters with the message, "Work without fear: Our staff are entitled to work without fear or intimidation."

But the reality remains that even the most sophisticated security policies and procedures for safety cannot guarantee that a violent incident will never occur. This, according to counsellor Thelma Williams, is why after-care - such as debriefing and trauma counselling - is as important as training. "Depression, fear, head-aches and flashbacks are typical responses to traumatic experiences. Very often, these responses resolve themselves in a few days, but when sufferers fail to acknowledge their emotions about the event, they can be heightened or prolonged. They may even lead to post-traumatic stress disorder," she says.

The solution is clear: a holistic way of managing violence in which all the company is involved. The alternative is potentially horrendous, as Nicola Fawssett's experience reveals. A 29-year-old receptionist at a local alcohol supplier, she was threatened at knifepoint four years ago. There had been few security measures in place and the only follow-up from her employer was a bouquet of flowers sent to her house. It was a further two years before she felt able to return to work.

Play it safe - stick to these rules

1. Be alert. Look confident and keep fit. Good posture, stamina and strength are an aid to self-protection.

2. Be aware. Trust your intuition. If you feel scared or uneasy, do not ignore the warning. Act on it.

3. Avoid risk. When going out from the workplace, leave written details of your movements and when you expect to be back.

4. Walk away. It is not weak to walk away from violence. Meeting aggression with aggression usually leads to confrontation.

5. Always report any incidents. No matter how trivial an event may seem to you, you should always report it. Failure to do so could put others at risk.

fields.headline: Breastplates, bikinis and blood
fields.standfirst:
Tantalus
The Lowry
Salford
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Tantalus
The Lowry
Salford
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Blood everywhere: encrusted on the hands of Agamemnon, reeking throughout the House of Atreus, but most of it in pools on the rehearsal room floor - for this is Tantalus, the barbaric tale of how the dynastic Hall twisted the knife into the prophet Barton, sacrificing one of the bard's plays so that the other nine might live and bludgeon audiences into cowed amazement.

The legend of this mega-production's gestation became as bitter as the blood-feud it depicts. John Barton's epic 10-play Trojan war cycle was stripped down for the sake of stageworthiness by his long-time friend and collaborator, Sir Peter Hall. Barton, outraged, stormed off the project, followed by two leading actors and a third of the directorial team, leaving matters in sole charge of the Halls, Sir Peter and his son Edward.

Only massive artistic and financial support from the Denver Center for the Performing Arts enabled the Royal Shakespeare Company to hoist the flailing behemoth to its feet in Colorado last autumn, with a crack Anglo-American cast.

At nine hours total playing time, Tantalus even sounds like a lewd activity for theatrical masochists. Over-ambitious? Over-long? British audiences can finally judge for themselves because at last it is over here.

Tantalus himself, the man punished with perpetual frustration for filching ambrosia from the gods, does not appear. But this is all part of Barton's grand design to sketch all the bits of mythology the ancients missed out. What Homer leaves unexplained, or whatever parts of the great tragedians' oeuvre have vanished forever, Barton boldly attempts to conjecture in this massive chthonic net, painstakingly stitched together from holes.

It all begins casually on a beach in Greece, where a group of bronzed, female holiday-makers are interrupted, as holiday-makers are, by an itinerant pedlar with a tray full of tat. This particular beach vendor, however, turns out to be Peleus, rogue king of Phthia and myth-monger to the gods, whose stories deflect the attention of these sun-worshippers towards a different and altogether more malevolent pantheon of deities.

This pleasingly scatological start determines the production's mix-and-match approach, which finds a place for breastplates and bikinis, declamatory speech and demotic interjection, tragic masks and waterproof mascara. The Halls' joint production is a thing of exquisite beauty: Dionysis Fotopoulos's design suspends the beach in a black, reflective void - as if the shifting sands of destiny were contained within a glittering, dark crystal. Such simplicity enables the action to unfold fluently, with a symmetry it is hard to believe Barton's original 10-play programme possessed.

Barton's essential point is that wars are complex phenomena of indeterminate cause and effect: "Much depends," declares Peleus, gnomically, "on the starting point." Barton delves further back than the familiar mythology usually allows, suggesting that the abduction of Helen was itself merely a tit-for-tat response to the Greeks seizure of the Trojan princess Hesione, and so forth down to the looming presence of Tantalus, whose indiscretion with the ambrosia began the whole sorry mess.

Only the use of masks remains a moot point. Greg Hicks, whose noble performance provides the production with its centre of gravity, flits effortlessly between the personae of the Greek leader Agamemnon, his cuckolded brother Menelaus and his Trojan opponent Priam: the conventions of the mask literally enabling him to become his own worst enemy.

Less certain is Peter Hall's avowed confidence in the mask as a precision lens which focuses attention on the language. Perhaps it is here that Hall, whatever the true nature of their dramaturgical disagreements, inadvertently does his estranged colleague the greater disservice: for Barton (a compelling story-teller and a sure-footed dramaturge) is not, alas, a particularly riveting poet. His ascetic free verse is rhetorical and expository but discomfortingly barren of metaphor or imagery: the line is often little more than an unornamented conveyor of meaning. Given that Tantalus purports to be the most tantalising story ever told, it is strange that the spoken word should prove to be its Achilles heel.

 Nottingham Theatre Royal February 14-24, then touring until May 19. RSC information line: 01789 403440.

The legend of this mega-production's gestation became as bitter as the blood-feud it depicts. John Barton's epic 10-play Trojan war cycle was stripped down for the sake of stageworthiness by his long-time friend and collaborator, Sir Peter Hall. Barton, outraged, stormed off the project, followed by two leading actors and a third of the directorial team, leaving matters in sole charge of the Halls, Sir Peter and his son Edward. Only massive artistic and financial support from the Denver Center for the Performing Arts enabled the Royal Shakespeare Company to hoist the flailing behemoth to its feet in Colorado last autumn, with a crack Anglo-American cast. At nine hours total playing time, Tantalus even sounds like a lewd activity for theatrical masochists. Over-ambitious? Over-long? British audiences can finally judge for themselves because at last it is over here. Tantalus himself, the man punished with perpetual frustration for filching ambrosia from the gods, does not appear. But this is all part of Barton's grand design to sketch all the bits of mythology the ancients missed out. What Homer leaves unexplained, or whatever parts of the great tragedians' oeuvre have vanished forever, Barton boldly attempts to conjecture in this massive chthonic net, painstakingly stitched together from holes. It all begins casually on a beach in Greece, where a group of bronzed, female holiday-makers are interrupted, as holiday-makers are, by an itinerant pedlar with a tray full of tat. This particular beach vendor, however, turns out to be Peleus, rogue king of Phthia and myth-monger to the gods, whose stories deflect the attention of these sun-worshippers towards a different and altogether more malevolent pantheon of deities. This pleasingly scatological start determines the production's mix-and-match approach, which finds a place for breastplates and bikinis, declamatory speech and demotic interjection, tragic masks and waterproof mascara. The Halls' joint production is a thing of exquisite beauty: Dionysis Fotopoulos's design suspends the beach in a black, reflective void - as if the shifting sands of destiny were contained within a glittering, dark crystal. Such simplicity enables the action to unfold fluently, with a symmetry it is hard to believe Barton's original 10-play programme possessed. Barton's essential point is that wars are complex phenomena of indeterminate cause and effect: "Much depends," declares Peleus, gnomically, "on the starting point." Barton delves further back than the familiar mythology usually allows, suggesting that the abduction of Helen was itself merely a tit-for-tat response to the Greeks seizure of the Trojan princess Hesione, and so forth down to the looming presence of Tantalus, whose indiscretion with the ambrosia began the whole sorry mess. Only the use of masks remains a moot point. Greg Hicks, whose noble performance provides the production with its centre of gravity, flits effortlessly between the personae of the Greek leader Agamemnon, his cuckolded brother Menelaus and his Trojan opponent Priam: the conventions of the mask literally enabling him to become his own worst enemy. Less certain is Peter Hall's avowed confidence in the mask as a precision lens which focuses attention on the language. Perhaps it is here that Hall, whatever the true nature of their dramaturgical disagreements, inadvertently does his estranged colleague the greater disservice: for Barton (a compelling story-teller and a sure-footed dramaturge) is not, alas, a particularly riveting poet. His ascetic free verse is rhetorical and expository but discomfortingly barren of metaphor or imagery: the line is often little more than an unornamented conveyor of meaning. Given that Tantalus purports to be the most tantalising story ever told, it is strange that the spoken word should prove to be its Achilles heel.  Nottingham Theatre Royal February 14-24, then touring until May 19. fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: Keeping up with the current catchphrase, a chilling web version of a Roald Dahl story, the most subversive cyber cinema in the world
fields.trailText: Keeping up with the current catchphrase, a chilling web version of a Roald Dahl story, the most subversive cyber cinema in the world
fields.body:
Did You See It?
(www.filmfilm.com)
This peppy, glossy one-minute comedy neatly encapsulates all those workday mornings when a duff multiplex choice leaves you suddenly the odd man out. Roger hasn't seen the hot new movie (or heard the hero's catchphrase: "That doesn't sound very sanitary!"), but is determined not to admit it. Can he bluff his way safely through the corridor chat? In fact it's so peppy, glossy and compact that I fully expect to see it reborn shortly as, say, a Diet Coke commercial. Catch the original, while you can. (KS)
 View the film

Genesis and Catastrophe
(www.ifilm.com)
Jonathan Liebesman's chilling and dignified drama took Best Short at the Austin Film Festival last year, earning its director a Hollywood agent and some big-name notice. You'll need a fairly strong stomach to make it through his harrowing account of a late 19C delivery in which a despairing mother and her unborn child hover on the brink between life and death. Stick with it however, since this well-crafted adaptation of a Roald Dahl short story turns out to be a horribly thought-provoking historical snapshot. Show it to anyone you know who insists that webfilm is strictly eye-candy for anoraks, and watch their jaw drop. (KS)
View the film

www.craptv.com
Crap TV is a small, subversive cyber cinema based in California that is quickly developing a speciality in degrading and defacing contemporary US icons. One minute it's having a pop at the political process (On the Campaign Trail), the next it's casting a drag queen as Whitney Houston and singling her out as a paranoid control freak (Mama's Little Baby). Many of the films use borrowed bits of video footage (Smokeabowl for Superbowl) and few have anything like a traditional narrative. So lovers of twee shockwave animations beware: many of the films here are undeniably nasty. But they do cut deeper into the heart of US culture than anywhere else on the net. (SD)
 View the site

webTitle: Government and consumers line up against the cowboys

fields.headline: Government and consumers line up against the cowboys
fields.trailText: Cowboy builders could soon be driven out of town thanks to a government-backed crackdown and a number of new websites being launched which list reputable contractors.
fields.body:
Cowboy builders could soon be driven out of town thanks to a government-backed crackdown and a number of new websites being launched which list reputable contractors.

According to the Office of Fair Trading, around 100,000 complaints are made against tradesmen each year - and the rate is rising annually by 5%.

Trade & Industry Secretary, Stephen Byers has announced that trading standards departments will be given the powers this month to enforce so-called Stop Now orders. This will mean magistrates are brought in to impose bans on offenders from trading. Those who breach this could face up to years in prison and unlimited fines. These new laws will not require parliamentary assent.

The government is also piloting a new quality mark scheme. To qualify for this, builders must complete a form and submit references as well as send in a financial statement and their qualifications. They must also pay an application fee of between of £350.

Planning minister, Nick Raynsford, has admitted take up has been low, but believes it will pick up as awareness increases.

In addition, a number of websites have been set up that list approved builders and other home improvements contractors.

These include Improveline.com, which vets contractors before providing their details to consumers needing work done. The company says it has turned down 37,000 of the 180,000 it has scrutinised to date. Cowboy characteristics include having county court judgements against them and records showing bad credit ratings. Others have been vetoed because of poor customer references and lack of business experience.

Marshall King, managing director of Improveline said: "There is little legalisation to protect the consumer. Anyone with a ladder and van can set themselves up as builder, painter or decorator."

A Scottish website, House-solutions.co.uk has also set up a website of approved contractors. Houseowners' projects are posted on the site and each job is then monitored.

A high profile court case last year brought cowboy builders to the attention of the Scottish public. Last March, Cumbernauld builder William McPhee, who was dubbed King of the Cowboys, was jailed for four years and ordered to pay £60,000 compensation to mainly elderly victims.

His scams included promising one 91-year-old woman from Newton Mearns a new roof, which he instead painted green to make it look new.

McPhee had also avoided taxes by registering his business in Wyoming, known as the Cowboy State.

Improveline.com makes the following recommendations to anyone using a contractor for home improvements:

 Obtain quotes - three is best for price comparison
 Find out if a contractor belongs to a trade association
 Obtain estimates in writing, study these to check the time the work will take and the amount of disruption
 Ask for references if you are unsure of the company
 Avoid contractors who ask for cash to avoid VAT. This is illegal and means you have no recourse to action
 Check the contractor is insured
 If interim payments are required, check when these are due. If grants are due, a builder may want to see the necessary paperwork to check they will be paid on time.
 If there are defects, it is the contractor's responsibility to put it right at no extra cost. It is always worth trying to make sure every eventuality is covered before work starts in the contract.

fields.headline: Stakeholder pensions remain a secret
fields.trailText: The pensions industry is desperately trying to raise awareness of stakeholder pension plans due to be launched in less that three months, after research found that three quarters of the population had never heard of them.
fields.body:
The pensions industry is desperately trying to raise awareness of stakeholder pension plans due to be launched in less that three months, after research found that three quarters of the population had never heard of them.

Stakeholder pensions offer low charges that are capped at 1%, are flexible and can be transferred if someone moves job. They have been launched because the government believes there will be insufficient money in the state scheme to support the population.

The latest research, from the Marks & Spencer Financial Services Stakeholder Barometer, shows that three quarters of those asked are unaware of the scheme. Awareness is especially low among the key groups the government wants to attract, including younger people on lower incomes.

The survey shows higher income groups are twice as likely to have heard of stakeholder pensions Ð some 44% of those earning £35,000 and above know what they were, while only 22% of those earning £10,000 to £19,999 had heard of them.

Yet it is this second group that the government sees as its key target. More men Ð 26% - knew about stakeholder plans compared to 18% of women. And twice as many people approaching retirement (some 32% of 55-64 year olds) have heard of them, compared to just 13% of 18 to 24 year olds.

One of the main pensions providers, Legal & General said that while awareness was low, many young people would still be interested in saving for retirement. Its own research showed that 68% of 16-24 year olds had not started making provision for their retirement and only 15% had heard of stakeholder plans. But, once they understood the concept, 34% said they would be very or fairly likely to buy one within the next five years.

Access to a stakeholder pension must be supplied by any employer with five or more staff. But, if companies donÕt let staff know about these plans, they could risk substantial fines of up to £50,000.

In the UK, there are 600,000 firms with five or more employees. There are some exemptions such as employers who use staff on a contract basis or through an agency. But, if they are temporary and have been taken on directly by the company, the employer must still provide access to stakeholder plans. Other exemptions are for staff aged under 18 or over 75. Staff earning less than £72 are also exempt

fields.headline: Romeo and Juliet
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Kenneth MacMillan's Romeo and Juliet is one of the most frequently performed ballets at Covent Garden, and regular fans may feel it can no longer surprise them. But for the ballet's first outing in the refurbished House (its 327th performance) there are actually changes to be seen. The existing designs by Nicholas Georgiadis have been re-worked (partly to allow the ballet to be toured more easily) and while they don't alter the essence of the production, their feel is lighter and loftier, and they allow the dancing to breathe more freely.

One single improvement is that the first act balcony scene now runs on more smoothly from the Capulet ball - and the fact that it happens to takes place in a deserted ballroom rather than in the most famous location in theatre history doesn't matter.

The shock of Romeo and Juliet's first glimpse of each other at the ball and the menacing presence of the Capulet clan still echo in the space where the lovers chart their growing passion. The final scene in the crypt is also improved by having the action compressed into a much smaller space. Juliet is no longer required to race around the whole stage and we see so much more intimately that death is the only place which the lovers can call their own.

Of course, different dancers re-imagine the ballet, too, and the other novelty for Friday's audience was seeing Nicolas Le Riche performing Romeo to Sylvie Guillem's Juliet. Le Riche, a principal dancer with Paris Opera, was last seen in London partnering Guillem in Ashton's Marguerite and Armand, his rugged dancing and dramatic impetuosity a foil to her delicate intensity. The more extended role of Romeo does, in fact, expose the ragged edges of Le Riche's technique (suprisingly ragged for a Paris-trained dancer) but it's also a lesson in how performers can often define their style out of their limitations.

Le Riche's footwork and pirouettes are not perfectly finessed, yet as compensation he rides the swell of the music with powered assurance and his beautifully articulate arms and hands give wit to both his phrasing and his acting. In real life, his Romeo would be a man of bounding energies, a great teller of jokes and a great kisser.

With this confidence, he matches Guillem's headstrong, free-spirited Juliet well. When we first see the latter, she's less a vulnerable child than a mischievous flirt, dancing on a bubble of laughter and impatience. Her accelerating love for Romeo is stormily physical and Le Riche's strong partnering allows the pair to take heady risks.

What's lacking in Guillem's Juliet, though, is a sense of tragedy. She's so fine and free and glamorous from the start that we do not feel her actual powerlessness before fate and the family vendetta.

Our hearts, though, may have been hardened on Friday by the indecisive, gloomy playing that came from the pit.

 In rep until April 16. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Pay rise trend erodes hopes of rate cut

fields.headline: Pay rise trend erodes hopes of rate cut
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pay deals have risen significantly at the start of the new year, according to a survey published today - casting doubt on the expected outcome of this week's meeting of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee.
fields.body:
Pay deals have risen significantly at the start of the new year, according to a survey published today - casting doubt on the expected outcome of this week's meeting of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee.

Most City analysts expect interest rates to be cut by 25 basis points to 5.75% on Thursday, but the new pay figures from Incomes Data Services (IDS), showing deals clustered between 3.5% and 5%, suggest the MPC may leave them on hold for the 12th month in a row to prevent higher inflation.

IDS said it had recorded 46 increases so far this year, covering 188,000 employees. "Many are inflation-linked rises paid under long-term deals, typically giving increases in the 3.2% to 3.7% range. However, the newly negotiated January deals are generally a little higher - those monitored so far are mostly between 3.5% and 5%."

IDS blamed the pick-up in pay deals in January, the crucial month for private sector settlements, on last year's rise in the headline rate of inflation. Although it fell in December, November's inflation rate of 3.2% was a strong influence on January pay budgets. The increase in pay set tlements is likely to reinforce fears among the hawks on the MPC, notably labour market expert Stephen Nickell, that low unemployment could still create a wage/price spiral, although other committee members are more concerned about the deflationary impact of weakening global growth.

January's vote was the closest for months, with four of the nine members voting for a rate cut. Since then, underlying inflation, excluding mortgage interest payments, has fallen further below target and GDP growth in the fourth quarter of last year slowed to its weakest rate for two years.

However, the GDP figures were distorted by an erratic fall in energy output, and most short-term indicators suggest business and consumer activity remains strong despite the sharp slowdown in the US.

A survey published yesterday suggested business leaders needed a rate cut. The BDO Business Trends report found that, although the economy remained relatively healthy, business confidence was continuing to deteriorate.

Peter Hemington, a partner at BDO Stoy Hayward, said: "The report shows that UK business is in danger of talking itself into a slowdown, even though the economic outlook remains reasonably positive."

fields.headline: Rattle lights up every bar in Amsterdam
fields.standfirst:
Tristan und Isolde
Netherlands Opera
Amsterdam
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Tristan und Isolde
Netherlands Opera
Amsterdam
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Simon Rattle has never disguised his suspicion of opera, but gradually he seems to be coming to terms with the compromises any conductor has to make when working in a medium with so many variables beyond his control. He still chooses the opera houses in which he works with care, though: last summer he conducted Janacek at Aix-en-Provence, in May he will tackle Beethoven's Fidelio at Glyndebourne, and just now he is in charge of Tristan und Isolde at the Netherlands Opera - his third show, following Pelleas et Melisande and Parsifal, at the Amsterdam Muziektheater. Though the cast and the production are serviceable enough, it is Rattle's contribution that will be the main interest of this Tristan.

Without a resident orchestra of its own, the Netherlands Opera rotates the country's leading bands in the pit; for this show it is the Rotterdam Philharmonic, and they play for Rattle with a clarity that suits his approach very well. In an ideal world, the strings could have more body (though the Muziektheater acoustic doesn't help them) so that the longer phrases could blossom more expressively, but Rattle's concern is less with the long, ecstatic paragraphs than with the passing details of the score; he makes every bar light up with inner intensity, delivers the climaxes with crushing definition. It is not the only way to present this strange work, but it is a compellingly immediate and theatrical one.

To some extent that theatricality is diffused by Alfred Kirchner's staging of this everyday story of Cornish folk, which is routine in most of its details and its acting. It may not be as bland as the Ring cycle he mounted for Bayreuth in the 1990s, but what glosses it does provide are mostly unremarkable. Like a schoolgirl with a crush, Isolde keeps a photograph of Tristan in her locker, which she reveals to him at the climax of the first act confrontation - a reminder, presumably, that the love potion (which, Brangaene's behaviour suggests, is administered by mistake) is only the catalyst for their passion and not the cause, while Tristan pulls himself onto Melot's sword at the end of the second.

Annette Murschetz's sets mix cold abstraction and cosier naturalism sometimes disconcertingly - there is an ever-changing seascape projected throughout the first act, a grassy knoll and a blazing tree strewn across the stage in the second; the rest is all steely walkways and panels, tellingly lit by Jean Kalman.

Gabriele Schnaut's improbably blonde Isolde is a good deal more animated than her semaphoric characterisation for the Royal Opera last autumn, and generally better sung, too. Instead of the armour-piercing stridency of that performance, there is much more light and shade, even some warmth too. Her partner is the British tenor John Treleaven, hardly ever heard in his homeland nowadays, but a robust and convincing Tristan here. His is not a particularly seductive sound, but it is effective and well-sustained.

There is excellent support from Petra Lang's ever-dependable Brangaene, Robert Lloyd's rather sinister King Marke, and Alan Held's relatively understated Kurwenal. All of them are attentively nurtured by Rattle, though whether his contribution is enough to raise the show above the ordinary remains another matter.

 Performances tonight and February 9, 13, 17, 21, 25, 26. Box office: 00 31 20 6255 455.
fields.bodyText: Simon Rattle has never disguised his suspicion of opera, but gradually he seems to be coming to terms with the compromises any conductor has to make when working in a medium with so many variables beyond his control. He still chooses the opera houses in which he works with care, though: last summer he conducted Janacek at Aix-en-Provence, in May he will tackle Beethoven's Fidelio at Glyndebourne, and just now he is in charge of Tristan und Isolde at the Netherlands Opera - his third show, following Pelleas et Melisande and Parsifal, at the Amsterdam Muziektheater. Though the cast and the production are serviceable enough, it is Rattle's contribution that will be the main interest of this Tristan. Without a resident orchestra of its own, the Netherlands Opera rotates the country's leading bands in the pit; for this show it is the Rotterdam Philharmonic, and they play for Rattle with a clarity that suits his approach very well. In an ideal world, the strings could have more body (though the Muziektheater acoustic doesn't help them) so that the longer phrases could blossom more expressively, but Rattle's concern is less with the long, ecstatic paragraphs than with the passing details of the score; he makes every bar light up with inner intensity, delivers the climaxes with crushing definition. It is not the only way to present this strange work, but it is a compellingly immediate and theatrical one. To some extent that theatricality is diffused by Alfred Kirchner's staging of this everyday story of Cornish folk, which is routine in most of its details and its acting. It may not be as bland as the Ring cycle he mounted for Bayreuth in the 1990s, but what glosses it does provide are mostly unremarkable. Like a schoolgirl with a crush, Isolde keeps a photograph of Tristan in her locker, which she reveals to him at the climax of the first act confrontation - a reminder, presumably, that the love potion (which, Brangaene's behaviour suggests, is administered by mistake) is only the catalyst for their passion and not the cause, while Tristan pulls himself onto Melot's sword at the end of the second. Annette Murschetz's sets mix cold abstraction and cosier naturalism sometimes disconcertingly - there is an ever-changing seascape projected throughout the first act, a grassy knoll and a blazing tree strewn across the stage in the second; the rest is all steely walkways and panels, tellingly lit by Jean Kalman. Gabriele Schnaut's improbably blonde Isolde is a good deal more animated than her semaphoric characterisation for the Royal Opera last autumn, and generally better sung, too. Instead of the armour-piercing stridency of that performance, there is much more light and shade, even some warmth too. Her partner is the British tenor John Treleaven, hardly ever heard in his homeland nowadays, but a robust and convincing Tristan here. His is not a particularly seductive sound, but it is effective and well-sustained. There is excellent support from Petra Lang's ever-dependable Brangaene, Robert Lloyd's rather sinister King Marke, and Alan Held's relatively understated Kurwenal. All of them are attentively nurtured by Rattle, though whether his contribution is enough to raise the show above the ordinary remains another matter.  Performances tonight and February 9, 13, 17, 21, 25, 26. fields.headline: Clapton's hoochie coochie homecoming
fields.standfirst:
Eric Clapton
Royal Albert Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Eric Clapton
Royal Albert Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
If a performer can be said to have a natural habitat, then Eric Clapton's is surely the Albert Hall. The last time I saw him was at Earls Court, where you can hear the proceedings just as well from a passing bus as you can from being inside the auditorium. Clapton was miles away, both physically and emotionally. But returning to the Albert for this latest season of shows felt, he said, like "coming home" - and he and his band responded to the occasion with a warm and involving performance.

Clapton's catalogue spans so many different phases that merely selecting the right balance of material is a major challenge. However, his yardstick has always been the blues, so he wisely avoided excursions into adult-orientated schlock and stuck closely to his roots. Even Wonderful Tonight, always a potential quagmire of slush, sounded quite plausible, while Tears In Heaven gained immeasurably from its understated acoustic arrangement. Bell Bottom Blues, also in acoustic format, was a vivid reminder that there was much more to the Layla album than the title track.

The evening's special guests were The Impressions, who delivered a couple of their own numbers before adopting the role of superior backing vocalists. They added weight to I Shot The Sheriff and could hardly have been better suited to the soul/gospel feel of Don't Let Me Be Lonely Tonight, though the combined weight of the Clapton band plus the vocal quartet left a version of JJ Cale's Travellin' Light sounding lumberingly top heavy.

Perhaps Clapton sensed this, since The Impressions promptly vanished while he took an excursion into some pared-to-the-bone blues. Hoochie Coochie Man was as stark and raw as Clapton is likely to get without actually moving to a shack in Alabama, while on Have You Ever Been Mistreated?, he matched some ferocious guitar solos with bellowing, sore-throat vocals.

Somehow, despite all the industry awards and platinum discs that sit on Clapton's mantelpieces around the world, he remains earthed by the blues.

The Layla riff was the audience's cue to start rushing the stage, but better still was a version of the old Cream tune Badge, where Clapton took much delight in peeling off the arpeggio bit in the middle. Climax of the night was an encore of Sunshine Of Your Love, where the band locked into a steaming, funked-up groove which sounded as if it might roll on into the early hours, while Clapton swapped vocals with bassist Nathan East and guitarist Andy Fairweather-Lowe. He looks good for a few decades yet.

 At the Albert Hall February 6, 7, 9, 10. Box office: 020-7589 8212. Then touring.

fields.headline: Eat your way to the top
fields.standfirst:
We all know that the right foods will make us healthier, but a new study shows that they could also do wonders for our productivity at work. Dolly Dhingra reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: We all know that the right foods will make us healthier, but a new study shows that they could also do wonders for our productivity at work. Dolly Dhingra reports
fields.body:
If you are what you eat, you are also what your employer makes you eat. So what exactly is your company turning you into? Are you a limp, white, margarine- covered ham sandwich personified? A plate of greasy bacon, sausage and chips? Chances are you're nothing too nutritious. A new study called The Employee Energy Report - is your workforce running on full power? reveals that UK employers are failing to provide workers with enough support for healthy eating.

Written by Penny Hunking, a dietitian and managing director of nutrition education company Energise Nutrition, the study is being hailed as the first of its kind, investigating the link between diet and energy levels at work.

"Considering how much time we spend at work and how important it is for a company's productivity to have a healthy, energetic workforce, it's surprising how few employers do anything to influence and encourage better eating and exercise habits among the workforce," says Hunking.

The single largest complaint came from the 66% of those surveyed who said that fresh fruit was hard to come by. While chocolate bars and packets of crisps were readily obtainable, people were not being encouraged to eat nature's sweets. Although 80% of companies had self-catering facilities, kettles, fridges and microwaves were not always made available to all staff. Only a tiny minority of those interviewed ate the recommended five portions of fruit and vegetables each day. Carbohydrate intake was generally lower and fat intake higher than UK recommendations. Most women lacked sufficient calcium and iron in their diets and just 7% were getting enough fibre. On the whole, it doesn't look good.

So whose responsibility is food in the workplace? Hunking says it rests with the employees as well as the employers. "The individual can help themselves and look after themselves. You have to make sure you make the best of any bad situation. Don't get caught out, you can always make your own packed lunch, carry water with you, a cereal bar, food that travels well. It's empowering if you're preparing food that's better than that available at work."

She recommends that employers provide a separate place for people to eat, as well as making sure fridges and microwaves are available for staff use.

Although employers should provide a varied and nutritious diet, there are also other things they can do. Education is a key factor, says Hunking. Even if employers are not providing food on the premises, they can provide nutritional guides via email or as leaflets. Tips of the day could be flashed on computer screens. Did you know, for instance, that one kiwi fruit contains the equivalent vitamin C of five oranges?

One simple tactic that employers should try is to encourage more water drinking. Four pints a day is hugely beneficial to health and energy levels of staff, especially in comparison to tea and coffee which serve only to dehydrate and de- energise workers (contrary to the promises of that initial caffeine "hit").

But what should those who have to shop outdoors for their nosh be eating? The proprietor of the Islington Green Sandwich Company in London, Peter Studd, has a few things to say about high street food fashions. "You only have to watch telly to discover that food is the new rock and roll," he says. "Fifteen years ago you'd go down the high street and all you could get were warm chips, sandwiches were cheese and pickle, corned beef and salad cream. Back then, toast was a luxury. That's when I saw a gap in the market, but now it's ciabattas and focaccias, you've got Pret a Manger on every high street - you're spoilt for choice."

For a staple lunchtime diet, he recommends something that incorporates pasta, a sandwich made of good bread filled with meat or fish and salad, fresh fruit juice and fresh fruit. None of which will harm his business - he delivers fresh products to customers daily, keeping up the energy levels of an office minority in Islington at least.
